Praise for Ask More, Get More

《多问，多得》好评如潮

“Michael Alden recounts his poverty-laden upbringing … His struggling single mother … jostled for food stamps and begged to keep her son and herself from eviction … Alden’s story … motivates and educates.… Whether you’re rich or poor, content or striving, Ask More, Get More has golden nuggets of information sprinkled from cover to cover … a must read!”

迈克尔·奥尔登讲述了他贫困的童年……他那生活拮据的单身母亲……为了领取食品券四处奔波，苦苦哀求，只为保住自己和儿子免遭驱逐……奥尔登的故事……既鼓舞人心，又发人深省……无论你是富裕还是贫穷，安于现状还是奋发向上，《多问，多得》这本书从头到尾都充满了宝贵的信息……绝对值得一读！

— John Abdo, Olympic Strength & Conditioning Coach, 1976, 1980, 1984, and 1988 Olympic Games, Master Fitness Trainer, National Fitness Hall of Fame Inductee

——约翰·阿布多，奥运会体能教练，曾任1976年、1980年、1984年和1988年奥运会体能教练，资深健身教练，入选美国国家健身名人堂

“ Ask More, Get More teaches anyone from any background not only how to make money, save money, and create wealth, but how to be successful in any aspect of life.”

《多问，多得》这本书不仅教会任何背景的人如何赚钱、省钱和创造财富，还教会他们如何在生活的各个方面取得成功。

— Jim Shriner, best-selling author of Live Disease Free to 103

——吉姆·施赖纳，《活到103岁，远离疾病》畅销书作者

Ask more, get more : how to earn more, save more, and live more—just by asking / Michael Alden.—1st ed.

To the most important person
in my life,
my little girl, Morgan.
Daddy loves you!

致我生命中最重要的人，我的小女儿摩根。爸爸爱你！

Acknowledgments

致谢

Thank you to my friends and my family for their continued encouragement. I would not be who I am today without their support. I also thank my dedicated and talented editor Chris Benguhe, without whose support this book would not be what it is today.

感谢我的朋友和家人一直以来的鼓励。没有他们的支持，就没有今天的我。我还要感谢我敬业且才华横溢的编辑克里斯·本古赫，没有他的支持，这本书也不会是现在的样子。

#↩

INTRODUCTION

介绍

Thank God, I was born poor. I would not have wanted it any other way. Growing up poor was actually a gift; a gift that is very difficult to see when you are growing up. After all, how can living in constant fear of being homeless, having your electricity shut off, and eating from food pantry shelves be considered a gift? How can standing in the special free food lunch line or going to school early to get state-sponsored breakfast for twelve years be a gift? How can growing up in a neighborhood that was surrounded by crime, violence, and drugs be a gift?

感谢上帝，我生于贫寒。我并不希望是另一种生活。在贫困中长大其实是一种恩赐；一种在成长过程中很难察觉的恩赐。毕竟，生活在随时可能流落街头、随时可能断电、只能靠救济粮度日的恐惧中，怎么能算是恩赐呢？在免费午餐的队伍里排队，或者为了领取政府提供的早餐而早早去上学，持续了十二年，这怎么能算是恩赐呢？在一个充斥着犯罪、暴力和毒品的社区长大，这怎么能算是恩赐呢？

Growing up poor taught me the value of money and hard work. Growing up poor taught me how to save, share, and be generous. Growing up poor caused me to yearn for more. The way I grew up may have been tough, but there are many worse situations than mine. I was never homeless, but often had the fear of being evicted. I never went hungry, but we had to improvise, adapt, and find ways to eat. I never had a Christmas without gifts or a special treat, but many of our holidays were subsidized by a charitable organization or completely funded by the Salvation Army. As a young child, I watched my mother struggle and cry trying to figure out how to get by. I used to listen to my mother negotiate and beg the Housing Authority not to evict us. I remember once when my mother’s old, beat-up Dodge Colt was repossessed and she had to negotiate more money than it was worth to get the car back. You get the picture: I was poor—not the poorest of poor, but certainly below the poverty level and poor enough to qualify for government-subsidized housing, food stamps, and state cheese.

贫困的童年教会了我金钱和辛勤工作的价值。贫困教会了我如何节俭、分享和慷慨。贫困也让我渴望拥有更多。我的成长经历或许艰辛，但比我更糟糕的情况比比皆是。我从未流落街头，但常常担心被驱逐。我从未挨饿，但我们不得不随机应变，想方设法解决温饱问题。我的圣诞节从未缺少礼物或特别的款待，但我们的许多节日都得到了慈善机构的补贴，或者完全由救世军资助。小时候，我看着母亲为了生存苦苦挣扎，哭泣不止。我常常听着母亲与住房管理局讨价还价，恳求他们不要驱逐我们。我记得有一次，母亲那辆破旧的道奇科尔特轿车被收回，她不得不支付远高于车本身价值的价格才把它赎回来。你应该能想象到：我很穷——虽然不是穷到极点，但肯定低于贫困线，穷到可以领取政府补贴的住房、食品券和州政府提供的奶酪。

Growing up poor forced me to learn how to use what I had within me to make more out of life. And as far back as I can remember, I have always worked.

贫困的童年经历迫使我学会如何利用自身优势去创造更美好的生活。而且，从我记事起，我就一直在工作。

Growing up in New England, we always expected a few snowstorms in the winter and blistering hot days in the summer. I was so excited when it snowed and school was cancelled. Even at age nine, I got up early, grabbed my shovel, and walked door-to-door to shovel driveways in what I thought were the rich neighborhoods. Depending on the day and the amount of snow, I partnered with a friend and we’d either split up or do the driveways together to cover more houses. I literally worked from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. or even later. And on a good snow day, I’d come home with one hundred dollars in my pocket! When other kids were building snowmen, I was out hustling driveways. If I grew up middle class or rich, would I have done the same thing?

在新英格兰长大，我们总是预料到冬天会下几场暴雪，夏天会酷热难耐。下雪停课的时候，我兴奋极了。即使只有九岁，我也会早早起床，拿起铲子，挨家挨户地去铲雪，我当时觉得那些地方都是富人区。根据雪量和当天的情况，我会找个朋友搭档，要么分工合作，要么一起铲，这样就能覆盖更多的房子。我真的从早上七点一直干到晚上七点，甚至更晚。如果雪下得大，我回家的时候口袋里就能揣着一百美元！当其他孩子在堆雪人的时候，我已经在外面忙着铲雪了。如果我出身中产阶级或者富裕家庭，我还会做同样的事吗？

During the summers, I set up a lemonade stand on a busy street that was close to my house and solicited people driving by. Sometimes I got lucky, and a jogger or walker passed by. They almost always bought a cup of lemonade. One summer I franchised my business and we had three stands surrounding the neighborhood close to my house. We took turns riding our bikes back and forth to replenish the lemonade, and I learned the important concept that the direct, concerted effort of many is much more powerful than that of just one person.

夏天的时候，我会在我家附近一条繁忙的街道上摆个柠檬水摊，招揽过往的司机。有时候运气好，会遇到慢跑者或散步的人路过。他们几乎都会买一杯柠檬水。有一年夏天，我把生意做成了连锁店，在我家附近的街区里摆了三个摊位。我们轮流骑着自行车来回补充柠檬水，我也从中领悟到一个重要的道理：众人齐心协力的力量远胜于单打独斗。

At the age of ten, I dreamed of owning a cool BMX bike with all the accessories—chrome rims, cool brakes, and flashy colors. But these types of bikes—GT, Redline, or Haro—cost a minimum of $300. I saw kids in my neighborhood riding around on these kinds of bikes, knowing full well that they stole them. If I wanted to keep my integrity, for me they were unattainable.

十岁那年，我梦想拥有一辆酷炫的BMX自行车，配上所有配件——镀铬轮圈、炫酷刹车和亮眼的颜色。但这类自行车——比如GT、Redline或Haro——至少要300美元。我看到邻居家的孩子们骑着这些车到处转悠，他们明明知道这些车是偷来的。为了保持我的正直，这些车对我来说是遥不可及的。

My uncle, Buddy, worked as a janitor at a Pontiac dealership in Danvers, Massachusetts, and every week or so he brought me giant bags full of aluminum soda cans worth five cents a piece. All I had to do was bring them to the redemption center and get the money. I forget what a big bag was worth, but it was probably around five or ten dollars. I think my mom gave me the idea to save that money for the bike I wanted. I thought it was a great idea, and not only did I save, but then I went out and found more cans. I picked cans out of barrels; I asked family members to save cans; I went on hunting excursions … and then I discovered that a two-liter soda bottle was worth ten cents! Ten cents! That was awesome, and I hunted for them on a daily basis to get pocket change to buy things like candy or baseball cards. Over time I was able to buy that bike. I was so proud; it wasn’t stolen, and it wasn’t a gift. I bought it with the help of Uncle Buddy. It had magnum green fluorescent wheels and all of the chrome accessories a bike could handle. And that bike, well … it also made me a lot of money, as you shall read.

我叔叔巴迪在马萨诸塞州丹弗斯的一家庞蒂亚克汽车经销店当清洁工，他大约每周都会给我带回一大袋铝制汽水罐，每个罐子值五美分。我只需要把它们拿到回收中心就能拿到钱。我忘了一大袋多少钱，但大概五到十美元吧。我想是我妈妈教我把这些钱攒起来买我想要的自行车。我觉得这个主意太棒了，我不仅开始攒钱，还到处找汽水罐。我从桶里捡罐子；我让家人帮我收集；我甚至去“寻罐”……然后我发现一个两升装的汽水瓶居然值十美分！十美分！这简直太棒了，我每天都去找汽水瓶，攒零钱买糖果或棒球卡之类的东西。慢慢地，我终于买到了那辆自行车。我当时特别自豪；它不是偷来的，也不是别人送的。这辆车是我在巴迪叔叔的帮助下买的。它有荧光绿的轮毂，还有所有你能想到的镀铬配件。至于那辆车嘛……正如你将看到的，它也让我赚了不少钱。

When I was ten, I got a paper route and kept it through middle school, picking up new customers every week. The paper route was a tough responsibility. It had to be done every day and the papers had to be delivered before 4:00 p.m. My customers expected to see the “unwet” paper on their doorstep when they came home from work. When school ended at 2:00 in the afternoon, I rushed home and got on my BMX bike to deliver my papers. I was just beginning to get involved in sports and had to be very disciplined with my time so I didn’t miss practice for football, baseball, or basketball. Finally, I would get home and do my homework (sometimes). The paper route wasn’t a super profitable venture, but I made a decent amount of money; I cleared about fifty dollars a week, which was not bad for a kid living in the projects. I learned to appreciate the value of hard work and the almighty dollar. Many times my mom needed to “borrow” my money, and I remember being a bit annoyed since I had worked so hard. Looking back, I can barely comprehend how my mother managed and am glad I was able to contribute.

我十岁的时候开始送报纸，一直做到中学毕业，每周都会有新的客户。送报纸可不是件轻松的事。每天都得送，而且报纸必须在下午四点前送到。我的客户们都希望下班回家的时候能看到“干爽”的报纸放在家门口。每天下午两点放学后，我都会赶紧回家，骑上我的BMX自行车去送报纸。那时我刚开始参加体育运动，所以必须严格安排时间，以免错过足球、棒球或篮球的训练。最后，我回家后（有时候）还会做作业。送报纸虽然不算特别赚钱，但我也能挣到一笔可观的收入；每周大概能挣五十美元，对于一个住在贫民窟的孩子来说，这已经很不错了。我学会了珍惜辛勤劳动和金钱的价值。很多时候，我妈妈需要“借”我的钱，我记得当时有点生气，因为那是我辛辛苦苦挣来的。回想过去，我几乎无法理解母亲是如何熬过来的，也很庆幸自己能够为母亲做些贡献。

Eventually, I gave up the paper route because sports and school were more important. During the summers of my early to mid-teens I began a mini landscaping business. I had about four or five regular customers who paid me ten to fifteen dollars to cut their lawns. I invested most of that money back into new equipment. I scoured neighborhoods, looking for old lawn mowers people had thrown out that I could fix. I remember buying my first weed whacker (also known as a hedge trimmer) and thought it was the coolest thing ever. I dreamt of running my own landscaping company. At fourteen, I had two or three lawn mowers, some hedge clippers, and a couple of weed whackers, and every summer I hit up my regular customers for more work.

最终，我放弃了送报纸的工作，因为运动和学业对我来说更重要。十几岁到二十出头的那几个夏天，我开始做起了小型园艺生意。我有四五个固定客户，他们付我十到十五美元让我帮他们修剪草坪。我把大部分收入都投入到了新设备上。我挨家挨户地寻找别人丢弃的旧割草机，希望能修好。我记得我买的第一台除草机（也叫绿篱修剪机）让我觉得它酷毙了。我梦想着拥有自己的园艺公司。十四岁的时候，我已经有了两三台割草机、几把绿篱修剪机和几台除草机，每年夏天我都会去找我的老客户，让他们多给我一些活儿干。

When I got more tools I offered additional services like trimming hedges. Though trimming hedges wasn’t as profitable as mowing lawns, it allowed me to charge for a new service and increase my cash flow.

当我添置了更多工具后，我开始提供修剪树篱等额外服务。虽然修剪树篱不如割草赚钱，但它让我可以收取新服务的费用，增加我的现金流。

Finally, sports and my grades took over, and at fifteen I realized that my grades were not where they were supposed to be. To be honest, I was also getting in trouble and hanging out with the older kids from my neighborhood. Although I had other jobs, I knew that in order to make it out of the neighborhood, I needed more than drive. Later on I will discuss other areas in my life that helped me learn how to harness the traits we all have inside: traits that enable us to achieve our goals while getting the most out of life.

最终，运动和学业占据了我的全部生活，十五岁那年我意识到自己的成绩远未达到预期。说实话，我也开始惹麻烦，和邻居里那些年纪比我大的孩子混在一起。虽然我还有其他工作，但我知道，要想离开那个街区，光靠开车是不够的。之后，我会谈到我人生中其他一些方面，这些方面帮助我学会了如何运用我们每个人都拥有的内在特质：这些特质使我们能够实现目标，并最大限度地享受生活。

I tell these stories to provide some perspective on my background and help you realize you have the same skills, the same opportunities, and the same abilities and drive within you . I was lucky that I was forced to find a way to get the things I wanted in life by finding honest ways to make money at a very young age. Ask More, Get More isn’t an autobiography, however; it is a book that shows you that we all have within us the same drive, skills, desires, and abilities to get more out of life, just by asking. And not only asking others, but asking yourself questions that will harness the power of the human genome and spirit beyond what you thought possible.

我讲述这些故事，是为了让大家了解我的背景，并帮助你们意识到，你们也拥有同样的技能、机会、能力和动力。我很幸运，很小的时候就被迫寻找诚实赚钱的途径，从而获得我想要的生活。然而，《多问，多得》并非自传；这本书旨在向你们展示，我们每个人都拥有同样的动力、技能、渴望和能力，只要开口询问，就能获得更多。而且，不仅是向他人提问，还要向自己提出问题，这些问题将激发人类基因组和精神的力量，超越你想象的极限。

When reading Ask More, Get More , don’t jump ahead or skip any part of the book. Cleanse your mind of all assumptions, knowledge, and judgment. Embrace the thought that you are willing to apply these principles and techniques in your life. And then apply them with enthusiasm each day. Don’t say, “Oh, I knew that,” “that is stupid,” or “that won’t work.” If they were stupid and didn’t work or if you already knew all these strategies and techniques then you must be an extraordinarily successful individual. Therefore, as a successful person, you will appreciate the refresher course on some of the skills you may have forgotten (we all do).

阅读《多问，多得》时，不要跳读或跳过任何章节。抛开所有先入为主的假设、知识和判断。要坚信自己愿意将这些原则和技巧运用到生活中，并每天满怀热情地实践。不要说“哦，我知道”、“这太蠢了”或“这行不通”。如果这些方法真的愚蠢且无效，或者你已经掌握了所有这些策略和技巧，那么你一定是一位非常成功的人。因此，作为一名成功人士，你会很感激这门课程，它能帮助你温习一些你可能已经遗忘的技能（我们都会遗忘）。

INSANITY

疯狂

Most people do the same thing over and over every day and expect a different result; yes, they say that is the definition of insanity. Well, you are most likely not insane if you have this book in your hands. All of us suffer “temporary insanity” at some point in our life. I have been working out since I was twelve years old, and being of the mesomorph body type, I am considered a “big guy.” I played football, baseball, basketball, and soccer, among other sports, for most of my life—some better than others. But after I graduated college, I realized that I didn’t need my football weight anymore. I kept doing my same football workout for a few years and ate the same way … and I couldn’t lose the weight. Finally, around age twenty-eight, I did the Body for Life Program. It changed my thinking about exercise and nutrition, even though I already “knew” most of the concepts and strategies. I knew the techniques were simple and easy. However, one very profound thing I learned from Body for Life was that if you can’t be honest with yourself, then who can you be honest with? If you lie to yourself and say that you dieted properly, or that your intensity level was at a ten when you know it was at a five, then you are lying to yourself and ultimately hurting yourself. So, I constantly ask myself questions—the same questions you will learn to ask yourself and others throughout this book.

大多数人每天重复做同样的事情，却期待不同的结果；没错，人们常说这就是疯狂的定义。不过，如果你手里拿着这本书，那你很可能并不疯狂。我们每个人一生中都会经历“暂时的疯狂”。我从十二岁就开始健身，由于是中胚型体质，我被认为是“大块头”。我一生中的大部分时间都从事过各种运动，包括橄榄球、棒球、篮球和足球——有些运动我打得比其他的要好。但大学毕业后，我意识到我不再需要橄榄球时期的体重了。我继续保持着同样的橄榄球训练计划和饮食习惯好几年……但我却减不下来。最终，大约二十八岁的时候，我参加了“终身健身计划”。它改变了我对运动和营养的看法，尽管我之前已经“了解”了其中的大部分概念和策略。我知道这些技巧简单易行。然而，我从《健美人生》这本书中学到的一个非常深刻的道理是：如果你不能对自己诚实，又能对谁诚实呢？如果你自欺欺人，说自己节食得当，或者明明强度只有五却说是十，那么你就是在欺骗自己，最终伤害自己。所以，我经常问自己一些问题——这些问题你也会在本书中学会如何问自己和他人。

Once I applied the strategies I learned in Body for Life, I lost more than thirty pounds and had visible abdominal muscles for the first time in my life. Now, fast-forward to the age of thirty-six. I am in a physical rut. I “go” to the gym almost every day. I have a trainer. I try to “diet” and do all the things that I was doing in the past. I still cannot lose weight. I am also an avid reader of magazines like Muscle and Fitness and Men’s Health , and yet I still cannot lose weight. In fact, I am/was at my all-time high in tonnage! So, rather than doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results, I mix it up. I try something new. I added—and am now addicted to—yoga … any type. And I have lost weight, improved my muscle tone, posture, and mental clarity, and ultimately feel great.

自从我运用了《健美人生》中学到的策略后，我减掉了三十多磅，生平第一次拥有了清晰可见的腹肌。如今，我已三十六岁，却陷入了健身瓶颈。我几乎每天都去健身房，也请了私人教练。我尝试节食，也做了以前做过的所有事情，但体重依然没有减轻。我还是《肌肉与健身》和《男士健康》等杂志的忠实读者，但体重依然不见起色。事实上，我的体重已经达到了历史最高点！所以，与其一遍又一遍地重复同样的事情却期待不同的结果，我决定改变一下。我尝试了一些新的方法。我开始练习瑜伽——而且现在已经上瘾了——各种类型的瑜伽。结果，我不仅减掉了体重，还改善了肌肉线条、体态和思维清晰度，最终感觉棒极了。

Just by purchasing this book you have made the decision to change your habits, change your thoughts, change your life, and cure yourself of the “temporary insanity.” As I have said on television, many of these techniques are simple, easy , and effective. Of some you will say, “Well, that is ridiculous,” or “it’s just too easy,” or “what’s the catch?” The fact is—there is no catch. Many of the Ask More, Get More principles you may have “heard” or “knew about,” but you just didn’t do them for one reason or another.

购买这本书本身就意味着你决定改变习惯、改变想法、改变人生，并治愈“暂时性精神错乱”。正如我在电视上所说，这些技巧大多简单易行，而且行之有效。你可能会对某些技巧说：“这太荒谬了”、“这也太容易了吧”，或者“这里面有什么猫腻？” 事实是——没有任何猫腻。你可能“听说过”或“知道”许多“多问多得”的原则，但由于这样那样的原因，你一直没有付诸实践。

I was in one of my first “hot” yoga classes—out of my element, exhausted, sweating, a bit delirious due to the rapid loss of electrolytes—wondering if I belonged in the class. The instructor said something profound when describing a basic yoga move and its effectiveness for core strength. “Simple things work only if you do them.”

那是我第一次上高温瑜伽课——感觉很不适应，筋疲力尽，汗流浃背，由于电解质迅速流失，甚至有点神志不清——我怀疑自己是否适合这门课。老师在讲解一个基础瑜伽动作及其对核心力量的锻炼效果时，说了一句意味深长的话：“简单的事情只有去做才有效。”

Let me repeat: Simple things work, but only if you do them.

我再说一遍：简单的事情往往有效，但前提是你得去做。

So enjoy the book page by page, chapter by chapter, and once you finish you will have internalized the principles of Ask More, Get More and you will have in your brain the skills that many people only think they have. You will not only have these skills, you will know how to recognize them and, better yet, how to use them. You will notice that there are margins in this book where you can and should take notes. There is significant research that confirms that when you write something down, you will have better retention. When I read, I am constantly underlining text and writing notes. Also, there may be a few words (only a few) new to you or that you may not understand. Don’t skip over the word. Look the word up at Dictionary.com —they even sound out the word for you. If you are reading this book on the Kindle, iPad, or any other tablet, many of them have features that allow you to highlight the word and get the definition quickly.

所以，请一页一页、一章一章地细细品读这本书。读完之后，你就会真正理解“多问，多得”的原则，并掌握许多人自以为拥有的技能。你不仅会拥有这些技能，还会知道如何识别它们，更重要的是，如何运用它们。你会注意到，这本书里有很多空白页，你可以在那里做笔记，而且也应该这样做。大量的研究证实，当你把内容写下来的时候，记忆效果会更好。我读书的时候，总是会划重点、做笔记。另外，书中可能有一些你不熟悉或者不理解的单词（只有几个）。不要跳过这些单词。去Dictionary.com查一下——他们甚至会帮你读出单词的发音。如果你是在Kindle、iPad或其他平板电脑上阅读这本书，很多平板电脑都有高亮显示单词并快速查看释义的功能。

The Ask More, Get More techniques work, some faster than others, and they are easy to implement and simple to understand. I cannot emphasize enough: these principles, strategies, and techniques are simple and easy and they work ! You just need to do them! So smile, and be excited. Get more out of life just by asking and doing things that we all can do. Tap into the skills we all have within.

“多问，多得”的技巧确实有效，有些见效快，有些见效慢，但它们都易于实施，也简单易懂。我必须强调：这些原则、策略和技巧简单易行，而且真的有效！你只需要付诸行动！所以，微笑吧，充满热情。只需提出问题，做一些我们每个人都能做到的事情，就能让生活更加精彩。挖掘我们每个人内在的潜能。

#↩

PART I

第一部分

ASK MORE FROM YOURSELF

对自己提出更高的要求

#↩

CHAPTER 1

第一章

ASK YOURSELF TO THINK DIFFERENTLY

试着换个角度思考

If you properly use your imagination it will help you convert your failures and mistakes into assets of priceless value; it will lead you to discovery of a truth known only to those who use their imagination; namely, that the greatest reverses and misfortunes of life often open the door to golden opportunities.

如果你能正确运用你的想象力，它将帮助你把失败和错误转化为无价的财富；它将引导你发现一个只有运用想象力的人才知道的真理；那就是，生活中最大的挫折和不幸往往会打开通往黄金机会的大门。

—Napoleon Hill

——拿破仑·希尔

WHAT MAKES YOU SO DIFFERENT? NOTHING.

你有什么特别之处？没有。

My mother is HIV positive, my stepfather died of AIDS, my father was addicted to cocaine, both of my grandparents on my mother’s side were hard-core alcoholics, and my brother Dominic spent most of his life “locked up” and eventually died of a drug overdose. One of my other brothers spent a majority of his youth behind bars for offenses that range from drug possession to armed robbery. Another brother was in rehab for a heroin addiction, and a close friend I grew up with is in jail for life for first-degree murder. Sounds horrible, doesn’t it? Why have I had success? Why was I able to graduate high school, go on to college and then law school, have a successful career as a lawyer, and then become the CEO of a very successful marketing firm that generates millions of dollars?

我母亲是艾滋病毒携带者，继父死于艾滋病，父亲曾吸食可卡因成瘾，外祖父母都是酗酒成瘾者，哥哥多米尼克一生大部分时间都在监狱里度过，最终死于吸毒过量。我的另一个兄弟青少年时期大部分时间都在监狱里度过，罪名从持有毒品到持械抢劫不等。还有一个兄弟曾因海洛因成瘾接受戒毒治疗，我的一位儿时好友因一级谋杀罪被判终身监禁。听起来很可怕，不是吗？为什么我取得了成功？为什么我能高中毕业，上大学，然后又读法学院，成为一名成功的律师，最终成为一家年收入数百万美元的营销公司的首席执行官？

People always ask me, what makes me different? How did I “make it”? Well, if you were to analyze our DNA, nothing would be different between my family members and me. What is really different is the way I think. That’s it. I am not smarter than any other person. I was not lucky, and I wasn’t given anything other than opportunity. Some would argue with me and say things like, “Well so and so had a disability, their DNA showed,” or blah, blah, blah that inhibited their success.

人们总是问我，我有什么特别之处？我是怎么“成功”的？其实，如果分析我们的DNA，我和我的家人之间并没有什么不同。真正不同的是我的思维方式。仅此而已。我并不比其他人聪明。我并非幸运，也并非被赋予了什么，只是拥有了机会。有些人会反驳我，说“某某有残疾，他们的DNA检测结果显示如此”，或者诸如此类，说这些都阻碍了他们的成功。

Now here is the good news. My mom is doing great, and she is an inspiration. She was diagnosed almost thirty years ago but is still going strong. My father is also doing very well. He overcame a drug addiction and never looked back. My brothers are also finding their way and are destined for great things.

现在有个好消息。我妈妈现在很好，她激励着我。她确诊已经快三十年了，但依然坚强地生活着。我爸爸也很好。他克服了毒瘾，从此走上了正轨。我的兄弟们也在努力寻找自己的人生方向，他们注定会成就一番事业。

My intention here is not to shine a light on my own greatness or success—just the opposite. I am pointing out that if a schlub like me from a crazy family like mine (and I say that with love) can make something out of himself and have the kind of life I dreamed of having, then so can you!

我此举并非意在炫耀自己的伟大或成功——恰恰相反。我只是想指出，如果像我这样来自一个古怪家庭（我这么说绝无恶意）的普通人都能有所成就，过上我梦寐以求的生活，那么你也可以！

I am no different than any other human being. I am far from perfect and, like everyone else, I have lots to work on, but I have programmed my mind to think differently, to ask questions in order to get more out of life. I want more out of life, and I am sure you do too. You just need to ask , and more will come!

我和其他人没什么不同。我远非完美，也和所有人一样，有很多需要改进的地方，但我已经训练自己以不同的方式思考，提出问题，从而更好地享受生活。我渴望拥有更美好的生活，我相信你也一样。你只需要开口询问，更多精彩就会到来！

IMAGINATION: one of the most powerful tools that humans have to help us visualize our dreams and goals.

想象力：是人类拥有的最强大的工具之一，可以帮助我们将梦想和目标形象化。

Imagination is our ability to form mental images and concepts in our brains to foster ideas and turn our goals into reality.

想象力是我们大脑中形成心理图像和概念的能力，它可以激发想法并将我们的目标变为现实。

“SO YOU WANT TO BE A CRIMINAL?” HOW I USED TO THINK—AND WHY I CHANGED

“所以你想当罪犯？”我过去的想法——以及我改变的原因

When I was at the pivotal age of fifteen, some thought of me as the poor kid who was also a punk. Some also thought of me as a troublemaker who was getting involved in criminal activity: stuff like shoplifting, fighting, and just being a bad kid.

在我十五岁这个关键的年纪，有些人认为我是个穷小子，还是个叛逆少年。有些人则认为我是个惹是生非的捣蛋鬼，参与各种犯罪活动：比如入店行窃、打架斗殴，总之就是个坏孩子。

My father many times would have me stay at his house on the weekends, even when I was fifteen. One weekend he took me to the beach and as we were walking he turns to me and says, “So you want to be a criminal?” He said it like a father might ask, “So you want to be a doctor?” I was shocked and didn’t understand why he asked that. He then said, “Well right now, the things you are doing would put you into the class of a wannabe criminal and just a punk.” He said if I wanted to continue to do what I was doing then we should make sure I was good at it. I was in complete shock. He told me he could introduce me to some people he knew: people who were actual gangsters, drug dealers, and other unsavory characters.

我父亲经常让我周末去他家住，即使我十五岁的时候也是如此。有一次周末，他带我去海滩，我们边走边聊，他突然转过头问我：“你想当罪犯吗？”他的语气就像父亲问“你想当医生吗？”一样。我当时很震惊，不明白他为什么这么问。然后他说：“嗯，你现在做的这些事，只能让你沦为一个想当罪犯的混混。”他说，如果我还想继续做这些事，那就得确保我能做得更好。我完全懵了。他还说他可以介绍我认识一些人：一些真正的黑帮分子、毒贩和其他不法之徒。

He then went on to describe what my life would be like. I would be constantly looking over my shoulder, maybe carrying a gun, and most certainly be in and out of jail. He asked me if I was prepared to be shot at, possibly killed, and most certainly incarcerated.

然后他开始描述我未来的生活会是什么样子。我会时刻提防着别人，可能还要随身携带枪支，而且肯定会频繁进出监狱。他问我是否做好了被枪击、被杀以及被监禁的准备。

Recently I was working in my dad’s garden, and I asked him if he remembered that talk. He said of course he did. I told him that that conversation changed the way I saw my future. I looked into the life he described and realized that it was not what I wanted. I thanked him for changing the way I thought about where I wanted to be in life at the time of that talk and in the future.

最近我在父亲的花园里干活，问他是否还记得那次谈话。他说当然记得。我告诉他，那次谈话改变了我对未来的看法。我仔细思考了他所描述的生活，意识到那并非我想要的。我感谢他改变了我当时以及未来对人生方向的思考。

Whether you are someone who is in trouble with the law, not happy with your current living situation, or dissatisfied with your employment situation, ask yourself, where you sit today: What does your future look like if you keep doing what you are doing? Are you happy with the end result? If you are not happy, then the good news is that no matter what the situation is, you can change it.

无论你是身陷法律纠纷、对目前的生活状况不满，还是对工作不满意，都应该扪心自问：如果你继续这样下去，你的未来会是什么样子？你对最终结果满意吗？如果你不满意，那么好消息是，无论情况如何，你都可以改变它。

MY BEST FRIEND AND HOW HE CHANGED HIS LIFE

我的挚友以及他如何改变了自己的人生

But I say again: Do not put me up on some kind of pedestal because I was able to change my life. My best friend has a pretty amazing story as well. In fact it’s astonishing that we are even friends at all, considering how we met.

但我还是要说：别因为我改变了自己的人生就把我捧上神坛。我最好的朋友也有着一段非常精彩的经历。事实上，考虑到我们相识的方式，我们能成为朋友本身就是一个奇迹。

When I was in eighth grade, I was jumped by a bunch of kids from the other side of my town. There were about four or five of them against me. The police came, the aggressors were arrested, and some were put into protective custody. One of them was a kid my age; his name was Kevin. Kevin grew up in very similar circumstances to mine, just in a different neighborhood. He hung around with bad kids, got into fights a lot, and was going down the wrong path. We were not friends and did not like each other at all. But we came to have something very important in common.

我上八年级的时候，被镇子另一边的一群孩子围殴。大概有四五个人。警察来了，把那些施暴者都抓了起来，其中一些人被送去保护性拘留。其中一个跟我同龄，名叫凯文。凯文的成长经历跟我很相似，只是住在不同的街区。他跟一些坏孩子混在一起，经常打架，走上了一条不归路。我们以前不是朋友，彼此都不喜欢对方。但后来，我们之间却有了一个非常重要的共同点。

The day after the fight I was at home and there was a knock on my door; Kevin and his mom were standing on my front steps. As you can imagine, I was reluctant to open the door. But I did, and Kevin and his mom came into my house. Kevin’s mom made him apologize, and she said something that was prophetic. She said, “Shake hands, and who knows? Maybe you guys will be best friends someday.” We didn’t agree but both shook hands.

争吵后的第二天，我在家，有人敲门；凯文和他妈妈站在我家门口。可想而知，我不太想开门。但我还是开了门，凯文和他妈妈进了屋。凯文的妈妈让他道歉，然后说了一句颇有预见性的话。她说：“握手吧，说不定你们以后会成为好朋友呢。”我们并不认同，但还是握了手。

Kevin went to the trade school within my high school. Trade-school kids were in a different wing of the high school and were also looked down upon by the other students. They didn’t take regular classes and were considered dumb. Kevin was considered by many as a tough guy who was not the brightest bulb on the tree. I also thought that.

凯文去了我高中里的职业学校。职业学校的学生在高中的另一个教学楼里，也被其他学生瞧不起。他们不上正规课程，被认为很笨。很多人都觉得凯文是个硬汉，但脑子不太灵光。我也这么认为。

After we graduated high school, Kevin enlisted in the military. We always kept in touch, and Kevin had a successful career in the military. While I was in college Kevin was protecting our country. What Kevin learned in the military was invaluable; he learned that not only was he not dumb, but he was extremely smart. Whenever he could, he took classes while in the military to make himself better. After his service Kevin enrolled at the local community college. The interesting thing was that Kevin not only went full time, but actually took seven classes one semester. Kevin got straight A’s for those two years of community college. The “dumb kid” from the trade school knew he was smart, but most everyone else didn’t. After graduating, Kevin was encouraged by Harvard to apply for admission. Harvard! I remember talking with Kevin about it. It was surreal: the tough-guy, trade-school kid was now considering Harvard! Well, after much thought, Kevin ended up going to Northeastern in Boston because they had a strong criminal justice program. Kevin is now a very successful police officer in New York. He teaches firearms safety and tactical classes. Kevin, too, is no different than anyone else. He just decided he was going to think differently. Kevin made the decision that he wasn’t going to succumb to negative thoughts and give in to what others perceived him to be.

高中毕业后，凯文应征入伍。我们一直保持联系，凯文在军队里也取得了成功。我上大学的时候，凯文正在保卫我们的国家。凯文在军队里学到的东西弥足珍贵；他发现自己不仅不笨，而且非常聪明。只要有机会，他就会利用服役期间的时间来学习，提升自己。退伍后，凯文进入当地的社区大学就读。有趣的是，凯文不仅全日制学习，而且在一个学期里竟然选修了七门课。他在社区大学的两年里门门功课都是A。这个曾经在技校里被认为是“笨蛋”的家伙，其实很聪明，但大多数人却不知道。毕业后，凯文受到哈佛大学的鼓励，申请了哈佛！哈佛！我记得当时和凯文聊起这件事。这感觉很不真实：这个曾经的“硬汉”技校出身的家伙，现在竟然在考虑哈佛！经过一番深思熟虑，凯文最终选择了波士顿的东北大学，因为那里的刑事司法专业很强。如今，凯文是纽约一位非常成功的警官。他教授枪械安全和战术课程。凯文也和其他人一样，只是他决定换个角度思考。凯文决定不再屈服于消极的想法，也不再受制于别人对他的看法。

Kevin’s mom was right; Kevin and I became extremely close in high school, and to this day I consider Kevin my best friend. The tough trade-school kid who was also going down the wrong path knew he could be more, and that’s exactly what he did. Kevin asked more out of himself, and that’s what he got: more . More than anyone thought possible—and he just asked .

凯文的妈妈说得对；高中时我和凯文成了非常要好的朋友，直到今天，我仍然视凯文为我最好的朋友。这个曾经误入歧途、在技校苦读的年轻人知道自己可以做得更好，而他也确实做到了。凯文对自己要求更高，而他也确实得到了更多。比任何人想象的都要多——而他只是提出了自己的要求。

EMBRACE YOUR IMAGINATION AND IMAGINE WHAT YOU CAN HAVE—JUST ASK!

发挥你的想象力，想象你能拥有什么——大胆开口吧！

Have you ever heard someone say, “Oh, don’t mind him, he has a vivid imagination,” or “He has an overactive imagination”? Though there are many factors to success, I can’t stress enough the importance of imagination . Your imagination is one of the most powerful tools available to the human mind. Encourage imagination, embrace it, and utilize it. There is no such thing as an overactive imagination.

你是否曾听人说过：“别理他，他想象力很丰富”或者“他想象力太丰富了”？虽然成功有很多因素，但我必须强调想象力的重要性。想象力是人类思维最强大的工具之一。鼓励想象力，拥抱它，并善加利用它。根本不存在想象力过度活跃这种说法。

Imagine this—what if Leonardo DaVinci’s parents told him he should stop imagining things? Or what if Steve Jobs was told to stop imagining a better computer? Do you think we would have the Mona Lisa or the iPad if their imaginations were suppressed? Leonardo DaVinci built a robot in 1495. 1495! Steve Jobs modestly said he has never invented anything, he just imagined a better version of what was already out there. There were hundreds of MP3 players on the market before the iPod, but which device revolutionized the music industry? As a result of the iPod, the iTunes store was created and literally changed the way we listen to and pay for music.

试想一下——如果达芬奇的父母告诉他停止想象，会怎么样？或者如果乔布斯被告知停止想象更先进的电脑，又会怎么样？你认为如果他们的想象力被压制，我们还能拥有《蒙娜丽莎》或iPad吗？达芬奇在1495年就制造出了机器人。1495年！乔布斯谦虚地说，他从未发明过任何东西，他只是想象出了现有产品的更佳版本。在iPod问世之前，市面上已经有数百种MP3播放器，但究竟是哪款设备彻底改变了音乐产业？正是由于iPod的出现，iTunes商店应运而生，并彻底改变了我们听音乐和付费的方式。

When I was in fifth grade we built one of Leonardo’s inventions: a parachute that looked like an inverted pyramid. It seemed like a ridiculous contraption and most certainly wouldn’t work. But that didn’t matter; we learned about gravity and the thought process behind building it. After we completed it we had the opportunity to stand on the roof of our elementary school and let it go to see what would happen. We had also made a traditional parachute to compare the utility of each. The point is, our imaginations ran wild as we thought about possibilities—the sky was the limit.

我五年级的时候，我们制作了达芬奇的一项发明：一个倒金字塔形状的降落伞。它看起来是个很滑稽的装置，肯定不会管用。但这并不重要；我们学到了重力以及制作它的思路。完成后，我们有机会站在小学的屋顶上，把它放飞，看看会发生什么。我们还制作了一个传统的降落伞，用来比较两者的实用性。总之，我们天马行空地想象着各种可能性——天空才是我们的极限。

We always hear the phrase “think outside the box,” which simply means use your imagination. I can’t tell you how many times we’ve brainstormed creative and imaginative ideas that propelled our business ventures at my company. We solved so many challenges not by looking at our schooling, at our transcripts in school, or at our SAT, LSAT, GRE, or any other standardized test score, but rather by focusing our collective imagination to solve challenges and grow our business.

我们经常听到“跳出思维定式”这句话，其实就是发挥想象力。在我的公司里，我们无数次集思广益，迸发出各种创意和想象力，最终推动了业务发展。我们解决诸多挑战，并非依靠学历、成绩单，或是SAT、LSAT、GRE或其他任何标准化考试分数，而是集中我们集体的想象力去应对挑战，发展业务。

But most of all we force ourselves and others to see ourselves and our company as a success in every venture; we refuse to accept any other outcome.

但最重要的是，我们强迫自己和他人将自己和公司视为每次尝试的成功者；我们拒绝接受任何其他结果。

WHAT IS CONTRARIAN THINKING? AND HOW CAN IT HELP YOU?

什么是逆向思维？它如何帮助你？

In case you haven’t already figured out who I am—or, I should say, who I was—I was the kid who should have ended up in jail or dead. In fact when I was sixteen, my girlfriend’s mother told me that’s how I was going to end up. Maybe she said that to motivate me. But to be honest I don’t think that’s why she said that; I think she believed it.

如果你还没弄明白我是谁——或者更确切地说，我曾经是谁——我就是那种本该进监狱或者死去的孩子。事实上，我十六岁的时候，我女朋友的妈妈就跟我说我会落得那样的下场。也许她这么说是为了激励我。但说实话，我觉得她这么说并非出于这个目的；我认为她是真心这么想的。

Regardless of her intentions, that comment bothered me and has stuck with me to this day. That is what people thought of me! Jail or dead? Well I became determined to defy them and their predictions about me. And so I did whatever I could to change. I started to ask for more in the way I thought and the way I lived.

无论她本意如何，那句话一直让我耿耿于怀，至今难忘。人们就是这么看我的！要么坐牢，要么死？我下定决心要打破他们的预言。于是，我竭尽所能地改变自己。我开始在思想和生活方式上追求更高的境界。

My cumulative grades in high school were horrible. My SAT scores were barely enough to allow me to play sports if I got into college. But, around the age of fifteen, I started to change the way I thought and also to change my social circle. It was a gradual process, and I had many missteps.

我高中时的总成绩很糟糕。我的SAT分数勉强够格进入大学后参加校队。但是，大约十五岁的时候，我开始改变我的思维方式，也开始改变我的社交圈。这是一个循序渐进的过程，期间我犯了很多错误。

But when you look at my transcripts, you can see a gradual increase in my grade point average, and eventually there were a lot of A’s and B’s. I went on to be elected senior class president and captain of my football team. Due to my commitment to my academics coupled with my extracurricular activities and the support of my family and teachers, I was fortunate enough to get accepted into a couple of colleges. I eventually chose Springfield College, the place where basketball was invented, the YMCA principles were espoused, and where Dr. Seuss lived—the famous author who not only changed my life as a child but impacted the lives of millions of other children. Coincidence? I’m not sure.

但当你查看我的成绩单时，你会发现我的平均绩点稳步提升，最终获得了许多A和B。我后来当选为高年级学生会主席和足球队队长。由于我对学业的投入、积极参与课外活动以及家人和老师的支持，我很幸运地被几所大学录取。最终，我选择了斯普林菲尔德学院——篮球运动的发源地、基督教青年会理念的倡导地，以及著名作家苏斯博士的故乡。苏斯博士不仅改变了我的童年，也影响了数百万其他孩子的生活。这难道是巧合吗？我不敢肯定。

When I first got into college it was a bit of a culture shock, and to be honest I wasn’t sure if I belonged. But I told myself that I did belong and that I wasn’t going to let myself down along with the countless other people who gave me the opportunities that ultimately opened the door to college. I had a decent undergraduate academic record, was respected by my peers and professors, and went on to be class president for three years before going to law school. I did all this by taking what you might call a contrarian view.

刚进大学的时候，我确实经历了一番文化冲击，说实话，我当时并不确定自己是否能融入其中。但我告诉自己，我属于这里，我不能辜负自己，也不能辜负无数给予我机会、最终为我打开大学大门的人们。我的本科成绩不错，也得到了同学和教授的尊重，在进入法学院之前，我还担任了三年的班长。而这一切，我都是凭借一种可以说是反传统的思维方式实现的。

CONTRARIAN THINKING

逆向思维

A contrarian is defined as a person who takes an opposing view, especially one who rejects the majority opinion, as in economic matters. The first time I heard the word “contrarian” was about two years ago when I was interviewing my good friend Dean Graziosi about his new real estate program. My infomercials are in an interview-style format similar to that of Charlie Rose.

“逆向思维者”指的是持有相反观点的人，尤其是在经济领域，他们往往不认同大多数人的意见。我第一次听到“逆向思维者”这个词大约是在两年前，当时我正在采访我的好朋友迪恩·格拉齐奥西，了解他的新房地产项目。我的电视购物广告采用了类似查理·罗斯访谈节目的访谈形式。

Dean said, “When people are worried about the real estate market, they should think more like a contrarian.” I had never heard the word and I just nodded my head and agreed with him. After the cameras were off, I asked him what it meant. He explained that his whole life, people told him not to do things because they didn’t make financial sense to them. These people would say things like, “The real estate market is crashing; why would you buy real estate in this economy?” Dean just thought a little differently, and it has paid off for him.

迪恩说：“人们担心房地产市场的时候，应该多想想逆向思维。”我以前从没听过这个词，只是点点头表示同意。拍摄结束后，我问他这是什么意思。他解释说，他这辈子经常听到别人劝他不要做某些事，因为在他们看来这些事不划算。这些人会说：“房地产市场崩盘了，你为什么要在这种经济形势下买房？”迪恩的思路稍微不同，而事实证明，他的选择是正确的。

Now in my advertisements on television for Ask More, Get More I take shots at real estate programs sold on television and say they are not easy. I point out that they work for a limited number of people, and I still stand by that statement. However, the difference between Dean Graziosi and many other so-called real estate gurus is that he really does this stuff. Every day he is actually buying and selling real estate and has done so for almost twenty years. If after reading my book, you want to dive into the real estate investment world and learn Dean’s strategies, then go to www.deangraziosi.com and check out his program. I have met his students, and many have made a lot of money. Or if, after reading this book and going to Dean’s site, you are really interested, go to my website, AskMore-GetMore.com , for a special discount on all of Dean’s products and services.

现在，我在电视上为《多问多得》（Ask More, Get More）一书做的广告中，抨击了电视上兜售的房地产课程，指出它们并不容易。我强调这些课程只对少数人有效，而且我仍然坚持这个观点。然而，迪恩·格拉齐奥西（Dean Graziosi）与许多其他所谓的房地产大师的不同之处在于，他是真正实践这些课程的。他每天都在实际买卖房地产，并且已经这样做了近二十年。如果您读完我的书后，想要深入了解房地产投资领域并学习迪恩的策略，请访问 www.deangraziosi.com 了解他的课程。我见过他的学生，其中许多人都赚了很多钱。或者，如果您在读完这本书并访问迪恩的网站后仍然很感兴趣，请访问我的网站 AskMore-GetMore.com，享受迪恩所有产品和服务的特别折扣。

Dean taught me something I already knew; I just didn’t know the word for it. In order to be successful in life, you can’t always go with the masses and do what you are supposed to do. During the Great Depression Howard Heinz, of the H. J. Heinz Corporation, built more factories, hired people, offered medical benefits, added product lines, and expanded outside of the United States. It was a bold move, and many questioned the decisions he made, but today Heinz is one of the largest companies in the world and sells more than just ketchup.

迪恩教了我一些我早已知道的东西，只是我不知道该如何表达。要想在生活中取得成功，你不能总是随波逐流，做别人认为你应该做的事。在大萧条时期，亨氏公司的霍华德·亨氏建造了更多工厂，雇佣了更多员工，提供了医疗福利，增加了产品线，并将业务拓展到美国以外的地区。这是一个大胆的举措，许多人质疑他的决定，但如今亨氏已成为世界上最大的公司之一，其产品远不止番茄酱。

I am in no way in the same class as Heinz, but many times I make decisions or come up with ideas that some would say are crazy. I have found that in order to be successful, you have to think differently. It is more than thinking big ; you have to ask questions that others consider crazy or stupid. But if you don’t ask questions or push the boundaries you will never know the limits.

我当然无法与亨氏相提并论，但我很多时候做出的决定或提出的想法，在别人看来或许有些疯狂。我发现，要想成功，就必须跳出固有思维模式。这不仅仅是胸怀大志；你还得提出那些在别人看来疯狂或愚蠢的问题。但如果你不去提问，不去挑战极限，就永远不会知道自己的潜能在哪里。

FORTY HOURS A WEEK

每周四十小时

Arlen, a Brazilian in his mid-thirties, who cleans my office, speaks broken English. My office is roughly 20,000 square feet, and he is here seven days a week—my office is always clean. You can eat off the floor in my bathrooms. Many times when I am at the office at night, I enjoy talking with Arlen. He is always here, no matter what. Now, the interesting thing about Arlen is that he has a full-time job delivering supplies for a company that sells everything from gravel to sand and loam. One day he came into my office with a big smile on his face and said, “Hey, Mike, how many hours you think I had last week?” I asked, “At your other job?” and he said, “Yeah,” so I guessed, “Seventy-five.”

阿伦是个三十多岁的巴西人，负责打扫我的办公室，他的英语不太好。我的办公室大约有两万平方英尺，他一周七天都在这里——我的办公室总是干净得一尘不染。我的卫生间地板干净得都能直接吃饭了。很多时候，我晚上在办公室的时候，都喜欢和阿伦聊天。不管怎样，他总是在这里。阿伦有趣的地方在于，他还有一份全职工作，为一家公司送货，这家公司卖的东西五花八门，从砾石到沙子和壤土都有。有一天，他笑容满面地走进我的办公室，说：“嘿，迈克，你猜我上周工作了多少个小时？”我问：“是你另一份工作吗？”他说：“对。”于是我猜：“七十五个小时。”

I was close; he worked seventy-seven hours the prior week, plus he was at my office every day .

我猜得差不多了；他前一周工作了 77 个小时，而且每天都来我的办公室。

I asked him why he had so many hours of overtime, and he told me it was because he was a producer. He went on to tell me how the other drivers don’t like him, because they are paid hourly and don’t understand how he outproduces them week in and week out, based on a forty-hour week. He told me that he averages twenty deliveries a day, while everyone else achieves ten or eleven a day.

我问他为什么加班那么多，他说因为他是业绩最好的。他还告诉我其他司机都不喜欢他，因为他们是按小时计薪的，不明白他每周工作四十小时，业绩怎么还能比他们都好。他说他平均每天能送二十单，而其他人一天也就十单或十一单。

I then asked how he did it. He said he maps out his routes and finds the fastest way to get to the point of delivery. The other drivers take the long way, because they are paid hourly and they are content with just getting paid for forty hours a week. He then told me, “Even though I’m paid hourly, if I can make my deliveries faster, then my employer will give me more hours.” So, rather than thinking only about his forty-hour pay, he is thinking about how to get more hours. He does it, not by milking the forty hours and just doing the minimum, but by finding a way to get his work done faster, become more valuable to his employer, and thus make double what all of his fellow drivers make.

我问他是怎么做到的。他说他会事先规划好路线，找到最快的送货路线。其他司机都绕远路，因为他们是按小时计薪，每周只拿四十个小时的工资就心满意足了。他接着告诉我：“虽然我是按小时计薪，但如果我能更快地送货，雇主就会给我更多的工时。”所以，他想的不是仅仅为了那四十个小时的工资，而是如何争取更多的工时。他不是只做最低限度的工作，而是想方设法更快地完成工作，提升自身价值，从而赚到比其他司机多一倍的钱。

Even though he is being paid overtime, Arlen is more valuable to his employer, because he doubles the number of deliveries. By making more deliveries faster, he not only makes his employer more money, but the clients receiving the shipment are more productive. Arlen thought just a little differently—and doubled his compensation!

尽管阿伦拿的是加班费，但他对雇主来说更有价值，因为他的送货量翻了一番。他不仅能更快地完成更多送货，还能让收货的客户提高工作效率。阿伦的思路略有不同——结果他的收入翻了一番！

“I’M GOOD ENOUGH. I’M SMART ENOUGH. AND DOGGONE IT, PEOPLE LIKE ME .”

“我足够优秀。我足够聪明。而且，该死的，人们都喜欢我。”

—Stuart Smalley, Saturday Night Live fictitious character

——斯图尔特·斯莫利，《周六夜现场》虚构人物

THE POWER OF POSITIVE THINKING

积极思考的力量

There are books, courses, articles, tapes, videos, and everything in between about the power of positive thinking. Thinking in a positive manner can boost your health, your wealth, and your life. It is a scientific fact that maintaining a positive attitude improves your life. But how can you do such a thing when you are living in a shelter, unemployed, have no prospect of employment, or if your current situation seems impossible to extricate yourself from? How can you think positively if you feel like you are underappreciated at your job or seem to always have speed bumps in your way? How can you think positively if every time you seem to move one step forward, someone else is pulling you two steps back? How can you think positively if you are sick, injured, or somehow handicapped?

关于积极思考的力量，书籍、课程、文章、录音带、视频等等，不胜枚举。积极思考可以提升你的健康、财富和生活品质。保持积极的态度能够改善生活，这已是科学事实。但是，当你住在收容所、失业、看不到就业前景，或者身处困境难以自拔时，该如何做到这一点呢？如果你在工作中感觉自己不被赏识，或者总是遇到阻碍，又该如何保持积极思考呢？如果你每次前进一步，总有人把你拉后两步，又该如何保持积极思考呢？如果你生病、受伤或身有残疾，又该如何保持积极思考呢？

You just do! Your thoughts do not control you; you control your thoughts. When you realize that you are in control of your mind, then you will realize that the thoughts you put into your head are what will determine your future.

你只需要去做！不是你的想法控制你，而是你控制你的想法。当你意识到你能掌控自己的思想时，你就会明白，你脑海中的想法将决定你的未来。

A lot of the books and tapes out there go on and on about the importance of positive thinking. I could probably cover a couple of hundred pages myself with stories about how positive-thinking people are almost always successful. Everybody gets down; I know—I do too. I am human, and I can certainly be a grouch (ask my amazing assistant), but I remind myself of the indisputable power of the mind and its effect on everything around me.

市面上很多书籍和录音带都在不厌其烦地强调积极思考的重要性。我自己也能写上几百页，讲述那些积极思考的人几乎总是成功的故事。每个人都会有情绪低落的时候；我知道——我自己也会。我是人，我当然也会发脾气（问问我那了不起的助理就知道了），但我会提醒自己，思想的力量是无可辩驳的，它影响着我周围的一切。

I met a woman named Ellen in yoga a while back who reinforced with an exclamation point what I already knew. I was running late for the class and I noticed that a woman in her mid-forties was also trying to get to the door before it locked for the duration of the class—and the woman was wearing an oxygen tank! My first thought was that there is no way this woman is going into a Bikram Power Yoga class. It is 100 degrees and 100 percent humidity.

前段时间我在瑜伽课上认识了一位名叫艾伦的女士，她用一种感叹号般的语气印证了我早已知道的事情。那天我上课快迟到了，注意到一位四十多岁的女士也在赶着去上课，因为门马上就要锁上了——而且她还背着氧气罐！我当时的第一反应是，这女人肯定没法去上高温瑜伽课。外面可是100华氏度（约38摄氏度）高温，湿度100%啊！

I was wrong. For an entire hour this woman, with an oxygen tank, performed some of the most difficult poses the instructor offered. I was humbled and amazed. But perhaps her ailment was temporary or slight asthma, I thought. So after the class, I asked, “How do you do this class with an oxygen tank?”

我错了。整整一个小时，这位女士背着氧气瓶，完成了教练布置的一些最难的瑜伽体式。我既佩服又惊叹。但我心想，也许她的病只是暂时的，或者只是轻微的哮喘。所以下课后，我问她：“你是怎么背着氧气瓶上这节课的？”

She responded enthusiastically, “Honey, I was supposed to be dead six years ago!”

她热情地回答说：“亲爱的，我本该六年前就死了！”

So of course, I asked, “What do you mean?”

所以，我当然问：“你是什么意思？”

She went on to tell me how she was diagnosed with a rare disease called lymphangioleiomyomatosis, or LAM. LAM is a rare disease that basically forms tumors all over the lungs, effectively destroying them; there is no cure and no understanding of the cause of the illness. I had never heard of LAM before, but I asked her how she did it.

她接着告诉我，她被诊断出患有一种叫做淋巴管肌瘤病（LAM）的罕见疾病。LAM是一种罕见病，它会在肺部形成肿瘤，最终破坏肺部；目前尚无治愈方法，病因也无人知晓。我以前从未听说过LAM，但我还是问了她是怎么知道的。

And she said, “Because I know I can , I am going to live, and I know I can do this .” She was so positive and vibrant. Her story is inspiring. But there are Ellens all over the world, and the only explanation for her survival is the power of positive thinking.

她说：“因为我知道我能活下去，我知道我能做到。”她如此积极乐观，充满活力。她的故事鼓舞人心。但世界各地还有许多像艾伦一样的人，她能够活下来的唯一解释就是积极思考的力量。

I have a very dear friend, Jim, whose wife has suffered with rheumatoid arthritis since the age of sixteen. This debilitating auto-immune disease is degenerative and causes severe pain. Her name is Julie, and she is an amazing woman. She lives her life in constant pain, has had multiple surgeries, and has even faced amputation of her foot due to the severe pain. I do not see Julie all that often, but a few years ago we all went to the Red Sox game, walking from bar to bar before the game and having a few beers along the way. Keep in mind, this woman is in severe pain with every step, but she not only walked with us, she stood up in crowded bars, smiling, making jokes, and having a good time. Her husband, Jim, is one of the most positive people I know, though as I type this, Julie’s health is failing due to the drugs she is forced to take to just allow her to function. When I asked Jim how she does it, he said, “We just get up every day and thank the Lord for what we have, and look forward to the day.” They maintain a positive attitude. Jim and Julie are two amazing people who always think positively despite how hard life may be.

我有一位非常要好的朋友，吉姆，他的妻子朱莉从十六岁起就患有类风湿性关节炎。这种令人痛苦的自身免疫性疾病会逐渐恶化，并引发剧烈疼痛。她叫朱莉，是一位了不起的女性。她一生都在忍受着疼痛，做过多次手术，甚至因为疼痛难忍而面临截肢。我并不经常见到朱莉，但几年前我们一起去看红袜队的比赛，赛前我们一家一家地逛酒吧，边走边喝啤酒。要知道，她每走一步都承受着巨大的痛苦，但她不仅和我们一起走，还在拥挤的酒吧里站着，面带微笑，开着玩笑，玩得很开心。她的丈夫吉姆是我认识的最乐观的人之一，然而就在我写下这些文字的时候，朱莉的健康状况却在恶化，因为她不得不服用药物才能勉强维持正常的生活。当我问吉姆她是怎么做到的，他说：“我们每天起床后都会感谢上帝赐予我们的一切，然后期待新的一天。”他们始终保持积极乐观的态度。吉姆和朱莉是两个了不起的人，无论生活多么艰难，他们总是积极向上。

At the start of this section, there is a quote from Stuart Smalley, a fictional character on Saturday Night Live . With Stuart, SNL was essentially making fun of the power of positive thinking. Stuart would look into the mirror and say, “I’m good enough, I’m smart enough, and doggone it, people like me.”

本节开头引用了《周六夜现场》虚构人物斯图尔特·斯莫利的一句话。斯图尔特这个角色，本质上是在讽刺积极思考的力量。斯图尔特会对着镜子说：“我足够优秀，我足够聪明，而且，该死的，人们都喜欢我。”

But I learned from the immortal Zig Ziglar that what Stuart Smalley did works ! In Ziglar’s book See You at the Top , he suggests doing the following exercise every morning when you wake up: clap your hands and say out loud, “Today is going to be a terrific day, I am not going to make excuses, and I will not give up.”

但我从不朽的齐格·齐格勒那里学到，斯图尔特·斯莫利的方法确实有效！在齐格勒的著作《巅峰相见》中，他建议每天早上醒来后做以下练习：拍拍手，大声说：“今天将会是美好的一天，我不会找借口，我也不会放弃。”

I’M MAGNIFICENT, BUT I WILL GET BETTER

我很棒，但我会变得更好。

I do some business with Zig Ziglar’s nephew, John Ziglar. We speak often on the telephone and every time I ask him how he is doing, he replies in his jolly Southern accent, “I’m magnificent, but I will get better.” He has trained himself in the habit of projecting to others that he is magnificent. When most people hear that response, they are taken aback, as they don’t expect it. Now, John has not had an easy go at business; he has struggled like many of us during this tough economic time, but no matter what the situation he always responds the same way— magnificent .

我和齐格·齐格勒的侄子约翰·齐格勒有一些生意往来。我们经常通电话，每次我问他近况如何，他都会用他那爽朗的南方口音回答说：“我棒极了，不过我会越来越好。”他已经习惯了在别人面前表现得非常出色。大多数人听到这种回答都会感到惊讶，因为他们没想到他会这么说。约翰的生意之路并不平坦；和我们许多人一样，他在这段艰难的经济时期也经历了不少挣扎，但无论情况如何，他的反应总是如出一辙——棒极了。

I was on a conference call the other day with the CEO of a huge, billion-dollar nutrition company, and to be honest, I was a little nervous when I first realized he wanted to speak with me. But, when he called me and asked me how I was, I responded by saying, “Fabulous, but it’s only 11:30; I will get better.” He laughed and said, “Great.” This was the first time I spoke with this man and we only spoke for about ten minutes, but he ended the call by telling me he wants to do business with my company. When people ask me how I’m doing, I say, “Fantastic, fabulous, wonderful!” It really throws people for a loop. But, it trains my subconscious mind to feel fantastic and to have a fantastic day. It is also infectious—the person who asked the question smiles, which helps them feel better. Then, hopefully they will have a better day.

前几天我跟一家市值数十亿美元的巨型营养品公司的CEO开了个电话会议。说实话，一开始我意识到他要跟我说话的时候，我还有点紧张。不过，当他打电话过来问我最近怎么样的时候，我回答说：“棒极了，不过现在才11点半，我会越来越好的。”他笑着说：“太好了。”这是我第一次跟这位CEO通话，我们只聊了大概十分钟，但他最后告诉我他想跟我们公司合作。现在别人问我最近怎么样，我都会说：“太棒了，太棒了，太好了！”这常常让别人摸不着头脑。但这能潜移默化地训练我的潜意识，让我感觉棒极了，也让我的心情变得美好。而且这种感觉还有感染力——问问题的人会微笑，这让他们感觉更好。然后，他们或许也会拥有更美好的一天。

A couple years ago I was at the home of a very successful businessman. This man made millions of dollars and his house was magnificent. Imagine 10,000 square feet, seven bedrooms, ten bathrooms, a four-car garage, and every toy imaginable. I used one of the many bathrooms, and there I found taped on the mirror a piece of paper that looked like it had been there for years. This paper had the following list written on it:

几年前，我去一位非常成功的商人家里做客。这位商人身价数百万美元，他的房子也十分豪华。想象一下，一万平方英尺（约930平方米），七间卧室，十间浴室，一个四车位的车库，以及你能想象到的所有玩具。我使用了其中一间浴室，发现镜子上贴着一张纸，看起来已经贴了好几年了。纸上写着以下清单：

  • I am going to have an amazing day.


    我今天一定会过得很精彩。
  • I am going to be successful.


    我一定会成功。
  • I am worthy of my success.


    我的成功实至名归。
  • I will achieve anything I set my mind to.
    我只要下定决心，就一定能做到。

I don’t know if those four things have any particular significance to this person, but the fact is this dog-eared piece of paper with its handwritten list of four phrases meant something to him. I have on my desk my own motivational phrases that I look at every day. I do this because I know that successful people before me have done the same. I encourage you to do it, too.

我不知道这四句话对这个人有什么特别的意义，但事实是，这张卷了角的纸片上手写的四句话对他来说意义非凡。我的办公桌上也放着我自己的励志语录，我每天都会看一眼。我这样做是因为我知道，在我之前的成功人士也这样做过。我鼓励你也这样做。

So now that you know one of my trademark secrets, when you are asked how you are doing, respond in your own way by saying something positive like, “I’m terrific, magnificent, wonderful.” I do it all the time. Every day when you wake up, clap your hands with enthusiasm and say, “Today is going to be a terrific day, I am not going to make excuses, and I will not give up.” Do this every day !

既然你已经知道了我的一个独门秘诀，那么当别人问你最近怎么样时，就用你自己的方式积极回应，比如“我棒极了！太好了！太棒了！”我经常这样做。每天早上醒来，就热情地拍拍手，然后说：“今天将会是美好的一天，我不会找借口，也不会放弃！”每天都这样做！

“IT ISN’T THE PEOPLE YOU HIRE WHO WILL MAKE YOUR LIFE MISERABLE; IT’S THE PEOPLE YOU DON’T FIRE .”

“真正让你痛苦的不是你雇佣的人，而是你没有解雇的人。”

—Harvey Mackay

——哈维·麦凯

CLEANSE YOUR SOCIAL CIRCLE

清理你的社交圈

When I was a kid, I sometimes crossed the line between what was right and wrong with my ruffian friends. But I was lucky. My elementary school was a wonderful (though unintentional) social experiment. The school was located in an area that had some of the town’s most affluent kids and also the poorest kids—like me. I was always getting in trouble, but I took notice of the more affluent kids and realized I wanted what they had. I didn’t want to be embarrassed about my living situation; I wanted nice clothes and an unsubsidized lunch. The social diversity at my elementary school, and even in my middle and high school, gave me a glimpse into the world of possibilities. I didn’t know exactly how I was going to get there, but I knew that one day I was going to achieve a higher standard of living. What I didn’t realize then, at least consciously, was that achieving that dream would be a result not only of the things that I did or didn’t do, but it would also depend on the actions of the people I chose to surround myself with.

小时候，我和几个顽劣的朋友有时会越过是非界限。但我很幸运。我的小学就像一个奇妙（虽然并非有意为之）的社会实验场。学校位于一个既有镇上最富裕的孩子，也有像我一样最贫困的孩子的社区。我总是惹麻烦，但我注意到那些家境优渥的孩子，意识到自己也想要他们拥有的一切。我不想为自己的出身感到羞耻；我想要漂亮的衣服和免费的午餐。小学，甚至中学和高中的社会多样性，让我看到了无限的可能。我不知道自己究竟该如何实现目标，但我知道总有一天我会拥有更高的生活水平。当时我并没有意识到，至少在意识层面上，实现这个梦想不仅取决于我做了什么或没做什么，还取决于我选择与哪些人为伍。

When I was about sixteen my life changed forever when a friend in the neighborhood made a decision that took the life of a young girl. This decision ruined his life as well as many others. When this tragic murder happened, I was dating a girl who was upper middle class. She had the things I wanted—a nice house and a car. Her dad was a doctor, which allowed her family to live comfortably. I, on the other hand, was still flirting with the line between right and wrong. Right around this time, sports became a very important part of my life and I became friends with other athletic kids from the more affluent parts of town.

大约十六岁那年，我的人生彻底改变了。邻居的一个朋友做出了一个决定，夺走了一个年轻女孩的生命。这个决定不仅毁了他自己的人生，也毁了许多其他人的生活。这场悲剧发生时，我正在和一个家境优渥的女孩交往。她拥有我梦寐以求的一切——漂亮的房子和车子。她的父亲是医生，这让她的家庭过上了舒适的生活。而我，却还在善恶的边缘徘徊。就在那时，体育运动成了我生活中非常重要的一部分，我也结识了一些来自富裕社区、同样热爱运动的孩子。

The boy who made the horrific decision to take someone else’s life did not see the opportunities that I saw and was not taking advantage of school activities or sports. Because of his poor choices, I made the decision to distance myself from him, and we were no longer close friends. One summer day, he asked me to go for a walk with him and a group of other boys, and something inside of me said not to. Fortunately at that very moment, my well-off girlfriend drove by my neighborhood and asked me to go out with her. That day, this sixteen-year-old friend murdered his fourteen-year-old girlfriend and was ultimately sentenced to life without parole. One event, one choice changed my life forever.

那个做出夺人性命的可怕决定的男孩，没有看到我看到的机会，也没有积极参与学校活动或体育运动。因为他的错误选择，我决定疏远他，我们不再是亲密的朋友。一个夏日，他邀请我和他以及一群其他男孩一起散步，我内心深处有个声音告诉我不要去。幸运的是，就在那时，我家境优渥的女友开车经过我家附近，邀请我出去。那天，这个十六岁的朋友杀害了他十四岁的女友，最终被判处终身监禁，不得假释。一件小事，一个选择，彻底改变了我的人生。

Still, I wasn’t out of the woods. I was trying to escape the neighborhood circle of bad boys I grew up with, but this murder brought me back in, and the media and others lumped all of the kids from my neighborhood into one basket. The media unjustly crucified us as all bad kids, even though by the time the case went to trial, I was class president and captain of the football team. I had to testify in court, and what I testified about was not good, since I saw a lot of bad things when I was a kid. The district attorney at the time was attacking me personally in the paper. I didn’t understand why; I was just a kid.

然而，我并没有完全脱离险境。我一直试图逃离从小一起长大的那群坏孩子，但这起谋杀案又把我拉了回去。媒体和其他人把我们街区的所有孩子都一概而论。媒体不公正地把我们都钉在十字架上，说我们都是坏孩子，尽管到了开庭审理的时候，我已经是班长和足球队队长了。我不得不出庭作证，而我的证词并不光彩，因为我小时候目睹了很多不好的事情。当时的地区检察官在报纸上对我进行人身攻击。我不明白为什么；我当时只是个孩子。

But many of my peers, teachers, family members, and coaches came to my aid, and the district attorney realized what he had done was wrong. Coaches and teachers wrote to the local paper in my defense, and it was wonderful to read what they thought of me and my character. This was such a difficult time for me, but I was fortunate to be able to discuss this horrific situation with many of my coaches and teachers. Their message was clear; they all told me that I had great potential and that this was the time to cleanse my social circle. Following their advice, I decided to quit hanging out with kids or other people who were a negative influence.

但我的许多同学、老师、家人和教练都伸出援手，地方检察官也意识到自己做错了。教练和老师们还写信给当地报纸为我辩护，读到他们对我以及我的人品的评价，我感到非常欣慰。那段时间对我来说非常艰难，但我很幸运能够和许多教练和老师讨论这件可怕的事情。他们的意见很明确：他们都告诉我，我很有潜力，现在是时候清理我的社交圈了。听从他们的建议，我决定不再和那些对我产生负面影响的孩子或其他人来往。

Fast-forward to my career, and the same lesson rings true. One of the most difficult but important things I have learned about in business is having to fire people. I don’t know many people who actually enjoy the act of letting an employee go. But if you don’t make the tough decisions, your business suffers and, in some instances, fails. When it pertains to your personal life, you must do the same. In order to grow personally, professionally, and spiritually, you need to fire the negative people around you.

快进到我的职业生涯，同样的道理依然适用。我在商业中学到的最难但也最重要的事情之一就是解雇员工。我认识的人里，没几个真正喜欢解雇员工的。但如果你不做这些艰难的决定，你的企业就会遭受损失，在某些情况下甚至会倒闭。在个人生活中，你也必须这样做。为了在个人、职业和精神层面都得到成长，你需要远离身边那些消极的人。

FRIENDS

朋友们

A friend is someone you can trust and whose opinions and companionship you value. You can define what friendship means to you, but for me, the preceding phrase describes a friend. Several years ago, I had a momentous day. I had set a goal of purchasing a Rolex Submariner with a gold and steel band and the blue face. It is a very expensive watch, and it was a goal that I had set several years prior to the purchase. I, of course, used my phrase that I will mention later in this book and got a great deal at a real Rolex dealer. I was so excited; a kid who grew up with nothing, I now had on my wrist something worth more than some people make in a year. It was a goal I achieved.

朋友是你可以信任的人，是你会珍视其意见和陪伴的人。友谊对你的意义因人而异，但对我而言，前面那句话描述的就是朋友。几年前，我经历了一个意义非凡的日子。我给自己定了个目标，要买一块金钢表带、蓝盘的劳力士潜航者型腕表。这是一款非常昂贵的腕表，也是我几年前就定下的目标。当然，我用了我稍后会在书中提到的那句口头禅，最终在一家正规的劳力士经销商那里以非常优惠的价格买到了它。我当时兴奋极了；一个从小一无所有的孩子，如今手腕上戴着一块价值超过某些人一年收入的腕表。我实现了这个目标。

That night I met up with a couple of high school friends of mine who were upper to middle class. They had grown up in my town and were both college educated. We met in a smoke-filled club and ordered a couple of cheap drinks while I showed them my watch. They looked at it and made comments like, “A watch doesn’t define me,” “I can tell time just by looking at my cheap twenty-dollar watch,” and “A Rolex isn’t going to make you a better person.” All of these were valid comments, but each one was negative.

那天晚上，我跟几个高中同学见面，他们家境属于中上阶层。他们都和我一样在同一个小镇长大，而且都受过大学教育。我们约在一家烟雾缭绕的酒吧见面，点了几杯便宜的酒，我给他们看了我的手表。他们看了看，然后说了些诸如“手表不能定义我”、“我看一眼我那块二十美元的便宜表就能知道时间”、“劳力士不会让你变成更好的人”之类的话。这些话都很有道理，但每一句都带着负面的意味。

I tried to tell them that it was a goal I set for myself, and I had achieved my goal. As they sat on their bar stools in a smoke-infested club, surrounded by old men who could have been somebody, I realized that I could no longer hang out with these guys.

我试图告诉他们，这是我给自己设定的目标，而我已经实现了。当他们坐在烟雾缭绕的酒吧吧台上，周围都是些曾经辉煌过的老男人时，我意识到我再也不能和这些人混在一起了。

It’s not that they are bad people—I still consider them good friends—but in order for me to be successful I need to be surrounded by people who also want to be successful. They were not trying to rain on my parade or be downers, at least not consciously. They were just conditioned by their surroundings to be this way. I realized that I had to cleanse myself of these acquaintances. Now, just to be clear, cleansing your friends doesn’t mean you have to expel them from your life forever, but depending on the level of their negativity and potentially destructive behavior, you just stop hanging out with them. It doesn’t mean you can’t be where they may be, and you may even still talk with them, but you have to realize that socializing with negative people, friends or not, for extended periods of time can harm you and potentially infect you with “excusetosis,” a disease I will talk to you about in the next chapter.

倒不是说他们是坏人——我仍然把他们当成好朋友——但要想成功，我需要身边都是同样渴望成功的人。他们并非有意扫我的兴或让我沮丧，至少不是有意识的。他们只是受环境影响而变成了这样。我意识到我必须和这些人断绝关系。需要说明的是，断绝朋友关系并不意味着要永远把他们赶出你的生活，而是根据他们消极情绪和潜在破坏性行为的程度，停止和他们来往。这并不意味着你不能出现在他们可能出现的地方，你甚至可以继续和他们聊天，但你必须意识到，长时间和消极的人交往，无论是不是朋友，都会对你造成伤害，甚至可能让你患上“借口症”，我会在下一章详细讨论这种疾病。

I tell you this story not to disparage my high school friends but rather to get you to look at your circle of friends and ask yourself if they are bringing you down. If they are, you need to distance yourself from them— now . Do not get infected with diseases such as procrastination, excusetosis, and failure.

我讲这个故事不是为了贬低我的高中朋友，而是想让你审视一下自己的朋友圈，问问自己他们是否在拖你的后腿。如果是，你必须立刻和他们保持距离。不要让自己染上拖延症、找借口和失败症。

I have only a few close friends and many associates, or “people I know.” The associates are people I grab a drink with here and there. My true friends are confidants and successful in their world. Your friends do not have to be wildly successful people, but they need to be people who won’t bring you down.

我只有几个知心好友，还有很多熟人，或者说“认识的人”。熟人就是偶尔会一起喝上一杯的人。我真正的朋友都是我的知己，而且在各自的领域都很成功。你的朋友不一定要非常成功，但他们必须是不会拖你后腿的人。

An interesting fact about one of the guys in the preceding story is that he has completely changed his life and his way of thinking. He is much more positive, he is physically in great shape, he changed what he eats, and also no longer drinks any alcohol. I now enjoy speaking with him; he has embraced positive thinking and now sees that he too wants more out of life than hanging out in smoke-filled rooms with has-beens.

前面故事里提到的那位男士，有个很有意思的地方：他彻底改变了自己的人生和思维方式。他变得更加积极乐观，身体也变得非常健康，饮食习惯也发生了改变，而且滴酒不沾。我现在很喜欢和他聊天；他接受了积极的心态，并且意识到，他的人生目标不仅仅是和那些过气明星在烟雾缭绕的房间里消磨时光。

WHAT ABOUT THOSE CRAZY FAMILY MEMBERS?

那些古怪的家庭成员呢？

Unfortunately for me and for many others, sometimes the people we need to fire are family members. Now, let me be clear: family does come first, but that does not mean you need to be around family members all the time. You may find that in many instances it is a family member or even the entire family circle that brings you down.

不幸的是，对我以及许多其他人来说，有时我们需要解雇的人恰恰是家人。现在，我要明确一点：家人固然重要，但这并不意味着你必须时时刻刻和家人待在一起。你可能会发现，很多时候，拖你后腿的正是某个家人，甚至是整个家庭。

When my family reads this book I’m sure they will say things like, “Well, that wasn’t me,” or “I always knew he would make it,” in order to make themselves feel better. The truth is I had very close family members who said and continue to say very negative things.

我确信，当我的家人读到这本书时，他们会说“嗯，那不是我做的”或者“我一直都知道他会成功的”之类的话，以此来安慰自己。但事实是，我的一些至亲好友过去和现在都说过一些非常负面的话。

When I made the decision to go to college I had one family member, one whom I actually looked up to, say to me, “Are you sure you want to go to college? What about community college? That is what your other relatives did.” I felt angry at this comment from a family member, basically trying to kill my dreams and aspirations. Then when I decided to go to law school I had another very close family member say to me, “Are you sure that’s what you want to do?” Can you imagine? Rather than words of encouragement, like “Great idea!” “You are going to make a great lawyer!” or “I will support you all they way,” I got “are you sure?” I don’t think either relative was trying to be malicious, but they both have been infected with excusetosis and were subconsciously spreading the disease.

当我决定上大学时，一位我非常敬重的家人对我说：“你确定要上大学吗？社区大学怎么样？你其他亲戚都是这么做的。” 我当时很生气，感觉这位家人简直是在扼杀我的梦想和抱负。后来，当我决定读法学院时，另一位关系非常亲近的家人又问我：“你确定这是你想要的吗？” 你能想象吗？他们没有像“好主意！”“你会成为一名优秀的律师！”或者“我会一直支持你”那样鼓励我，而是问我“你确定吗？” 我觉得这两位亲戚都不是故意的，但他们都患上了“找借口症”，而且在不知不觉中把这种病传染给了别人。

I am still close with these family members, but there are other more explosive and more critical things that many other people are subjected to from their family members that are considered verbal abuse! You need to step back from your family to decide who in your family circle is holding you back. These are the people who need to take a leave of absence from your life. This can be done without hurting anyone’s feelings—you just do it. The two family members I just mentioned probably have no idea that they made these comments and most certainly have no idea that I have distanced myself from them.

我和这些家人关系依然很亲密，但还有很多人遭受着来自家人更激烈、更尖锐的言语攻击，这些都属于语言暴力！你需要暂时离开你的家庭，好好想想是谁在阻碍你前进。这些人需要从你的生活中“请假”。这样做不会伤害任何人——你只需要去做就好。我刚才提到的那两位家人可能根本不知道他们说过那些话，更不知道我已经和他们疏远了。

ASK FOR MORE EDUCATION—TAKE A CLASS

寻求更多教育机会——参加课程

I have had the great fortune of having gone to college and then law school, and I’ve learned a lot of things. But the most interesting thing about education, and most of the curricula in the higher educational systems in the world, is that there are not classes on how to build confidence or how to become successful. Though I graduated confidently from law school, law school did not teach me how to become a lawyer, let alone how to be successful.

我很幸运能够上大学，然后又读法学院，学到了很多东西。但教育中最有趣的一点，也是世界上大多数高等教育体系的课程设置，就是没有开设如何建立自信或如何获得成功的课程。虽然我从法学院毕业时信心满满，但法学院并没有教我如何成为一名律师，更遑论如何获得成功。

Most of the lessons I learned about success were achieved through life experience. Despite this, after my formal education I took a few classes about negotiation, and I also went through extensive sales training. It bothers me that the world’s educational systems do not spend time on teaching success principles and techniques. If we as a human race were taught these skills at a young age, it is my belief that most of the world’s problems, from poverty to genocidal violence, would not occur. Learning the success principles and techniques that are in this book and available to everyone in courses and seminars all over the world teaches us how to better interact and achieve greatness through strong morals, ethics, and values. We can then leave behind the negative activities of jealousy and hatred for others.

我所学到的成功经验大多来自人生阅历。尽管如此，在完成正规教育后，我还是参加了一些谈判课程，并接受了大量的销售培训。令我感到困扰的是，世界各地的教育体系并没有花时间教授成功的原则和技巧。我相信，如果我们人类从小就能学习这些技能，那么世界上大多数问题，从贫困到种族灭绝，都不会发生。本书中阐述的成功原则和技巧，以及世界各地开设的课程和研讨会所教授的内容，能够教会我们如何更好地与人交往，并通过强大的道德、伦理和价值观成就卓越。如此，我们才能摒弃嫉妒和仇恨等负面情绪。

Check out your local university or community college and enroll yourself in classes on confidence. These are usually offered at night and are inexpensive. On my website, AskMore-GetMore.com , I also have a list of other classes that are offered around the world and also classes that can be completed online to help improve your chances of success.

不妨了解一下你所在地区的大学或社区学院，报名参加一些提升自信的课程。这些课程通常在晚上开设，而且费用不高。我的网站 AskMore-GetMore.com 上也列出了世界各地开设的其他课程，以及一些可以在线完成的课程，这些都能帮助你提高成功的几率。

FAILURE IS A DISEASE THAT CAN BE CURED

失败是一种可以治愈的疾病。

There is really no such thing as failure, unless you believe you have failed. Failure is temporary—unless you give up and allow it to become permanent. In fact, temporary failures, also known as “temporary defeats,” make us stronger and prepare us for the future. I view each “temporary defeat” as a learning experience. I’ve said this before, and you need to say it every day: I have never failed at anything; I have only experienced defeat, and I will learn from it . This is one of the easiest things to understand; we never fail, rather we experience adversity, which truly makes us stronger. Failure is fatal and it ends the experience. By using your imagination, every negative experience or “failure” can truly be turned into a positive lesson.

其实，除非你认为自己失败了，否则根本不存在真正的失败。失败是暂时的——除非你放弃，让它变成永久的失败。事实上，暂时的失败，也就是所谓的“暂时的挫败”，会让我们变得更强大，为未来做好准备。我把每一次“暂时的挫败”都看作是一次学习的经历。我以前说过，你也需要每天都这样说：我从未真正失败过；我只是经历过挫折，而我会从中吸取教训。这是最容易理解的道理之一；我们从未真正失败过，我们经历的只是逆境，而逆境恰恰能让我们变得更强大。真正的失败是致命的，它会终结一切。但只要你发挥想象力，每一次负面的经历或“失败”都可以转化为一次积极的学习机会。

At fourteen, I was arrested for driving around on a dirt bike like a crazy kid, and I sat in jail for several hours until my mother finally picked me up. I was embarrassed and apologetic, but that did not persuade the judge—he gave me one year on supervised probation! I thank God for that judge. I had to visit a probation officer every week, and I showed up for every meeting. When I was in the juvenile system, I decided to learn from this experience and take advantage of the resources given to me. My probation officer was a scary guy who commanded respect and demanded that I change my ways. Interestingly, he had played professional football in Canada, so we had a common interest. Too many kids who get in trouble simply take their punishment and don’t learn from the experience or discover the “silver lining” of opportunity. I decided to improve my grades, discipline my time, and observe my surroundings.

十四岁那年，我因为像个疯孩子一样骑着越野摩托车到处乱窜而被捕，在监狱里待了好几个小时，直到我妈来接我。我当时又羞又愧，连连道歉，但这并没有打动法官——他判了我一年缓刑！我感谢上帝，也感谢那位法官。我必须每周都去见缓刑监督官，而且每次都去了。在少年司法系统中，我决定从这段经历中吸取教训，并充分利用各种资源。我的缓刑监督官是个很厉害的人，他很有威严，要求我改过自新。有趣的是，他曾在加拿大打过职业橄榄球，所以我们有共同的爱好。太多孩子犯了错就默默承受惩罚，却不从中吸取教训，也不去发现其中的“一线希望”。我决定努力提高成绩，合理安排时间，并观察周围的环境。

Fast-forward to 2003. During my last semester of law school, I called the same district attorney who crucified me when I was in high school and asked him to hire me as an intern. He was delighted to hear from me and jumped at the chance to make right what he had done to a young kid. I became 303 Certified with the Supreme Judicial Court of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts as a district attorney, which means I could do everything a lawyer does under the supervision of a licensed attorney. Guess who I saw on a daily basis? My old probation officer! In fact we worked together on a couple of issues. The experience of being arrested when I was fourteen, which was negative and unfortunate, ultimately became a positive, life-changing experience. I became very interested in the law and observed how things worked within the judicial system. What seemed like a failure or act of deviance by a young kid turned into a positive experience that changed my life.

时间快进到2003年。在我法学院的最后一个学期，我给高中时曾严厉批评我的那位地方检察官打了电话，请求他聘我做实习生。他接到我的电话后欣喜若狂，并抓住这个机会弥补他当年对一个年轻人造成的伤害。我获得了马萨诸塞州最高司法法院颁发的303认证，成为一名地方检察官，这意味着在一名持证律师的监督下，我可以从事律师的所有工作。猜猜我每天都能见到谁？我以前的缓刑监督官！事实上，我们还一起处理过几个问题。十四岁时被捕的经历，虽然令人沮丧和不幸，但最终却成为了一次积极的、改变人生的经历。我对法律产生了浓厚的兴趣，并开始观察司法系统的运作。一个年轻人的过错或越轨行为，最终却变成了一次改变我人生的积极经历。

SILVER LINING

一线希望

Some would say I have lived a tough life. I grew up poor, surrounded by drugs, and witnessing violence. I had very few role models, missed passing the bar exam the first time around, declared bankruptcy, and had to testify in a murder trial at a very young age.

有人会说我的人生很坎坷。我出身贫寒，身边充斥着毒品，目睹过暴力。我几乎没有榜样，第一次参加律师资格考试没通过，还宣布破产，年纪轻轻就被迫在谋杀案审判中作证。

These were all pretty hard things to go through. We all have personal struggles and tragedies. I taught myself that no matter how bad a situation is, I should always try to learn from it and search for the “silver lining” in the clouds. Adversity and challenges will always be present in your life, but once you are able to find the silver lining, things won’t seem so bad. There is always a silver lining; you just need to train yourself to find it. One big silver lining for me is that today I realize the difficult times and struggles in my life have made me who I am and allowed me to write Ask More, Get More in order to change people’s lives.

这些都是非常艰难的经历。我们每个人都会遇到个人的困境和不幸。我告诉自己，无论处境多么糟糕，都应该努力从中吸取教训，努力寻找“乌云背后的希望”。逆境和挑战总是会伴随你的人生，但一旦你找到了希望，一切就不会显得那么糟糕了。总会有一线希望，你只需要训练自己去发现它。对我来说，最大的希望之一就是，如今我意识到，人生中的艰难时刻和挣扎造就了今天的我，也让我有机会写下《多问，多得》（Ask More, Get More）这本书，希望能改变人们的生活。

The reason I tell you the stories about my life is to show you that once you decide to make a change—at any age and from any background—it can be done. There is no stronger force than that of the human spirit. And believe me, there are many more amazing stories of overcoming adversity than mine.

我之所以讲述我的人生故事，是想告诉你们，只要你下定决心做出改变——无论年龄多大，无论出身如何——你都能做到。没有什么力量比人类精神更强大。而且，相信我，还有很多比我的故事更精彩的战胜逆境的故事。

But ultimately Ask More, Get More isn’t about my or others’ stories, it is about yours. It’s about your commitment to change what you want to change right now. In my next book I want to tell your story. So start writing it now !

但归根结底，《多问，多得》这本书讲述的不是我或其他人的故事，而是你的故事。它关乎你现在就下定决心去改变你想改变的事情。在我的下一本书里，我想讲述你的故事。所以，现在就开始写吧！

#↩

CHAPTER 2

第二章

ASK YOURSELF TO STOP MAKING EXCUSES

告诉自己不要再找借口了。

When you correct your mind, everything else will fall into place.

当你调整好心态，其他一切都会迎刃而解。

—Dr. Wayne Dyer

——韦恩·戴尔博士

HOW I STOPPED MAKING EXCUSES AND STARTED MAKING MONEY

我是如何不再找借口并开始赚钱的

It wasn’t until I was in my late twenties that I really understood how harmful excuses can become to a person’s life, and I became consciously aware of “excusetosis.” But even earlier, now that I look back, I realize that I was finding ways to overcome this awful disease from the time I was a child. When I discussed how I am no different than anyone else, that is true, but at a very young age I just learned not to make excuses. I learned how to shield myself from excusetosis through the advice of my mom and my teachers, but those who really drove home the harmful nature of excusetosis were my coaches. As I stated earlier, I played baseball, football, soccer, and even basketball when I was a child. My coaches were all working dads who decided to help out within the community by coaching. Looking back on it, I realize that coaching is such an awesome responsibility; as you are about to learn, the values they teach you will change your life—even when it’s about something as simple as learning to bunt.

直到快三十岁的时候，我才真正明白借口对一个人的生活有多么有害，并开始有意识地意识到“借口症”。但现在回想起来，其实更早的时候，我就在想方设法克服这种可怕的“疾病”。我之前说过我和其他人没什么不同，这没错，但我很小的时候就学会了不找借口。我从妈妈和老师那里学会了如何保护自己免受借口症的困扰，但真正让我深刻体会到借口症危害的是我的教练们。正如我之前提到的，我小时候打过棒球、橄榄球、足球，甚至还打过篮球。我的教练都是工作繁忙的父亲，他们选择通过执教来回馈社区。现在回想起来，我意识到执教是一项多么了不起的责任；正如你即将了解到的，他们教给你的价值观将会改变你的一生——即使是像学习短打这样简单的技巧。

I think a lot of kids are afraid of getting hit by a baseball, and so the skill of bunting is somewhat intimidating. When you bunt a baseball, you essentially square your body over the plate and try to do what some would say is the hardest thing to do in all sports: make contact between a round bat and a round ball. I remember one day telling my coach that I just couldn’t do it. My main excuse was that I was afraid of being hit by the ball. He said that every time I went up to the plate, that was a possibility. But I went on to explain very methodically that squaring the body over the plate would actually increase the chances of getting hit, and it could really hurt. He then explained to me the importance of the bunting technique and how it could cause a team to win or lose, so everyone had to learn how to bunt. I continued to say why I couldn’t, and, somewhat exasperated, he had our star pitcher and me go up to the mound and throw balls at him as fast as possible, and he bunted every single one. I remember being amazed at his skill, but it still did not comfort me. Well, I finally tried it, and after a while I got the hang of it. Now, I was always a big kid, and when I got up to the plate, it was usually a home run or a strikeout (I wasn’t the best batter).

我觉得很多孩子都害怕被棒球击中，所以触击这项技巧对他们来说有点吓人。触击棒球的时候，你基本上要把身体摆正在本垒板正上方，然后尝试完成一些运动中最难的事情：用圆球棒击中圆球。我记得有一天我跟教练说我根本做不到。我的主要理由是害怕被球击中。他说每次我上击球区都有可能被球击中。但我还是很有条理地解释说，把身体摆正在本垒板正上方实际上会增加被球击中的几率，而且真的会很疼。然后他跟我解释了触击技巧的重要性，以及它如何影响球队的胜负，所以每个人都必须学会触击。我继续解释我为什么做不到，他有点恼火了，就让我们队的主力投手和我上投手丘，尽可能快地向他投球，结果他每次都成功触击了。我记得当时我很佩服他的球技，但这并没有让我感到安慰。后来，我终于也试了试，过了一会儿就掌握了要领。我从小个子就很高，每次上场打击，要么就打出全垒打，要么就被三振出局（我的击球水平并不好）。

The following Saturday we had a game on a baseball field that I am looking at as I type. The game wasn’t one of any importance other than that we of course wanted to win. Well, as you can imagine, it was late in the game, bottom of the ninth, two outs, tied up 2–2 with a man on third and guess who was up to bat? Now, again, I was very inconsistent with my batting skills, so I looked over at my coach and he gave the signal for a bunt! A suicide squeeze is what it was actually called; I had to bunt the ball just so that it would go down the first base line, run as fast as I could, and my teammate would run from third and hopefully score and we would then be ahead by a run. Well, I had two options: not listen to my coach, swing for the bleachers, hit a home run, and gloriously walk off the field; or listen to what I was taught and bunt. Well, I decided not to make an excuse in my head as to why I would not listen to him, and I laid down the perfect bunt, right down the first base line. My teammate safely made it to home plate, and we won the game. I could have totally missed the ball, gotten hit, or not laid down the bunt properly, but I would never know the answer if I had made an excuse as to why I would not bunt the ball.

接下来的周六，我们在棒球场上打了一场比赛，我现在一边打字一边看着这块场地。这场比赛本身并不重要，当然，我们当然想赢。可想而知，比赛进行到九局下半，两出局，比分2比2平，三垒有人，猜猜谁上场打击？我的击球技术一直很不稳定，所以我看了看教练，他示意我短打！这其实叫“自杀式触击”，我得轻轻地把球打到一垒线附近，然后拼命跑，我的队友从三垒跑过去，希望他能得分，这样我们就能领先一分。当时我有两个选择：要么不听教练的，猛挥一棒，打出全垒打，然后光荣地走下球场；要么听从教练的指导，选择短打。我决定不再为自己不听他的话找借口，而是完美地完成了一次触击，球沿着一垒线飞过。我的队友安全跑回本垒，我们赢得了比赛。我本来可能完全没接到球，被球击中，或者触击没成功，但如果我找借口不去触击，我就永远无法知道结果了。

That day I learned a few lessons that don’t need a lot of explanation. Number one: when you are being taught something by someone who knows more than you, listen. This person knows more than you ! Number two: apply the skills you learned from your “coach” to whatever situation applies. Number three: making excuses takes away your opportunity to see what could have been. Don’t ever be that person who says “If I had only listened to my coach; if I had only done this or that.” Excuses can kill your dreams and goals, no matter how big or small.

那天我学到了一些无需过多解释的道理。第一：当有人比你懂得多时，一定要认真听讲。毕竟，他比你懂得多！第二：把你从“教练”那里学到的技能运用到任何适用的情境中。第三：找借口会让你错失良机，看不到自己本可以取得的成就。永远不要成为那种总是说“如果我当初听了教练的话就好了”或者“如果我当初做了这个或那个就好了”的人。借口会扼杀你的梦想和目标，无论它们多么巨大或渺小。

EXCUSOLOGY: THE STUDY OF THE DISEASE OF EXCUSETOSIS (HOW TO REMOVE EXCUSES FROM YOUR MIND)

借口学：借口症的研究（如何从你的脑海中消除借口）

Many books discuss how excuses set us back and prevent us from achieving our goals. We all make and use excuses every day: I didn’t work out today because I’m too busy, too tired, or there is not enough time in the day … I didn’t accomplish my goal today because I was distracted by one of my colleagues … I wasn’t able to give that presentation because I was afraid of what people would think of me … and on it goes. I could fill this entire chapter by listing thousands of excuses for every possible situation. Most of our excuses are just ways of making ourselves feel better about why we didn’t do something, and oftentimes our loved ones help perpetuate this disease.

许多书籍都探讨过借口如何阻碍我们前进，妨碍我们实现目标。我们每天都在编造和使用借口：我今天没锻炼，因为我太忙、太累，或者一天的时间不够……我今天没完成目标，因为我被同事分心了……我没能做那个演讲，因为我害怕别人怎么看我……等等等等。我可以列举出成千上万个借口，涵盖各种可能的情况，写满整整一章。我们大多数的借口只是为了让自己感觉好一些，解释为什么我们没有做某件事，而我们的亲人往往也在助长这种风气。

Your mom might have said to you when you were a kid, “That’s okay, you didn’t have enough time to practice, that’s why you didn’t make the team”; or “You’re overweight because it’s in our genes, you’re big boned”; or “It’s not your fault we are poor, it is the economy.” Your parents were just trying to ease the pain of excusetosis by giving you more excuses, but in all reality they were acting as a secondary host of this disease and making you sicker.

你小时候，妈妈可能对你说：“没关系，你练习的时间不够，所以才没入选球队”；或者“你超重是因为遗传，你骨架大”；又或者“我们穷不是你的错，是经济不景气”。你的父母只是想通过给你更多借口来减轻你“找借口症”带来的痛苦，但实际上，他们却成了这种疾病的帮凶，让你病情加重。
