When you study this disease you will find one very profound thing: successful people are either naturally immune or have developed an immunity to excusetosis. People who seem to have been born with an immunity to this disease most likely inherited this protective trait through their upbringing. Their parents didn’t allow for excuses. Their teachers, coaches, and family members understood that exposure to this disease early on could have severe consequences in the attainment of success, and thus trained the child to develop the immunity to excusetosis. In all reality there are very few people brought up in this world who were never exposed to excusetosis, as most were infected at a very early age. It is airborne—it surrounds us via the television, radio, Internet, and in society as a whole. The good news is that excusetosis is curable at any stage in life, and curing it can have a profoundly positive impact on your life. The second you realize that this disease can only survive if the host allows it to live, you will be on your way to a more fulfilled life.

当你研究这种“疾病”时，你会发现一个非常深刻的道理：成功人士要么天生免疫，要么后天培养了对“找借口症”的免疫力。那些似乎天生就对这种“疾病”免疫的人，很可能是通过后天的教育继承了这种保护机制。他们的父母不允许他们找借口。他们的老师、教练和家人都明白，过早接触这种“疾病”可能会严重影响未来的成功，因此他们从小就训练孩子培养对“找借口症”的免疫力。事实上，世界上几乎没有人从未接触过“找借口症”，因为大多数人在很小的时候就已经“感染”了它。它通过各种渠道传播——电视、广播、互联网以及整个社会都充斥着它。好消息是，“找借口症”在任何阶段都是可以治愈的，而且治愈它会对你的生活产生深远的积极影响。当你意识到这种“疾病”只有在宿主允许的情况下才能生存时，你就走上了一条通往更充实人生的道路。

Before we go any further, I want you to think about something. Imagine for a moment that when a child begins to be able to walk he just decides that it is too hard because “I am too small,” “It’s not safe for me to walk,” “I could bang my head,” “I banged my knee, so I’m just going to crawl,” “I can still get to where I need to go; it may take me a bit more time, but I will get there and most likely won’t get hurt.” Imagine what society would be like if that happened. It would be a mess! But, I also want you to understand that everyone , and this also includes children who are born with physical challenges, everyone is not born with excusetosis. In fact, our DNA does not have anywhere in it a gene that gives up. There is not an excuse gene. Excusetosis is a disease that is contracted from other human beings that can be transmitted many different ways. You were not supposed to make excuses, but somewhere along the way, you decided that it was okay to make them. Well, I’m sure you can tell by now, it is not okay to make excuses for setbacks in your life— ever !

在我们继续之前，我想请你们思考一下。想象一下，当一个孩子开始学走路时，他却因为“我太小了”、“走路不安全”、“我会撞到头”、“我撞到膝盖了，所以我还是爬吧”、“我还是能到目的地；可能要花更多时间，但我肯定能到，而且很可能不会受伤”而放弃。想象一下，如果这种情况真的发生，社会会变成什么样？那将会是一团糟！但是，我也想让你们明白，并非每个人，包括那些天生有身体障碍的孩子，都天生患有“找借口症”。事实上，我们的DNA中没有任何放弃的基因。根本不存在“找借口”基因。“找借口症”是一种从其他人那里传染的疾病，可以通过多种途径传播。你原本不应该找借口，但不知从何时起，你却觉得找借口是可以接受的。我相信你现在已经明白，为生活中的挫折找借口是绝对不行的——永远都不行！

SCHOOL LUNCH: ARE YOU BEING SERVED WHAT YOU WANT?

学校午餐：你吃到的是你想要的吗？

Ever since I can remember, my school meals were subsidized: at elementary school, middle school, and even high school. I remember being segregated from the other kids into a different line to get my food. It was humiliating. That feeling of being the poor kid or the kid whose parents couldn’t provide was devastating for my psyche. I remember looking at the free-lunch kids and feeling like I didn’t belong there. Even then I realized I wanted more out of life.

从我记事起，我的学校午餐就一直有政府补贴：小学、初中，甚至高中都是如此。我记得当时要和其他孩子分开，排在不同的队伍里领饭。那感觉很屈辱。那种觉得自己是穷孩子，或者父母养不起孩子的感觉，对我的心理打击很大。我记得看着那些吃免费午餐的孩子们，觉得自己格格不入。即使在那时，我也意识到自己想要拥有更美好的生活。

Before I continue, let me say there is nothing wrong with being in the free lunch line, and we are not lesser human beings because of it. But, I felt that way. There were many days where I would save money just so I could go in the “normal” line. I remember vividly going to the cashier and having to have her look up my name and check to make sure I was on the free lunch list—which simply added an exclamation point to the announcement to the world that I was a poor kid.

在继续之前，我想先说明，排队领免费午餐并没有什么错，我们也不会因此就低人一等。但是，我曾经就是这么想的。很多时候，我省吃俭用，就是为了能去“正常”队伍排队。我清楚地记得，每次去收银台，都要让收银员查我的名字，确认我是否在免费午餐名单上——这简直就像是在向全世界宣告我是个穷孩子。

Many of the kids in that line felt the same way I did, but they also believed that they were lesser human beings and there was nothing that they could do about it. It is a horrible thing to realize, but most of them were fatally infected with excusetosis, and being separated from the other kids just allowed the disease to metastasize.

队伍里很多孩子都和我一样有这种感觉，但他们也觉得自己低人一等，而且对此无能为力。意识到这一点很残酷，但他们中的大多数都患上了严重的“找借口症”，而与其他孩子隔离只会让这种“疾病”迅速扩散。

So when I am asked when that point in my life occurred when I truly stopped making excuses, I can point to bunting in baseball as the moment when I started to understand. But as for the point when I was consciously and deliberately curing myself of excusetosis, it really was in that school lunch line when the desire to be seen as more than just the poor kid was engrained into my brain. At that very young age I knew I wanted more. I remember telling my Aunt Lucia that I was going to be a millionaire by the time I was twenty-one. I didn’t really know what that meant or how I would get there, but I knew I just didn’t want to be poor anymore. I never really have had a desire to obtain material things that display success, but I just decided that I was going to get more out of life: more than what society thought I was worth, more than what my friends thought I was worth, and more than what my family believed I should be worth.

所以，当有人问我，我人生中真正停止找借口的转折点是什么时候，我会说，棒球中的触击短打让我开始明白这一点。但要说我何时有意识地、刻意地克服了“找借口”的毛病，那其实是在学校午餐排队的时候，那时，想要摆脱“穷孩子”的刻板印象深深地烙印在我的脑海里。很小的时候，我就知道自己想要更多。我记得我跟露西亚阿姨说，我21岁的时候一定要成为百万富翁。我当时并不真正明白那意味着什么，也不知道该如何实现，但我知道我不想再贫穷了。我从来没有真正渴望过用物质来证明成功，我只是决定要拥有更精彩的人生：超越社会对我的评价，超越朋友对我的评价，超越家人对我的期望。

So for me, the cure for excusetosis was the desire to escape the stigma and reality of poverty and realizing that excuses would only hold me back. I didn’t become a millionaire until about thirty-four, but I will never be that poor kid again. And it started at that point as a child when I said, “I am not going to make any excuses for being poor; I am simply not going to be poor!”

对我来说，克服“找借口”的良方是摆脱贫穷的耻辱和现实，并意识到借口只会阻碍我前进。我直到34岁左右才成为百万富翁，但我再也不会是那个穷孩子了。这一切都始于我小时候对自己说的那句话：“我不会再为贫穷找任何借口；我绝不会再贫穷！”

NO ARMS, NO LEGS

没有胳膊，没有腿

A while back I was watching ESPN and I saw a remarkable story that affirms my belief that we are not born with excusetosis. The story was about a man named Craig Dietz who was born in the rural town of St. Mary, Pennsylvania—without any arms or legs. Despite being born without limbs, Craig was a very active child, engaging in everything from bowling to hunting, and he was also an excellent student.

前段时间我在看ESPN，看到一个令人动容的故事，更加坚定了我一直以来的信念：我们并非天生就有借口。故事的主人公名叫克雷格·迪茨，他出生在宾夕法尼亚州圣玛丽镇，天生没有四肢。尽管如此，克雷格从小就非常活跃，从保龄球到狩猎，他什么都玩，而且学习成绩也非常好。

In addition to all of Craig’s other sports-related activities, he had a passion for swimming, which seems impossible to most. After all, he has no arms and no legs! Craig actively competes in swim meets and even triathlons. Craig is also a lawyer and passed the bar exam the first time (good for him; it took me two tries!) without any accommodations from the Board of Bar Overseers. There are many other people just like Craig who prove my theory. You are not born with excusetosis, and you are not supposed to give up.

除了克雷格的其他体育活动之外，他还热爱游泳，这在大多数人看来简直不可思议。毕竟，他没有双臂也没有双腿！克雷格积极参加游泳比赛，甚至还参加铁人三项。克雷格也是一名律师，并且一次性通过了律师资格考试（真棒！我可是考了两次才通过！），没有得到律师资格考试委员会的任何特殊照顾。像克雷格这样的人还有很多，他们证明了我的理论：你生来就没有借口，你也不应该轻易放弃。

Now, when I discuss this disease with people, I get comments like, “What if they were born poor?” or “What if they were born disabled?” Some ask, “What if they suffered some sort of tragic event that prevented them from achieving their goals and dreams?” Tell that to Craig Dietz!

现在，当我跟别人谈论这种疾病时，他们会说：“如果他们生来贫穷呢？”或者“如果他们生来残疾呢？”有些人还会问：“如果他们遭遇某种悲剧，导致他们无法实现目标和梦想呢？” 去跟克雷格·迪茨说说这些吧！

These statements are, in and of themselves, excuses. We can’t determine when and where we are born, nor can we control freak accidents, but we can control our minds. Setbacks, temporary defeats, or physical limitations are not things that should call for an excuse. When toddlers fall down, they don’t throw in the towel. They use that fall as a learning experience to achieve the goal of walking. Some children take longer than others, but all able-bodied children walk at some point.

这些说法本身就是借口。我们无法决定自己的出生时间和地点，也无法控制意外事故，但我们可以控制自己的思想。挫折、暂时的失败或身体上的局限都不应该成为借口。幼儿摔倒后，不会就此放弃。他们会把摔倒当作学习的机会，最终学会走路。有些孩子学走路的时间长一些，但所有身体健全的孩子最终都会学会走路。

OVERACTIVE KID TO OLYMPIAN

从过度活跃的孩子到奥运冠军

There is a story about a now-twenty-something guy who was a troublemaker, was very rambunctious, had concentration challenges, and was just a handful. Well, his mother got him involved in a team and also individual sports. He practiced every day to the point of exhaustion. He was very lucky to have amazing coaches who anticipated things such as the lights potentially going off during his competitions, and he even trained for that. That person is the most decorated Olympian in the United States, Michael Phelps.

有一个故事讲的是一个现在二十多岁的年轻人，他以前是个惹是生非、非常活泼好动、注意力难以集中、难以管教的孩子。后来，他的母亲让他参加了团体和个人运动项目。他每天都训练到筋疲力尽。他很幸运地遇到了非常棒的教练，这些教练甚至能预料到比赛中可能会出现的灯光故障，他也为此进行了专门的训练。这个人就是美国历史上获得奥运奖牌最多的运动员——迈克尔·菲尔普斯。

His commitment to swimming, his discipline, and his ability to overcome adversity have made him one of the best athletes in the world, in any sport. One of the most remarkable stories about Michael Phelps was in the gold medal match in Beijing in 2008. The second he hit the water his goggles filled with water, and he swam the entire race unable to see! He not only won the gold but set the world record! Michael and his coaches prepared for what could go wrong by asking, “What if this happens? What will I do?” Michael chose to push through, not using any excuses, and relied on what he was taught. It is an amazing story. And it can be your story, too!

他对游泳的执着、自律以及克服逆境的能力，使他成为世界上最优秀的运动员之一，无论在任何运动项目中。关于迈克尔·菲尔普斯最令人难忘的故事之一，发生在2008年北京奥运会的决赛中。他刚入水，泳镜就灌满了水，他只能在视线模糊的情况下游完全程！他不仅赢得了金牌，还打破了世界纪录！为了应对可能发生的意外，菲尔普斯和他的教练们做了充分的准备，他们反复问自己：“如果这种情况发生怎么办？我该怎么办？”菲尔普斯选择坚持到底，不找任何借口，而是依靠自己所学到的技能。这是一个令人惊叹的故事。而它，也可以成为你的故事！

TO SLEEP OR NOT TO SLEEP

睡还是不睡

My senior year in high school, I was coasting through. I didn’t have a solid plan as far as college, but I was pretty sure I was going to further my education. What I didn’t realize at the time was that my senior year was extremely important with respect to my overall grade point average. I had gone from failing classes my freshman year to getting on the dean’s list my senior year. But like many high school kids, especially seniors, I grew a little lazy and thought I could just coast through the rest of the year. Early on in the year I was tardy a lot, just missing classes due to pure laziness. I was oversleeping too much.

高三那年，我过得浑浑噩噩。我对大学并没有明确的计划，但我很确定自己会继续深造。当时我并没有意识到，高三这一年对我的总平均绩点至关重要。我从高一挂科到高三荣登院长嘉奖名单，可谓是天壤之别。但和很多高中生一样，尤其是高三学生，我变得有些懒散，觉得可以混日子混到毕业。开学初期，我经常迟到，纯粹是因为懒惰而缺课。我睡得太多了。

One fateful day when I was home in bed I got a phone call from my English teacher, and she told me that if I didn’t show up, she would fail me and she would kick me out of her class! The nerve! About fifteen minutes later the head coach of the football team told me if I didn’t show up he would kick me off the team. Let me put this in perspective: I was class president and captain of the football team. I felt that I was untouchable. “You can’t fail me and kick me off the team,” I thought. “Or can you?”

那天，我躺在家里的床上，突然接到英语老师的电话。她威胁我说，如果我不去上课，她就要让我不及格，还要把我赶出她的班级！真是岂有此理！大约十五分钟后，足球队主教练又告诉我，如果我不去上课，他就要把我踢出球队。要知道，我可是班长兼足球队队长，我觉得自己是不可撼动的。“你不能让我不及格，也不能把我踢出球队，”我心想。“难道真的可以吗？”

Well, one thing that I always respected was authority. I got my lazy ass out of bed and made it to English class and football practice. The incident could have changed my life for the worse if I came down with a case of excusetosis! Imagine what my life would look like now if I was kicked off the team and flunked English my senior year. The problem is, far too many people don’t recognize moments in their life that are like the proverbial fork in the road. Pick one way and your life looks like this, pick the other and it looks like that. When I received two phone calls at 8:00 in the morning I was fortunately able to ask myself, “What would my life look like if I was kicked off the team and flunked English?” Doesn’t take Nostradamus to answer that question. My coach and my English teacher helped to change my life that day, for the better. Thank you, Mr. Rosinski and Mrs. Nicholson! But, I also changed my own life by asking myself what would most likely happen if I did not show up. I respected not only authority but myself. I asked for more from myself!

我一直都很尊重权威。那天我懒懒地起床，去上了英语课，参加了足球训练。如果我当时犯了“找借口”的毛病，我的人生可能会变得更糟！想想看，如果我被踢出球队，高三英语挂科，我现在的生活会是什么样子。问题是，太多人意识不到人生中那些如同岔路口般的时刻。选一条路，你的生活会是这样；选另一条路，你的生活会是那样。那天早上八点，我接到了两个电话，幸运的是，我能够问自己：“如果我被踢出球队，英语挂科，我的生活会是什么样子？” 这个问题不需要预言家也能回答。我的教练和英语老师那天帮助我改变了人生，让我的人生变得更好。谢谢罗辛斯基先生和尼科尔森女士！但是，我也通过问自己，如果我不去，最可能发生什么，改变了自己的人生。我不仅尊重权威，也尊重自己。我对自己提出了更高的要求！

SO WHAT’S YOUR EXCUSE?

所以你的借口是什么？

As I have already shared, when I was a kid my surroundings were filled with despair, violence, drug abuse, and poverty. I could have used any of these as my excuse not to ask for more. But thankfully, when I was a kid and I asked my mother why life was always so hard, she responded with motherly love, “Things will get easier. Keep working. You will get through it.” She never said, “It’s hard because we are poor and have no money.” When I was upset with a grade I received, she never said that I just wasn’t smart enough. She said, “Keep trying and put your mind to it. You can do it.”

正如我之前所说，我小时候的生活环境充斥着绝望、暴力、毒品和贫困。我本可以以此为借口，不再奢求更多。但幸运的是，当我小时候问妈妈为什么生活总是这么艰难时，她总是用慈母般的爱回答我：“情况会好起来的。坚持下去，你会挺过去的。”她从未说过：“因为我们穷，所以生活才这么艰难。”当我因为考试成绩不开心时，她也从未说我不够聪明。她总是说：“继续努力，下定决心，你一定能做到。”

When I graduated college in 1997, people told me I would not make more than $20,000 a year and not to expect more than that. This was despite the fact that I had decent grades, had interned for a congressman, and was class president for three years. Twenty thousand dollars? Really? I must admit that statement infected me for a while, and that’s all I thought I was worth. But I quickly reprogrammed my mind and made double that my first year in the workforce!

1997年大学毕业时，人们告诉我年收入不会超过2万美元，不要抱太大期望。尽管我成绩不错，曾在国会议员办公室实习，还当了三年班长。2万美元？真的吗？我必须承认，这句话一度影响了我，让我觉得自己只值这么多钱。但我很快就改变了想法，工作第一年就赚到了这个数额的两倍！

Have you made an excuse for not getting something that you always wanted? Sure, we all have. But in order to actually achieve your goal, you need to cure the disease. There isn’t a magic pill. No one else can do it but you. Opportunities are not going to slap you in the face. You will not wake up one day with everything you ever wanted—until you cure the disease of excusetosis.

你是否曾为没能得到梦寐以求的东西而找借口？当然，我们都曾有过。但要想真正实现目标，你需要治好这个“病”。没有灵丹妙药，除了你自己，没人能帮你做到。机会不会自己送上门来。除非你治好“找借口症”，否则你不会一夜之间拥有所有想要的东西。

So what now? What do you do to cure the disease? The good news is treatment can start today. Excusetosis is curable! You don’t need insurance, you don’t need a prescription, and you don’t need money. You only need yourself and the willingness to cure yourself of this disease. Some symptoms are worse than others, but regardless of how severe a case of excusetosis you have, it can be cured.

那么现在该怎么办？如何才能治愈这种疾病？好消息是，治疗可以从今天开始。借口症是可以治愈的！你不需要保险，不需要处方，也不需要钱。你只需要你自己和治愈这种疾病的意愿。有些症状比其他症状更严重，但无论你的借口症病情有多严重，它都是可以治愈的。

STEP 1

步骤 1

The first thing you need to do is take total and full responsibility for where you are in life and be accountable for your past actions and all of your future decisions.

你首先要做的是对你现在的生活状态承担全部责任，并对过去的行动和未来的所有决定负责。

It is not your parents, your coworkers, your spouse, your boss, or anyone else’s fault that you have this disease. We can’t change what has happened to you, and you have to accept that fact. Looking back at what happened, how it happened, or why it happened will not cure the disease. You have to just accept that you are infected.

你患上这种疾病，不是你的父母、同事、配偶、老板，也不是任何人的错。我们无法改变已经发生在你身上的事，你必须接受这个事实。回顾过去、探究事情的来龙去脉，或者探究疾病发生的原因，都无法治愈这种疾病。你只能接受自己已被感染的事实。

STEP 2

步骤 2

You need to accept that like many other diseases, excusetosis may come back. But if you are aware of the symptoms you can destroy it the same way chemotherapy kills cancer cells. The symptoms are not complex: any time you decide to blame something, someone, or some circumstance as to why a goal is not achieved, you will know the disease is back. At that point, step back, take a deep breath, and reprogram your mind. When you get into the habit of doing this day in and day out, at some point your habit will no longer be a habit but a natural subconscious action that will magically work for you. You control your thoughts, they do not control you.

你必须接受这样一个事实：像许多其他疾病一样，找借口的习惯可能会复发。但如果你了解它的症状，就能像化疗杀死癌细胞一样彻底摆脱它。症状并不复杂：每当你试图把目标未能达成的原因归咎于某件事、某个人或某种情况时，你就知道这种习惯又回来了。这时，退后一步，深呼吸，重新调整你的思维模式。当你养成日复一日这样做的习惯后，你的习惯终将不再是习惯，而是一种自然而然的潜意识行为，它会神奇地为你带来益处。你掌控你的思想，而不是被思想掌控。

HABIT: something you do every day so that it is involuntary and positive.

习惯：每天都会做的事情，以至于成为一种无意识的、积极的现象。

The best way to reprogram yourself—besides reading my book—is to remind yourself of all those people out there who could have made excuses but didn’t, and how they changed the world. Then look at some of those people who aren’t living up to their potential because they are making excuses.

除了读我的书之外，重塑自我的最佳方法就是想想那些本可以找借口却没有的人，以及他们如何改变了世界。然后再看看那些因为找借口而未能发挥自身潜力的人。

MY DAD’S POTENTIAL EXCUSE

我爸可能的借口

My dad is a perfect example. He is sixty-one years old (soon to be sixty-two). He is a hard worker and always has been, and he instilled the value of hard work in me when I was a kid. He used to take me out on weekends, but many times he had to work. At that time he was a “tree guy”—in other words, he cut down and removed trees. He took me with him and put me to work. I loved it. I hung out with my dad, learned what he did, and got paid! Most recently he was working as a machinist, and he was concerned about his current job because of his age. He was worried that if he was laid off or lost his job, it would be very difficult to get another job because he is “too old.” Later on in the book I tell the story about how I taught my dad some simple techniques that not only cured his excusetosis, but also increased his personal net worth.

我爸爸就是个很好的例子。他今年六十一岁（马上就六十二岁了）。他一直都很勤奋，从小就给我灌输了努力工作的价值。他以前周末会带我出去玩，但很多时候他都得工作。那时候他是个“伐木工”——换句话说，就是砍树、移树。他会带我一起去，让我干活。我特别喜欢。我可以和爸爸待在一起，学习他的工作内容，还能挣钱！最近他做机械师，但他很担心自己的工作，因为他年纪大了。他害怕如果被裁员或者丢了工作，会很难再找到另一份工作，因为他“太老了”。在书的后面部分，我会讲我是如何教爸爸一些简单的技巧，这些技巧不仅治好了他的“找借口”毛病，还增加了他的个人财富。

HENRY FORD’S POTENTIAL EXCUSE

亨利·福特的潜在借口

Henry Ford didn’t start Ford Motor Company until he was forty-five, well after his peak earning potential. Would Ford Motor Company have ever been created if Henry Ford thought he was “too old”? Henry Ford may have been halfway through his life when he started Ford Motor Company, but his life experience and temporary defeats prepared him for founding one of the most successful companies in existence today. Henry Ford didn’t think he was too old to start a gigantic, multinational company. He knew his age was an asset.

亨利·福特直到45岁才创办福特汽车公司，那时他早已过了收入巅峰期。如果亨利·福特认为自己“太老了”，福特汽车公司还会存在吗？亨利·福特创办福特汽车公司时或许已步入人生中期，但他的人生经历和曾经的挫折，都为他日后创立如今最成功的公司之一奠定了基础。亨利·福特并不认为自己年纪太大而无法创办一家庞大的跨国公司。他深知自己的年龄是一种优势。

THEO EPSTEIN’S POTENTIAL EXCUSE

西奥·爱泼斯坦的潜在借口

One of the classic excuses in life, and the inverse of “I’m too old,” is “I’m too young.” Ageitis, a form of excusetosis, is also curable. Theo Epstein was twenty-eight when he became the general manager of one of baseball’s most iconic teams, the Boston Red Sox. Theo was certainly too young to be the general manager of a baseball team in one of the most unforgiving markets in the country, a team that has a current value of close to $700 million—right? Many people thought that, but in 2004, under Theo Epstein, the Red Sox won their first World Series in eighty-six years, and then did it again in 2007. Imagine what the team would be like if Theo thought he was “too young.” Rather than thinking Theo was too young and inexperienced, the ownership saw a smart kid who had drive, who worked while he was in law school, who studied baseball, and who dreamed about working for the Boston Red Sox. Theo’s age was never an issue for him or the ownership of the Red Sox. I have managers working for me who are in their twenties, and they manage teams of people who are of all ages—most of them much older than my managers. They are my managers because they are good at what they do—period!

人生中最常见的借口之一，也是“我太老了”的反义词，就是“我太年轻了”。这种“年龄焦虑症”（ageitis）——一种找借口的习惯——也是可以治愈的。西奥·爱泼斯坦28岁时就成为了棒球史上最具标志性的球队之一——波士顿红袜队的总经理。西奥当时的确太年轻了，不适合执掌一支身处全美竞争最残酷的市场之一、且目前价值接近7亿美元的球队——对吧？很多人都这么认为，但在2004年，在西奥·爱泼斯坦的带领下，红袜队赢得了86年来的首个世界大赛冠军，并在2007年再次夺冠。试想一下，如果西奥觉得自己“太年轻”，球队会是什么样子？然而，球队老板们并没有认为西奥太年轻、缺乏经验，而是看到了一个聪明上进的年轻人，他在法学院读书期间就坚持工作，认真研究棒球，并且梦想着为波士顿红袜队效力。西奥的年龄对他本人或红袜队的老板来说从来都不是问题。我手下也有二十多岁的经理，他们管理的团队成员年龄跨度很大——其中大多数人的年纪都比我的经理大得多。他们之所以能成为我的经理，是因为他们工作能力强——仅此而已！

MICHAEL ALDEN’S POTENTIAL EXCUSE (JUST ONE OF MANY I HAD TO CHOOSE FROM)

迈克尔·奥尔登的潜在借口（这只是我众多选择之一）

I’m not smart enough! I could have easily chosen to believe that. But it is not the amount of education or the prestige of your educational source; rather it is what you get out of it.

我不够聪明！我本来可以轻易地相信这一点。但重要的不是你受过多少教育，也不是你的教育机构多么声名显赫，而是你从中获得了什么。

You know how many times I heard that I wasn’t smart enough? When I was a senior in high school, my guidance counselor tried to inject me with a lethal dose of excusetosis by telling me, “College isn’t for everyone.” I will never forget that day. This guy was my guidance counselor, a person who was supposed to help me succeed! Several years later I was in the ICU unit at the hospital where my grandmother was dying, and amazingly it just so happened that my guidance counselor was in the room adjacent to my grandmother’s, visiting a sick relative of his own. I said hello to him and just thanked him. I could have said something nasty to my guidance counselor, and I admit, I wanted to; but as you will learn, negative behavior would have been counterproductive and would not accomplish anything, not to mention that we were both saying goodbye to loved ones. Instead, I thanked my guidance counselor, because his lack in belief in me essentially drove me to prove him wrong. I’m sure that every day we all face doubts from others about our abilities. Ask yourself, “What will I do to prove them wrong?”

你知道我听过多少次别人说我不够聪明吗？高中毕业那年，我的升学指导老师试图用一句“大学不是人人都能上的”来打击我的自信心。我永远不会忘记那天。这个人可是我的升学指导老师啊，他本该帮助我走向成功！几年后，我奶奶病危，我在医院的重症监护室里，巧合的是，我的升学指导老师当时就在隔壁病房，探望他自己生病的亲戚。我跟他打了个招呼，并向他道了谢。我本可以对我的升学指导老师说些难听的话，我承认，我当时确实想这么做；但正如你将看到的，消极的行为只会适得其反，于事无补，更何况我们当时都在和亲人告别。所以我没有，而是感谢了我的升学指导老师，因为他对我的不信任，反而激励我证明他是错的。我相信，我们每天都会面临来自他人对我们能力的质疑。问问自己：“我该怎么做才能证明他们错了？”

Intelligence has nothing to do with success. What is intelligence, anyway? Well, this book isn’t the book to expound on what is smart or whether or not you are intelligent. If you have this book in your hands, you can answer both questions in the affirmative. You are smart and intelligent. Why? Because you decided to change your future. You are smart and intelligent at everything you do. Believe it! Repeat this phrase and write it down in the margin of this book or somewhere that will ensure you will see it every day, then do it every day until you have programmed your subconscious mind to believe it. Throughout my book I reference several other books. Get copies of these books; they are like vitamins for your brain that help suppress the disease of excusetosis.

智力与成功无关。那么，智力究竟是什么呢？这本书并非旨在阐述什么是聪明，或者你是否聪明。如果你手捧此书，你就可以肯定地回答这两个问题：你很聪明，很有智慧。为什么？因为你决定改变自己的未来。无论做什么，你都很聪明，很有智慧。相信这一点！反复默念这句话，并把它写在书页的空白处或其他你每天都能看到的地方，然后每天坚持，直到你的潜意识里相信它为止。在书中，我引用了其他几本书。去买几本吧；它们就像大脑的维生素，能帮助你克服“找借口症”。

NOT MY FAULT: MY BROTHER’S EXCUSE

这不是我的错：这是我哥哥的借口

I was at my brother’s wedding a few months back, and I was sitting next to one of my other brothers. I love all of my family members, so this is a tough thing to write about. He spent most of his life in and out of prison, is addicted to drugs, and has overdosed several times. One time when he overdosed he actually died and had to be revived. But, like people say, the truth hurts. I asked my brother how he was, and of course he said he was doing well, but anyone could clearly tell that he wasn’t okay. I asked him about his goals and more specifically where he was on his apprenticeship as an electrician. He told me, “Dad screwed it up.”

几个月前，我参加了哥哥的婚礼，坐在我另一个兄弟旁边。我爱我的所有家人，所以这件事很难写。他一生大部分时间都在监狱里进进出出，染上了毒瘾，而且多次吸毒过量。有一次他吸毒过量甚至死了，幸亏抢救才活了下来。但是，就像人们常说的，真相总是残酷的。我问哥哥近况如何，他当然说自己很好，但谁都能看出他其实并不好。我问他未来的目标，特别是他作为电工学徒的进度。他告诉我：“我爸毁了我的一切。”

So I inquired, “What happened? How did Dad screw up your career goals?”

于是我问道：“发生了什么事？爸爸是怎么毁了你的职业目标的？”

He proceeded to tell me that while he was in prison, Dad didn’t pay the renewal fee for his license. He was adamant! My brother was in prison … and Dad screwed it up? I looked my brother in the eye and said, “You screwed it up,” and he retorted, “How did I screw it up? I was locked up .” I smiled and said, “Exactly! You were locked up , and that’s why you screwed it up.”

他接着告诉我，他爸在监狱里的时候没交驾照续费。他一口咬定！我哥在监狱里……居然是爸搞砸了？我看着我哥的眼睛说：“是你搞砸的。”他反驳道：“我怎么搞砸了？我被关起来了。”我笑着说：“没错！你被关起来了，所以你才搞砸了。”

Now, I’m pretty sure I didn’t get through to him, and I am saddened to tell you that he went on to overdose again—a fourth time—and this time he passed away. But as terrible as that is, it is never anyone else’s fault. Once you realize that and accept it, you will find that your path to success and happiness will be smooth.

现在，我很确定我没能说服他，很遗憾地告诉你，他后来又一次服药过量——第四次——这一次他去世了。但无论这多么令人痛心，这永远都不是别人的错。一旦你明白并接受这一点，你就会发现通往成功和幸福的道路将会一帆风顺。

NOT OUR FAULT!

不是我们的错！

Sometimes I wonder when bad things happen at my company, when there are technical errors, or when things just don’t go right, if maybe it really isn’t our fault. There have been times when it seems like there was a common force continually working against us. Is it really not our fault? For example, when our phone system shuts down, or when an advertisement doesn’t air when it is supposed to, or when we lose electricity in our building, or when packages get lost in the mail—the obvious fault of third parties, right? These are things that are outside of our control … right? Wrong!

有时我会想，当公司发生糟糕的事情，出现技术故障，或者其他不顺利的事情时，是不是真的不是我们的错。有时候，感觉好像有一股力量一直在和我们作对。难道真的不是我们的错吗？比如，电话系统瘫痪，广告没按时播出，大楼停电，包裹在邮寄过程中丢失——这些显然是第三方的责任，对吧？这些事情我们根本无法控制……对吗？错！

ACCOUNTABILITY: our ability to acknowledge our own acts and take responsibility for those acts.

问责制：我们承认自身行为并承担相应责任的能力。

We can’t control everything, but we can prepare for things to go wrong and have systems in place so that when others interfere with our success, it won’t matter. I tell my executives, it is never the phone company’s fault, the electric company’s fault, the postal service’s fault. It is our fault: everyone at my company is accountable , and it is never a third party’s fault. Be accountable, and you will be successful in anything that you do.

我们无法掌控一切，但我们可以未雨绸缪，建立完善的系统，这样即使有人干扰我们的成功，也不会造成太大影响。我常跟我的高管们说，这绝不是电话公司、电力公司或邮政服务的错，而是我们自己的错：公司里的每个人都负有责任，也绝不是第三方的责任。勇于承担责任，你就能在任何领域取得成功。

THE TIME ISN’T RIGHT

现在时机还不成熟。

Well, when is the time ever right? The light is never going to be green. The stars will never be perfectly aligned. Why is it that people always wait till the first of the year to make their resolution? That is an excuse. I know a guy who is a smoker and has been for fifteen years. One day in January he posted on one of the major social networking sites that he was quitting smoking in August because that was the month his daughter was born, and she deserved better. I guess she didn’t deserve better for the seven months in between. He continues to this day to post that he is changing his habits but never does. I recently reached out to him and told him that he needs to do it . Stop telling people you are going to change; just do it ! Why wait? Every day you smoke it decreases the amount of time you will be on this planet and the time you will spend with your daughter.

什么时候才是合适的时机呢？时机永远不会成熟，一切也永远不会完美契合。为什么人们总是要等到新年伊始才下决心呢？那只是个借口。我认识一个抽烟十五年的人。一月份的某一天，他在一个主流社交网站上发帖说，他八月份要戒烟，因为女儿八月份出生，她值得更好的。我猜，在女儿出生后的七个月里，她并不值得更好的。直到今天，他还在社交媒体上发帖说要改变习惯，但从未真正行动。最近我联系了他，告诉他必须行动起来。别再光说不练了，赶紧行动吧！为什么要等？你每抽一天烟，你的寿命就会缩短，陪伴女儿的时间也会减少。

Why is it that all diets start on Monday? Why wait? You know what happens the weekend before? People gorge themselves and then attempt to diet.

为什么所有的节食计划都从周一开始？为什么要等？你知道前一个周末会发生什么吗？人们会暴饮暴食，然后再尝试节食。

If you want to do something, don’t wait for the timing to be right. I recently bought some silver, and a friend of mine told me how it is going to drop in price and that I should wait. Well, he may be right, and it may be a mistake, and if so I will learn from it, but how would I feel if the current price of silver skyrockets to $180 an ounce? The time was right for me. I could make excuses for the next ten years to justify why not to buy, and I could convince myself not to buy if I listened to others.

如果你想做某件事，不要等待所谓的“最佳时机”。我最近买了一些白银，一个朋友告诉我白银价格会下跌，让我等等。好吧，他说的也许没错，也许我错了，如果真是这样，我会从中吸取教训。但如果白银价格飙升到每盎司180美元，我会作何感想？对我来说，时机已经成熟了。如果我听从别人的建议，未来十年我都可以找到各种理由不买，也可以说服自己不要买。

STEP 3

步骤 3

The third thing you need to do every time you find yourself making an excuse is instantly find a reason why it can be done. That way, it will get done. You may find that along the way you will be faced with dozens, if not hundreds, of excuses for why you can’t. All you have to do is tell yourself it can and will be done. Does this seem too simple? Some may think so, but you have this book in your hands, and you spent your hard-earned money to purchase it. Don’t spread the disease by making excuses as to why you can’t do something.

第三，当你每次找借口的时候，你需要做的就是立刻找到一个能做到的理由。这样，事情就能完成。你可能会发现，在这个过程中，你会遇到几十个，甚至上百个你做不到的借口。你只需要告诉自己，这件事能做到，而且一定会做到。这听起来太简单了吗？有些人可能这么认为，但你手里拿着这本书，而且你还花了辛苦赚来的钱买下了它。不要再找借口，让这种消极心态蔓延开来。

YOU CAN AND YOU WILL!

你可以，而且你一定会！

Here are just a few of the common excuses that begin to infect us, along with some provided phrases to immunize you against this disease. Every time you hear yourself saying one of the tired phrases on the left, change it to the inspired phrase on the right.

这里列举了一些常见的借口，它们会逐渐侵蚀我们的生活，同时还提供了一些短语，帮助你抵御这些“疾病”。每当你听到自己说出左边这些老掉牙的借口时，就把它换成右边这些充满灵感的短语。

You have your own symptoms that you need to diagnose and cure. Curing yourself starts today . It may take a little time, but once you are cured, this book and everything else in your life will become more fulfilling than you ever imagined.

你自身存在一些症状，需要你自己去诊断和治疗。自我疗愈从今天开始。这或许需要一些时间，但一旦你痊愈，这本书以及你生活中的一切都会变得比你想象的更加充实。

I can’t make it work
我做不到。 		I WILL MAKE IT WORK
我会让它成功
It is too difficult
太难了 		IT’S CHALLENGING, BUT I WILL GET IT
虽然很有挑战性，但我一定能做到。
I’m not good enough
我不够好。 		I WILL GET BETTER
我会好起来的
I’m too out of shape
我体能太差了。 		I’M GOING TO GET HEALTHY
我要变得健康。
I can’t do that
我做不到。 		I WILL DO THAT
我会这么做。
I will do it later
我稍后会做。 		I WILL DO IT NOW
我现在就做。
I can’t finish in time
我无法按时完成 		I WILL FIND THE TIME
我会抽出时间
It’s risky
这很冒险 		I WILL FIND A WAY TO MAKE IT WORK
我会找到办法让它奏效。
I don’t deserve it
我不配拥有它 		I DO DESERVE IT
我确实值得拥有它
I can’t afford it
我买不起 		I WILL FIND THE MONEY
TO GET WHAT I WANT
我会找到钱去得到我想要的东西
It’s not my fault
这不是我的错。 		I ACCEPT RESPONSIBILITY,
AND I WILL RECTIFY IT
我接受责任，
我将改正它
It’s never happened before
以前从未发生过这种情况。 		IT WILL HAPPEN
这一定会发生
I can’t
我不能 		I CAN
我可以
Not possible
不可能 		IT IS POSSIBLE
这是有可能的
I’m tired
我累了 		I’M ALIVE, AWAKE, AND READY
FOR THE DAY/TASK AT HAND
我活着，清醒着，并且准备好迎接新的一天/手头的任务。

THE MERCHANT PROCESSOR: THE ULTIMATE EXCUSE I DIDN’T MAKE

商户处理商：我没有找的终极借口

Imagine this: After about one year of bootstrapping my business, millions of dollars in debt and one foot over the brink of failure, I made the decision to expand our offices and the business. Most of my executives were nervous and not sure about the decision. I knew that it was what we needed in order to survive. So, I borrowed more money and had our offices custom built to suit our needs.

试想一下：在白手起家创业一年后，我背负了数百万美元的债务，濒临破产边缘。这时，我决定扩大办公场所和业务规模。我的大多数高管都感到紧张和犹豫。但我知道，这是我们生存下去的必要之举。于是，我又借了钱，定制建造了符合我们需求的办公楼。

Now imagine this: About a week after moving into our new offices I received a FedEx from my merchant processor (the company that allows me to process credit cards) that said they had seized almost $300,000 and that they were terminating my ability to process credit cards. At the time, processing credit cards was my business’s primary and only way to receive funds and sell things. We had almost two hundred employees, growing debt, and no way to process credit cards. And they had seized almost $300,000! Oh, and did I mention … it was a payroll week?

想象一下：搬进新办公室大约一周后，我收到一家支付处理公司（允许我处理信用卡付款的公司）寄来的联邦快递，说他们冻结了近30万美元，并终止了我的信用卡处理权限。当时，处理信用卡付款是我公司收款和销售的唯一主要方式。我们有近两百名员工，债务不断增加，却无法处理信用卡付款。他们竟然冻结了近30万美元！哦，对了……那周还是发工资的周！

The story is pretty involved, but ultimately it boils down to the fact that this company had it in for me and was trying to slice my throat and put me out of business. In fact, they actually told me that they were going to put me out of business. I was in complete shock! The good news was that I had a backup merchant processor, and I was able to move my business to them. The bad news is that the amount of business we moved made my new processor very nervous and they, too, were telling me they were going to shut me off!

事情经过相当复杂，但归根结底，这家公司就是想跟我过不去，想把我逼到破产。事实上，他们真的跟我说过要让我关门大吉。我当时完全懵了！好消息是我还有备用的支付处理商，所以我把业务转移过去了。坏消息是，我们转移的业务量太大，让新的支付处理商非常紧张，他们也威胁说要切断我的服务！

If those events had caused me to go out of business, it would have been very easy to blame my demise on others. But I would not allow myself to even entertain what would have been a totally understandable excuse. My family, my employees, and their families relied on my ability to keep our business afloat in order to put food on their tables. An excuse just was not an option. So I met with several other processors who were extremely reluctant to even speak with me due to the fact that I had been terminated and that I was involved in a lawsuit with my previous processor. But I persevered and refused to take no for an answer. Ultimately, I was able to secure a new processor to whom I am forever grateful. They knew we were good people running a good business. As I type, I have systems in place to make sure that what happened to us will never happen again. At our company we do not blame third parties for mistakes or adversity. Instead, we try to have the foresight to look into the future and anticipate what could happen or what could go wrong.

如果那些事件导致我破产，我很容易就能把责任推卸给别人。但我绝不会允许自己接受这种完全可以理解的借口。我的家人、我的员工以及他们的家人都依赖我维持公司运营，养家糊口。找借口根本不在我的考虑范围之内。所以我联系了几家新的支付处理商，但由于我之前被解雇，而且还和之前的支付处理商有诉讼纠纷，他们都非常不愿意和我谈。但我坚持不懈，不肯轻易放弃。最终，我找到了新的支付处理商，对此我永远心存感激。他们知道我们是好人，经营着一家好公司。此刻，我已经建立了完善的系统，确保我们遭遇的困境永远不会重演。在我们公司，我们不会把错误或逆境归咎于第三方。相反，我们会努力未雨绸缪，预见未来可能发生的情况或潜在的风险。

Some would say that is a negative way to think; they are wrong. Looking ahead and trying to anticipate what could go wrong is actually the responsible and rational thing to do. I am a hack chess player, but in chess you are always trying to think about your next move. The best chess players in the world know not only their next move, but they can anticipate what their opponent will do and they know what they will do in order to win. Ask yourself, what is your next move? What does the future look like? Can you do something now to anticipate a future event so that it will ensure your success? The answer is yes , you can and you should.

有些人会说这种想法太消极了；他们错了。展望未来，预判可能出错的地方，实际上才是负责任和理性的做法。我只是个水平一般的棋手，但在下棋的时候，你总是要思考下一步该怎么走。世界上最优秀的棋手不仅知道自己下一步该怎么走，还能预判对手的下一步行动，并且知道如何才能赢得比赛。问问自己，你的下一步该怎么走？未来会怎样？你现在能做些什么来预判未来可能发生的情况，从而确保成功吗？答案是肯定的，你可以，而且你应该这样做。

EDUCATE YOURSELF

自我教育

One other great way to cure excusetosis is through personal education. Throughout the book I mention several other books that have had a positive impact on my life, and I suggest you read them. Go to your local library and search the personal development section. Download a free ebook. This does not have to cost you a dime.

克服找借口症的另一个好方法是自我学习。我在书中提到了几本对我的生活产生积极影响的书籍，建议你也读一读。去当地图书馆，在个人发展类书籍区查找。下载一本免费电子书。这完全不需要花费你一分钱。

Zig Ziglar once told me that he reads three hours a day—every day. He also tells a great story in his book about his secretary—who has her master’s degree from what Ziglar calls “Automobile University”—utilizing time spent in traffic to educate herself. She has no formal education, but listening to CDs to and from work every day helped her achieve success. Take it from the expert: educate yourself to cure yourself and improve your life.

齐格·齐格勒曾告诉我，他每天都坚持阅读三个小时。他的书中还讲述了一个关于他秘书的精彩故事。这位秘书拥有齐格勒所谓的“汽车大学”的硕士学位，她利用通勤时间自学。她没有接受过正规教育，但每天上下班听CD帮助她取得了成功。听听专家的建议：学习可以治愈自己，改善生活。

#↩

CHAPTER 3

第三章

ASK YOURSELF TO SHAPE UP YOUR BODY

要求自己塑造体型

GROW YOUR BANK ACCOUNT, NOT YOUR GUT!

增长你的银行存款，而不是你的胆量！

Why do I dedicate an entire chapter in my book to the topics of health and wellness? Because your physical health affects your mental health. When your body isn’t healthy, your mind is almost always unhealthy as well. And you cannot ask for more from your life if you are not asking for more from your own body and your own mind. If you do ask more out of your body, it will definitely bring you more .

为什么我要在书中用整整一章的篇幅来探讨健康和养生呢？因为你的身体健康会影响你的心理健康。当你的身体不健康时，你的精神几乎也必然会受到影响。如果你不对自己的身体和精神提出更高的要求，你就无法对生活抱有更高的期望。如果你对自己的身体提出更高的要求，它一定会回馈给你更多。

Was I always in shape? Well, that is a complex question to answer. When I was a kid my mom used to buy my clothes at Ann & Hope in the Husky section. It was a nice way of saying “the fat kid section.” We also bought my clothes in the irregular section, because my body wasn’t “regular.” What the hell does “irregular” mean? I don’t know, but it wasn’t a positive thing.

我一直身材都很好吗？嗯，这个问题很难回答。小时候，我妈常去Ann & Hope的“Husky区”给我买衣服。说得委婉点，其实就是“胖小孩区”。我们也会去“不规则区”买衣服，因为我的身材“不规则”。“不规则”到底是什么意思？我也不知道，反正肯定不是什么好话。

Now, I don’t think I was really a “fat” kid, or “irregular.” But I was always big, and I do remember how it made me feel. I felt like a “fat irregular” kid. I may have developed a body image complex as a result, but the positive side of what really happened was that I became very interested in sports, health, and nutrition. I didn’t become fanatical about how I ate or about my body, but I became acutely aware of how nutrition and exercise affected my body. And that wasn’t always easy, because when you are a poor kid, nutrition is not as important as having a full belly. And I wasn’t always able to get healthy things to eat, because even back then, healthy food was expensive. But I digress.

现在，我不认为自己小时候是个“胖”孩子，或者“不正常”的孩子。但我一直都比较胖，而且我还记得那种感觉。我觉得自己像个“又胖又不正常”的孩子。这或许让我产生了身材焦虑，但这件事积极的一面是，我开始对运动、健康和营养产生了浓厚的兴趣。我并没有对自己的饮食或身材过度执着，但我敏锐地意识到营养和运动对身体的影响。这并非易事，因为对于一个家境贫寒的孩子来说，吃饱肚子比营养更重要。而且，我并非总能吃到健康的食物，因为即使在那个年代，健康食品也很贵。不过，我扯远了。

RATS! NOT ALL THAT TALK ABOUT NUTRITION AGAIN!

老鼠！别再谈营养了！

To make a long story interesting, I think the way I came to ask for more out of my nutrition was thanks to rats. In ninth grade biology class we had to do a science project that not only had to be presented to the class, but was also automatically entered in the school science fair. Around this same time I was becoming increasingly involved in working out. I started to read magazines such as Flex and Muscle and Fitness and was very interested in supplementation. I discovered ginseng and how it had an energizing effect. I began taking ginseng before workouts and even before practices and noticed a significant increase in energy. So, I decided that my science fair project would be “The Effect of Ginseng on Rats.” Now this was twenty-plus years ago, and ginseng wasn’t in every food product and health and beauty product as it is now. I conducted a six-week study on how ginseng affected the behavior in rats. I had a control group and an experimental group. Every day I gave the experimental group ginseng, while the control group did not receive ginseng. My results validated my own personal experimentation with ginseng: the experimental group was much more active, they actually grew faster, and they seemed to be more energetic during their time on the wheel versus the control group.

为了让故事更有趣，我想说，我开始重视营养这件事要归功于老鼠。九年级生物课上，我们要做一项科学项目，不仅要向全班同学展示，还要自动参加学校的科学展览。差不多同一时间，我开始越来越热衷于健身。我开始阅读《Flex》和《Muscle and Fitness》之类的杂志，对营养补充剂非常感兴趣。我发现了人参，以及它具有提神醒脑的功效。我开始在锻炼前甚至训练前服用人参，并注意到精力明显提升。于是，我决定把我的科学展览项目定为“人参对老鼠的影响”。这已经是二十多年前的事了，那时候人参不像现在这样被添加到各种食品、保健品和美容产品中。我进行了一项为期六周的研究，观察人参对老鼠行为的影响。我设置了对照组和实验组。每天，我给实验组老鼠服用人参，而对照组则不服用。我的结果证实了我自己对人参的实验：实验组更加活跃，生长速度更快，而且在轮子上运动时，他们似乎比对照组更有活力。

Now as you already know, I was a kid who at this time was not the best academically. But after presenting my “super rats” to my class, I received an A on the project and I got to spend a Saturday at the science fair presenting my project to scientists and other judges. At the time I thought it was a waste of time. But during the fair I noticed that I had more interest in my booth than others in the science fair. At the end of the day, when awards were being presented and we were breaking down our displays, I was called to the stage! I actually took second place in the science fair! Most of my fellow students were in complete shock and were making excuses as to why they didn’t win—even accusing me of somehow making the entire project up. Well, I knew that I had put the work in, and I was extremely proud of my project. I remember what it was like receiving the award in front of my peers; it felt very good. That moment in the ninth grade obviously inspired an interest in nutrition, but it also changed the way I thought about my grades. There is a diametrical difference between receiving an A and an F, and the emotional gratification of an A is euphoric. I not only began to think more about health and nutrition but also about how good it felt getting the acclaim and reward of good grades for my hard work.

正如你所知，我小时候学习成绩并不好。但是，在向全班同学展示我的“超级老鼠”项目后，我获得了A的成绩，并得以参加一个周六的科学展览会，向科学家和其他评委展示我的项目。当时我觉得这纯粹是浪费时间。但在展览会期间，我注意到我的展位比其他人的更受关注。一天结束时，颁奖典礼开始了，我们也在拆卸展位，这时我被叫上了台！我竟然获得了科学展览会的第二名！我的大多数同学都震惊不已，纷纷找借口解释自己为什么没获奖——甚至有人指责我编造了整个项目。但我知道我付出了努力，我为我的项目感到无比自豪。我还记得在同学们面前领奖时的感受；那种感觉真的太棒了。九年级的那次经历不仅激发了我对营养学的兴趣，也改变了我对成绩的看法。得A和得F之间有着天壤之别，得A带来的情感满足感令人欣喜若狂。我不仅开始更多地思考健康和营养，也开始体会到努力学习后获得好成绩所带来的认可和奖励是多么美好。

IF IT WEREN’T FOR ATHLETICS … I WOULD NOT BE THE PERSON I AM TODAY

如果没有体育运动……我就不会成为今天的我。

Athletics, and particularly team sports, changed the way my body looked, but more importantly they shaped my mind. Team sports directly and indirectly teach discipline, humility, respect, how to deal with adversity, time management, how to interact with others, how to win, how to lose, and how to work as a team. Entire books and courses in colleges all across the country are teaching future coaches how to teach their players these skills. I was very fortunate to have parents who got me involved in sports at a very young age. In my first experience of soccer we were the champions of our league at about the age of eight. My team name was the Sharks and the trophies we received were bigger than us! And then my first experience in football was even better—yes, better! We were undefeated and unscored-on champions! I was about ten, and it was Peewee football. I played guard and center. The field was only eighty yards, but still, no other team scored on us for the entire season!

体育运动，尤其是团队运动，改变了我的体型，但更重要的是，它们塑造了我的心智。团队运动直接或间接地教会我自律、谦逊、尊重、如何应对逆境、时间管理、如何与他人相处、如何取胜、如何面对失败以及如何团队合作。全国各地的大学都开设了大量的书籍和课程，教授未来的教练如何培养队员的这些技能。我很幸运，我的父母在我很小的时候就让我参与体育运动。我第一次接触足球时，大约八岁，我们就赢得了联赛冠军。我的球队名叫“鲨鱼队”，我们赢得的奖杯比我们个头还大！而我第一次接触橄榄球的经历更加精彩——没错，更精彩！我们保持不败，并且一分未失，最终夺得冠军！当时我大约十岁，参加的是少年组橄榄球比赛。我打后卫和中锋。球场只有八十码长，但即便如此，整个赛季我们都没有被其他球队攻破球门！

This was where I had a chance to turn an excuse into an asset. When it came to football, I was lucky to be the “husky” kid, and because of my size I dominated at a very young age. In the book Outliers , Malcolm Gladwell discusses how athletes who excel get more attention from coaches and thus get better as a result. It is true, and I know it is, because I was treated a little differently on the football field. I wasn’t the poor kid in the free lunch line anymore; I was a dominating force on the field. Still, I was never coddled. My coaches used to yell at me, push me, make me do laps, and expect more out of me. This type of attention I did not like. But it was teaching me how to be humble and respect my coaches even if I did not agree with their tactics.

这正是我化劣势为优势的机会。在橄榄球方面，我很幸运地体格健壮，这得益于我的身材优势，让我很小就称霸赛场。在《异类》一书中，马尔科姆·格拉德威尔探讨了优秀运动员如何获得更多教练的关注，从而取得进步。这确实如此，而且我知道这是真的，因为在橄榄球场上，我受到的待遇确实有所不同。我不再是排队领免费午餐的穷孩子；我成了球场上的主宰。尽管如此，我从未被娇惯。我的教练会对我大吼大叫，推搡我，让我跑圈，对我有更高的期望。我不喜欢这种关注。但这教会了我如何谦逊，如何尊重我的教练，即使我并不认同他们的战术。

As a result of my ability to respect my coaches, I began to respect the team and was very disciplined. There were many times throughout my life where my mom did not have a car, but that did not mean I could miss practice, so I used to put my football gear on and ride my bike to and from practice! There were several other kids in my neighborhood and other poor neighborhoods who did the same thing, but there were also kids who used the excuse of not being able to get to practice as a way to skip. Guess what happened to those kids? The coaches lost faith and did not pay attention to them.

因为我尊重教练，所以我也开始尊重球队，并且非常自律。我小时候，妈妈经常没有车，但这并不意味着我可以错过训练，所以我经常穿上橄榄球装备，骑自行车往返训练场！我家附近以及其他贫困社区里，有很多孩子也这样做，但也有一些孩子以无法参加训练为借口逃课。你猜这些孩子后来怎么样了？教练们对他们失去了信心，不再理会他们。

This is just an example of what happens in life. If you withdraw from the Emotional Bank Account (I will discuss this more in the next chapter) in any aspect of your life, it is extremely difficult to even get back to a zero balance, let alone a surplus. I realized this at a very young age and made sure that not only did I make it to practice, but when I was there I worked hard.

这只是生活中会发生的事情的一个例子。如果你在生活的任何方面动用了你的“情感银行账户”（我会在下一章详细讨论），那么即使回到零余额也极其困难，更别提盈余了。我很小的时候就意识到了这一点，所以我不仅确保自己按时参加练习，而且在练习时也格外努力。

The football program at Beverly High School was extremely competitive, and there were a lot of talented athletes. As a freshman, if you were good enough you were called up to practice with the varsity team to help them prepare for the Thanksgiving game. So, the reward for being good was … another two weeks of practice? Two weeks of getting knocked around by actual men, and two weeks of getting teased and hazed—this was the reward? Yes it was, because it was an opportunity for me to show the varsity coaches what they had to look forward to in me. For those two weeks in the bitter cold I got knocked down, pushed, punched, and even knocked out a few times.

贝弗利高中的橄榄球项目竞争异常激烈，人才济济。作为一名新生，如果你足够优秀，就会被召入校队一起训练，帮助他们备战感恩节比赛。所以，优秀的奖励竟然是……再加两周的训练？两周被真正的成年人揍得鼻青脸肿，两周被嘲笑和欺负——这就是奖励？没错，这就是奖励，因为这是我向校队教练展示我实力的机会。在那两周的严寒中，我被击倒、被推搡、被拳打脚踢，甚至有好几次被打晕。

There were a couple of freshmen, and we were essentially human dummies and sacrificial lambs. But our actual job was to make the team better. I went full-speed all the time and got beat up bad every day. One particular senior guard hated me! I was making him look bad, because I was getting through the line and really was just a better athlete. But he was huge ! His name was Tom and he did not like me! On one play he literally grabbed my shoulder pads and punched me in the throat. All of this went unnoticed by the coaches, or maybe they were simply looking the other way. Now, obviously some of Tom’s actions were straight-up dirty and nasty, but I was learning how to deal with adversity, learning how to know my place, and at the same time showing the coaches who I was. I was exploiting my opportunity to be more ! That year we had a close Thanksgiving game, but we won. When I was on the bus in my clean and white uniform—because freshmen don’t play in the Thanksgiving game—Tom came up to me and thanked me. He thanked me for pushing him and making him better. It was such a great feeling. At that moment I realized that my efforts, my ability to overcome physical adversity, my ability to respect authority, and my ability to work with a team played a small part in the win that day.

队里有几个新生，我们基本上就是人肉靶子和替罪羊。但我们真正的任务是提升球队实力。我总是全力以赴，每天都被揍得鼻青脸肿。有个高年级的后卫特别讨厌我！我让他难堪，因为我突破了防线，而且我的运动能力确实比他强。但他块头很大！他叫汤姆，他就是不喜欢我！有一次，他竟然抓住我的肩垫，一拳打在我的喉咙上。教练们对此视而不见，或许他们只是装聋作哑。当然，汤姆的一些行为确实很卑鄙下流，但我从中学会了如何应对逆境，学会了认清自己的位置，同时也向教练们展现了我的实力。我抓住了机会，让自己变得更好！那年感恩节我们打了一场势均力敌的比赛，但最终我们赢了。当我穿着干净的白色队服坐在大巴上时——因为新生不参加感恩节比赛——汤姆走过来向我道谢。他感谢我督促他进步。那种感觉真是太棒了。那一刻我意识到，我的努力、我克服身体劣势的能力、我尊重权威的能力以及我与团队合作的能力，在那场胜利中都发挥了微薄的作用。

A HEALTHY BODY EQUALS A HEALTHY MIND—AND A HEALTHY WALLET

健康的身体带来健康的头脑——以及健康的钱包

So in everything from rats to rushing the quarterback on the field, I had the opportunity to learn the importance and value of physical health and fitness when I was young, and it changed my life in many ways. Years later I came to realize that many of the world’s most successful people have the same respect for health and fitness. I had the opportunity to learn more of its impact on your life from none other than Zig Ziglar. In his book, See You at the Top , Zig discusses how he was overweight and sluggish and how he made the decision to lose a pound a day. Weight loss has obvious health benefits, but more importantly the change in your appearance improves your self-image and your confidence, two very important things we all need to be healthy.

从捉老鼠到在球场上冲锋陷阵，我从小就有机会体会到身体健康和体能的重要性，这在很多方面改变了我的人生。多年后，我意识到世界上许多成功人士都同样重视健康和体能。我有幸从齐格·齐格勒（Zig Ziglar）那里更深入地了解了健康对生活的影响。在他的著作《巅峰相见》（See You at the Top）中，齐格讲述了他曾经超重、行动迟缓，以及他如何下定决心每天减掉一磅的经历。减肥对健康益处显而易见，但更重要的是，外貌的改变能够提升自我形象和自信心，而这两点对于我们每个人的健康都至关重要。

While I dined with Mr. Ziglar at Legal Seafood, a restaurant known for serving large seafood portions, one of the guests ordered lobster. The server stated that they only had three-pound lobsters. This guest ordered the lobster, and it was so big that people walked over from other tables to take pictures of it. Mr. Ziglar ordered a baked potato, steamed broccoli, and grilled haddock. He went on to tell me that once he set the goal to lose the weight, he never gained it back. Zig acknowledges in his book that after losing thirty-seven pounds, his personal image improved. He also felt it was important to preach the values and attributes of improving your mental and physical health with equal importance.

我和齐格勒先生在以海鲜分量大而闻名的Legal Seafood餐厅用餐时，一位客人点了龙虾。服务员说他们只有三磅重的龙虾。这位客人点了龙虾，结果龙虾个头巨大，引得其他桌的客人纷纷走过来拍照。齐格勒先生则点了烤土豆、蒸西兰花和烤黑线鳕。他告诉我，一旦他下定决心减肥，就再也没有反弹过。齐格勒先生在他的书中也承认，减掉37磅后，他的个人形象得到了改善。他还认为，倡导身心健康同等重要的价值观和理念至关重要。

Later I attended the “fifty-ninth anniversary” of Mr. Ziglar’s twenty-first birthday, a grand event at the Gaylord Texan at which no alcohol could be found. Zig Ziglar is one of the best motivational speakers I have ever seen, and his books have been sold all over the world. Anything he does or doesn’t do is definitely worth paying attention to, and I highly recommend his books as well.

后来，我参加了齐格勒先生21岁生日的“五十九周年纪念”庆祝活动，那是在盖洛德德克萨斯酒店举办的一场盛大宴会，现场竟然没有酒水。齐格·齐格勒是我见过的最优秀的励志演说家之一，他的书畅销全球。他的一言一行都值得关注，我也强烈推荐他的书。

Napoleon Hill, the author of The Law of Success and Think and Grow Rich , was a man of great importance in the field of positive thinking and success. Hill believed that in order to become successful, you have to cleanse your system. Cleansing is also another great technique that has been used for thousands of years all over the world to maintain youth. There are all types of bodily cleanses—liver, colon, kidney, lungs, lymphatic system, and others. The following is an excerpt from The Law of Success . This section is reprinted unedited, not as a guide or a recommendation for cleansing, but rather as a beginning of your understanding of how a healthy body equals a healthy mind. On just two pages of this book, there’s enough sound advice to keep the average person healthy and ready for action during sixteen of the twenty-four hours of the day, but the advice is so simple that most people would not follow it.

《成功法则》和《思考致富》的作者拿破仑·希尔是积极思考和成功领域举足轻重的人物。希尔认为，要想获得成功，就必须净化身体系统。净化也是一项流传数千年的绝佳方法，在世界各地被用于保持青春活力。身体净化的方式多种多样，包括肝脏、结肠、肾脏、肺部、淋巴系统等等。以下摘自《成功法则》。本节内容未经编辑，并非作为净化指南或建议，而是旨在帮助您初步了解健康的身体如何造就健康的头脑。本书仅两页就包含了足够多的实用建议，足以让普通人在一天24小时中的16个小时里保持健康活力，但这些建议过于简单，以至于大多数人难以付诸实践。

AN EXCERPT FROM THE LAW OF SUCCESS

摘自《成功法则》

The amount of work that I perform every day and still keep in good physical condition is a source of wonderment and mystery to those who know me intimately. Yet there is no mystery to it, and the system I follow does not cost anything and here it is, for your use if you want it:

我每天的工作量如此之大，却依然保持着良好的身体状态，这令熟悉我的人感到惊奇和困惑。然而，这其中并没有什么秘密，我所遵循的方法完全免费，如果你也想使用，以下就是我的方法：

First: I drink a cup of hot water when I first get up in the morning, before I have breakfast.

首先：我每天早上起床后，在吃早餐之前，会先喝一杯热水。

Second: My breakfast consists of rolls made of whole wheat and bran, breakfast cereal, fruit, soft-boiled eggs once in a while, and coffee. For luncheon I eat vegetables (most any kind), whole wheat bread, and a glass of butter-milk. For supper, I usually enjoy a well-cooked steak once or twice a week, along with vegetables (especially lettuce) and coffee.

第二：我的早餐包括全麦麸皮面包卷、早餐麦片、水果、偶尔吃个溏心蛋，还有咖啡。午餐我吃蔬菜（几乎各种蔬菜都吃）、全麦面包和一杯酪乳。晚餐我通常每周吃一到两次全熟牛排，搭配蔬菜（尤其是生菜）和咖啡。

Third: I walk an average of ten miles a day: five miles into the country and five miles back, using this period for meditation and thought. When it comes to building health, perhaps the thinking is just as valuable, as a health builder, as the walk.

第三：我平均每天步行十英里：五英里进城，五英里返回，利用这段时间冥想和思考。就增进健康而言，思考或许与步行一样重要，都是促进健康的有效途径。

Fourth: I lie across a straight-bottom chair, flat on my back, with most of my weight resting on the small of my back, with my head and arms relaxed completely, until they almost touch the floor. These movements give the nervous energy of my body an opportunity to properly balance and distribute itself; ten minutes in this position will completely relieve all signs of fatigue, no matter how tired I may be.

第四：我平躺在一张直底椅上，背部完全贴地，大部分重量都落在腰部，头部和手臂完全放松，几乎触地。这些动作能让身体的神经能量得到适当的平衡和分配；保持这个姿势十分钟，就能彻底消除所有疲劳感，无论我多么疲惫。

Fifth: I take an enema at least once every ten days, and more often if I feel the need of it, using water that is a little below blood temperature, with a tablespoonful of salt in it, chest and knee position.

第五：我至少每十天灌肠一次，如果需要的话，我会更频繁地灌肠，灌肠时使用比体温略低的水，加入一汤匙盐，采取胸膝位。

Sixth: I take a hot shower bath, followed immediately by a cold shower, every day, usually in the morning when I first get up.

第六：我每天都会先洗个热水澡，然后马上再洗个冷水澡，通常是在早上起床后。

These simple things I do for myself. Mother Nature tends to everything else necessary for my health.

这些都是我为自己做的简单事情。至于其他一切维持我健康所需的东西，大自然会照料好。

I cannot lay too much stress upon the importance of keeping the intestines clean, for it is a well-known fact that the city dwellers of today are literally poisoning themselves to death by neglecting to cleanse their intestines with water. You should not wait until you are constipated to take an enema. When you get to the stage of constipation, you are practically ill and immediate relief is absolutely essential, but if you will give yourself the proper attention regularly, just as you attend to keeping the outside of your body clean, you will never be bothered with constipation.

保持肠道清洁的重要性怎么强调都不为过，因为众所周知，如今的城市居民由于疏于用清水冲洗肠道，实际上是在慢性自杀。你不应该等到便秘才去灌肠。一旦便秘，你实际上就病倒了，必须立即缓解。但如果你像注重保持体外清洁一样，定期给予肠道适当的护理，你就不会再受便秘的困扰。

For more than fifteen years, no single week ever passed without my having a headache. Usually I administered a dose of aspirin and got temporary relief. I was suffering with auto-intoxication and did not know it, for the reason that I was not constipated.

十五年来，我几乎每周都会头痛。通常我会服用一片阿司匹林，暂时缓解疼痛。我当时患有自体中毒，却浑然不知，因为我并没有便秘。

When I found out what my trouble was I did two things, both of which I recommend to you. Namely, I quit using aspirin and I cut down my daily consumption of food nearly one-half.

当我找到问题所在后，我做了两件事，这两件事我都建议你也这样做。具体来说，我停止服用阿司匹林，并将每日食物摄入量减少了近一半。

Just a word about aspirin—a word which those who profit by its sale will not like—it effects no permanent cure of headache. Aspirin producers will not tell you about this, but it’s true. What it does might be compared to a lineman that cuts the telegraph wire while the operator is using that wire in a call for aid; suppose that the operator is calling the fire department in order to save the burning building in which he is located. Aspirin cuts or “deadens” the line or nerve communication that runs from the stomach or the intestinal region, where auto-intoxication is pouring poison into the blood, allowing it to eventually reach into the brain, where the effect of that poison is registering its call in the form of intense pain.

关于阿司匹林，我只想说一句——那些靠它赚钱的人肯定不喜欢听——它并不能永久治愈头痛。阿司匹林生产商不会告诉你这一点，但这却是事实。它的作用就像一个线路工人在电报员用电报线呼叫救援时切断了电线；假设电报员正在呼叫消防部门，以拯救他所在的着火建筑物。阿司匹林切断或“麻痹”了从胃或肠道区域延伸到大脑的神经通路，而自体中毒正是通过这些区域将毒素注入血液，最终使毒素到达大脑，并在大脑中以剧烈疼痛的形式发出信号。

Cutting the telegraph line over which a call for the fire department is being sent does not put out the fire; nor does it remove the root cause of your pain. The nerve line over which a headache is registering is simply a call for help.

切断呼叫消防队的电报线路并不能扑灭大火，也无法消除疼痛的根源。头痛所经的神经通路，其实就是一条求救信号。

You cannot be a person of action if you permit yourself to go without proper physical attention until auto-intoxication takes your brain and kneads it into an inoperative mass that resembles a ball of putty. Neither can you be a person of action if you eat the usual devitalized concoction called “white bread”—which has had all the real food value removed from it—and twice as much meat as your system can digest and properly dispose of.

如果你放任自己缺乏适当的身体护理，直到中毒导致大脑瘫痪，变成一团像橡皮泥一样的无力物质，你就无法成为一个行动派。同样，如果你吃那种被剥夺了所有真正营养价值的、通常被称为“白面包”的普通无营养混合物，以及超过身体消化和代谢能力两倍的肉类，你也无法成为一个行动派。

You cannot be a person of action if you run to the pill bottle every time you have—or imagine you have—an ache or pain, or swallow an aspirin tablet every time your intestines call on your brain for a douche bag of water and a spoonful of salt for cleansing purposes.

如果你每次感到疼痛（或者想象自己感到疼痛）就跑去拿药瓶，或者每次肠胃发出需要用水和一勺盐进行清洁的警报时就吞下一片阿司匹林，那你就不是一个行动派。

You cannot be a person of action if you overeat and under-exercise.

如果你暴饮暴食又缺乏运动，你就不可能成为一个行动派。

You cannot be a person of action if you read the patent medicine booklets and begin to imagine yourself ailing with the symptoms described by the clever advertisement writer, who has reached your pocketbook through the power of suggestion.

如果你阅读专利药品的宣传册，并开始想象自己患上广告撰写者所描述的症状，而这些广告撰写者通过暗示的力量让你掏钱购买药品，那么你就不可能成为一个行动派。

Amazingly, the preceding excerpt is in a book about success, not about health or wellness. But Napoleon Hill understood that in order to truly be healthy, we need to rid our body of impurities. Cleansing the body is another well-known way to improve one’s health; its benefits range from curing disease to improving energy and vitality. And ultimately we know that our physical health does impact our mental health.

令人惊讶的是，上述摘录出自一本关于成功而非健康或养生的书籍。但拿破仑·希尔明白，要想真正健康，我们需要清除体内的杂质。清洁身体是另一种众所周知的改善健康的方法；它的益处涵盖了从治愈疾病到提升精力和活力等诸多方面。最终，我们都知道，身体健康确实会影响心理健康。

THE JIM SHRINER STORY

吉姆·施赖纳的故事

Jim Shriner, the author of Live Disease Free to 103 , is a very good friend of mine. Jim’s story is nothing short of amazing. When he was sixteen he was diagnosed with a tumor in his vertebrae that caused paralysis. Through a long surgical procedure by a revolutionary doctor, the tumor was removed and his vertebrae rebuilt. At that time Jim made the decision to rebuild his body and his mind. He went on to become Mr. Indiana and was one of the original contestants on American Gladiator . Today Jim is fifty years old and in amazing shape. He lives an abundant life and is one of the most energetic and inspirational people I know. Jim told me that when he was in the hospital in a full body cast and not sure if he would ever walk again, he began to think about how his body was truly a temple. When he was finally able to get released from the hospital, he dedicated his life to not only his own body but also to helping others. He became a trainer and developed products for others, and he really has as his heart’s desire helping others live disease-free. Jim’s physical appearance is a reflection of his mental attitude.

《活到103岁，远离疾病》的作者吉姆·施赖纳是我的挚友。吉姆的故事堪称传奇。16岁时，他被诊断出脊椎长了肿瘤，导致瘫痪。一位革命性的医生为他进行了漫长的手术，切除了肿瘤并重建了他的脊椎。那时，吉姆下定决心要重塑自己的身心。他后来荣膺印第安纳先生，并成为《美国角斗士》节目的首批参赛选手之一。如今，吉姆已经50岁了，身体依然健壮。他过着充实的生活，是我认识的最有活力、最鼓舞人心的人之一。吉姆告诉我，当他全身打着石膏住院，甚至不知道自己是否还能再次行走时，他开始思考自己的身体是多么神圣。出院后，他不仅致力于自己的健康，也致力于帮助他人。他成为了一名健身教练，开发了相关产品，帮助他人远离疾病，是他毕生的愿望。吉姆的外表反映了他的精神状态。

He looks good and always feels good. He has more energy than anyone I have ever met. He recently told me that he is 186 pounds and ripped—at fifty! The interesting thing about Jim—and many others who experience a life-changing, traumatic event and overcome it—is that his mental attitude is always positive. You don’t need a traumatic event to change your health, but many people wait until it’s too late to get healthy. Move forward with your health, or you will be moving backward.

他看起来精神很好，感觉也总是很好。他精力充沛，是我见过最有活力的人。他最近告诉我，他50岁了，体重186磅，身材健硕！吉姆和许多其他经历过改变人生的创伤事件并最终克服的人一样，最令人称奇的是，他们的心态始终积极乐观。你不需要经历创伤事件才能改善健康状况，但很多人却等到为时已晚才开始关注健康。积极改善健康，否则只会适得其反。

FIND THE SWAN IN YOU

找到你心中的天鹅

Greg Comeaux was the original trainer in the hit TV show The Swan . Greg is almost sixty years of age, and he has less than 6 percent body fat. Greg has always been an athlete and in good shape, but what inspires me about Greg is that with age he seems to get in better shape. He is mentally sharp, a true physical specimen, and continues to help people all over the country maintain a healthy lifestyle. His effervescent personality is infectious, and he motivates me to continue to hit the gym, ride my bike, go for walks, and generally keep pushing. Just today I was in a crossfit class and I truly felt like I was going to vomit. But I remember working out with Greg years ago, and his personal drive pushed me through my workout. Greg has residences all over the United States but spends most of his time in Southern California, where everyone almost always seems to have “something going on.” Greg, too, has many irons in the fire, and most never pan out. But he always pushes forward, and it is because at the age of almost sixty, he feels good physically and mentally, even when faced with constant disappointment. He is constantly writing, training, and speaking to others. To put it in perspective, I have produced probably a dozen infomercials with Greg for various products of his, from weight loss products to energy drinks that he endorses. Only one of them ever worked—and it paid off. That’s why it pays to stay positive, despite setbacks; you’re only one win away from success!

格雷格·科莫是热门电视节目《天鹅》的初代教练。他快六十岁了，体脂率不到6%。格雷格一直都是个运动员，身材也保持得很好，但最让我敬佩的是，随着年龄的增长，他的状态似乎越来越好。他思维敏捷，体格健壮，并且一直帮助着全国各地的人们保持健康的生活方式。他热情洋溢的个性极具感染力，激励着我坚持去健身房、骑自行车、散步，总之就是不断挑战自我。就在今天，我参加了一节CrossFit课，感觉自己快要吐了。但我记得几年前和格雷格一起训练时，他那股不服输的劲头一直激励着我坚持下去。格雷格在美国各地都有住所，但他大部分时间都待在南加州，那里的人们似乎总是“忙个不停”。格雷格也一样，同时做着很多事情，但大多数都以失败告终。但他总是勇往直前，因为即便年近六十，他依然保持着良好的身心状态，即便面对不断的挫折也毫不动摇。他坚持写作、训练，并与他人交流。举个例子，我曾与格雷格合作，为他代言的各种产品制作过十几个电视购物广告，从减肥产品到能量饮料，应有尽有。但只有一条广告真正奏效——而且效果显著。这就是为什么即使遭遇挫折也要保持积极心态的原因；你离成功只差一次胜利！

DON’T INDULGE!

不要放纵自己！

Several years ago I was at my gym and I saw on the wall what looked like a project from a high school student. It was an advertisement for a book called The Health Club Diet . I loved the title and I asked one of my executives to find the author and ask him if he would be interested in having my company market his book. His name is Michael Atwood, and he is a humble, down-to-earth fitness trainer who created a blueprint for people to lose weight and stay fit. Now, I have seen everything that people have created to lose weight: from fitness machines to magical weight loss pills. But, what made Atwood’s approach unique was his ability to recognize that most Americans are going to indulge. He taught in his book how to be less of a glutton. Since I met Atwood, my company has marketed his book and I have also had the good fortune to be trained by him. I don’t know his age, but he is over forty and he lives and breathes his book. He also inspires me to keep exercising and getting better. What I like about Michael’s book and Michael as a person is that he knows that being successful can truly be simple once you recognize that little changes will make a huge difference in your physical and mental health.

几年前，我在健身房看到墙上贴着一张广告，看起来像是高中生的作品。广告宣传的是一本名为《健身俱乐部饮食法》的书。我很喜欢这个书名，于是让一位主管去找作者，问问他是否愿意让公司帮他推广这本书。他叫迈克尔·阿特伍德，是一位谦逊务实的健身教练，他为人们制定了一套减肥健身方案。我见过各种各样的减肥方法：从健身器材到神奇的减肥药。但阿特伍德的方法之所以独特，是因为他意识到大多数美国人都会放纵自己。他在书中教大家如何减少暴饮暴食。自从认识阿特伍德以来，我的公司就开始推广他的书，而且我有幸接受过他的指导。我不知道他多大年纪，但他肯定四十多岁了，而且他身体力行地践行着书中的理念。他也激励着我坚持锻炼，不断进步。我喜欢迈克尔的书以及他这个人，因为他明白，一旦你意识到微小的改变会对你的身心健康产生巨大的影响，成功其实可以很简单。

PHYSICAL ACTIVITY MEANS BRAIN ACTIVITY!

体育锻炼意味着大脑活动！

Physical activity releases chemicals like dopamine in our body and makes us feel good. When dopamine is released, neurotransmitters become activated and blood and oxygen flow more easily through our body. We cannot function without blood and oxygen. When the blood is flowing properly and your brain is receiving the proper amount of oxygen, you will think more clearly. When you are physically able to do things, you are able to ask more out of everything—from others and from yourself.

运动能促进体内多巴胺等化学物质的释放，让我们感觉良好。多巴胺释放后，神经递质被激活，血液和氧气更容易在体内流动。没有血液和氧气，我们就无法正常运作。当血液循环顺畅，大脑获得充足的氧气时，你的思维会更加清晰。当你身体健康，能够完成各种事情时，你就能在各方面——无论是对他人的期望还是对自己的要求——上提出更高的要求。

When I exercise, I increase my creativity and solve problems. As I discussed earlier, I am now almost addicted to yoga. I love the challenge and what it does for my body and mind. Find something you like to do that is physical, and do it every day. Your mind and your body will thank you for it.

运动能提升我的创造力，帮助我解决问题。正如我之前提到的，我现在几乎对瑜伽上瘾了。我喜欢瑜伽带来的挑战，以及它对我的身心带来的益处。找到一项你喜欢的运动，并坚持每天练习。你的身心都会感谢你的。

POWER YOGA

力量瑜伽

As I have said in my advertisements for Ask More, Get More , anybody can apply the techniques and strategies in this book. Yoga is one of the techniques that, when applied, will enhance your life in ways you never imagined. Yoga is of course considered meditation, but power yoga contains more of a fitness approach, and there is an emphasis on maintaining strength, good posture, and flexibility. It is understood as a practice to maintain a healthy lifestyle—whether to reduce stress, for emotional healing, controlling heart conditions, or even enhancing memory and learning. Doctors and healthcare providers are becoming more open minded about yoga and recommending the practice to their clients and patients at an increasing rate.

正如我在《多问，多得》的广告中所说，任何人都可以运用本书中的技巧和策略。瑜伽就是其中之一，一旦运用，它将以你从未想象过的方式提升你的生活。瑜伽当然被认为是一种冥想，但力量瑜伽更侧重于健身，强调保持力量、良好的姿势和柔韧性。它被视为一种维持健康生活方式的练习——无论是为了减轻压力、疗愈情绪、控制心脏疾病，甚至是增强记忆力和学习能力。医生和医疗保健人员对瑜伽的态度也越来越开放，并越来越多地向他们的客户和患者推荐瑜伽。

Yoga incorporates a certain type of breathing: a deep, long, and slow inhalation from your nose that glides over the top of your throat. It almost sounds like ocean movement. The exhalation, out through your mouth, has the same sound and feel. The deep, repetitive, and very controlled breathing sets your sails for a peaceful and stress-free meditation.

瑜伽包含一种特殊的呼吸方式：从鼻腔深长而缓慢地吸气，让空气滑过喉咙上部，听起来几乎像海浪的律动。呼气时，从嘴巴呼出，声音和感觉也与之相同。这种深沉、重复且高度控制的呼吸，能让你扬帆起航，进入平静无压力的冥想状态。

During this meditation there is a boost in oxytocin, a hormone in the body that is associated with feeling relaxed and connected to others. Yoga also helps stabilize your mood, and the intense breathing in yoga boosts the levels of oxygen in your brain for added awareness. Yoga is also believed by some to help with depression and obsessive-compulsive disorder.

冥想过程中，体内催产素水平会提升，这种激素与放松和与他人建立联系的感觉有关。瑜伽还有助于稳定情绪，瑜伽中的深呼吸可以提高大脑的氧气含量，从而增强意识。一些人认为瑜伽也有助于缓解抑郁症和强迫症。

Increasing numbers of Americans are experiencing some type of heart disease due to a sedentary lifestyle. Those who practice yoga slow their heart rate down, which in turn lowers their blood pressure. This is a way to help prevent strokes and lower the risk of having to go through heart surgery. Power yoga is practiced in a heated room, so you are perspiring and sweating out the toxins that you have consumed. Yoga also may lower cholesterol and boost your immune system. The best part of yoga and meditating is that every individual can modify his or her movements to what feels good individually. Of course, there are some positions that need to be done in a certain way and may feel uncomfortable, but in total, power yoga relaxes and soothes your mind, body, and soul.

由于久坐不动的生活方式，越来越多的美国人患上了各种类型的心脏病。练习瑜伽可以减缓心率，从而降低血压。这有助于预防中风，并降低心脏手术的风险。力量瑜伽通常在高温的房间内进行，通过大量出汗排出体内毒素。瑜伽还可以降低胆固醇，增强免疫系统。瑜伽和冥想最棒的地方在于，每个人都可以根据自身感觉调整动作。当然，有些体式需要以特定的方式完成，可能会感到不适，但总的来说，力量瑜伽能够放松身心，舒缓压力。

TAKE A WALK OUTSIDE

到户外散步

Getting outside is a great way to reset your mind. Spending time outside, no matter what the weather, naturally improves your health, and what’s better than that? There’s something soothing about being outside. One cannot deny that the fresh scents of nature calm your mind and body. On the other hand, there is no question that the stifling heat of summer or frigid cold of winter can make attempts at outdoor activity less inviting. But becoming aware of all of the health benefits may give you that extra push to head outside to walk.

到户外走走是放松身心的好方法。无论天气如何，在户外待一段时间都能自然而然地改善健康，还有什么比这更好呢？置身户外本身就有一种舒缓身心的魔力。不可否认，大自然的清新气息能够使身心平静。另一方面，夏季的酷暑或冬季的严寒无疑会降低人们进行户外活动的意愿。但是，了解户外活动的种种益处或许能给你额外的动力，让你走出家门，享受散步的乐趣。

While on your walk, make sure you take in those big, deep breaths of fresh air. Fresh air supplies us with a strong flow of oxygen, which is extremely important for our brains. We all need fresh air, especially those who are sick or whose bodies are in a stage of healing or repairing. The best air to breathe in is typically around plants, trees, rivers, waterfalls, and oceans, especially right after a thunderstorm.

散步时，一定要深呼吸几口新鲜空气。新鲜空气能为我们提供充足的氧气，这对我们的大脑至关重要。我们都需要新鲜空气，尤其是那些生病或身体处于康复或修复阶段的人。通常来说，植物、树木、河流、瀑布和海洋周围的空气最为清新，尤其是在雷雨过后。

Here are just some of the benefits that you can naturally gain from being outside:

以下是一些您能从户外活动中获得的自然益处：

  • helps the airways of your lungs dilate;


    帮助肺部气道扩张；
  • improves the cleansing process of your lungs;


    改善肺部清洁过程；
  • helps improve your heart and blood pressure rates;


    有助于改善心率和血压；
  • helps your immune system fight off disease more effectively;


    帮助增强免疫系统，更有效地抵抗疾病；
  • stimulates your appetite and helps digest your food better;


    刺激食欲，帮助更好地消化食物；
  • improves concentration by clearing your mind.


    通过清空思绪来提高注意力。

Many people go on their daily walks to keep up their physical health. However, changing up the scenery and taking a walk in a peaceful and natural setting can help reduce stress levels by giving individuals a sense of connectivity to themselves. The feeling of “escaping” is relaxing and also exciting, and it may help ease the pressures of the day. A more relaxed state of mind leads to various healthy achievements.

许多人每天散步是为了保持身体健康。然而，变换一下环境，在宁静自然的环境中散步，可以帮助人们减轻压力，增强自我连接感。这种“逃离”的感觉既令人放松又令人兴奋，有助于缓解一天的压力。更放松的心态会带来诸多健康益处。

An easy, low-impact walk is all you need; it does not have to be vigorous by any means. The long, steady pace will help you ease into a higher level of conditional strength and overall health. Walking is the most inexpensive and simplest way to exercise. Start today. It does not take long. Start with a ten-minute walk, and you are on your way to a healthier you!

轻松、低强度的散步就足够了；完全不需要剧烈运动。缓慢而稳定的步伐能帮助你逐步提升体能和整体健康水平。散步是最经济、最简单的锻炼方式。今天就开始吧！这并不需要很长时间。从十分钟的散步开始，你就能朝着更健康的自己迈进！

Some other benefits of walking:

步行的其他一些好处：

  • staying strong;


    保持坚强；
  • feeling more energetic;


    感觉更有活力；
  • helps you sleep better;


    帮助你睡得更好；
  • improves self-esteem;


    提升自尊心；
  • weight management;


    体重管理；
  • lower levels of cholesterol;


    胆固醇水平降低；
  • reduces risk of or helps manage type-2 diabetes;


    降低患2型糖尿病的风险或有助于控制2型糖尿病；
  • reduces risk of heart disease, stroke, high blood pressure, and colon cancer;


    降低患心脏病、中风、高血压和结肠癌的风险；
  • protects against falling and bone fractures in older adults;


    预防老年人跌倒和骨折；
  • helps control joint swelling and discomfort from arthritis.


    有助于控制关节炎引起的关节肿胀和不适。

I mention yoga and walking, because almost anybody can do these activities. There are different, less vigorous types of yoga for beginners, and more rigorous types of walking, but both forms of activity still have the same effect on the body and mind. If you are for some reason physically challenged, then try meditation. Meditation and visualization are great ways to keep your mind healthy. There are many other activities that we can all do to stay healthy; just choose one that works best for you. Whether it is weight training, walking, riding a bike, or gardening, physical activity improves your spirit, mind, and body.

我之所以提到瑜伽和散步，是因为几乎人人都能进行这些活动。瑜伽有适合初学者的较为温和的类型，散步也有强度更高的类型，但这两种运动对身心健康都有相同的益处。如果您因某种原因行动不便，不妨尝试冥想。冥想和视觉化练习是保持心理健康的绝佳方法。我们还可以进行许多其他有益健康的活动；只需选择最适合自己的即可。无论是力量训练、散步、骑自行车还是园艺，体育锻炼都能改善您的精神、思维和身体状况。

THE BODY RESURRECTS THE MIND AND VICE VERSA

身体使心灵复苏，反之亦然。

Several years ago a woman gave birth to an amazing little girl. This woman had always been in shape her whole life. She was a yoga instructor and lived in a part of the country where almost everyone was in shape. After her pregnancy she gained roughly fifty pounds and could not lose the weight. She was fatigued and beginning to feel depressed about her struggles. She was then diagnosed with lupus, a debilitating disease in which your immune system essentially attacks your own organs and joints. She has the kind that attacks her joints. When everything seemed almost hopeless, she decided that she was going to enter fitness competitions! At forty-one this woman—my wife, Kristin—went on to not only enter but win several fitness competitions and inspired other post-pregnancy moms to get in shape and stay fit. She did it by asking herself to commit to a very rigid diet and exercise plan. Well, she still has lupus, but she is in fantastic shape, and her pain due to the lupus has reduced dramatically. Her thought process was that of a contrarian. Most people in her situation would allow excusetosis to infect them and give them a reason to just give up. She did the complete opposite and asked more out of herself physically, and she was compensated tenfold, mentally and emotionally.

几年前，一位女士生下了一个可爱的小女孩。这位女士一生都保持着良好的身材。她是一名瑜伽教练，住在几乎人人身材都很好的地区。怀孕后，她体重增加了大约五十磅，而且怎么也减不下来。她感到疲惫不堪，并开始因为减肥的困境而感到沮丧。后来，她被诊断出患有红斑狼疮，这是一种会使免疫系统攻击自身器官和关节的疾病。她患的是攻击关节的那种。当一切似乎都毫无希望的时候，她决定参加健身比赛！四十一岁的她——我的妻子克里斯汀——不仅参加了比赛，还赢得了几项健身比赛的冠军，并激励了其他产后妈妈们恢复身材，保持健康。她通过严格执行饮食和锻炼计划做到了这一点。如今，她仍然患有红斑狼疮，但她的身材非常好，而且红斑狼疮引起的疼痛也大大减轻了。她的想法非常具有反叛精神。大多数人在她那种情况下都会任由借口蒙蔽双眼，最终选择放弃。但她却恰恰相反，对自己提出了更高的身体要求，结果在精神和情感上都获得了十倍的回报。

DRUGS CHANGED MY LIFE—DON’T LET THEM CHANGE YOURS FOR THE WORSE

毒品改变了我的人生——别让它们也让你的人生变得更糟。

When I was about ten, my dad admitted himself into a rehabilitation center for a cocaine addiction. My parents were divorced, so I didn’t really notice anything, but my dad had the good sense to know he had a problem. About one week into his rehabilitation he asked that I come visit him. I vividly remember visiting him in a place that was like a hospital and him sitting me down to explain why he was there. Now at ten, I think it was difficult for me to understand, but I remember not wanting to be there again.

我大概十岁的时候，爸爸因为可卡因成瘾住进了戒毒中心。我父母已经离婚了，所以我当时并没有太在意，但我爸爸很清楚自己有问题。他入院大约一周后，就让我去探望他。我清楚地记得，我去的那个地方就像医院一样，他让我坐下，跟我解释他为什么在那里。现在想想，当时的我只有十岁，可能很难理解，但我记得我当时真的不想再去那里了。

My stepfather died of AIDS contracted because of a heroin addiction. My mother was infected by him. My brother, my stepfather’s son, was also in rehab for heroin. A cousin of mine is addicted to methamphetamines and is a lady of the evening. Another cousin was in a car accident that almost killed everyone in the car, and one passenger is in a persistent vegetative state. My cousin wrecked the car because he was high, and he served five years in prison. I have another family member who is addicted to prescription pills and, as a result, can’t work. I have friends who have overdosed and died. Every single person I know started out smoking cigarettes, then smoking pot, and then moving on to the next drug.

我的继父死于艾滋病，而艾滋病是因吸食海洛因而感染的。我的母亲也被他传染了。我的弟弟，也就是我继父的儿子，也曾因吸食海洛因而接受戒毒治疗。我的一个表亲吸食冰毒成瘾，并且从事性工作。我的另一个表亲遭遇了一场几乎夺走车上所有人性命的车祸，其中一名乘客至今处于持续植物人状态。我的表亲因为吸毒而撞毁了汽车，并因此入狱五年。我还有一位家人对处方药上瘾，结果无法工作。我的一些朋友因吸毒过量而死亡。我认识的每个人都是从抽烟开始，然后吸食大麻，之后又尝试其他毒品。

Now, I am not judging anyone, and several people that I know, including some of the above, who have had substance abuse issues have recovered and are doing well. I drink socially, which is admittedly using a drug, but for me doing something illegal takes it to a whole new level. Certainly, alcohol can destroy one’s life just like any other drug. But, for me, after seeing what illegal drugs do to people, I decided not to even experiment. Nothing good ever comes out of doing drugs. If you don’t agree with that statement, then you are probably on drugs.

我并不是在评判任何人，我认识的几个人，包括上面提到的一些人，都曾有过药物滥用问题，但他们都已经康复，现在过得很好。我偶尔会和朋友小酌，这当然也算是吸毒，但对我来说，吸食毒品完全是另一回事。当然，酒精和其他毒品一样，会毁掉一个人的一生。但是，在我亲眼目睹了毒品对人们的危害之后，我决定连尝试都不尝试。吸毒没有任何好处。如果你不同意我的观点，那你可能正在吸毒。

I knew a businessperson who appeared to be successful. This person had everything you could want—sports cars, million-dollar boats, and summer homes. This individual traveled first class, and most people thought this person was successful. The person I’m talking about even appeared to apply all the principles found in all of the success books. Despite this façade, the individual was not physically healthy. Poor diet and a body polluted with drugs and alcohol led to increased numbers of mistakes. Poor physical health soon resulted in poor mental health, which wound up ruining the individual’s personal and professional life. This person, who appeared to be successful to so many, was physically unhealthy, and this caused a deteriorated mental state that eventually destroyed the individual’s world.

我认识一位看起来很成功的商人。他拥有你所能想象的一切——跑车、价值百万美元的游艇和度假别墅。他出行都乘坐头等舱，大多数人都认为他很成功。我说的这个人甚至似乎把所有成功学书籍里的原则都运用到了实践中。然而，尽管他外表光鲜，身体却很不健康。不良的饮食习惯加上药物和酒精的滥用，导致他犯的错误越来越多。糟糕的身体状况很快又导致了糟糕的精神状态，最终毁掉了他的个人生活和职业生涯。这个人，在许多人眼中看似成功，但实际上身体状况很差，这导致了精神状态的恶化，最终摧毁了他的一切。

All too often we hear about professional athletes and celebrities who have it all but succumb to drugs and alcohol and lose everything. Many times “everything” to a celebrity or a professional athlete is an image or reputation. A classic example of a recent celebrity who lost everything is Robert Downey Jr., a highly acclaimed actor. He was nominated for an Academy Award early in his career, but he had an epic and very public collapse due to his voracious addiction to drugs. His addiction is not important; what is important is how the drugs had an obvious impact on his body and mind and almost ruined his career forever. Since he became clean, his career has been resurrected and he is again at the top, with a healthy body and thus a healthy mind.

我们经常听到这样的故事：职业运动员和名人曾经拥有一切，却最终沉迷于毒品和酒精，失去所有。对名人或职业运动员来说，“一切”往往指的是形象或声誉。罗伯特·唐尼就是一个典型的例子，这位备受赞誉的演员早年曾获得奥斯卡奖提名，但由于对毒品的严重依赖，他经历了一次轰动性的、公开的崩溃。他的毒瘾本身并不重要；重要的是毒品对他的身心造成了多么显著的影响，几乎彻底毁掉了他的事业。自从他戒毒成功后，他的事业重获新生，如今他拥有了健康的身体，也因此拥有了健康的头脑。

I have studied many successful people and have been fortunate to have been able to rub elbows with people who have achieved magnificent success. I have never met a truly successful person who pollutes his or her body with drugs or alcohol. I will say that I do have a drink here and there when I’m at a dinner or socializing with some friends, but you won’t see me conducting important meetings with a glass of scotch in hand.

我研究过许多成功人士，也很幸运能与一些成就斐然的人近距离接触。我从未见过哪个真正成功的人会沉迷于毒品或酒精。我承认，偶尔在晚宴或与朋友聚会时，我也会小酌几杯，但你绝对不会看到我手里拿着一杯苏格兰威士忌去主持重要会议。

FAT PEOPLE DON’T GET HIRED

胖子找不到工作
