My editor begged me to remove the above subheading due to a potentially inflammatory response from overweight people. Rather than remove it, I will say it again: fat people don’t get hired . Employers do not discriminate, but the harsh reality is that people do, and science confirms that fat people are not only discriminated against as potential employees, but they are also less likely to climb the corporate ladder within an organization. Despite the fact that nearly 70 percent of the American population is overweight or obese, research confirms that overweight people are less likely to get hired and less likely to get promoted. The research indicates that the perception of fat people is that they are lazy, less competent, indecisive, inactive, disorganized, and not successful. Additional research has shown that employers believe that fat people are more likely to get sick and do not display a good image for the company.

我的编辑恳求我删除上面的小标题，因为这可能会引起超重人群的强烈反应。但我不会删除，而是要再次强调：胖人很难找到工作。雇主不会歧视，但残酷的现实是，人们确实会歧视。科学研究也证实，胖人不仅在求职过程中受到歧视，而且在公司内部晋升的机会也更少。尽管近70%的美国人超重或肥胖，但研究证实，超重者更难被录用，也更难获得晋升。研究表明，人们对胖人的固有印象是懒惰、能力不足、优柔寡断、缺乏活力、做事杂乱无章，而且不成功。此外，研究还表明，雇主认为胖人更容易生病，而且会损害公司的形象。

One of the standards by which a person’s health is measured is their body mass index (BMI), which is a calculation of height and weight compared to the general population. If a person’s BMI is high (generally over twenty-five), research confirms that advancement is negatively impacted.

衡量一个人健康状况的标准之一是身体质量指数（BMI），它是根据身高和体重计算得出的，并与一般人群的BMI进行比较。研究证实，如果一个人的BMI过高（通常超过25），其发育会受到负面影响。

The fact is that being overweight downright limits your employability; if you are a manual laborer, your prospective employer will wonder if you can keep up or if you will get hurt. If you are in a retail setting, your prospective employer will think twice about the company’s corporate image and may not hire an overweight person versus someone who is fit. If an overweight person is lucky enough to get hired, his or her weight and appearance also have a negative impact on placement and promotion.

事实上，超重会直接限制你的就业机会；如果你从事体力劳动，未来的雇主会担心你是否能胜任工作，或者是否会受伤。如果你在零售业工作，未来的雇主会更加在意公司的企业形象，可能不会选择雇用超重者，而是会选择身材苗条的人。即使超重者幸运地被录用，他们的体重和外貌也会对职位安排和晋升产生负面影响。

LOSING WEIGHT AND LOOKING GREAT

减肥并拥有好身材

A study conducted in 2010 by Slimming World found that very overweight workers earn less than their more fit counterparts and were more likely to be passed over for a promotion. A study published in the Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences found that “attractiveness” can significantly improve a person’s chances of getting hired. The study went on to say that a person’s “attractive” appearance creates the impression that the person has greater intelligence and possesses many other social traits that would make him or her a better employee. We discussed appearance earlier, and science confirms it: people who appear to be healthier earn more.

2010年，减肥机构Slimming World进行的一项研究发现，严重超重的员工收入低于身材更苗条的同事，而且更容易错失晋升机会。发表在《纽约科学院年鉴》上的一项研究发现，“吸引力”可以显著提高一个人的求职成功率。该研究还指出，一个人的“吸引力”会给人留下这样的印象：他/她拥有更高的智商，并具备许多其他优秀的社交特质，这些特质会使他/她成为更优秀的员工。我们之前讨论过外貌，而科学也证实了这一点：看起来更健康的人收入更高。

If you are overweight, make the decision today to lose the excess weight. Don’t wait until Monday or next week, make the decision today . There are many ways to lose weight, and only you can choose what is best for you. I like a couple different books in addition to Body for Life ; I also recommend The Health Club Diet and Live Disease-Free to 103 . I know both of the latter two authors personally, and we have sold both books together for several years. The customer feedback we get is always positive. You can go to www.diseasefreebook.com and www.healthclubdiet.com to learn more about these two titles.

如果你超重，今天就下定决心减掉多余的体重。不要等到周一或下周，今天就行动。减肥的方法有很多，只有你自己才能选择最适合自己的方法。除了《健美人生》（Body for Life）之外，我还推荐几本书：《健康俱乐部饮食》（The Health Club Diet）和《健康无病活到103岁》（Live Disease-Free to 103）。我认识后两本书的作者，我们一起销售这两本书已经好几年了。我们收到的客户反馈一直都很积极。你可以访问www.diseasefreebook.com和www.healthclubdiet.com了解更多关于这两本书的信息。

Regardless of what you do, when you lose weight you feel great, and when you feel great, your attitude becomes great. A healthy self-image goes a long way toward improving your overall life.

无论你做什么，减肥成功后你都会感觉很棒，而感觉棒极了，你的心态也会随之变得积极。健康的自我形象对改善你的整体生活大有裨益。

ASK FOR MORE FROM YOUR BODY—AND IT MIGHT EVEN GET YOU A BETTER JOB!

对你的身体提出更高的要求——这甚至可能让你找到一份更好的工作！

When I was in college I interned for a congressman, and we were looking to hire a full-time person to work in our legislative office in Washington, DC. You can imagine how competitive this position was, as people with PhDs, JDs, and MBAs applied for the job. Many had all three! My job was not to judge the résumés, but just to compile them as they came in.

大学期间，我曾在一位国会议员的办公室实习。当时我们正在招聘一名全职员工，在华盛顿特区的立法办公室工作。你可以想象这个职位竞争有多激烈，应聘者中不乏博士、法学博士和工商管理硕士。很多人甚至三者兼备！我的工作不是筛选简历，而是把收到的简历整理归档。

We ultimately hired a young woman who was a member of the bar, and seemed equally as qualified as many of the other résumés that we received. I asked the congressman’s chief of staff what set her apart. He said to me that she listed on her résumé that she had completed the New York and Boston Marathons several times. He said that he was an avid runner and that anyone who had the discipline to train for and complete a marathon was obviously someone who was not afraid of hard work, someone who understood how to overcome adversity, and someone who knew how to push through to the finish line. It really hit home with me. We had hundreds of résumés and though most all of them were qualified for the position, this woman got an interview and ultimately the job because of her personal hobbies outside of work.

我们最终聘用了一位年轻的女律师，她拥有律师资格，看起来和其他许多应聘者一样优秀。我问那位国会议员的幕僚长，她有什么过人之处。他告诉我，她的简历上写着她曾多次完成纽约马拉松和波士顿马拉松。他说他自己也是一位跑步爱好者，任何能够自律地训练并完成马拉松的人，显然都是不怕吃苦、懂得如何克服逆境、并且知道如何坚持到终点的人。这番话深深触动了我。我们收到了数百份简历，虽然几乎所有人都符合职位要求，但这位女士最终凭借工作之外的个人爱好获得了面试机会，并最终得到了这份工作。

FROM GINSENG ON RATS TO MILLIONS OF CAPSULES SOLD

从老鼠实验中发现人参的功效，到如今售出数百万粒胶囊。

When I became involved in the direct response industry almost fifteen years ago, I was just a customer service agent, but my knowledge of health, nutrition, and supplements allowed me to be able to build a rapport with customers and even management. Through hard work I climbed the corporate ladder and became general counsel of a very large direct response company that specialized in selling supplements.

大约十五年前，我刚入行直销行业时，只是个客服代表。但我对健康、营养和保健品的了解，让我能够与客户甚至管理层建立良好的关系。凭借努力工作，我一步步晋升，最终成为一家大型保健品直销公司的法律总顾问。

This company had a host of legal challenges that ultimately led to its demise. But my legal education, understanding of sales, and understanding of supplements allowed me to help defend this company and also allowed me to grow as a lawyer and businessperson.

这家公司遭遇了一系列法律挑战，最终导致了它的倒闭。但我的法律教育背景、对销售的理解以及对保健品的了解，使我能够帮助这家公司进行辩护，同时也让我作为一名律师和商人得到了成长。

I started Blue Vase in 2009, and we have sold hundreds of millions of capsules of dietary supplements via infomercial. I am the host of most of our infomercials, and my education about dietary supplements combined with my legal background allows me to ask pointed questions that elicit compelling responses. I don’t know if I believe in fate or not, but I do think that each event in your life is somehow tied to your future.

我于2009年创办了Blue Vase公司，我们通过电视购物广告售出了数亿粒膳食补充剂胶囊。我主持了大部分电视购物广告，我对膳食补充剂的了解以及我的法律背景使我能够提出切中要害的问题，从而获得令人信服的回答。我不知道自己是否相信命运，但我确实认为人生中的每件事都与你的未来有着某种联系。

My decision to study ginseng with rats is directly related to my success as a lawyer and as a businessperson. My company is the best company in the world that sells supplements via infomercial, and if it weren’t for that science fair years ago, maybe I would not be writing this book.

我决定用老鼠研究人参，这与我作为律师和商人的成功息息相关。我的公司是全球通过电视购物销售保健品的最佳公司，如果不是多年前的那次科学展览，也许我就不会写这本书了。

#↩

CHAPTER 4

第四章

ASK YOURSELF TO INCREASE YOUR VALUE

问问自己如何提升自身价值

Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot / Nothing is going to get better / It’s not.

除非有人像你一样非常关心/情况不会好转/真的不会好转。

—Dr. Seuss, The Lorax

——苏斯博士，《洛拉克斯》

I meant what I said, I said what I meant / An Elephant’s faithful, one hundred percent.

我说到做到，言出必行 / 大象百分之百忠诚。

—Horton, Horton Hatches an Egg

——霍顿，《霍顿孵蛋记》

WHY I INCREASED MY VALUE!

我为什么提升了自己的价值！

When I was a child I was very fortunate to have a loving and caring mother. My mom would read to me almost every night. One story that I remember and that has stuck with me my whole life is Horton Hatches an Egg by Dr. Seuss. This beloved author has touched millions of people, but this story did more than touch me; it changed the way I think. This is not the more common Horton story that most people read, which is Horton Hears a Who . Both are great stories. But in Horton Hatches an Egg , Horton overcomes adversity, stands up for what he believes in, doesn’t care about being a pariah, and most importantly, does what he said he would do.

我小时候很幸运，有一位慈爱又细心的母亲。妈妈几乎每天晚上都会给我读书。我记忆犹新、伴随我一生的故事之一是苏斯博士的《霍顿孵蛋记》。这位深受喜爱的作家感动了千百万人，但这个故事对我的影响远不止于此；它改变了我的思维方式。这并非大多数人读过的霍顿故事——《霍顿听到了呼呼声》。两个故事都很精彩。但在《霍顿孵蛋记》中，霍顿克服了逆境，坚持自己的信念，不顾被排斥，最重要的是，他言出必行。

In the story, Horton the elephant is asked to protect and guard an egg that had a life in it—an awesome responsibility. Horton recognized his responsibility and he followed through with the task that he was given, despite being ridiculed, sitting through rain and sleet, and almost getting killed. He saw it through until the very end. There are so many things to take away from this Horton story, but one of the most important things is that when you are given a task, a job, or a responsibility, you should follow through and do what you say you are going to do. When your task, job, or responsibility seems difficult—even impossible— ask more out of yourself. You will be amazed at what you accomplish! And that’s the first step you will take to increasing your perceived value to others.

故事中，大象霍顿受命保护一枚蕴藏着生命的蛋——这是一项艰巨的任务。霍顿意识到自己的责任，并尽职尽责地完成了任务，尽管他遭到嘲笑，冒着风雨，甚至差点丧命。他坚持到了最后。霍顿的故事蕴含着许多道理，其中最重要的一点是：当你被赋予一项任务、一份工作或一项责任时，你应该信守承诺，说到做到。当你的任务、工作或责任看似困难重重，甚至不可能完成时，不妨挑战自我，争取更大的成就。你会惊讶于自己最终取得的成就！而这正是你提升自身价值的第一步。

FOOTBALL IN THE RAIN

雨中足球

When I played football as a kid, I noticed a few kids that were just athletically gifted, but I also noticed that those kids always worked harder. Their dads were always at the games and practices, and I would see these kids—yes, kids—jogging the streets, doing sprints after practice, and just working harder. I was a pretty good athlete, but other than being big, I wasn’t truly gifted; I always had to work at it. In Pop Warner football we didn’t practice every night, and when we didn’t I would try to practice on my own. I would try to improve on the skills taught to me the previous week or day. I vividly remember one day putting on my full uniform in a torrential downpour and walking to a field by myself to do wind sprints. I remember feeling a little weird and hoping the other kids didn’t see me. But I was building value in me—I was getting faster. Building value in you in whatever you do won’t always be easy, but simply doing a little more, trying a little harder, and sometimes going out in the rain will forever build value in you .

小时候踢足球的时候，我注意到有些孩子运动天赋极佳，但我也注意到他们总是更加努力。他们的爸爸总是到场观看比赛和训练，我经常看到这些孩子——没错，是孩子——在街上慢跑，训练后进行冲刺跑，总之就是更加刻苦。我运动能力还不错，但除了个子高之外，我并没有什么真正的天赋；我总是需要付出努力。在少年橄榄球联盟（Pop Warner）的时候，我们并不是每天晚上都训练，所以当没有训练的时候，我就会自己练习。我会努力提高前一周或前一天学到的技能。我清楚地记得有一天，我穿着全套队服，冒着倾盆大雨独自走到一片空地上进行冲刺跑。我记得当时感觉有点怪异，希望其他孩子没看到我。但我的确在提升自己的价值——我的速度越来越快了。无论做什么事，提升自身价值并不总是容易的，但只要多做一点，多努力一点，有时甚至冒雨外出，就能永远提升自身的价值。

I GRADUATE FROM COLLEGE … NOW WHAT?

我大学毕业了……接下来该做什么？

After graduating college, my plan of becoming a lawyer was not completely mapped out. I knew that I was tired of being poor, I knew that I had student loans, and I knew that I wanted to begin making money. But with a degree in political science and relatively no work experience, getting a job isn’t that easy. After searching for about a month or two I saw a listing in the local paper for a sales job. They had a base salary of $425 a week plus commission. Now this was in 1997, the economy was booming, and people were making a lot of money. The people who were making a lot of money back then were salespeople: they were selling everything from software to stocks, but the big earners were salespeople. There aren’t many worse stigmas than that of a car salesman, but I wanted to make money, and even though the economy was booming, I had no experience. So, I responded to the ad in the newspaper and went in for an interview. At that interview I realized that I was being hired not because I had a résumé, but because I had an outgoing personality and seemed likeable. I was excited and nervous at the same time.

大学毕业后，我成为律师的计划并没有完全成型。我知道自己厌倦了贫穷，知道自己背负着学生贷款，也知道自己想要开始赚钱。但拥有政治学学位，又缺乏工作经验，找工作并不容易。找了一两个月后，我在当地报纸上看到一则销售员的招聘广告。底薪每周425美元，外加佣金。那是1997年，经济繁荣，人们收入颇丰。当时的高收入人群是销售员：他们销售的产品五花八门，从软件到股票，但真正赚大钱的还是销售员。没有什么比汽车销售员更受人诟病的了，但我渴望赚钱，尽管经济繁荣，我却没有任何经验。于是，我应聘了报纸上的广告，去参加了面试。面试时我意识到，我被录用不是因为我简历优秀，而是因为我性格外向，看起来很讨人喜欢。我当时既兴奋又紧张。

My start date wasn’t for two weeks, but I went into the dealership a couple days after my interview, grabbed every brochure on every car, and studied them. I remember looking at these brochures and being intimidated and impressed at the same time. Lincoln/Mercury made some great cars. But, to put this into perspective, I couldn’t change a tire if you asked me to. In fact, the day I was driving home from college, my Subaru started to overheat, and I had no money and no idea what to do. To my surprise, my little thirteen-year-old brother, who was in the car with me, got under the hood, asked me if I had an eraser—which I did—and he used it to plug something. We put some water in the radiator and we were off. So, the point is that I knew nothing about cars.

虽然我的入职日期还有两周，但面试后几天我就去了经销商那里，把每辆车的宣传册都拿了出来，仔细研究了一遍。我记得当时看着这些宣传册，既感到敬畏又印象深刻。林肯/水星确实造了一些很棒的车。但说实话，就算你让我换轮胎，我也不会。事实上，我放学回家那天，我的斯巴鲁开始过热，我身无分文，也不知道该怎么办。出乎我意料的是，和我一起在车里的十三岁弟弟打开引擎盖，问我有没有橡皮擦——我正好有——然后用橡皮擦堵住了某个地方。我们往散热器里加了点水，车就又能开了。所以，重点是，我对车一窍不通。

But if I hadn’t responded to that ad, I might not be where I am today. Ford/Lincoln/Mercury trained its employees to not only know how to sell, but also about the products and how to build value in not only the products but in themselves. Many of my friends looked down on the job I had due to the stereotype many people have of car salespeople. But what I was doing was building value in me.

但如果我当初没有回应那则广告，我可能就不会有今天的成就。福特/林肯/水星公司不仅培训员工如何销售，还让他们了解产品，以及如何提升自身价值，而不仅仅是产品本身的价值。我的很多朋友都瞧不起我的工作，因为很多人对汽车销售员抱有刻板印象。但我所做的，却是在提升我自己的价值。

I was a top producer, I made great money, I was learning valuable sales skills, and ultimately I was educating myself about the real world. I met some amazing people selling cars: from professional hockey players to world-renowned architects. I was fascinated with their lifestyles and how they carried themselves. I met people who didn’t blink at writing $80,000 checks. I knew that someday I wanted to be where they were.

我曾是业绩顶尖的销售员，收入颇丰，学到了许多宝贵的销售技巧，最终也对现实世界有了更深入的了解。在卖车的过程中，我结识了许多杰出人士：从职业冰球运动员到世界知名的建筑师。他们的生活方式和举止令我着迷。我遇到过那些毫不犹豫就能开出8万美元支票的人。我知道，总有一天，我也要成为他们那样的人。

By this time in my life, I have written much bigger checks. I also made some great friends who are very successful and continue to be. I will discuss rapport building later on in the book, but for now let me just say that most of all, I have built up my brand and my personal value.

到了我人生的这个阶段，我已经开出了数额更大的支票。我也结交了一些非常成功的朋友，他们现在和将来都会继续取得成功。我会在本书后面讨论如何建立良好的人际关系，但现在我想说的是，最重要的是，我已经打造了自己的品牌和个人价值。

STOP GOING TO WORK

停止上班

One of the things I realized early on in life is that most people don’t like to go to work. I could never understand why until recently. When I was a kid I enjoyed work because I got the reward of a paycheck at the end of the week. I enjoyed my paper route, I enjoyed working at Chuck E. Cheese’s, I enjoyed working for the Lincoln dealership, I enjoyed working as a recruiter, I enjoyed working as a lawyer, and I love what I do now! Notice, I said, “I love what I do now.” I did not say I enjoyed my current “work” or “job.”

我从小就意识到，大多数人都不喜欢上班。直到最近我才明白为什么。小时候我喜欢工作，因为每周结束时都能拿到工资。我喜欢送报纸，喜欢在Chuck E. Cheese's餐厅打工，喜欢在林肯汽车经销店工作，喜欢做招聘人员，喜欢做律师，而且我热爱我现在的工作！请注意，我说的是“我热爱我现在的工作”，而不是说我喜欢我现在这份“工作”或“职业”。

Larry King made the profound statement, “I haven’t worked in fifty-five years!” He continued by saying that when he got up in the morning early in his career, he went to the radio station, he went to CNN, or wherever else. But, according to him, the last time he “worked” was when he delivered packages for UPS at age twenty-one. Larry King is seventy-seven, and while he no longer has Larry King Live , he continues with many other professional endeavors. The key thing to remember is that he considers none of them to be work.

拉里·金曾发表过一句意味深长的言论：“我已经五十五年没工作过了！” 他接着说，在他职业生涯早期，每天早上起床后，他会去广播电台、CNN或其他任何地方。但据他所说，他最后一次“工作”是在二十一岁时为UPS送包裹。拉里·金今年七十七岁，虽然他不再主持《拉里·金现场秀》，但他仍然从事着许多其他的职业。最重要的是，他认为这些都不是工作。

If you are employed, you may not like what you are doing, but one immediate way to increase your net worth and your personal productivity is to simply stop going to “work.” Though your present situation may not be what you want, until you find something more appealing to you, stop going to work .

如果你有工作，你可能不喜欢现在的工作，但提升个人净资产和工作效率的一个立竿见影的方法就是停止“上班”。虽然你目前的处境可能并非你所愿，但在找到更吸引你的工作之前，请停止上班。

Wait! Did I just tell you to quit? No, I’m not insane. I am telling you to change your thought process. If you are employed at a factory, then you are going to the [insert the actual name here] factory. If you are employed at a law firm, then you are going to the [insert the actual name here] law firm. If you are employed at a fast-food restaurant, then you are going to the [insert the actual name here] fast-food restaurant. Change your place of employment from something you refer to as “work” into an actual place you go to learn skills and improve the quality of your product. Change your “job” into a place you go that puts food in your family’s mouths and allows you to afford the things you like. If you do that, you will no longer be thinking of yourself as “working.” Instead, you will be contributing to the company and increasing your personal net worth .

等等！我刚才是不是让你辞职了？不，我没疯。我是说要你改变一下思维方式。如果你在工厂上班，那就去工厂（此处填写工厂名称）。如果你在律师事务所上班，那就去律师事务所（此处填写律师事务所名称）。如果你在快餐店上班，那就去快餐店（此处填写快餐店名称）。把你的工作场所从你所谓的“工作”变成一个你真正去学习技能、提升产品质量的地方。把你的“工作”变成一个让你养家糊口、让你有能力购买自己喜欢的东西的地方。如果你能做到这一点，你就不会再觉得自己是在“工作”。相反，你会为公司做出贡献，并增加你的个人净资产。

If you are not employed and are looking to land a job, then stop looking for “work.” Start looking for a way to improve your life. Look for an actual place of employment that will get you off unemployment benefits and provide you and your family with stability. Too many people look for the ideal “job” or hold out for something better. Though I believe it is a good idea to try to find something you are passionate about, I would urge you to stop looking for “work.” Once you start to look for a place where you can improve your quality of life, then many more doors will begin to open, and you will find employment faster than you imagined.

如果你目前失业，正在找工作，那就别再到处找“工作”了。开始寻找改善生活的方法吧。找一份真正能让你摆脱失业救济金、为你和家人提供稳定生活的正式工作。太多人都在寻找理想的“工作”，或者苦苦等待更好的机会。虽然我认为尝试找到自己热爱的事业是件好事，但我还是要劝你别再到处找“工作”了。一旦你开始寻找能够提升生活质量的工作，机会之门就会为你敞开，你找到工作的速度也会比你想象的快得多。

Once you quit going to “work,” you will find that whatever you do becomes fulfilling and meaningful. It may not be your first choice of employment, but that is okay. So stop working, and start looking for a place that will get you to where you want to go. Only you can make the decision—today—that you no longer work anywhere.

一旦你不再“上班”，你会发现无论做什么都会变得充实而有意义。这或许不是你最理想的工作，但这没关系。所以，停止工作，开始寻找能带你走向目标的途径。只有你才能在今天做出不再为任何地方工作的决定。

My company has close to 150 employees, and although I do not know everyone, I can say with confidence that my executives don’t come to “work.” They come to a place where they contribute, grow, and improve not only their net worth but also the company’s productivity. How do I know this? Well, my executive team is on the job 24/7, and most of them tell me that they love coming in to the office. Every day we are faced with adversity and challenges, and we work through them, but we are never “working”; we are all a part of something special. You too can be a part of something special; you just need to change the way you think about your employment.

我的公司有近150名员工，虽然我不可能认识所有人，但我可以肯定地说，我的高管们来公司不是为了“上班”。他们来这里是为了贡献力量、不断成长，不仅提升自身价值，也提升公司生产力。我怎么知道的？因为我的管理团队全天候都在工作，而且他们中的大多数人都告诉我，他们热爱来办公室。我们每天都会面临各种挑战和困难，我们会努力克服，但我们从不觉得是在“上班”；我们都是某个特别团队的一份子。你也可以成为这个特别团队的一份子；你只需要改变一下你对工作的看法。

Finally, be proud of what you do. I don’t care if you clean septic tanks or run a Fortune 500 company; every career is honorable, and you need to be proud of it. Take pride in what you do at your place of employment. At my company I have a fairly large call center, with people taking incoming calls for sales and customer service. My salespeople at Blue Vase Marketing are titled sales professionals. They are not call center reps, and they take pride in what they do. My customer service agents are customer satisfaction professionals who don’t just serve customers—they provide customer satisfaction. All of my employees take pride in what they do. If they don’t, or they can’t internalize the principles that are in not only this book but also instilled in our staff, then they will not be employed at Blue Vase Marketing very long.

最后，要为你的工作感到自豪。我不在乎你是清理化粪池还是经营一家财富500强公司；每份职业都是值得尊敬的，你都应该为此感到自豪。要为你在工作场所所做的工作感到自豪。在我的公司，我有一个相当大的呼叫中心，有人接听销售和客户服务的来电。在Blue Vase Marketing，我的销售人员是专业的销售人员。他们不是普通的呼叫中心客服代表，他们为自己的工作感到自豪。我的客户服务人员是客户满意度专家，他们不仅仅是服务客户——他们致力于让客户满意。我的所有员工都为自己的工作感到自豪。如果他们不这样做，或者他们无法理解本书以及我们灌输给员工的这些原则，那么他们在Blue Vase Marketing的工作不会长久。

WHY TO INCREASE YOUR VALUE!

为什么要提升你的价值！

When I was selling cars there were a couple of lot boys or lot guys. One was a kid named Max. Max was about nineteen, had just dropped out of college, and was just floating through life. Max was very smart, and he knew everything about these cars. He could tell you everything from how much they weighed to their gas mileage. He also knew about every other car on the planet. Max was making $9 an hour, while some salespeople were making six figures. One day one of the senior sales guys told him he should sell cars. Max was reluctant and a bit nervous. He wasn’t a “salesman.”

我卖车的时候，停车场里有几个小伙子，叫麦克斯。他大概十九岁，刚从大学辍学，整天无所事事。麦克斯很聪明，对这些车了如指掌。从车重到油耗，他都能告诉你。他还知道地球上其他所有车型。麦克斯的时薪是9美元，而有些销售员的年薪都达到六位数。有一天，一个资深销售员跟他说，他应该去卖车。麦克斯有点犹豫，也有些紧张。他觉得自己不是那种“销售员”。

Well, Max decided to give it a shot. He went through the two-week training period, and on his first day on the sales floor he sold five cars. He made in a day what he normally made in two weeks, parking cars. It wasn’t beginner’s luck either; Max went on to sell lots of cars and made a bunch of money. After selling cars for a while and really learning how to sell, Max asked , what more could he sell? Well, Max went on to the mortgage business and was making high six figures—only a few years after he was earning $9 an hour! Today, Max is a very close friend of mine and is a top executive at Monster.com , where he has a team working under him and where he makes more money than 99 percent of the American public. Most important, he has a beautiful family, a nice house, and is very happy. And it’s all because Max built value in himself.

于是，马克斯决定试一试。他完成了为期两周的培训，第一天上班就卖出了五辆车。他一天赚的钱，相当于他以前做泊车员两周的收入。这可不是新手运气；马克斯之后卖出了很多车，赚了不少钱。卖了一段时间车，真正掌握了销售技巧后，马克斯问自己，还能卖什么呢？于是，马克斯转行进入了抵押贷款行业，年收入达到了六位数——而就在几年前，他的时薪还只有9美元！如今，马克斯是我的挚友，他是Monster.com的高管，手下有一个团队，收入比99%的美国人都高。更重要的是，他拥有一个幸福的家庭，一栋漂亮的房子，生活非常快乐。而这一切都源于马克斯提升了自己的价值。

There was another lot boy who worked with Max, and he was a great guy. But, that is all he saw for his future. He thought he would always be a lot boy, and last I heard, he still is. Actually, this guy is not a “boy”; he is a grown man with a family and was barely making it. He just never decided to increase his personal value. He was afraid of failing. Sometimes you have to be defeated to build value in you. Ask yourself: Would you rather park the cars, or sell them?

还有另一个跟麦克斯一起在停车场干活的小伙子，他是个很不错的人。但是，他眼里只有这一个职业。他觉得自己这辈子都只能当个停车场小伙子，我最后一次听说，他现在还是。其实，他已经不是“小伙子”了；他是个成年男人，有家室，而且生活拮据。他只是从来没想过要提升自己的价值。他害怕失败。有时候，你必须经历失败才能提升自身的价值。问问你自己：你是更愿意停车，还是更愿意卖车？

HOW TO BUILD VALUE IN YOU

如何提升自身价值

Too many of us are concerned with our dollars-and-cents compensation. After all, the economy is a mess, and we are having trouble making ends meet. However, if you understand my techniques, your “compensation” will increase in ways you would have never imagined. Just recently, I hired Nate as an unpaid intern for my information technology department. Nate came to us on his own initiative while he was working on a certificate program that does not offer school credits. He was not attending a college, and he was not asking to get paid. He simply took it upon himself to take a course that would teach him a new skill. I knew Nate had drive and was focused.

我们当中太多人只关心金钱上的回报。毕竟，经济形势糟糕，我们都难以维持生计。然而，如果你了解我的方法，你的“回报”将会以你从未想象过的方式增长。就在不久前，我聘请内特担任信息技术部门的无薪实习生。内特是主动来找我们的，当时他正在参加一个不提供学分的证书课程。他没有上大学，也没有要求报酬。他只是主动选择参加这个课程，学习一项新技能。我知道内特很有干劲，也很专注。

Nate joined our IT team, and there was no task he would not do. He took it upon himself to learn about all of our systems and procedures. During this unpaid internship, Nate was increasing his net worth. The more he learned how to do things at my company, the more valuable he became. There was an instance when we needed everyone to jump on the phones at my call center and make sales, and Nate had never “sold” anything in his life. But not only did Nate do this task, he did it with noticeable enthusiasm and outsold some of my sales professionals.

内特加入了我们的IT团队，他什么都愿意做。他主动学习了我们所有的系统和流程。在这段无薪实习期间，内特的净资产不断增长。他在我们公司学到的东西越多，他的价值就越高。有一次，我们需要呼叫中心的所有人都接听电话进行销售，而内特之前从未“卖过东西”。但内特不仅完成了这项任务，而且还展现出了惊人的热情，甚至超过了我们一些专业的销售人员。

As you can imagine, we hired Nate, and as an hourly employee he continued to increase his net worth. He learned how to take customer service calls. He learned how to install video systems. Nate would do anything we asked of him. He doesn’t think anything is beneath him (or above him, for that matter). One time, Nate installed cameras in our warehouse until 3:00 a.m. because he knew we needed them. Nate was given a private office and is making a salary people would kill for. He continued to increase his wealth, and over time the actual dollars will start to grow in his bank account.

正如你所想，我们聘用了内特，作为一名小时工，他的净资产不断增长。他学会了如何接听客服电话，学会了如何安装视频系统。内特总是尽心尽力完成我们交给他的任何任务。他从不觉得有什么事是他做不起的（或者说，有什么事是他做不出来的）。有一次，内特为了安装仓库里的摄像头，一直工作到凌晨三点，因为他知道我们需要这些摄像头。我们给内特配备了一间独立的办公室，他的薪水也令人艳羡。他的财富持续增长，随着时间的推移，他的银行账户里的真金白银也会越来越多。

You see, Nate thought a little differently. He understands that we as his employer aren’t just offering him a job; we have given him an opportunity to grow and learn and at the same time have a steady income. Nate actually left Blue Vase to start his own IT firm. I must say I was sad to see him go, but proud at the same time. Nate built value in himself by taking the course he did, getting the internship with us, and constantly improving. Nate would not be where he is today if not for the way he thought and his continual self-improvement. Building value in you today will increase your net worth tomorrow.

你看，内特的想法有点不一样。他明白我们作为他的雇主，不仅仅是给他提供一份工作；我们给了他一个成长和学习的机会，同时还能让他获得稳定的收入。内特最终离开了蓝花瓶公司，创办了自己的IT公司。说实话，我舍不得他走，但同时也为他感到骄傲。内特通过参加培训课程、在我们公司获得实习机会以及不断提升自身能力，不断提升自我价值。如果没有他独特的思维方式和持续的自我提升，内特今天就不会取得这样的成就。今天提升自身价值，明天就能增加你的财富。

Nate is just one example, and I could fill this entire book with more examples of how fortunate I am to have great employees. They increased their value by increasing my value and the value of the company. The night I started my company, my chief information officer, Chris, and I were up all night programming phones, because without phones we could not cover the calls. Our now-office manager and my amazing assistant Shauna (really our chief operating officer) came to the office at midnight with an air mattress and pillows. On another occasion, one Friday night at 8:00 p.m., Shauna took it upon herself to spot-test some of our systems and found they weren’t working. If she had not checked the system (a process that someone else usually does), we would have lost, conservatively, $70,000. Shauna literally knows every aspect of the business and if asked to do something, she can help out with any area of the company. Every one of my employees, when hired, is required to spend some time in every department. We do this to help them learn and understand how each division works and how together they must become a team. This also improves their value to the company. We also require each new hire to read The Go-Getter by Peter Kyne and The Fred Factor by Mark Sanborn. Both of these books have been instrumental in my success and the success of my companies. I recommend that you read them.

内特只是其中一个例子，我可以用更多例子来证明我拥有如此优秀的员工是多么幸运。他们通过提升我和公司的价值来提升自身的价值。公司成立当晚，我的首席信息官克里斯和我熬夜编写电话程序，因为没有电话，我们就无法接听电话。我们现在的办公室经理和我出色的助理肖娜（实际上是我们的首席运营官）在午夜带着充气床垫和枕头来到办公室。还有一次，在一个周五晚上8点，肖娜主动承担了抽查我们一些系统的任务，发现它们出了问题。如果她没有检查系统（这项工作通常由其他人负责），保守估计，我们会损失7万美元。肖娜对公司的方方面面都了如指掌，只要有人需要，她就能在公司的任何领域提供帮助。我要求每位员工在入职时都必须在每个部门轮岗一段时间。我们这样做是为了帮助他们学习和了解各个部门的运作方式，以及他们如何才能成为一个团队。这也有助于提升他们对公司的价值。我们还要求每位新员工阅读彼得·凯恩的《积极进取者》（The Go-Getter）和马克·桑伯恩的《弗雷德法则》（The Fred Factor）。这两本书对我个人以及我所在公司的成功都起到了至关重要的作用。我建议您也阅读一下。

A DEPOSIT IN THE EMOTIONAL BANK ACCOUNT

在情感银行账户中存入一笔钱

Several years ago, when I was a full-time lawyer and general counsel of another company, I was looking to hire an intern in my legal department. I went to the human resources department and asked them to help me find one. I received a couple of résumés that were okay, but nothing excited me or seemed like a fit. A few weeks into my search, I was told that there was a candidate in the foyer waiting to speak with me. I was a little shocked, since I did not have an interview set up. I asked my assistant to greet this individual and investigate. Well, apparently this young man saw our ad, took it upon himself to fill out an application, and was interested in meeting with me.

几年前，我还是另一家公司的全职律师兼总法律顾问时，想在法务部门招一名实习生。我去了人力资源部，请他们帮忙找人。我收到了几份简历，还算可以，但没有一份让我眼前一亮，感觉不太合适。几周后，我被告知有一位候选人在大厅等着和我面谈。我有点惊讶，因为我并没有安排面试。我让我的助理去迎接这位候选人并了解情况。原来，这位年轻人看到了我们的招聘广告，主动填写了申请表，并且有兴趣和我面谈。

I looked at his résumé and was impressed. He was a licensed attorney, he had some decent experience, and he went to a decent law school. So, for my own amusement and curiosity, I granted him an interview. To my surprise, he was well dressed, polite, articulate, and perfect . I even had a colleague interview this young man to make sure that my instincts were correct. However, I wasn’t hiring an attorney. I told him I was looking for an intern and couldn’t possibly pay him an adequate salary. Well, guess what? I hired him on the spot. He went on to work for me for several years and made six figures at the end of his tenure with the firm. I was so impressed by his performance that I then hired him at Blue Vase Marketing. He was always on time, stayed late, and had his work complete. In addition, he also took it upon himself to improve the department. I later found out that he originally sent me a personal letter, but human resources had intercepted it.

我看了他的简历，印象很深刻。他是一名执业律师，经验丰富，毕业于一所不错的法学院。出于好奇和兴趣，我给了他一次面试机会。令我惊讶的是，他衣着得体，彬彬有礼，口齿伶俐，简直完美。为了确认我的直觉，我还让一位同事也面试了这位年轻人。然而，我并没有打算聘用律师。我告诉他，我需要的是一名实习生，而且不可能给他支付足够的薪水。结果呢？我当场就聘用了他。他为我工作了好几年，离职时年薪达到了六位数。他的表现让我非常满意，所以我后来又把他招到了蓝花瓶营销公司。他总是准时上班，经常加班，而且总能按时完成工作。此外，他还主动承担起改进部门工作的责任。后来我才知道，他最初给我写了一封私人信件，但被人力资源部门截获了。

Right from the very beginning, this young man made a huge deposit into my emotional bank account. I knew that he was not afraid to take risks, that he was a go-getter, and that he was a hard worker, just by the way he showed up in a suit to fill out an application and asking to speak with me. Can you imagine? Some people may have been offended, but not me. He started out with a full bank account with me, and I was willing to invest in him. Today he is an integral part of my business and I trust him with making business decisions on my behalf. He came quite a long way from being basically an intern to helping with major business decisions.

从一开始，这个年轻人就给我留下了深刻的印象。他穿着西装来填写申请表，并要求和我面谈，我就知道他不怕冒险，是个积极进取的人，而且工作非常努力。你能想象吗？有些人可能会觉得被冒犯，但我不会。他一开始就对我充满信心，我愿意投资他。如今，他已成为我公司不可或缺的一部分，我信任他，让他代表我做出商业决策。他从一个实习生成长为能够参与重大商业决策的人，这真是一段了不起的历程。

RISE TO A CHALLENGE

迎接挑战

My old boss had a side project that he needed some help with. His family owned some property on a very private and wealthy island in New England. His neighbor had filed for a variance that, if granted, would have obstructed my boss’s beachfront property and diminished the value of the land. I knew nothing about real estate, property, or maritime law, but I spent countless hours researching the law and ways to prevent his neighbor from encroaching on his family’s property. The challenge was that his neighbor was and is a very powerful real estate lawyer! Of course, I am always up for a good challenge.

我以前的老板有个副业需要帮忙。他家在新英格兰一个非常私密且富裕的小岛上拥有一处房产。他的邻居申请了一项豁免，如果获批，将会妨碍我老板的海滨房产，并降低土地价值。我对房地产、物权法或海事法一窍不通，但我还是花了无数个小时研究相关法律，寻找阻止邻居侵占他家房产的方法。难点在于，他的邻居是一位实力雄厚的房地产律师！当然，我总是乐于接受挑战。

ACTION: the act by which we incorporate our goals, dreams, ideas, and imagination, turning them into a reality through persistent effort.

行动：我们将目标、梦想、想法和想象融入其中，并通过持续努力将其变为现实的行为。

One thing that I discovered when I was researching the area was that the shoreline was very unique; it is the only place in the world with a particular type of rock. I found a document from the 1800s in a library in Texas that substantiated the rarity of this type of rock. In addition to several other arguments, I was able to prevent the neighbor from building and ruining my boss’s family’s property due to the rarity of this rock and the potential destruction of the ecology. I did this for no monetary gain, but you can bet that this action was a huge deposit in his emotional bank account.

我在研究这片区域时发现，那里的海岸线非常独特；它是世界上唯一拥有这种特殊岩石的地方。我在德克萨斯州的一家图书馆里找到了一份19世纪的文献，证实了这种岩石的稀有性。凭借这种岩石的稀有性以及可能对生态环境造成的破坏，我成功阻止了邻居在我老板家的土地上建造房屋，避免了破坏。我这样做并非为了金钱利益，但可以肯定的是，这件事极大地抚慰了他的心灵。

DON’T ADD DEBT TO THE EMOTIONAL BANK ACCOUNT

不要在情感账户上增加债务

Withdrawals from the emotional bank account can cause emotional overdrafts, which incur fines and fees. How can this happen? If you are late, if you take advantage of your boss’s kindness, if you don’t do more than what is asked of you, or if you don’t finish a job you are asked to do—you’re running in the red. Just watch that emotional bank account deplete. It can empty faster than deposits are made.

从情感账户取款会导致情感透支，从而产生罚款和费用。这是怎么回事呢？如果你迟到，如果你滥用老板的善意，如果你只做被要求做的事情，或者如果你没有完成被安排的工作——你的情感账户就会透支。眼睁睁地看着你的情感账户被掏空吧。它的消耗速度可能比存款的速度还要快。

Deposits that improve your balance in your boss’s bank account:

增加你在老板银行账户余额的存款：

  • Be early.


    早点到。
  • Stay late.


    待到很晚。
  • Work on your days off (if necessary).


    必要时，休息日也要工作。
  • Support your boss’s objectives with sound advice.


    用合理的建议支持老板的目标。
  • Complete tasks early and make sure they are correct.


    提前完成任务并确保任务正确无误。
  • Never speak badly about anyone in the office or your place of employment.


    永远不要在办公室或工作场所说任何人的坏话。
  • Be a team player.


    要有团队合作精神。
  • Don’t point out your accomplishments (with some exceptions: see the following); they will be noticed.


    不要过分强调你的成就（某些例外情况除外：见下文）；它们自然会被人注意到。
  • Don’t expect something in return for doing more than what is asked of you.


    不要指望因为做了超出别人要求的事情而得到回报。
  • Be likeable and improve your social skills. Eighty-five percent of all people are hired because they are liked.


    努力提升个人魅力和社交能力。85%的人是因为人缘好而被录用。
  • Show your bosses respect at all times and never speak badly of them.


    始终尊重你的老板，永远不要说他们的坏话。

Just these few things will get you further in your place of employment and make you more valuable to your company. But not doing them—or running up overdrafts—will have the opposite result.

仅仅做到这几件事，就能让你在职场上更上一层楼，提升你对公司的价值。但如果不做这些事，或者透支账户，就会适得其反。

I had an employee who started with me the day I opened my doors. She was capable and willing to do anything. She was educated, likeable, and hardworking. However, she had a tendency to always be absent after a big athletic event. It didn’t matter if it was the Ryder Cup or the Final Four; she was sick the next day. It became comical; if the Red Sox were playing the Yankees on a Tuesday night, she was sick on Wednesday.

我有个员工从我开业那天就来上班了。她能力很强，也愿意做任何事。她受过良好的教育，人缘好，工作也很努力。然而，她有个毛病，每次大型体育赛事结束后都会缺勤。不管是莱德杯还是NCAA四强赛，她第二天都会生病。这事儿后来变得挺滑稽的：如果红袜队和洋基队周二晚上比赛，她周三就病倒了。

I think she realized that I began to take notice, so she said things like, “I will make up the hours on Saturday.” Of course, she never did. That is like hitting your debit card for the purchase of a car when your balance is zero! I spoke to her. She said she would not let it happen in the future, but it continued, and though I didn’t fire her immediately, the emotional bank account was drained and she had no credit lines to tap into at the end.

我觉得她意识到我开始注意到她了，所以就说了些诸如“我周六会补上工时”之类的话。当然，她根本没补。这就像信用卡余额为零的时候还去买车一样！我跟她谈过了。她说以后不会再发生这种事，但她还是继续这样，虽然我没有立刻解雇她，但我的情绪已经彻底崩溃，她最后也没有任何可以动用的余地了。

Finally, she was out for ten days without an email, a phone call, a text, a letter, nothing . We called her home and her husband said she was really ill, but why didn’t he think to call us? This woman held the title of vice president at my company, yet she couldn’t call someone or have her husband call to say she was on her deathbed? Every time I called, her phone was dead!

最后，她整整十天杳无音信，既没有邮件，也没有电话、短信、信件，什么都没有。我们打电话到她家，她丈夫说她病得很重，但他为什么没想到给我们打电话呢？这位女士可是我们公司的副总裁，难道她连个电话都打不通，或者让她丈夫打个电话告诉我们她病危吗？我每次打电话过去，她的手机都关机了！

We aren’t in high school, and “the dog ate my homework” excuse doesn’t work in the real world. It was brought to my attention by the young lawyer just referenced that a local lodge (in which she was very active) just happened to be on a cruise in the Bahamas during the exact same time she was out! Now, I never confirmed that she was on that ship, but the circumstantial evidence surely pointed in that direction. Sick for ten days at the same time as a cruise, with a dead cell phone and no communication? Either way, I fired her for job abandonment. This is an extreme example of depleting the emotional bank account. Her constant debits of absenteeism after sporting events and failing to make up her missed hours overdrafted the emotional bank account and ultimately maxed out all the lines of credit she had.

我们又不是高中生了，“作业被狗吃了”这种借口在现实世界里根本行不通。刚才提到的那位年轻律师告诉我，她积极参与的一个当地社团，竟然在她休假期间正好在巴哈马群岛进行游轮旅行！虽然我从未证实她是否真的在那艘船上，但种种迹象都指向了那个方向。生病十天，同时又赶上游轮旅行，手机没电，完全联系不上？不管怎样，我以擅离职守为由解雇了她。这真是个极端的例子，说明她是如何耗尽我的“情感账户”的。她经常在体育赛事后旷工，而且迟迟不补上缺勤的时间，最终耗尽了我的“情感账户”，让她所有的“信用额度”都用光了。

DON’T CONFUSE ACTIVITY WITH ACCOMPLISHMENT

不要把活动和成就混为一谈

Blue Vase Marketing is a decent-size company. Our employee base changes, but it’s always over one hundred employees. We have offices in Boston and Chicago, and we are expanding to London. Some analysts would call us a small business, but I would beg to differ.

Blue Vase Marketing 是一家规模适中的公司。我们的员工人数虽然会有所变动，但始终保持在一百人以上。我们在波士顿和芝加哥设有办事处，目前正在向伦敦扩张。一些分析师可能会称我们为小型企业，但我并不认同这种说法。

Several years ago I implemented a daily and weekly update program in which my key executives and some supporting staff send me daily reports on what they did the day before, weekly reports on the prior week, and what they plan on accomplishing the next day and the following week. Some of my executives were not excited about this, and I even had a few ask for my rationale. Well, the good news for me is that I am in the corner office for a reason, and as my mother used to say to me when I asked her why I couldn’t do something, my response was, “Because I said so”—kind of.

几年前，我推行了一项每日和每周的工作汇报制度，要求我的主要高管和一些支持人员每天向我汇报前一天的工作，每周汇报上周的工作，以及他们计划在第二天和下周完成的工作。一些高管对此并不热衷，甚至有人问我这么做的理由。不过，对我来说，好消息是我能坐上高管的位置是有原因的。就像我母亲过去常说的那样，当我问她为什么我不能做某件事时，我的回答是“因为我说了算”——差不多是这样。

But the real reason for this reporting system is that I learned in my business career that too many people confuse activity with accomplishment. Employees can get caught up doing tasks with zero benefit for the company. My daily reports allow me to monitor their activity and accomplishments. Activity is the busy work that people do in order to accomplish a goal. Accomplishment is the finalization and completion of the goal. One thing that I discussed with my executives about the reports is that they allow me to see what has been accomplished. But, it also allows them to see what they accomplished. When you write things down and reflect on the previous day, if you realize you did not accomplish something, then you know that your day was essentially wasted and you should be able to see it. I help them recognize this and also point them in the right direction.

但我设立这套报告系统的真正原因在于，我在职业生涯中发现，太多人把忙碌和成就混为一谈。员工常常忙于一些对公司毫无益处的任务。我的每日报告让我能够监控他们的工作和成就。忙碌是指人们为了达成目标而进行的琐碎工作，而成就则是目标的最终实现。我曾与高管们讨论过这份报告，它不仅让我了解已经完成的工作，也让他们看到自己完成了什么。当你把事情写下来并反思前一天的工作时，如果你发现自己没有完成任何任务，那么你就知道这一天基本上是浪费了，你应该能够意识到这一点。我会帮助他们认识到这一点，并为他们指明正确的方向。

So, whether you are working on your business or personal life, ask yourself, what did you accomplish today, and last week. Then what do you plan on accomplishing tomorrow and next week. Let me also say that in your personal life your accomplishments can be really small and you don’t have to change the world every day, sometimes just relaxing is an accomplishment. If your goal for the next day is to just relax, then accomplish that task, and if you didn’t then figure out why and ask how you can accomplish that goal the next day. When you recognize that you did or didn’t accomplish your daily goal, you will become so much more efficient and you will find that you will have a lot more time to accomplish even more things.

所以，无论你是忙于事业还是处理个人事务，都要问问自己：今天和上周你都完成了什么？然后，你计划明天和下周完成什么？我想说的是，在个人生活中，你的成就可以很小，你也不需要每天都改变世界，有时候，放松本身就是一种成就。如果你的第二天目标是放松，那就去完成这个目标；如果没有做到，那就找出原因，并思考第二天如何才能实现这个目标。当你意识到自己是否完成了每日目标时，你的效率会大大提高，你会发现自己有更多的时间去做更多的事情。

Recently I hired someone for my executive team who is very organized and is what most people would consider a type-A personality. But this person is a bit over the top and takes on too much “work.” I have had to have a few conversations with this individual, reminding him that taking on too much activity will not lead to accomplishment of the main objective. He is very smart, a hard worker, and cares about what he does. But, at the end of the day, none of that matters. If you have a position at a company and you have a goal or an objective, even if it is not well defined, you must find a way to ensure that you have accomplished something of value. The same goes for your personal life. Going to the gym and sitting in the sauna will not lead to weight loss. The activity of going to the gym is not what accomplishes the goal of weight loss and good health. The activity of actually exercising is what will accomplish your goal.

最近我为我的管理团队聘请了一位非常有条理、典型的A型性格的人。但这个人有点过于投入，承担了太多“工作”。我不得不和他谈了几次，提醒他承担太多工作并不会帮助他实现主要目标。他非常聪明，工作也很努力，对工作充满热情。但归根结底，这些都不重要。如果你在公司担任某个职位，并且有一个目标或任务，即使这个目标并不明确，你也必须找到方法确保自己有所作为。这同样适用于你的个人生活。去健身房和蒸桑拿并不能减肥。去健身房本身并不能帮助你达到减肥和保持健康的目的。真正能实现目标的是实际的锻炼行为。

YOU NEED TO BRING ATTENTION TO YOURSELF—IT’S OKAY

你需要吸引别人的注意——这没关系。

After another discussion with the aforementioned executive and a little more direction from me, his accomplishments have exceeded my expectations. But that only happened because he made me aware that his activity actually was an accomplishment. I needed to understand what he was actually doing as his job is very technical. The moral of this part of the story is that you should ask yourself, “Do my superiors actually know what I’m accomplishing?” If not, you need to find a way to make sure they know what you are doing and what you have done. Even though I see daily and weekly reports, I was still confused as to what he was doing, but after having our last talk and educating myself, I realized that his work was top-notch!

在与那位高管再次沟通并得到我进一步指导后，他的工作成果超出了我的预期。但这完全是因为他让我意识到他的工作本身就是一种成就。由于他的工作技术性很强，我需要了解他实际在做什么。这个故事的寓意在于，你应该问问自己：“我的上级真的了解我的工作成果吗？” 如果不清楚，你需要想办法让他们知道你在做什么以及已经完成了什么。尽管我每天都会查看他的报告，但我仍然不清楚他具体在做什么。不过，在上次谈话并进行自我学习之后，我意识到他的工作非常出色！

I DESERVE TO BE SUCCESSFUL—THE PROOF IS IN THE PERSONAL PROFILE

我理应成功——个人资料就是最好的证明。

I will never forget the day I bought my first real suit at Men’s Wear-house. It was 1997, and it was very exciting. I was fresh out of college and selling Lincoln/Mercury cars, and I cashed my first commission check of $1,507. For a young man who had come from the other side of the tracks with nothing, this felt like a million dollars. The most my mother had made for a whole year was $18,000.

我永远不会忘记在男装店买第一套真正意义上的西装的那一天。那是1997年，真是令人兴奋。我刚从大学毕业，在一家卖林肯/水星汽车的公司工作，拿到了第一张佣金支票，1507美元。对于一个来自贫民窟、一无所有的年轻人来说，这笔钱感觉就像一百万美元。我母亲一年的收入最多也只有18000美元。

So, I walked in with a goal of buying a really nice suit for no more than $500. Mind you, I had never purchased a suit before, or anything else—other than my first car—for more than $500. The salesperson greeted me: “Hello, sir. Welcome to Men’s Wearhouse.” He must have seen me coming from a hundred miles away with cash in my pocket. It was as if he had X-ray vision and was counting my greenbacks. He fitted me with a beautiful navy blue suit, a 46-athletic. Man, it looked good! I thought I was done there. But I wasn’t even close.

于是，我抱着买一套不超过500美元的漂亮西装的决心走进了店里。要知道，我以前从未买过超过500美元的西装，除了我的第一辆车之外，其他任何东西都没买过。销售员热情地招呼我：“您好，先生。欢迎光临男装店。”他肯定从百里之外就看到我兜里揣着现金过来了。就好像他有透视眼，正在数着我的钞票似的。他给我试穿了一套漂亮的藏蓝色西装，46码的运动款。哇，真好看！我以为这下总算搞定了。但其实远不止如此。

“Before you meet with the tailor,” the salesman stated, “try on this pair of shoes.”

“在你和裁缝见面之前，”售货员说道，“先试穿一下这双鞋。”

“I don’t need shoes,” I responded. To which he replied, “Well try them on, so when we meet with the tailor we can get a better fit.”

“我不需要鞋子，”我回答道。他回答说：“那就试试吧，这样我们去裁缝店的时候就能更合脚了。”

I was wearing sneakers. So I reluctantly tried on a shiny pair of burgundy shoes that perfectly matched my suit. “I’m not buying a $75 pair of shoes,” I assured him. “I already hit my cap of $500.”

我当时穿着运动鞋。所以，我不太情愿地试穿了一双锃亮的酒红色皮鞋，这双鞋和我的西装很搭。“我不会买一双75美元的鞋，”我向他保证道，“我的预算已经达到500美元了。”

He looked at me and said, “Mike, you wouldn’t drive a new car with old tires would you?” Well, you already know my answer: I walked out of that store with a suit, shoes, and a couple of nice ties—just over $700 in clothes. I felt great and couldn’t wait to wear my new suit and those shiny shoes. Funny thing—I still have those shoes, and guess what? Those shoes have made me millions of dollars.

他看着我说：“迈克，你不会开着新车配旧轮胎吧？” 嗯，你肯定知道我的答案：我走出那家店时，手里拿着一套西装、一双皮鞋和几条漂亮的领带——总共花了700多美元。我感觉棒极了，迫不及待地想穿上我的新西装和那双锃亮的皮鞋。有趣的是——我至今还留着那双鞋，你猜怎么着？那双鞋让我赚了数百万美元。

The lesson: Pay attention to your attire. Your clothes and shoes and the quality of the shoes project to others that you care, that you are on your game and ready for the task at hand. Any self-improvement book or publication worth reading will tell you to invest in your attire. When you dress for success, you will be successful. When you are at your current job and you wear a suit or a nice blouse and skirt, people notice.

教训：注重你的穿着打扮。你的衣着、鞋子以及鞋子的品质，都会向他人传递出你的用心程度，表明你状态良好，随时准备迎接挑战。任何值得一读的自我提升书籍或刊物都会告诉你，要重视自己的穿着。当你穿着得体时，你也会成功。当你上班时，如果穿着套装或漂亮的衬衫裙，人们会注意到你。

In The Magic of Thinking Big , David Schwartz spends a lot of time on this subject, and in The Strangest Secret (check this out before you read The Secret by Rhonda Byne), Earl Nightengale says, “You become what you think about.” Well, when you are dressed for success, you become who you think you are. When you dress like someone important, you will begin to act important. When you act important, people begin to treat you like the VIP you know you are. When you are a VIP you will rise to the top.

在《思考致富》一书中，大卫·施瓦茨用了大量篇幅探讨这个主题；而在《最奇特的秘密》（建议在阅读朗达·拜恩的《秘密》之前先看看这本书）中，厄尔·南丁格尔也说过：“你最终会成为你所想的。” 没错，当你衣着得体、气场强大时，你就会成为你认为自己是的那种人。当你穿着得体、举止得当时，你就会开始表现得像个重要人物。当你表现得像个重要人物时，人们就会开始像对待贵宾一样对待你，而你也知道自己就是贵宾。当你成为贵宾时，你就会登上顶峰。

Recently, I was visiting a local coffee shop/country store and overheard a woman named Betty tell a story proving this simple strategy. Betty told her friends about a colleague named Sue who had jury duty. Sue decided it was appropriate to dress up in her “business attire” for jury duty. Well, Sue went to jury duty and was dismissed early. Sue then decided to remain dressed in her “business attire” at her place of employment. That day, Betty noticed Sue was more productive; her work quality improved and she seemed happier. Others in the business treated Sue as though she were upper management. Unfortunately, Sue didn’t fully grasp what happened and returned the next day in her old clothes, going back to being unhappy and doing just enough to get by.

最近，我去一家当地的咖啡馆兼乡村商店，无意中听到一位名叫贝蒂的女士讲了一个故事，正好证明了这个简单的策略。贝蒂跟朋友们说起她的同事苏，苏要去参加陪审团。苏觉得穿着“职业装”去参加陪审团很合适。结果，苏去参加陪审团后提前被解散了。之后，苏决定穿着“职业装”去上班。那天，贝蒂注意到苏的工作效率更高了；她的工作质量提高了，而且看起来也更开心了。公司里的其他人对待苏就像对待高层管理人员一样。可惜的是，苏并没有完全意识到发生了什么，第二天她又穿着原来的衣服去了，又恢复了不开心的状态，只是勉强应付工作。

Your attire will not only change your attitude and your productivity but will also increase your net worth —guaranteed.

你的穿着不仅会改变你的态度和工作效率，而且还会增加你的净资产——这是绝对保证的。

And the opposite is most definitely true. One day I walked into my office and was greeted by our wonderful receptionist when I noticed a disheveled young man sitting in our waiting area. He looked as if he had taken his clothes from the bottom of his laundry basket, rolled out of bed, put on his sneakers, and arrived at my office. I inquired of my assistant who he was, as it appeared he was in need of help.

而事实恰恰相反。有一天，我走进办公室，热情的前台接待员迎接了我，这时我注意到候诊区坐着一位衣衫褴褛的年轻男子。他看起来像是从洗衣篮底下随便抓了件衣服，从床上滚下来，套上运动鞋就到了我的办公室。我问助理他是谁，因为他似乎需要帮助。

She told me he was at my company for an interview for one of our internship programs with the information technology department. Thoughts flashed through my mind: “No person who dresses like that for an interview will be allowed to touch a doorknob at this company, let alone a computer.” I went to my chief information officer and told him to sit this young man down in our beautiful conference room and explain to him immediately why we were not even going to consider his application, and then to hand him a copy of The Go-Getter and The Fred Factor .

她告诉我，他是来我们公司面试信息技术部门的实习生项目的。我脑子里闪过几个念头：“穿成这样来面试的人，连门把手都碰不得，更别说电脑了。” 我去找首席信息官，让他把这个年轻人叫到我们漂亮的会议室里坐下，立刻向他解释为什么我们根本不会考虑他的申请，然后给他一本《积极进取者》和《弗雷德法则》。

I thought it was a generous offer. Remarkably, he stormed out of the conference room, ran outside of our office, and threw the books at our doors while voicing a loud series of expletives. He may be the next Bill Gates or Steve Jobs, but I never would know that by the way he appeared or acted. Because of his poor personal profile, he was never even given the chance to reach his potential at Blue Vase Marketing. I hope someday he grows from that experience and it will be fruitful when he interviews for his next position.

我当时觉得这份工作很慷慨。没想到，他竟然怒气冲冲地走出会议室，跑出我们的办公室，一边咒骂一边把书砸在门上。他或许会成为下一个比尔·盖茨或史蒂夫·乔布斯，但从他的言行举止来看，我根本看不出来。由于他糟糕的个人形象，他甚至没有机会在蓝花瓶营销公司发挥自己的潜力。我希望他能从这段经历中吸取教训，并在下次求职时有所收获。

When I played college football at Springfield College, I never understood why we dressed up to go to the locker room on game day. After all, we were just going to change into a uniform that was going to get very filthy. It didn’t make sense, but I did it because I had to. Then one day it clicked.

我在斯普林菲尔德学院打大学橄榄球的时候，一直不明白为什么比赛日去更衣室要穿正装。毕竟，我们只是换上一套很快就会弄脏的球衣而已。这完全没道理，但我还是照做了，因为我不得不这么做。直到有一天，我突然明白了。

We had a home game and for home games, depending on how far the opposing team had to travel, they arrived either the day of the game or the day before. I can’t remember the team, but I remember watching them exit the bus. Every player had a tie on, some had a suit, others had a blazer, but they all looked like they were ready for business. I remember looking into the eyes of a few players and they all looked back at me with the confidence of being ready for the task. And at that moment I respected them as persons and as a team—not an opponent.

我们有一场主场比赛。主场比赛时，根据对手球队的路程远近，他们通常会在比赛当天或前一天抵达。我不记得那支球队的名字了，但我记得他们下车的情景。每个球员都打着领带，有的穿着西装，有的穿着休闲外套，但他们看起来都做好了比赛的准备。我记得我看着其中几个球员的眼睛，他们也都回望着我，眼神中充满了自信，仿佛已经准备好迎接挑战。那一刻，我由衷地敬佩他们，把他们当作个人，当作一个团队——而不是一个对手。

When we traveled to opposing teams we had uniforms we wore constantly. By the way, this habit translates well into professions that have a uniform. Our uniforms—wind pants and a jacket—were burgundy with white lettering. You could not get on the bus if you did not have your proper attire, and some athletes stayed back because they were not dressed properly. Our uniforms showed solidarity—we were a team and we cared how we looked. It is intimidating to the opposing side when the entire bus of football players steps out looking sharp and all wearing the same thing. I may have only played for division two and division three, but it didn’t matter—we had a dress code, detailed down to our cleats. If anyone was out of dress code, they couldn’t even stand on the sidelines. Plus, our football uniforms had to look nice while playing! Seems crazy, but this proven concept of looking good when you are playing a sport has a direct impact on the quality of play. Try it—it will also improve the quality of your work.

当我们客场挑战对手时，我们会一直穿着统一的队服。顺便说一句，这种习惯也适用于其他需要穿制服的职业。我们的队服——运动裤和夹克——是酒红色的，上面印着白色的字母。如果没有合适的着装，是不能上车的，有些运动员甚至因为着装不合规而被留在后面。我们的队服体现了团结——我们是一个团队，我们很在意自己的形象。当整车橄榄球队员都精神抖擞、穿着统一的队服走下车时，对方球队肯定会感到畏惧。我可能只打过二级和三级联赛，但这并不重要——我们有严格的着装规定，甚至连球鞋都有要求。如果有人着装不符合规定，连场边都不能站。而且，我们的橄榄球队服在比赛时也必须看起来很漂亮！这听起来可能有点不可思议，但事实证明，在运动时保持良好的形象确实会对比赛质量产生直接影响。不妨试试——它也能提升你的工作质量。

Have you ever observed a military platoon that looked all disheveled? No, not unless they were on the battlefield. Their uniforms have a standard: their shoes are so shiny you can see the soldiers’ reflections. If they have medals, they shine so brightly that if the sun reflects off just right you could be blinded. In addition, their uniforms have more starch than a plate of potatoes. Our military and virtually every military around the world understands the importance of looking good. If you don’t care what you look like, then you won’t care about the task at hand.

你见过衣衫褴褛的军队排吗？除非是在战场上，否则肯定不会。他们的制服都有统一的标准：皮鞋锃亮，能照出士兵的倒影。如果他们佩戴勋章，勋章的光泽更是耀眼夺目，阳光照射的角度恰到好处，足以刺瞎你的双眼。此外，他们的制服浆得比一盘土豆还多。我们的军队，以及世界上几乎所有国家的军队，都深知仪容整洁的重要性。如果你不在乎自己的形象，你也不会在乎手头的任务。

Whether you are a home team walking to your locker room on game day or you are dressing for success at work, it shows others you mean business and it tells your subconscious you are about to do something very important. When you are dressed nicely, people respect you and view you differently.

无论你是主场球队在比赛日走向更衣室，还是在工作中盛装打扮，你的穿着都能向他人表明你的认真态度，同时也会潜意识里告诉你，你即将着手处理一件非常重要的事情。当你穿着得体时，人们会尊重你，对你另眼相看。

Tomorrow, whether you have a job or are unemployed, I want you to put on your nicest attire and wear it proudly. Make sure your shirt is ironed, your pants or skirt are wrinkle-free, and your shoes are the best pair you have. If you’re wearing a suit, make sure it is lint-free and that your tie is perfectly tied and centered. Some people may snicker—hand them a copy of my book. Observe how others treat you. If your job doesn’t permit you to do this at work, then I want you to get dressed up in your nicest attire and go to the mall. Just walk into stores, sit down at the food court, and observe how others look at you. Observe how you feel. At first this may seem uncomfortable. Don’t worry; most people in the mall don’t know you. I guarantee you will have a great day and want to dress the same way each day moving forward.

明天，无论你是否有工作，我都希望你穿上你最体面的衣服，并自信地展现出来。确保你的衬衫熨烫平整，裤子或裙子没有褶皱，鞋子是你最好的那双。如果你穿的是西装，请确保它干净无毛絮，领带系得一丝不苟，居中对齐。有些人可能会窃笑——那就递给他们一本我的书。观察一下别人是如何看待你的。如果你的工作不允许你在工作场所这样做，那么我希望你穿上你最体面的衣服去商场。走进商店，在美食广场找个地方坐下，观察别人是如何看你的。观察一下你的感受。一开始你可能会觉得不自在。别担心，商场里的大多数人都不认识你。我保证你会度过美好的一天，并且以后每天都想这样打扮。

I hope I made this point clear. Dress like someone important. You will act important and you will be treated like you are important. This goes for any situation in any place of employment. If you work in a factory and have a uniform, make sure it is clean and pressed; if you work at a fast-food chain, make sure your uniform looks brand new. When I was a kid I was fortunate to get a job at Chuck E. Cheese’s. This beginning job taught me many things about business and how to act in a business environment. My experience was over twenty years ago, and Chuck E. Cheese’s is still thriving. I worked in the kitchen, and our uniform was a red shirt, a hat, khaki pants, and white shoes. I made sure my pants were always clean, my shirt was ironed, and my shoes were clean. This can be difficult when you are working in a kitchen. But, at fifteen, I was well respected by management, became a kitchen team leader, and regularly received raises without asking. Your appearance speaks not only to the people who are looking at you; it also speaks to your conscious and subconscious mind, letting both of them know that you are .

我希望我已经把这一点说清楚了。穿衣打扮要像个重要人物。你会表现得重要，别人也会像对待重要人物一样对待你。这适用于任何场合、任何工作场所。如果你在工厂工作，有制服，一定要确保它干净整洁；如果你在快餐连锁店工作，一定要确保你的制服看起来崭新如初。我小时候很幸运地在Chuck E. Cheese’s找到了一份工作。这份工作教会了我很多关于商业以及如何在商业环境中行事的知识。我的经历发生在二十多年前，而Chuck E. Cheese’s至今仍然生意兴隆。我在厨房工作，我们的制服是红色衬衫、帽子、卡其色裤子和白色鞋子。我总是确保我的裤子干净、衬衫熨烫平整、鞋子干净。在厨房工作，做到这一点并不容易。但是，十五岁时，我就受到了管理层的尊重，成为了厨房团队的负责人，并且经常在不主动要求的情况下获得加薪。你的外表不仅会影响到那些看着你的人；它还能与你的意识和潜意识对话，让它们都知道你的存在。

TIP: Don’t know how to tie a tie? Go to YouTube.com ; there are dozens of great videos. I even watched YouTube to learn how to tie a Windsor knot!

小贴士：不知道怎么打领带？去YouTube看看，上面有很多很棒的视频。我甚至在YouTube上学过怎么打温莎结！

TIP: Spend more and buy less. You will find that buying a quality suit and quality shoes will go much further than buying multiple suits and shoes for the same price.

建议：多花点钱，少买点东西。你会发现，买一套优质西装和一双优质皮鞋，比花同样的钱买多套西装和多双鞋要划算得多。

COMPLIMENT YOUR PEERS WITH SINCERITY

真诚地赞美你的同伴

A sincere compliment to your peers goes a long way in the work-a-day world. When a woman changes a hairstyle and you genuinely like it, or when a colleague has a sharp suit on, there is nothing wrong with saying things like, “Linda, I like what you have done with your hair. It looks great,” “Sarah, that is a terrific suit. You look great in red,” “Jason, that blazer looks sharp,” “John, nice tie. I like the color,” “Skip, those are some really nice shoes,” or, “Shauna, that is a nice suit.”

在日常工作中，真诚地赞美同事往往能起到意想不到的效果。当一位女士换了发型，而你真心喜欢时，或者当一位同事穿了一套帅气的西装时，你可以这样说：“琳达，你的发型真好看，很棒！”“莎拉，这套西装太棒了，你穿红色真好看！”“杰森，你的西装外套真帅！”“约翰，你的领带真好看，颜色我也很喜欢！”“斯基普，你的鞋子真漂亮！”或者“肖娜，你的西装真好看！”

People appreciate being noticed, and they will reciprocate. Ultimately, they will like being around you, and if you are their boss, they will work harder for you. Now unfortunately, in today’s age people are very concerned with sexual harassment and political correctness. Sometimes, even basic compliments can be misinterpreted. So I advise you to use this technique with caution.

人们喜欢被关注，也会给予回应。最终，他们会喜欢和你在一起，如果你是他们的老板，他们会更努力地为你工作。然而，不幸的是，在当今社会，人们非常关注性骚扰和政治正确。有时，即使是简单的赞美也可能被误解。所以我建议你谨慎使用这种方法。

BE SOCIAL—NOT JUST WITH MEDIA

要积极参与社交活动——不仅仅是与媒体互动

It seems that just as technology begins to make our lives easier it also makes us more introverted. Next time you are in a mall, notice that more than half of the people have their head down—looking at their smartphones. Go into a bar and you will spot dozens of people oblivious to their surroundings, texting or playing games on their phones. When you are in an elevator, take notice of how many people are looking down at their phones.

科技在让我们的生活更便捷的同时，似乎也让我们变得更加内向。下次你去商场时，不妨留意一下，超过一半的人都低着头，盯着自己的智能手机。走进酒吧，你会看到几十个人对周围的一切浑然不觉，只顾着发短信或玩游戏。当你乘坐电梯时，也要注意一下有多少人低头看着手机。

One of the best ways to gain an opportunity for employment is through your social circles. The good jobs are never in the help wanted section of newspapers or listed on the job boards. One lawyer who worked for me for a while also happens to be a very good friend from high school, and although I’m not a fan of nepotism, I hired him. I had not seen him for a while, but I met another friend out for dinner and a couple of drinks, and, lo and behold, my old high school buddy—who is extremely smart—was looking for something more than what he was doing. I told him that I had an opening. After going through an interview—more like just catching up and discussing what the position required—I hired him, and he is doing an amazing job. He hit the ground running and has made positive changes for my company.

获得就业机会的最佳途径之一就是利用你的社交圈。好工作从来不会出现在报纸的招聘广告栏目或求职网站上。我曾经的一位律师同事恰好是我高中时的挚友，虽然我并不赞成裙带关系，但我还是录用了他。我有一段时间没见到他了，但有一次我和另一个朋友一起吃饭喝酒，结果发现我这位非常聪明的高中老友正在寻找新的工作机会。我告诉他我公司正好有个空缺。经过一番“面试”（其实更像是叙旧和讨论职位要求），我录用了他，他现在做得非常出色。他很快就上手了，并为我的公司带来了积极的改变。

I’m not suggesting that you go to your local pub looking for a job, but I am suggesting that you get out of the house, put away your phone, tablet, PC, or whatever device you now use to communicate, and start talking to people. Last time I checked, people still have to talk to each other at some point in order to get things done.

我不是建议你去当地酒吧找工作，而是建议你走出家门，放下手机、平板电脑、电脑或其他任何你用来通讯的设备，开始和人交谈。据我所知，人们在做事情的时候仍然需要互相交流。

BECOME A MEMBER OF YOUR LOCAL BNI GROUP

加入您当地的BNI小组

Business Network International (BNI) is an organization that gets people together in their respective communities in a professional setting. The costs are minimal, and many times you can tag along with a friend. Their mission statement explains it all: “The mission of BNI is to help members increase their business through a structured, positive, and professional ‘word-of-mouth’ program that enables them to develop long-term, meaningful relationships with quality business professionals.” There you will meet people in your community who are successful, and many times these people are employers looking for quality people. You can go to www.bni.com to learn more about the organization, and I highly recommend doing so. No matter what your profession or trade, from carpentry to dentistry, joining a local BNI group will certainly provide you with more opportunities. There are several other organizations, like Toastmasters, which also increase your social circle. Toastmasters is also inexpensive and a great organization where you can meet successful people in your area and improve your communication skills. Their website is www.toastmasters.org . Other organizations to increase your prospective employment opportunities are the Shriners, Lions Club, and the Masonic Lodge. Not only do these organizations do wonderful things for the community, but many of their members are also professionals in your area.

国际商业网络 (BNI) 是一个将人们聚集在各自社区的专业组织。费用低廉，而且很多时候你可以带朋友一起参加。他们的使命宣言解释了一切：“BNI 的使命是通过结构化、积极且专业的‘口碑’计划，帮助会员拓展业务，使他们能够与优秀的商业人士建立长期、有意义的关系。” 在这里，你会结识社区里的成功人士，其中很多都是正在寻找优秀人才的雇主。你可以访问 www.bni.com 了解更多关于该组织的信息，我强烈建议你这样做。无论你的职业是什么，从木匠到牙医，加入当地的 BNI 小组无疑会为你提供更多机会。还有其他一些组织，例如 Toastmasters（国际演讲会），也能拓展你的社交圈。Toastmasters 的费用也不高，而且是一个很棒的组织，你可以在这里结识你所在地区的成功人士，并提升你的沟通技巧。他们的网站是 www.toastmasters.org。其他有助于提升就业机会的组织包括：Shriners（施莱纳兄弟会）、狮子会和共济会。这些组织不仅为社区做出了卓越贡献，而且其成员中也有许多是您所在领域的专业人士。

EXPLOIT OPPORTUNITY

把握机会

Any time you are given an opportunity at your employment, whatever it is, take it on with enthusiasm and give that opportunity your absolute best. When working in the kitchen at Chuck E. Cheese’s when I was a kid, I noticed there were different tasks that were more important. Only management made the dough, the key ingredient and foundation of the pizza. At the time I was allowed to make the pizzas, prep them, and prepare other food selections. I was also allowed to help in many other areas of the kitchen as the pizza chef as well. But then one morning I was given the opportunity—in the following I discuss the difference between an opportunity and responsibility—to work with my manager at making and kneading the dough. The process is more complex than simply mixing water and flour, and I was given an opportunity to learn. Over time, I learned the process and very soon, I was given the responsibility of making the dough—again increasing my net worth . By the time I left Chuck E. Cheese’s at seventeen, I was running the kitchen. This may seem trivial, but I realized that when given an opportunity to learn more about a current employer, you should do it; you become more valuable to the organization.

无论何时，只要工作中出现机会，无论是什么，都要满怀热情地抓住它，并全力以赴。我小时候在Chuck E. Cheese’s的厨房打工时，就注意到有些工作更重要。只有管理层才能制作面团，而面团是披萨的关键原料和基础。当时，我被允许制作披萨、准备食材以及其他一些食物。作为披萨师傅，我也被允许在厨房的其他许多方面提供帮助。但有一天早上，我得到了一个机会——接下来我会讨论机会和责任之间的区别——和我的经理一起制作和揉面。这个过程比简单地把水和面粉混合要复杂得多，我得到了学习的机会。随着时间的推移，我掌握了制作面团的技巧，很快，我就被委以重任，负责制作面团——这再次提升了我的价值。到我十七岁离开Chuck E. Cheese’s时，我已经能够管理整个厨房了。这看似微不足道，但我意识到，当有机会更多地了解当前雇主时，你应该这样做；你会对组织更有价值。

I often hear, “I wasn’t hired for that,” or “I went to college and shouldn’t be doing that” from the Y generation, and it scares me to think about what that generation will be like in the future and how they will run this country.

我经常听到Y世代的人说：“我不是来做这个的”，或者“我上过大学，不应该做这个”，想到他们未来会变成什么样，以及他们将如何治理这个国家，我就感到害怕。

OPPORTUNITY: a situation created by you that allows you to achieve your goals .

机会：由你创造的、能够让你实现目标的局面。

About a year ago, I made it mandatory that every person in my office learn how to make a sale on the phone. Everyone from Nate and Chris in information technology to the people in my accounting department had to learn how to make a sale. Why did I do this? Sure, I wanted to increase our productivity, but I was also giving everyone an opportunity , in addition to testing my employees’ drive and willingness to be a part of the team.

大约一年前，我强制要求办公室里的每个人都要学习如何通过电话销售。从信息技术部的内特和克里斯到会计部门的员工，每个人都必须学习销售技巧。我为什么要这么做？当然，我希望提高我们的工作效率，但我也想给每个人一个机会，同时检验员工的积极性和团队合作精神。

Unbeknownst to me, my accountant—whose office was across the hall from mine—packed up everything in his office and left for the night. He came back the next day and worked, but I didn’t go in his office until a few nights later, when I discovered that his office was stripped of all personal belongings. I called him in a panic, and he told me that he did that because he felt it was beneath him to “take sales calls,” and that this was not why he went to college. I explained to him that by taking sales calls it would give him a better idea of our operations, possibly improve our profitability, and ultimately increase his net worth. Then I fired him.

我毫不知情，我的会计——他的办公室就在我办公室对面——把办公室里的东西都打包好就离开了。第二天他回来上班了，但我直到几天后的晚上才去他的办公室，发现他办公室里所有个人物品都被搬空了。我惊慌失措地给他打电话，他告诉我，他这么做是因为他觉得“接销售电话”有失身份，而且他上大学也不是为了这个。我向他解释说，接销售电话能让他更好地了解我们的运营情况，有可能提高我们的盈利能力，最终还能增加他的个人财富。然后我就把他解雇了。

Ask yourself this question: “If I were the boss, what would I do?” You see, if you think you are too good for something, or if when called upon to help you do so begrudgingly, you hurt yourself and the company. There is a school of thought in the business world that executives shouldn’t get their hands dirty. That is a risky business philosophy and increases the gap between subordinates and executives; in essence, the guys at the top lose touch with reality. I do everything—I take customer service calls, I take out the trash, I make coffee or copies when necessary. It keeps me in touch with my company.

问问自己这个问题：“如果我是老板，我会怎么做？” 你看，如果你觉得自己高人一等，不屑于做某件事，或者被要求帮忙时很不情愿，你不仅会伤害自己，也会伤害公司。商界有一种观点认为，高管不应该亲力亲为。这是一种危险的商业理念，会加剧下属和高管之间的隔阂；本质上，高层会脱离实际。我什么都做——接听客服电话，倒垃圾，必要时还会煮咖啡或复印文件。这让我与公司保持紧密联系。

When you think like the boss, you may someday become the boss. When given an opportunity, embrace it, exploit it, and learn from it to increase your net worth ! No task is too big or too small.

当你拥有老板的思维方式时，你终有一天会成为老板。当机会来临时，要牢牢把握，充分利用，并从中学习，从而提升你的价值！没有任务是太大或太小的。

TAKE ON ADDITIONAL RESPONSIBILITY

承担额外责任

If you merely want to get by, I am sorry for that. But if you are reading this book, I believe it’s because you desire more from life. If you are given additional responsibilities, embrace them. Additional responsibility and opportunities may overlap. But additional responsibility is generally a task that is an extension or a part of your current career. For example, when I hired a lawyer who works in my legal department (the buddy I ran into at the local pub), his responsibility was contracts and compliance. He did not have a lot of legal experience, but in just under a year, he handled every aspect of my business that has any legal implication—which, by the way, is everything !

如果你只是想勉强糊口，我很遗憾。但如果你在读这本书，我相信是因为你渴望拥有更精彩的人生。如果你被赋予了额外的责任，请欣然接受。额外的责任和机遇或许会重叠，但通常来说，额外的责任是你现有工作的延伸或组成部分。例如，我聘请了一位在我法务部门工作的律师（我在当地酒吧偶遇的那位朋友），他的职责是合同和合规。他并没有太多的法律经验，但在不到一年的时间里，他就处理了我公司所有涉及法律的事务——顺便说一句，几乎所有事务都涉及法律！

I gave him the opportunity to learn the different facets of my business and entrusted him with this responsibility. I gave him the opportunity to make a few sales calls to understand the sales process, so that he could better serve the company and increase his knowledge and net worth . Each day that went by he increased his value to the company and his personal net worth . You see, his additional responsibility is also a bigger opportunity to learn different aspects of the law while being employed, and it makes him more valuable to the company.

我给了他学习我公司各个方面的机会，并委以重任。我让他打了一些销售电话，了解销售流程，以便他能更好地为公司服务，提升自身知识水平和个人价值。随着时间的推移，他对公司的价值和个人价值都在不断增长。你看，他承担的额外职责也为他提供了更多学习法律知识的机会，使他在工作的同时也能学习法律的各个方面，从而提升了他对公司的价值。

I mentioned the story of my dad and the technique he used to increase his net worth during tough economic times in a television advertisement for my book. My dad is a machinist and almost sixty-two. He has been with the same company for almost ten years but has always just been a machinist. I used to discuss with him that I thought he should try to climb the ladder and become a foreman or a shift supervisor, but he was nervous about “rocking the boat.” You see, his environment seemed pretty oppressive, or at least this is what I perceived it to be like.

我在为我的书做的电视广告里提到了我父亲的故事，以及他在经济困难时期如何增加净资产的方法。我父亲是一名机械师，快六十二岁了。他在同一家公司工作了近十年，但一直只是个机械师。我以前常跟他讨论，我觉得他应该努力晋升，当个工头或者班组长，但他担心“惹麻烦”。你知道，他当时的工作环境似乎很压抑，至少我是这么觉得的。

Recently, his company, like many others, experienced significant layoffs. He watched his peers get fired or laid off, and to make matters worse, my dad came down with Bell’s palsy, which required him to take a temporary leave of absence. When I was discussing my book with my dad, he asked me what he should do. I told him to do two things. Number one, take on more responsibility, and number two, exploit any opportunity given to him. I told him that most people, when surrounded with doom and gloom, wait around like cattle standing to be slaughtered. I told my dad that if he applied these two very basic and simple techniques, he would increase his personal net worth and eventually even increase his pay, despite others being let go.

最近，他所在的公司和许多其他公司一样，经历了大规模裁员。他眼睁睁地看着同事们被解雇或裁员，更糟糕的是，我父亲患上了贝尔氏麻痹症，不得不暂时休假。我和父亲讨论我的书时，他问我该怎么办。我告诉他两件事：第一，承担更多责任；第二，抓住一切机会。我告诉他，大多数人在身处逆境时，就像待宰的羔羊一样坐以待毙。我告诉父亲，如果他能运用这两个简单易行的基本方法，即使其他人被裁员，他也能增加个人财富，最终甚至能提高自己的收入。

My dad decided to take an active role in a safety committee at work. This was an opportunity he had been given a while ago, but this time he exploited the opportunity. He told me about a meeting he was in, and how the new chief operating officer took notice and began to seek my dad’s advice.

我父亲决定积极参与公司安全委员会的工作。其实他之前就曾有机会参与其中，但这次他抓住了这个机会。他跟我讲了他参加的一次会议，以及新任首席运营官如何注意到他，并开始征求他的意见。

Just being on the safety committee was an opportunity. After I explained more of the Ask More, Get More techniques, he has become the lead man in the safety committee and additional upper management has taken notice. During this downtime my father made the decision to work even harder and longer than he has in the past. Sometimes, he is working when he is not even on the clock.

仅仅是加入安全委员会本身就是一个机会。在我进一步解释了“多问多得”的技巧之后，他成为了安全委员会的负责人，也引起了高层管理人员的注意。在这段空闲时间里，我父亲决定比以往更加努力、更加长时间地工作。有时，他甚至在下班时间也在工作。

He also decided to take on more responsibility without being asked. He took it upon himself to help others around him and to take on more tasks for himself. I am happy to say that my dad now feels more secure than ever. He is not worried about losing his job and, God forbid, even if he were to lose it, he is now more valuable to other prospective employers. He can even use these experiences as part of his interview process. These are very simple, easy, and effective ways to increase your net worth in any job, and this works in any industry.

他还主动承担了更多责任。他主动帮助身边的人，也主动承担了更多自己的工作。我很高兴地说，我父亲现在比以往任何时候都更有安全感。他不再担心失去工作，而且，即便真的失去了工作，他现在对其他潜在雇主来说也更有价值了。他甚至可以把这些经历作为面试的一部分。这些都是非常简单、轻松且有效的方法，可以提升你在任何工作中的价值，而且适用于任何行业。

INTERVIEWING

面试

There are entire books and courses dedicated to the employment interview process. The interview is your first step to getting hired and should be taken very seriously. But I just want to say a few things about it here, since in an interview you also have a chance to increase your value, and there are specific ways to do it.

市面上有很多书籍和课程专门讲解求职面试流程。面试是你获得工作的第一步，务必认真对待。但我在这里只想简单提几句，因为面试也是你展现自身价值的机会，而且有一些具体的方法可以做到这一点。

Earlier I mentioned my confident—some would say cocky—attitude while interviewing. It is important to be careful not to cross the line from confidence to cockiness. If you appear to be cocky or act like a know-it-all, then you will not get hired. However, someone who is confident has a better shot.

我之前提到过我在面试时表现出的自信——有些人可能会说是自大。重要的是要小心，不要从自信变成自大。如果你显得自大或者一副什么都懂的样子，那么你就不会被录用。但是，自信的人成功的几率更大。

One very important thing you need to do prior to your interview is to set up a few mock interviews with your friends or family members and treat this mock interview as if it were the real thing. Create a realistic setting; if possible, use a conference room or a desk. Dress as if you were at the interview, and have your résumé ready and with you. If you have a camera, record the interview and see if you have a nervous twitch, repeat yourself, or say “umm” constantly. Practice the interview before the real thing, so that you are prepared to answer the tough questions. Most important, you will be more comfortable with the interview process, as interviews can be intimidating.

面试前，你需要做的一件非常重要的事情就是和朋友或家人进行几次模拟面试，并像对待正式面试一样认真对待。尽可能营造一个真实的面试环境；如果可以，可以使用会议室或办公桌。穿着得体，就像真的要去面试一样，并准备好简历。如果你有摄像机，可以录下整个过程，看看自己是否会紧张地抽搐、重复说话或不停地说“嗯”。在正式面试前进行充分的练习，这样你才能从容应对各种棘手的问题。最重要的是，你会更加适应面试流程，因为面试可能会让人感到紧张。

Tips:

尖端：

  • Always wear a suit to an interview.


    面试时一定要穿西装。
  • Always be positive, even when discussing your previous employment.


    即使在谈论你之前的工作时，也要保持积极的态度。
  • Be confident but not cocky.


    要自信，但不要自大。
  • Be prepared.


    做好准备。
  • Know the company you are interviewing with.


    了解你面试的公司。

A TIME TO JUST BE

一段静谧的时光

When I was a young lawyer a family member said to me one day that I was a lawyer now and I should start acting like one. What does a lawyer act like? There are plenty of jokes that answer that question, but just because I was now a lawyer I was not going to be someone else.

我年轻时当律师，有一天一位家人对我说，既然我现在是律师了，就应该像个律师一样行事。律师应该怎么做呢？关于这个问题，有很多笑话可以解答，但即便我现在是律师，我也不会变成另一个人。

I went to law school nights at Suffolk University in Boston. My first night in class the professor asked us to introduce ourselves. There were about 150 students in the class, and most of them were working professionals in Boston. Most were at major law firms, many had degrees from Harvard, Cornell, MIT, or Boston University, and seemed very serious. When it came to me, I said, “My name is Mike, I sell cars at North Shore Lincoln Mercury in Peabody, and if anyone needs a car, come see me.” The whole room broke out in laughter, and I must admit I was a little embarrassed. But, I was just being me . After that introduction I had several students approach me and tell me how much they enjoyed my candor and thought what I said was humorous. But one guy who approached me ended up becoming one of my closest friends. He later told me that he knew from what I said that I was a good guy and wasn’t fake. Which is true; I was just being me ! I made a lifelong friend who is very successful in his own world, and it may have never happened if I wasn’t just me . And by the way … I ended up selling two cars to two of my classmates.

我在波士顿萨福克大学参加了法学院的夜间课程。第一节课，教授让我们自我介绍。班上大约有150名学生，大部分都是在波士顿工作的专业人士。他们大多就职于大型律师事务所，许多人拥有哈佛、康奈尔、麻省理工或波士顿大学的学位，看起来都很严肃认真。轮到我时，我说：“我叫迈克，在皮博迪的北岸林肯水星汽车公司卖车，如果有人需要买车，就来找我。”全班哄堂大笑，我得承认，我当时有点尴尬。但我只是做我自己而已。自我介绍之后，有好几个学生走过来跟我说，他们很喜欢我的坦率，觉得我说的话很幽默。其中一个走过来跟我说话的男生后来成了我最亲密的朋友之一。他后来告诉我，他从我的言谈中看出我是一个好人，不虚伪。的确如此；我只是做我自己而已！我交到了一个终生挚友，他在自己的领域非常成功。如果不是因为我，这一切或许都不会发生。顺便一提……我还把两辆车卖给了我的两个同学。

A few months ago in one of my Bikram yoga classes, at the end, when we were essentially meditating, the instructor said that sometimes we have to just be. Most people would define my personality as a type-A: one who is always going and doing things and just pushing forward. But sometimes you have to just be . I had a real hard time conceptualizing what that really means. After actually discussing this with many people, I came to understand that just being is just being you, taking notice of who you are, and just focusing on the small things in life. It is also understanding who you are as a person. As we age, we grow individually, and knowing yourself and who you are evolves. But, sometimes stepping back and just being is crucial to understanding where you want to go and what you want to do. I am very fortunate that I can just be essentially when I want. Ask More, Get More is not only about financial freedom and success, but it is also about you being able to be you .

几个月前，在我的一次高温瑜伽课上，临近结束时，我们正进行冥想练习，老师说，有时候我们需要做的就是“存在”。大多数人会把我归类为A型人格：总是忙碌不停，不断前进。但有时候，你必须“存在”。我当时很难理解这句话的真正含义。在和很多人讨论之后，我逐渐明白，“存在”就是做你自己，关注你是谁，专注于生活中的点滴。它也意味着了解你作为一个人是谁。随着年龄的增长，我们每个人都在成长，对自我的认知也在不断变化。但是，有时候，退后一步，静下心来“存在”对于理解你想去哪里、想做什么至关重要。我很幸运，我可以随时随地“存在”。《多问，多得》这本书不仅仅关乎财务自由和成功，更关乎你能够做你自己。

When you are having a tough day, step back and just be . It may actually be one of the greatest ways to increase your perceived value.

当你遇到困难时，不妨停下来，静静地待着。这或许是提升自身价值的最佳方法之一。

#↩

PART II

第二部分

ASK MORE FROM OTHERS

对他人提出更高要求

#↩

CHAPTER 5

第五章

BE PREPARED TO ASK FOR MORE

做好要求更多要求的准备

“KNOW” BEFORE THEY SAY “NO”—HOW TO GET READY FOR THE BATTLE FOR MORE!

在他们说“不”之前“了解”——如何为争取更多做好准备！

Why are we afraid of being sold goods and services? Why are salespeople considered bad people? We live in a society and world that buys and sells things. People in other countries and cultures hard-sell things to each other every day. If you have ever been to a tropical island or a major city in other countries, street vendors constantly try to sell you their goods. It is just a way of life.

为什么我们会害怕被推销商品和服务？为什么推销员会被认为是坏人？我们生活在一个买卖商品的社会和世界里。其他国家和文化中的人们每天都在互相推销商品。如果你去过热带岛屿或其他国家的大城市，你会发现街头小贩会不断地向你兜售商品。这只是一种生活方式。

In upcoming chapters, I discuss negotiation and how we, as human beings, also resist the activity of negotiation. But, when we buy something, pay for something, purchase something, or sell something, most of us are uneasy or get nervous about these activities. The fact is, since the beginning of time we have bought, sold, paid for , and purchased things one way or another. Buying and selling things has made the world go round since the beginning of time.

在接下来的章节中，我将探讨谈判，以及我们作为人类，是如何抗拒谈判的。但是，当我们买东西、付钱、购买或出售东西时，大多数人都会感到不安或紧张。事实上，自古以来，我们就一直在以各种方式买卖东西。自古以来，买卖就推动着世界的运转。

Before currency, we bartered: “I will give you three sheep for your cow.” The bartering system inherently had negotiation built into it. There wasn’t really a set value for a pig or a cow. For example, does a barren cow have more or less value than one that could give birth to a calf? It all depends on what you want the cow to do. So, if you had a barren cow and you wanted to sell it, you would have to negotiate with the other party and convince them as to why that barren cow was good for the buyer, and conversely, the other person involved would have to convince you why they want to pay less for your cow, and that their commodity was worth more to you than you were asking.

在货币出现之前，我们以物易物：“我用三只羊换你的牛。”这种物物交换方式本身就包含谈判的成分。猪或牛并没有固定的价值。例如，一头不育的母牛比一头能生小牛的母牛更有价值还是更没价值？这完全取决于你希望这头牛做什么。所以，如果你有一头不育的母牛想卖掉，你就必须和对方谈判，说服他们这头不育的母牛对买家有好处；反之，对方也必须说服你，为什么他们愿意出更低的价格买你的牛，以及为什么他们的牛对你来说比你开价更高。
