Though the concept of bartering has been lost in modern economies like the United States, all over the world there are companies where you can get things for only the cost of your skills. For instance, if you are a lawyer and you need to have your cabinets refinished, you can go to places like SwapRight.com , where you essentially trade your services. There are many different types of companies similar to the above example. It is free to join and you can get things done without actually exchanging money.

虽然以物易物的概念在像美国这样的现代经济体中已经消失，但在世界各地，仍然有一些公司允许你仅用自己的技能换取所需物品。例如，如果你是一名律师，需要翻新橱柜，你可以访问像SwapRight.com这样的网站，在那里你可以用自己的服务进行交换。还有许多其他类型的公司也与上述例子类似。加入这些网站是免费的，而且你无需实际支付金钱就能完成交易。

3 P’S + 1 P

3个P + 1个P

So if buying and selling has been around forever, then why are people still so afraid of it? The real answer is that we do not trust salespeople and we also lack confidence in ourselves. One very important technique that will alleviate the fear of being taken advantage of by what you may perceive as an unscrupulous salesperson is my “3 P’s + 1 P” technique: Prepare, prepare, prepare + prepare one more time. Prepare for the purchase by researching everything possible about the item you intend to purchase. Once you have exhausted this tactic, prepare for it again as if you didn’t do it before. Repeat that one more time, and then finally, prepare again . Seems unnecessary, right? Well, it isn’t. Successful people, wealthy people, and happy people are prepared for whatever comes their way. 3 P’s + 1 P will improve your success rate in anything you do.

既然买卖由来已久，为什么人们至今仍然如此害怕它呢？真正的原因在于我们不信任销售人员，也缺乏自信。一个能有效缓解被你眼中那些不择手段的销售人员欺骗恐惧的重要技巧，就是我的“3P+1P”法则：准备，准备，再准备一次。首先，尽可能多地研究你打算购买的商品，为购买做好准备。当你完成这一步后，再像之前从未做过一样，重新做好准备。重复一次，最后，再准备一次。听起来似乎没必要，对吧？其实不然。成功人士、富人和快乐的人都为即将到来的一切做好了准备。“3P+1P”法则能提高你在任何事情上的成功率。

The book Outliers by Malcolm Gladwell edified my method by attempting to find the common denominators in successful people. One thing that seemed to be clear was that in order to be successful in anything, you need to put in 10,000 hours worth of work. Glad-well goes on to discuss professional athletes, businessmen like Bill Gates, and musicians like the Beatles. They all prepared for their success. The Beatles played almost every day all over Europe for two years before anyone knew who they were. Bill Gates was programming computers in middle school. Being prepared eliminates the fear of being “sold.” It also eliminates the fear of buying things and feeling bad about it. You will no longer think, “did I pay too much,” “is this the best brand,” or, “do I need this item?” Many of us get what we call “buyer’s remorse,” which ruins the positive experience of buying things. If you apply the 3 P’s + 1 P technique in any situation, whether buying, selling, taking an exam, or preparing for a meeting, you will ultimately be more successful and fulfilled. And if you are the type of person who just wings it and you still get by, then by using my system of 3 P’s + 1 P, you will achieve more success than you ever imagined.

马尔科姆·格拉德威尔的《异类》一书启发了我，它试图找出成功人士的共同点。其中一点似乎很明确：要想在任何领域取得成功，都需要投入相当于一万小时的努力。格拉德威尔接着探讨了职业运动员、像比尔·盖茨这样的商人以及像披头士乐队这样的音乐家。他们都为自己的成功做好了充分的准备。披头士乐队在成名之前，几乎每天都在欧洲各地演出，持续了两年之久。比尔·盖茨在中学时就开始编写计算机程序了。做好准备可以消除被“推销”的恐惧，也能消除买东西后后悔的恐惧。你不再会想“我买贵了吗”、“这是最好的品牌吗”或者“我需要这件东西吗？”我们很多人都会有所谓的“买家后悔”，这会破坏购物的积极体验。无论在买东西、卖东西、参加考试还是准备会议，只要你运用“3P+1P”技巧，最终都会更加成功，更有成就感。如果你是那种随性而为、勉强应付的人，那么运用我的“3P+1P”体系，你将取得远超想象的成功。

I am a licensed attorney in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, but in order to become licensed you need to pass the bar exam, a test that many say is the most difficult standardized test among professionals. It is certainly not an exam where you can just wing it (unless you are Leonardo DiCaprio in the film Catch Me If You Can ). I had the unpleasant experience of not passing the bar exam by the margin of a single question. When it’s that close, the entire exam goes before committees to review again to make sure the results are correct. And supposedly you usually get “bumped up” and they pass you. Well, that did not happen to me; I did not pass the bar exam.

我是马萨诸塞州的一名执业律师，但要获得执业资格，必须通过律师资格考试。许多人认为这是专业人士中最难的标准化考试。这绝对不是一场可以侥幸通过的考试（除非你是电影《逍遥法外》里的莱昂纳多·迪卡普里奥）。我曾有过一次不愉快的经历，仅仅因为一题之差就与律师资格考试失之交臂。在这种情况下，整份试卷都会提交给委员会重新审核，以确保结果的正确性。据说，通常情况下，你的成绩会被“提升”，从而通过考试。然而，我并没有遇到这种情况；我最终没能通过律师资格考试。

Two weeks before the exam, I was talking with a friend of mine around 11:00 in the evening in the local library. My friend told me how he could literally recall his notes that he had taken over the past eleven weeks . I said to myself, “Eleven weeks!” I had only been studying for about three weeks, and that was during off hours and on the weekends. When I got the envelope in the mail and it started out by saying, “We regret to inform,” it felt like someone had punched me in the stomach and kicked my dog. My classmates called to console me, but after the initial shock, I realized the reason I didn’t pass is because I wasn’t prepared the first time. People said things like, “Well, John F. Kennedy Jr. took the exam five times, and many people take it twice.” But there was nothing anyone could say to make me feel better. That November day when I opened the first letter after waiting almost six months for the results, I told myself I would be more prepared than any other candidate the second time around.

考试前两周，晚上11点左右，我在当地图书馆和朋友聊天。朋友告诉我，他竟然还能回忆起过去11周做的笔记。我心想：“11周！”我才复习了大概3周，而且还是利用课余时间和周末。收到信封，看到开头写着“很遗憾地通知您”，我感觉就像被人狠狠地打了一拳，又被人踢了一脚。同学们打电话来安慰我，但最初的震惊过后，我意识到自己没考过的原因是因为第一次准备不足。有人说：“约翰·F·肯尼迪二世考了五次，很多人考两次。”但这些话都无法让我感觉好一些。在等待了近六个月后，我终于在11月打开了第一封成绩单。我告诉自己，第二次我一定要比任何考生都准备得更充分。

I studied night and day, for a minimum of ten hours a day, for thirteen weeks straight. Every day! It was exhausting and difficult. I did not talk to friends, I barely talked with family, I lived on protein bars and caffeine, and I had a permanent spot at my local library. I actually trained my brain to have photographic recall, like my friend had. I had close to 300 handwritten pages of notes, meticulously organized by subject. I could close my eyes and see my notes, every word. It was remarkable, and I was prepared.

我日夜苦读，每天至少十个小时，连续十三周。每天都如此！这真是筋疲力尽，无比艰难。我不跟朋友说话，几乎不跟家人联系，只靠蛋白棒和咖啡因度日，还在当地图书馆占了个固定位置。我甚至像我朋友那样，训练自己拥有过目不忘的本领。我手写了将近三百页笔记，按主题一丝不苟地整理好。我闭上眼睛就能看到笔记，一个字都清晰可见。这真是太神奇了，我做好了充分的准备。

When the time came to sit for the bar exam, I felt that I knew more about the law than any person in that room, including all of the Harvard Law graduates. The exam takes two days, and when you walk into the large room, you see hundreds of people in various states of anxiety, all hoping to be lawyers. The ones you can almost guarantee will not pass are the ones walking in with notes, frantically looking down at them, trying to cram last-minute facts into their brains. I walked in the first day with just my driver’s license and my #2 pencils. I knew I was prepared. After the first day, I did not think about the first day’s questions or whether I got them right or wrong; I went to the gym, had dinner, watched a little television, and briefly went over the subjects that were going to come up the next day. On day two, I walked in confident, ready to show the Board of Bar Overseers that I was prepared and a worthy candidate to be a member of the bar. Several months later I got the envelope and it told me what I already knew—I passed.

到了参加律师资格考试的时候，我觉得自己比在场的任何人都更懂法律，包括所有哈佛法学院的毕业生。考试为期两天，走进考场，你会看到数百人，他们焦虑不安，都渴望成为律师。那些拿着笔记进来，慌慌张张地低头看着笔记，试图把考前最后一点知识点塞进脑子里的人，几乎肯定考不过。第一天，我只带了驾照和两支2号铅笔就进去了。我知道自己已经准备好了。第一天结束后，我没有去想第一天的考题，也没有去想自己答对了还是答错了；我去健身房锻炼，吃了晚饭，看了会儿电视，然后简单地复习了一下第二天要考的内容。第二天，我信心满满地走进考场，准备向律师资格考试委员会证明，我已经做好了充分的准备，是一个合格的律师候选人。几个月后，我收到了信封，里面的内容证实了我早已知道的事实——我通过了。

The 3 P’s + 1 P helped ensure that I was going to pass. The funny thing is that when you pass the bar exam, you do not know your score; you only receive your score when you don’t pass. But, I would be willing to bet that I was in the top 10 percent of the candidates on those two days. Then in June of 2004, I was sworn in at the historic Faneuil Hall in Boston, Massachusetts, and signed my name in the same book as the second president of the United States, John Adams.

3P+1P 确保了我顺利通过考试。有趣的是，通过律师资格考试后，你并不知道自己的分数；只有没通过时才会收到分数。但我敢打赌，在那两天里，我的成绩绝对排在前10%。2004年6月，我在马萨诸塞州波士顿历史悠久的法尼尔厅宣誓就职，并在美国第二任总统约翰·亚当斯的签名簿上签了名。

KNOW WHAT YOU WANT TO—OR SHOULD I SAY WILL —ACHIEVE

知道你想——或者应该说，将会——取得什么成就

Remember the story about my Rolex watch? That was something that I wanted. As I said in the story, my high school buddies had a different set of “wants.” Some would consider a Rolex a gluttonous piece of jewelry. However, it was a goal I set that I achieved. Is a Rolex something you want? Well, only you can determine that. And what you want is something that you do need to determine.

还记得我那块劳力士手表的故事吗？那是我梦寐以求的东西。正如我在故事里提到的，我的高中朋友们有着截然不同的“渴望”。有些人可能会觉得劳力士是奢侈的奢侈品。然而，这是我设定的目标，而且我最终实现了。劳力士是你想要的吗？嗯，只有你自己才能决定。而你想要什么，的确需要你自己去弄清楚。

There are many theories about goal setting. There are many ideas about how to properly meet your goals and dreams. Some say you need to set achievable goals, midlevel goals, and stretch goals. Some theories try to dissuade people from setting unrealistic and stretch goals because that only sets people up for failure. I don’t agree; that type of thought process in and of itself is negative. If you want something, if you really yearn for something, then focus on it and take action to get it. Set your goals as high as you want. If you focus and take action , you will achieve your goal and get what you want. One very useful technique to keep you focused and remind you of what you want is making a dream board: a collage of things you want. The “things” do not have to be material. For instance, if you want happiness, then put the word happiness on your dream board. Put on it the house you want, the vacation destination you want, or whatever else your goal is, and look at your dream board every day. I know many successful people who have dream boards—because they work.

关于目标设定有很多理论，关于如何正确实现目标和梦想也有很多说法。有人说你需要设定可实现的目标、中级目标和挑战性目标。有些理论试图劝阻人们设定不切实际的挑战性目标，因为这只会让人走向失败。我并不认同这种观点；这种想法本身就是消极的。如果你想要什么，如果你真的渴望得到什么，那就专注于它，并采取行动去实现它。把你的目标设定得尽可能高。如果你专注并采取行动，你就能实现目标，得到你想要的。一个非常有效的技巧是制作梦想板，它可以帮助你保持专注，并时刻提醒自己想要什么。梦想板就是一个把你所有想要的东西拼贴在一起的板子。这些“东西”不一定是物质的。例如，如果你想要幸福，那就把“幸福”这个词放在你的梦想板上。把你想要的房子、你想要的度假胜地，或者其他任何你想要实现的目标都放上去，然后每天都看看你的梦想板。我认识很多成功人士都有梦想板——因为它们真的有效。

I use a very similar technique, but I have pictures of things in my office that I want. I had a picture of a watch that I wanted. It was directly behind my desk so that when I actually walked into my office every day I would see it. About a year ago, I was in a spa at the Del Hotel on Coronado Island, and I opened my locker. Guess what was in the locker? The exact watch I wanted. On June 9, 2012, I actually sent a tweet from @MikeAlden2012 with a picture of the watch. Now, I did not imagine that was how I would acquire the watch, and as you would expect, I gave it to the attendant. But, about a week later I went and tried that watch on. It was a Ulysse Nardin. It turns out I didn’t like how it felt on my wrist. I still love the style; it just wasn’t a fit. But, I saw another watch I liked and wanted. I tried on this new watch several times, I looked at pictures of it online, and I kept pictures of this watch on my computer screen when I was in my office. Guess what? I just bought that watch about a week ago, and it is very similar in quality to a Ulysse Nardin.

我用的方法很类似，不过我会在办公室里放一些我想要的东西的照片。比如，我之前有一张心仪手表的照片，就放在办公桌后面，这样我每天走进办公室都能看到它。大约一年前，我在科罗纳多岛德尔酒店的水疗中心，打开了我的储物柜。你猜里面是什么？正是我想要的那块手表。2012年6月9日，我用@MikeAlden2012这个账号发了一条推特，附上了那块手表的照片。当然，我当时并没有想到会以这种方式得到它，不出所料，我把照片给了服务员。但是，大约一周后，我去试戴了那块表。它是一块雅典表。结果发现我不喜欢它戴在手腕上的感觉。我仍然很喜欢它的款式，只是不太适合我的手腕。不过，我又看到了另一块我喜欢的手表。我试戴了这块新表好几次，在网上看过它的图片，在办公室的时候也一直把这块表的图片放在电脑屏幕上。你猜怎么着？我大概一周前刚买了这块表，它的品质和雅典表非常相似。

What you and I want may be very different. But what really matters to you is not what I want, it is what you want. So, I ask you: What do you want, and how are you going to get it?

你我想要的东西可能截然不同。但真正重要的不是我想要什么，而是你想要什么。所以，我问你：你想要什么？你打算如何得到它？

ARE YOU SMARTER THAN A FIRST-GRADER? THEN YOU CAN SET GOALS

你比一年级学生聪明吗？如果是，你就可以设定目标了。

My daughter is in first grade, and we recently worked on her biography. Her teachers assigned things the biography should discuss, such as people they love, where they were born, important events, and other things about their lives. At the end of the assignment the teacher asked that the students discuss their dreams and goals and how they will accomplish them. It was totally amazing to me! First-graders were being taught to ask for what they wanted! My daughter is very lucky to be able to go to private school where they are teaching her this kind of thing at such a young age. I asked several people who have kids in first grade in public school, and no such question has been asked.

我女儿上一年级，我们最近一起写她的个人简介。老师布置了一些内容，比如她爱的人、出生地、人生中的重要事件以及其他与她生活相关的事。作业最后，老师让学生们谈谈他们的梦想和目标，以及他们将如何实现这些梦想和目标。这让我感到非常惊讶！一年级的孩子竟然被教导要表达自己的需求！我女儿很幸运，能在私立学校就读，这么小的年纪就能学到这些。我问过几个孩子在公立学校上一年级的家长，他们都没有问过类似的问题。

They asked, What are your goals and dreams, and what do you need to do to reach your goals and dreams? I have to say I was totally amazed by this question. From my own childhood, I remember being asked things like, “What do you want to be when you grow up?” But such a very pointed, direct question for seven-year-olds is amazing.

他们问：“你的目标和梦想是什么？为了实现这些目标和梦想，你需要做些什么？” 我不得不说，这个问题让我感到非常惊讶。我记得自己小时候也被问过类似“你长大后想做什么？”这样的问题，但对一个七岁的孩子来说，问出如此尖锐直接的问题，真是令人惊叹。

When I was working on the part of the biography we were supposed to help her with, I asked my daughter what her dreams were and then asked what she wanted to be when she grew up. I worked with her closely and we came up with this: “When I grow up I want to be a singer. I will need to practice every day to meet this goal.” But incredibly, then my seven-year-old little girl, on her own, changed what we collectively came up with to this: “When I grow up I will be a singer. I will need to practice every day to meet my goal.”

当我帮她撰写传记的那部分内容时，我问女儿她的梦想是什么，然后又问她长大后想做什么。我和她一起仔细思考，最终我们想出了这个答案：“我长大后想成为一名歌手。我需要每天练习才能实现这个目标。” 但令人难以置信的是，我七岁的小女儿竟然自己把我们共同想出来的答案改成了：“我长大后一定会成为一名歌手。我需要每天练习才能实现我的目标。”

She changed it to take ownership of her dream and goal of being a singer. She will be a singer and it is her goal. I always try to teach my daughter about goals and dreams and how to be successful—little, subtle things, but I can’t take credit for the above. I can attribute it to her teachers or most likely her seven-year-old, uninfected mind. She has not been infected with excusetosis yet, and her DNA has not been modified by negative thoughts. Take it from my daughter and set goals, then prepare to achieve your goals and dreams.

她改变了想法，开始掌控自己成为歌手的梦想和目标。她一定会成为一名歌手，这是她的目标。我一直努力教导女儿关于目标和梦想以及如何获得成功——一些细微之处，但以上这些并非我的功劳。这要归功于她的老师，或者更确切地说，是她那颗纯真无邪的七岁心灵。她还没有被“找借口”的思想所侵蚀，她的基因里也没有被负面想法所改变。听听我女儿的，设定目标，然后为实现你的目标和梦想做好准备吧。

Remember Gladwell’s common denominator for successful people in Outliers ? Ten thousand hours! I agree with his findings; however, you don’t need this amount of time to change the way you think, change your diet, change your financial future, or change the negative influences in your life. You just need to say that you will do it and that it is your dream and goal, and then prepare. Ask yourself this: Are you smarter than a first-grader?

还记得格拉德威尔在《异类》中提到的成功人士的共同点吗？一万小时！我同意他的观点；然而，你并不需要这么多时间来改变你的思维方式、饮食习惯、财务状况，或者改变生活中的负面影响。你只需要告诉自己你会去做，并且这是你的梦想和目标，然后做好准备。问问自己：你比一年级的小学生聪明吗？

BY THE WAY … WHAT DID I WANT TO BE?

对了……我当时想成为什么样的人？

Just in case you are wondering … Yes, when I was in elementary school, they had us write down what we wanted to be when we grew up. Most boys wrote things like doctor, fireman, or policeman. I wrote down lawyer. I am not sure if I knew what a lawyer was back then, but I knew that I didn’t like not knowing my rights. For kids growing up in the projects, police can be a good or a bad thing. I remember feeling powerless as a kid when police were in my house. I became a lawyer, not with the idealistic or naïve view of changing the world, but simply to have the education first for myself. Twenty-odd years after writing down what I wanted to be, my reasons stayed the same. It was to build value in me and what I knew. Everything else would fall into place.

如果你好奇的话……是的，我上小学的时候，老师让我们写下长大后想做什么。大多数男生写的是医生、消防员或警察之类的。我写的是律师。我不确定当时是否真的了解律师是做什么的，但我知道我不喜欢对自己的权利一无所知。对于在贫民窟长大的孩子来说，警察既可以是好事，也可以是坏事。我记得小时候警察来我家时，我感到无能为力。我最终成为一名律师，并非出于改变世界的理想主义或天真的想法，而仅仅是想先提升自己的专业素养。写下梦想的二十多年过去了，我的理由依然如故。我想提升自己的价值，积累知识。其他的一切都会水到渠成。

LEARNING HOW TO SELL

学习如何销售

Most schools across the country and across the world have fundraisers for things such as school supplies and paying for future field trips. My school was no different. I went to public schools until college, and at every level we had to sell something. We sold chocolate bars, candles, magazines, and gifts for the holiday season. I remember being excited about each new selling opportunity because we would usually be rewarded for our sales. Many kids’ parents just bought the amount of widgets needed so their child could be rewarded. Fortunately, I did not have parents who could do that. I would of course hit up my immediate family, and my mom or dad would sometimes try to bring stuff to work, so collectively they were always good for a few sales, but in order to really win a big prize or be recognized, I had to find my customers.

全国乃至全世界的大多数学校都会举办筹款活动，用于购买学习用品和支付未来的校外活动费用。我的学校也不例外。我一直读公立学校直到大学，每个阶段我们都必须做义卖。我们卖巧克力、蜡烛、杂志和节日礼物。我记得每次新的义卖机会都让我兴奋不已，因为我们通常会因为销售业绩而获得奖励。很多孩子的父母会直接购买足够数量的商品，好让孩子拿到奖励。幸运的是，我的父母不会这样做。我当然会向我的直系亲属求助，我的父母有时也会把东西带到单位来，所以他们加起来总能帮我卖出一些商品，但要想真正赢得大奖或获得表彰，我必须自己找到顾客。

As early as nine years of age I would canvass the surrounding neighborhoods, selling magazines or chocolate bars to strangers. Yes, I would be alone! Probably not the best idea at any time in history, but that is what I did. I can’t say that I remember each interaction, but I can say that my parents’ inability to buy my way to a prize gave me the ability to sell. To do so, I was forced to think of a way to sell those things and get what I wanted.

早在九岁的时候，我就开始挨家挨户地向陌生人兜售杂志或巧克力。没错，我就是一个人！这在历史上可能都不是什么好主意，但我当时就是这么做的。我记不清每一次交易的细节，但我可以肯定的是，父母无法用金钱让我获得奖项，这反而培养了我的销售能力。为了做到这一点，我不得不绞尽脑汁地想办法把那些东西卖出去，换取我想要的东西。

In retrospect the prizes looked much better in the catalogue than in person. But, I wanted the prize and had to get it. I used what every single one of us has—my mind and my body—to accomplish my goal . I was never the top seller, because most of my customers were parents buying stuff for their kids anyway, but I was always above the average, and most of the time I got the prize I was shooting for. The important thing is that I was learning the skills I needed, learning to ask for what I wanted. I was preparing to ask for more .

现在回想起来，奖品在目录上看起来比实物好得多。但是，我想要那个奖品，我必须得到它。我运用了我们每个人都拥有的——我的头脑和我的体力——来实现我的目标。我从来都不是销售冠军，因为我的顾客大多是给孩子买东西的家长，但我总是高于平均水平，而且大多数时候我都能拿到我想要的奖品。重要的是，我从中学习到了所需的技能，学会了如何争取我想要的东西。我为争取更多做好准备。

ASK FOR MORE THAN WHAT YOU WANT

索取比你想要的更多

Regardless of what you decide you want, don’t settle for that. This is very important and usually forgotten. A while ago I was discussing with my accountant our cash flow needs. We had a significant amount of money sitting in what we call a reserve account. This reserve account is actually held in trust by my merchant processor. The merchant processor makes the decision about how much money to hold and how much to release back to my company. After a discussion with my accountant, we decided that if we could get $100,000 released back to us and reduce the amount of reserve the merchant processor held in trust that our cash flow that particular week and long-term would be greatly improved. Well, I asked my merchant processor for $250,000 and that they stop taking a reserve. Because of my relationship with my merchant processor and our history, they gave me what I asked for. My accountant was elated. I knew what I wanted, I asked for more, and I got it. Too many times, whether it be negotiating for the price of a car or asking for a raise, people leave money on the table. Ask for more and you will get more . It’s not greed, it’s getting what you deserve. Ask for more out of yourself and you will get more .

无论你决定想要什么，都不要轻易妥协。这一点非常重要，却常常被人忽略。不久前，我和我的会计讨论了我们的现金流需求。我们有一大笔钱放在所谓的储备账户里。这个储备账户实际上是由我的支付处理商代为保管的。支付处理商决定持有多少资金，以及将多少资金返还给我的公司。经过与会计的讨论，我们决定，如果我们能拿到10万美元的返还款，并减少支付处理商代为保管的储备金，那么我们当周以及长期的现金流状况都会得到极大改善。于是，我向支付处理商申请了25万美元，并要求他们停止收取储备金。由于我和支付处理商的关系以及我们之前的合作，他们满足了我的要求。我的会计欣喜若狂。我知道自己想要什么，我提出了更高的要求，并且最终得到了。很多时候，无论是在汽车价格谈判还是要求加薪时，人们都会错失良机。大胆索取，你就会得到更多。这不是贪婪，而是得到你应得的。对自己提出更高的要求，你就会获得更多。

TIPS TO GET MORE CHIPS: WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW BEFORE THE NEGOTIATION

如何获得更多筹码：谈判前你需要知道的事

When most people hear the word “negotiation,” they feel uneasy or anxious. Nobody in this country likes the activity of negotiation. The fact is, much like the point I made in the beginning of this chapter about buying and selling, everything you do in your life is at some point a negotiation. You negotiate your way through the traffic to work by allowing others to pass at your expense or by passing someone else in order to make it to work on time. You negotiate your way through the crowd at the train station. You may not even say a word, but you and everyone around you has decided to give and take something in order to accomplish a goal. This is not to be confused with navigation, which merely means trying to get from point A to point B. As you navigate your way to work, you negotiate with the others around you. You negotiate with your family members about basic things like TV time, bathroom time, and who gets to use the family car.

大多数人一听到“谈判”这个词，就会感到不安或焦虑。在这个国家，没有人喜欢谈判。但事实上，就像我在本章开头提到的买卖一样，你生活中做的每件事在某种程度上都是一种谈判。比如，为了准时上班，你开车上班，要么让别人先行，要么自己超车。你挤过火车站的人群，也是在进行谈判。你可能一句话都没说，但你和周围的每个人都决定做出让步，以达成某个目标。这与导航不同，导航仅仅是指从A点到B点。在你上班的路上，你也在与周围的人进行谈判。你和家人就一些基本的事情进行谈判，比如看电视的时间、上厕所的时间，以及谁可以使用家里的车。

You also negotiate with yourself every day. You are fighting the disease of excusetosis and effectively negotiating with yourself by finding ways to get things done. When you wake up you may be tired, but as a part of your treatment for the disease, you tell yourself that you are full of energy and ready to get through the day. As you can see by these examples, it is in your genetic makeup to negotiate. You could not survive without negotiation. As you will see in the following, we all do this naturally. Once you understand that negotiation is a part of your human instincts, negotiation no longer becomes negotiation. It becomes a subconscious involuntary response to a situation in which you are trying to get more, and you deserve it.

你每天都在和自己谈判。你正在与“找借口症”作斗争，并通过寻找完成任务的方法有效地与自己谈判。当你醒来时，你可能感到疲惫，但作为治疗这种“疾病”的一部分，你会告诉自己精力充沛，准备好迎接新的一天。正如你从这些例子中看到的，谈判是你的基因使然。没有谈判，你将无法生存。正如你将在下文中看到的，我们所有人都会自然而然地进行谈判。一旦你理解谈判是你人类本能的一部分，谈判就不再仅仅是谈判。它会成为一种下意识的、不由自主的反应，让你在试图获得更多且理应得到的时候做出选择。

So for the rest of this chapter I will share with you some important realizations that will prepare you to negotiate like a pro. Once you get these in your head, they will transform you from someone who settles for less to someone who is prepared to ask for more.

在本章剩余部分，我将与你分享一些重要的心得，帮助你像谈判高手一样游刃有余。一旦你掌握了这些要点，你就能从一个安于现状的人转变为一个敢于争取更多的人。

NEGOTIATE LIKE A FIVE-YEAR-OLD: WHY ASK WHY? … WHY NOT?

像五岁小孩一样谈判：为什么要问为什么？……为什么不呢？

When my daughter Morgan was five years old, she used to ask “why” all the time. Now, most child psychologists might explain this by saying that this age is the most impressionable age, and that the brain of a five-year-old is growing rapidly and also absorbing information both consciously and subconsciously. If you have kids, I am sure you have noticed how the typical five-year-old would ask you “why” any time you say “no.” They ask “why” with no inhibitions; they are unapologetic, and they just keep asking, “Why? Why can’t I have M&Ms for breakfast? Why can’t I have that stuffed animal that is so cute and cuddly? Why do I have to brush my teeth? Why do I have to go to bed? Why can’t I stay up for one more show?” You get the picture. Many times a new parent has no idea what to say to these “whys.” The standard response is, “Because I said so.”

我女儿摩根五岁的时候，总是问“为什么”。现在，大多数儿童心理学家可能会解释说，这个年龄段的孩子最容易受到影响，他们的大脑正在快速发育，并且会潜移默化地吸收信息。如果你有孩子，我肯定你也注意到，典型的五岁孩子只要你说“不”，就会问“为什么”。他们问“为什么”毫不顾忌，毫不掩饰，不停地问：“为什么？为什么我早餐不能吃M&M巧克力豆？为什么我不能玩那个又可爱又毛茸茸的毛绒玩具？为什么我必须刷牙？为什么我必须睡觉？为什么我不能再看一集？” 你明白我的意思。很多时候，新手父母都不知道该如何回答这些“为什么”。标准的回答是：“因为我说了算。”

Now, my daughter may not really be negotiating with me—or is she? Where did she learn to ask “why” at five years old? I have to honestly say, despite my wife’s and my stellar parenting skills, she didn’t learn to ask “why” from us. Maybe she learned it from SpongeBob, but the reality is she doesn’t know anything else. It is in our genetic makeup to negotiate. But, somewhere along the line, we suppress the instinctive trait of negotiating.

现在，我女儿可能并没有真的在跟我谈判——或者她其实是在谈判？她五岁的时候是从哪里学会问“为什么”的呢？说实话，尽管我和妻子都尽心尽力地教养孩子，但她并不是从我们这里学会问“为什么”的。也许她是从海绵宝宝那里学来的，但事实是她根本不知道还有其他的沟通方式。谈判是我们的基因里固有的本能。但是，在人生的某个阶段，我们却压抑了这种谈判的本能。

Now, asking “why” as a five-year-old isn’t always negotiating, because it may be part of their cognitive growth and development, as those psychologists say. As in, “Why did the cat die?” or, “Why is the sky blue?” (good luck answering those). But my daughter’s subconscious mind definitely contains the innate skill and behavior that has been with us since the beginning of mankind. Cavemen negotiated with each other about who would get what food and territory. As we evolved, the negotiation skill became more cerebral and involved less violence—except for war, which is the ultimate negotiation. Up until society suppresses the negotiation gene, the question “why?” is a very effective negotiating question, and at the end of the day, negotiation is a part of our genetic survival makeup, one that we can use to get valuable information that will help us to negotiate for more. Take for instance the following:

现在，对于一个五岁的孩子来说，问“为什么”并不总是谈判，因为正如心理学家所说，这可能是他们认知成长和发展的一部分。比如，“猫为什么死了？”或者“天空为什么是蓝色的？”（祝你好运，看看谁能回答这些问题）。但我女儿的潜意识里确实蕴藏着一种自人类诞生之初就伴随我们的与生俱来的技能和行为。穴居人会就食物和领地的分配进行谈判。随着人类的进化，谈判技巧变得更加理性，暴力程度也降低了——除了战争，战争是终极的谈判。在社会抑制了这种谈判基因之前，“为什么？”这个问题一直是一个非常有效的谈判问题。归根结底，谈判是我们基因中生存本能的一部分，我们可以利用它来获取有价值的信息，从而帮助我们争取更多。例如：

  • Why won’t you sell it for less?


    为什么不愿意降价出售？
  • Why can’t you discount the price?


    为什么不能降价？
  • Why is the price so high when your competitors sell the same product for less?


    为什么你的价格这么高，而竞争对手销售的同款产品价格却更低？
  • Why can’t you honor a competitor’s coupon?


    为什么不能接受竞争对手的优惠券？
  • Why won’t you throw in a few extra if I buy twelve?


    如果我买十二个，为什么不多送几个呢？

During the heat of any negotiation, the five-year-old’s question of “why” is very powerful, as it disarms the other person and forces him or her to think. While they are thinking, most people will take the path of least resistance: “Well, if you buy twelve, I will throw in a few extra.” “We don’t normally honor a competitor’s coupon, but I will today.” Some people make up the answer, such as “Sorry, they don’t let us discount.” That is—pardon my French—BS. Just recently I bought four brand new suits at a high-end clothing store, the type of clothing store that offers you champagne or espresso when you are shopping. This was the second time I was there and the second purchase I made. My first purchase was a blazer and a few shirts. I used the phrase that you will learn in the next chapter, and the clerk said she couldn’t, and she didn’t discount my purchase. Why do I tell you about this temporary defeat? Well, with my second purchase I asked again, and this time she found the owner, who gave me a significant discount, gave me his personal cell phone number, and thanked me himself. In later chapters we discuss more on how to use the skills developed and mastered by a five-year-old.

在任何谈判的白热化阶段，五岁小孩问的“为什么”都极具威力，因为它能解除对方的戒备，迫使其思考。在对方思考的过程中，大多数人会选择阻力最小的方案：“嗯，如果你买十二件，我可以多送几件。”“我们通常不接受竞争对手的优惠券，但今天可以。”有些人还会编造理由，比如“抱歉，他们不允许我们打折。”恕我直言，这纯属胡扯。就在不久前，我在一家高档服装店买了四套全新的西装，就是那种会提供香槟或浓缩咖啡的店。这是我第二次去那里，也是第二次购物。我第一次买的是一件西装外套和几件衬衫。我用了你将在下一章学到的那句话，但店员说她不能，也没有给我打折。我为什么要跟你讲这段小小的挫败经历呢？第二次购买时，我又问了一遍，这次她找到了店主，店主给了我很大的折扣，给了我他的私人手机号码，还亲自向我道谢。在后面的章节中，我们会更详细地讨论如何运用五岁孩子培养和掌握的技能。

WHY ASK WHY? Because it works!

为什么要问为什么？因为它有效！

WHAT ARE THEY THINKING?

他们在想什么？

When you are in a negotiation, you need to determine what the other person has and what they want. My 3 P’s + 1 P technique will help answer these questions. For instance, if you are purchasing a car, you need to know what the invoice is on the car, what incentives are being offered, and what other dealerships are selling the car for. If you know what the other party wants and what they have, then before you even say a word you will be in a very powerful negotiating position.

谈判时，你需要了解对方的现有条件和需求。我的“3P+1P”技巧可以帮助你解答这些问题。例如，如果你要买车，你需要知道车辆的发票价格、提供的优惠以及其它经销商的售价。如果你了解对方的需求和现有条件，那么在你开口之前，就已经占据了非常有利的谈判地位。

WHAT ARE YOU THINKING?

你在想什么？

You need to know what you want, and what you have as well. You see, the other person, especially in a retail setting, is already sizing you up, and they probably already know how to get what they want out of you. So you need to know what you want out of you as well. This goes back to what I was saying in the beginning of the chapter: know what you want; it’s important. In a car purchase scenario (more about this in the next chapter), you need to know what your bottom line is and what kind of car you want. If you walk into a dealership “just to look,” then you are not ready to negotiate.

你需要清楚自己想要什么，以及自己拥有什么。你看，对方，尤其是在零售环境中，已经在评估你了，他们可能已经知道如何从你身上得到他们想要的东西。所以你也需要清楚自己想要什么。这和我在本章开头提到的一样：知道自己想要什么；这很重要。以买车为例（下一章会详细讲解），你需要知道你的底线是多少，以及你想要什么样的车。如果你走进车行“只是看看”，那么你还没有做好谈判的准备。

When you are ready, be on high alert, as buying a car, like many purchases, is an emotional experience. Buying anything on emotion is almost always a losing situation for you. So know what you want. People say, “Don’t go grocery shopping on an empty stomach, because if you do, you will end up buying things that you don’t need.” You also end up spending your hard-earned money on junk. Just like the grocery store, don’t ever enter any negotiation situation without knowing what you want and what the other party wants.

准备好之后，务必保持高度警惕，因为买车和许多其他消费一样，都是一种情绪化的体验。凭感情用事买东西几乎总是会让你吃亏。所以，一定要清楚自己想要什么。人们常说：“不要空着肚子去超市，否则你会买很多不需要的东西。”你最终会把辛苦赚来的钱浪费在无用的东西上。就像去超市一样，在谈判中，千万不要在不清楚自己想要什么以及对方想要什么的情况下贸然行动。

WIN-WIN NEGOTIATING

双赢谈判

Too many people negotiate with the winner-take-all mentality and are more concerned with “winning” and destroying the other party. I am not a fan of this technique—it usually doesn’t work and it frequently ruins the relationship with the other party. Now, you may say, “Well, who cares if I offend a clerk at Macy’s or a car salesperson?” I have often had situations where I had to deal with businesspeople I did not like. However, I negotiated with them in good faith and in a way that allowed both of us to win, and guess what? I continue to do business with them. By knowing what the other party is thinking and what they have, you are able to negotiate a deal that allows them to make a living while getting yourself the best deal. You will be surprised how the same tactics you use with the Macy’s clerk can also be used in major business deals that can net you millions. This may be difficult to grasp, but when you realize that winning the battle does not always win the war, you will find this technique will pay off in the long run.

太多人谈判时抱着赢者通吃的心态，更关心的是“赢”和如何摧毁对方。我并不赞同这种做法——它通常行不通，而且常常会破坏与对方的关系。你可能会说：“我得罪梅西百货的店员或汽车销售员又有什么关系呢？”我经常遇到一些我不喜欢的商人。然而，我始终秉持诚意与他们谈判，力求实现双赢。结果呢？我仍然和他们保持着业务往来。了解对方的想法和资源，你就能达成既能让他们维持生计又能让你获得最大利益的交易。你会惊讶地发现，你用来对付梅西百货店员的策略，同样也能运用到能为你带来数百万美元收益的大型商业交易中。这或许难以理解，但当你意识到赢得一场战斗并不总是赢得整场战争时，你会发现这种技巧从长远来看是值得的。

LOOKING DOWN

向下看

In 1989, a young black man humbly shined people’s shoes every day to make ends meet. He was reported to always be happy and appreciative. Many people looked down on him as though he were nothing more than just a shoe shiner.

1989年，一位年轻的黑人男子每天靠擦鞋维持生计。据说他总是面带笑容，心怀感恩。许多人瞧不起他，认为他不过是个擦鞋匠。

But this young black man was also an aspiring stand-up comedian who worked clubs at night and shined shoes by day. Fast-forward to 2004, and that young man is one of the most recognized and powerful entertainers in the world, a musician, comedian, and acclaimed actor. That man, Eric Marlon Bishop, also known as Jamie Foxx, accepted the Oscar for his portrayal of Ray Charles in the movie Ray . You would probably never guess that the man shining your shoes today could be the next big thing tomorrow, so be nice to people when you negotiate.

但这位年轻的黑人也曾是一位怀揣梦想的单口喜剧演员，白天擦鞋，晚上在俱乐部演出。时间快进到2004年，这位年轻人已成为世界上最知名、最有影响力的艺人之一，集音乐家、喜剧演员和著名演员于一身。他就是埃里克·马龙·毕肖普，也就是我们熟知的杰米·福克斯，凭借在电影《雷》中对雷·查尔斯的精彩演绎荣获奥斯卡奖。你可能永远想不到，今天为你擦鞋的人明天就可能成为下一个巨星，所以谈判时请善待他人。

DEFERRING TO A THIRD PARTY

听从第三方意见

This is a great technique when buying, selling, or in any negotiation, especially when it is impromptu. The typical scenario goes like this: You are interested in buying something and you begin to discuss the purchase with the salesperson. You don’t feel comfortable with the price or even the salesperson. The easiest way to get out of the situation is by saying, “I need to discuss this with my wife/spouse/brother/sister/grandmother.” The person you mention doesn’t matter. Let’s assume you are not comfortable with the price, and because of that you decide to use this technique. The salesperson can then do a number of things. We discuss this technique in a later chapter from the salesperson’s perspective, but this simple technique can be used to get you more out of any situation.

这在买卖或任何谈判中都是一个很棒的技巧，尤其是在临时谈判中。典型的场景是这样的：你对购买某件商品感兴趣，并开始与销售人员讨论购买事宜。你对价格甚至销售人员都感到不自在。最简单的脱身方法就是说：“我需要和我的妻子/配偶/兄弟姐妹/祖母商量一下。”你提到的人是谁并不重要。假设你对价格不满意，因此决定使用这个技巧。销售人员可以采取多种措施。我们将在后面的章节中从销售人员的角度讨论这个技巧，但这个简单的技巧可以帮助你在任何情况下都获得更大的优势。

BE PREPARED TO WALK AWAY

做好离开的准备

When you enter into a negotiation, you need to be prepared to walk away from the deal. This takes discipline and sometimes a little drama, but in any negotiation you need to be prepared to walk away. If for some reason none of the techniques we discuss in this book are effective in your negotiation, be prepared to walk away. I don’t care if it is your dream home, dream car, or a chocolate truffle, be prepared to walk away if you do not get the deal you know you can get. Many people walk away from deals to avoid confrontation as a result of their inability to control their emotions. When you use my 3 P’s + 1 P technique and you know what they want and what you want, then walking away is just another tactic, not a knee-jerk, emotional reaction. Walking away from a deal is a powerful and sometimes risky maneuver, but nine times out of ten it gets you a better deal.

当你进入谈判时，你必须做好放弃交易的准备。这需要自律，有时甚至需要一点戏剧化的手段，但在任何谈判中，你都必须做好放弃的准备。如果由于某种原因，本书中讨论的所有技巧都无法在你的谈判中奏效，那就做好放弃的准备。我不在乎这笔交易是你的梦想之家、梦想之车，还是一块巧克力松露，如果你没有得到你认为可以得到的价格，就做好放弃的准备。许多人放弃交易是为了避免冲突，因为他们无法控制自己的情绪。当你运用我的“3P+1P”技巧，并且清楚地知道对方想要什么以及你想要什么时，放弃就只是一种策略，而不是一种下意识的情绪反应。放弃交易是一种强有力的、有时甚至是冒险的策略，但十有八九它能让你获得更好的结果。

People often send me products that they want my company to market, and there was one product in particular that I fell in love with—it was unique and had mass appeal. In addition, it was already developed and was a great all-around product. The inventor is a nice guy, but he didn’t understand my business and wanted a very large royalty. Financially, his request didn’t make sense for my company. Now, I can’t stress how much I loved this product. We went back and forth several times, and it appeared we were not able to come to a deal, so I walked away. I didn’t get emotional, even though I must admit I was frustrated, but I was prepared to walk away if the deal was not a win-win agreement. Several months later, the owner reached out to me and agreed to the terms I proposed. As I type this page, we are in negotiations with another multinational company that is going to do a joint venture with my firm. This deal will most likely generate tens of millions of dollars.

人们经常给我寄来他们想让我公司推广的产品，其中有一款产品让我一见倾心——它独具特色，而且极具市场潜力。此外，它已经开发完成，是一款各方面都很出色的产品。发明者人很好，但他并不了解我的业务，而且索要的版税非常高。从财务角度来看，他的要求对我的公司来说并不划算。说实话，我真的非常喜欢这款产品。我们来回沟通了好几次，但似乎始终无法达成协议，所以我放弃了。虽然我必须承认当时很沮丧，但我并没有情绪失控，因为如果最终无法达成双赢的协议，我已经做好了放弃的准备。几个月后，发明者联系了我，并同意了我提出的条件。就在我写下这些文字的时候，我们正在与另一家跨国公司洽谈，这家公司将与我的公司成立一家合资企业。这笔交易很可能会带来数千万美元的收益。

The key points to remember in any negotiation strategy are:

任何谈判策略都需要牢记以下几点：

  • Being prepared is important.


    做好准备很重要。
  • Understand what your goal is during the negotiation.


    在谈判过程中，要明确自己的目标。
  • Have as much knowledge as possible.


    尽可能多地学习知识。
  • Be prepared to walk away.


    做好随时离开的准备。
  • Take the deal when you have achieved your pre-set goal.


    当你达到预设目标后再接受交易。

TAKE THE DEAL

接受这笔交易

I have witnessed large business negotiations collapse not only due to a lack of preparedness, but also because of greed and not really knowing what was wanted. When you know the purpose of your negotiation strategy and you achieve your goal, then be prepared to take the deal. It may seem hypocritical to say such a thing for a book titled Ask More, Get More , but you will learn you can still ask more and get more without losing the deal.

我曾亲眼目睹大型商业谈判破裂，不仅因为准备不足，还因为贪婪和对自身需求一无所知。当你明确谈判策略的目标并达成目标后，就应该做好接受交易的准备。对于一本名为《多要多得》的书来说，这番话或许显得有些自相矛盾，但你会从中了解到，即使不放弃交易，你仍然可以提出更多要求并获得更多回报。

Taking the deal that you have in front of you takes discipline. Successful professional gamblers who earn a living playing cards or table games set a daily limit or a goal up or down . If their goal is to make $1,000 and they hit that goal—they walk away. If their threshold for a loss is also $1,000—they also walk away. Successful professional gamblers take the deal that is beneficial to them. By the way, there are not too many professional gamblers. They are an elite group of people who are very prepared and disciplined and who are constantly studying and exercising ways to control their breathing and thoughts. But at the end of the day, they take the deal . When a professional gambler walks into a casino, the house doesn’t have a chance—that is why many pros are banned from the casino.

接受摆在眼前的牌局需要自律。那些靠打牌或玩桌面游戏谋生的成功职业赌徒会设定每日限额或目标。如果他们的目标是赢1000美元，并且达到了这个目标——他们就会离开。如果他们的亏损阈值也是1000美元——他们也会离开。成功的职业赌徒会接受对他们有利的牌局。顺便说一句，职业赌徒并不多。他们是一群精英，准备充分、自律性强，并且不断学习和练习控制呼吸和思维的方法。但最终，他们还是会接受牌局。当职业赌徒走进赌场时，赌场几乎没有胜算——这就是为什么很多职业赌徒会被赌场列入黑名单的原因。

USE TECHNOLOGY TO YOUR ADVANTAGE

善用科技优势

I am a big fan of the telephone, and I use the telephone for almost 90 percent of the deals that I put together. Maybe it’s because I have a large call center or perhaps because my grandfather had call centers in the ’50s. But I actually think it is because of the ease with which we can instantly communicate with people all over the world. Some people prefer to look into the whites of another’s eyes. As for me, I can tell if the individual is a good person just by what they say and how they say it. If you are going to make a big transaction buying or selling something, use the phone as a way to gather information as a part of your preparation. Ask as many questions as you feel necessary; this will prepare you if you need to come face-to-face.

我非常喜欢电话，我经手的交易中几乎90%都是通过电话完成的。也许是因为我拥有一个大型呼叫中心，也许是因为我祖父在20世纪50年代就经营过呼叫中心。但我认为真正的原因是，我们可以如此便捷地与世界各地的人即时沟通。有些人喜欢面对面交流，而我，只需听一听对方的言谈举止，就能判断他是否为人正直。如果你打算进行一笔大额交易，无论是买卖，都应该利用电话收集信息，做好充分的准备。尽可能多地提问，这将有助于你在需要面对面交流时做好准备。

INTERNET

互联网

Today we can google everything. The Internet is so powerful that you can find almost anything you want, but you must check your sources. Many websites seem to have accurate information, but in reality are not even close. After you find the information you think you need, become a detective and check your sources.

如今，我们几乎可以上网搜索任何东西。互联网如此强大，几乎可以找到任何你想要的信息，但你必须核实信息的来源。许多网站看似提供准确的信息，但实际上却大相径庭。找到你认为需要的信息后，要像侦探一样仔细核查信息来源。

EMAIL

电子邮件

I have a 250-page book somewhere in my library that teaches people how to communicate properly via email. There is a definite value in knowing how to communicate this way. What I usually do in a negotiation being conducted through email is write the message, save the draft, and review it—before I send it. I think about how the other person could react when they read my words, and I ask myself, “Does the email effectively communicate what I want?” I spell-check one more time, reread, and then I hit “send.”

我的图书馆里有一本250页的书，教人们如何正确地使用电子邮件进行沟通。掌握这种沟通方式确实很有价值。在通过电子邮件进行谈判时，我通常的做法是：写好邮件，保存草稿，然后在发送前仔细检查一遍。我会设想对方读到我的文字后可能会有什么反应，并问自己：“这封邮件是否有效地传达了我的意图？”我会再检查一遍拼写，重新阅读一遍，然后点击“发送”。

#↩

CHAPTER 6

第六章

HOW TO NEGOTIATE FOR MORE: THE PHRASE THAT WILL MAKE YOU MORE MONEY, SAVE YOU MORE MONEY, AND INCREASE YOUR BOTTOM LINE—GUARANTEED!

如何谈判获得更多：一句保证能让你赚更多钱、省更多钱、提高利润的话语！

“IS THERE ANYTHING ELSE YOU CAN DO FOR ME?”

“还有什么你能帮我的吗？”

That is the phrase. Think about it: “Is there anything else you can do for me?” What is the phrase really asking? Well, it depends on your situation. I use this in virtually every aspect of my life, from negotiation with business associates to taking my car in for repairs to buying a Diet Coke at McDonald’s.

这就是那句话。想想看：“还有什么可以帮到我的吗？” 这句话真正想问的是什么？嗯，这取决于你的具体情况。我几乎在生活的方方面面都会用到这句话，从与商业伙伴谈判到送车去修车，再到在麦当劳买一瓶健怡可乐。

Let’s say you are trying to get a discount on a service bill at your dealership that is unexpectedly high. When you walk into the car dealership, a service technician, who by the way is a highly trained and skilled salesperson, greets you. In this scenario, the service technician, who, again I stress, is “trained” to “help you,” has an ulterior motive that affects his personal compensation. When you are presented with the cost of the service bill, the technician will “help you out” by mentioning all the work that “must” be done on your car. The technician will explain that your car needs tires and new filters, and that you need these to operate the vehicle at optimal and safe levels. Many times—if not every time—the customer agrees to the price, or maybe says things like, “Wow, that is high,” or “I didn’t expect that,” or “That’s too expensive.” These statements are defensive in nature and offensive to the highly skilled service technician, causing him to be less likely to “help you.”

假设您在汽车经销商处想就一张意外高昂的维修账单争取折扣。当您走进经销店时，一位服务技师（顺便一提，他其实是一位训练有素、技能娴熟的销售员）接待了您。在这种情况下，这位服务技师（我再次强调，他“受过培训”来“帮助您”）却另有图谋，这会影响到他的个人收入。当您看到维修账单时，技师会“帮您”列举出您爱车“必须”进行的所有维修项目。他会解释说，您的车需要更换轮胎和滤芯，而这些对于车辆的最佳安全运行至关重要。很多时候——如果不是每次——顾客都会接受这个价格，或者会说：“哇，这也太贵了吧”、“我没想到会这样”、“这也太贵了”。这些话带有防御性质，而且会冒犯这位技能娴熟的服务技师，从而降低他“帮您”的可能性。

When presented with the bill, rather than getting excited and agitated, ask the service technicians the magic question: “Is there anything else you can do for me?” In their mind they are thinking many things like, “What does he mean?” “Is he looking for a discount?” “Is he looking for a free detail?” The beauty is, that is up to you. In most instances the service technician will sharpen his pencil and give you a reduced price. How can I say this with confidence? Because I do it every time I bring my car in for service, and I save money each time. Additionally, many of my friends, family members, and employees have done this exact thing and saved hundreds of dollars off of their service bills.

拿到账单时，不要激动或焦躁，而是问维修技师一个关键问题：“还有什么可以帮到我的吗？” 他们心里可能在想：“他这是什么意思？” “他是想打折吗？” “他是想免费洗车吗？” 妙处就在于，这完全取决于你。大多数情况下，维修技师会主动给你优惠。我为什么这么肯定？因为我每次保养车都这么做，而且每次都省了钱。此外，我的很多朋友、家人和同事也都这么做，省下了几百美元的保养费用。

Now, it doesn’t stop there. If your goal is to get a reduced price, then great , you just saved money. Let’s say you saved $50—for many people that is a half-day of pay—and the true cost of your ownership of your car has been reduced by $50. Now multiply that by four on an annual basis—four being the average number of times someone brings a car in for service. You pocketed $200, which is like making $57,000 if invested in the stock market with an average rate of return of 12 percent for fifty years. Cut the years in half, and $200 saved is still $23,500! This number is not exact due to compound interest, but you get the picture.

但这还没完。如果你的目标是获得折扣，那太好了，你省钱了。假设你省了 50 美元——对很多人来说，这相当于半天的工资——而你拥有这辆车的实际成本也减少了 50 美元。现在，把这个数字乘以每年四次——四次是平均每辆车保养的次数。你净赚了 200 美元，这相当于把这笔钱投资到股市，假设年均收益率为 12%，持续 50 年，最终能赚到 57,000 美元。即使把时间减半，省下的 200 美元仍然能带来 23,500 美元的收益！由于复利效应，这个数字可能并不完全精确，但你应该明白我的意思了。

But why stop there? Next comes a follow-up question, all within the premise of the service technician helping you: “ What else can you do for me?” When asking a follow-up question, it is paramount that you ask this question with absolute sincerity. What you are really saying is, “Are you really going to charge me that much, make me go somewhere else, get it cheaper, and ultimately become an unhappy customer? Does that make you feel good?” He is also thinking, “Well, did he get a price somewhere else? Has he had this done here before?”

但为什么就此止步呢？接下来，在维修技师为您提供服务的前提下，您可以追问：“您还能为我做些什么？” 提出追问时，务必真诚。您真正想问的是：“您真的要收我这么多钱，让我去别的地方，找到更便宜的维修服务，最终让我成为一个不满意的客户吗？这样您觉得满意吗？” 他也在想：“他有没有在别的地方问过价格？他以前在我们这里做过类似的维修吗？”

IT’S ALL RIGHT FOR THEM TO ASK—AND FOR YOU TO ASK, TOO!

他们问没问题——你问也没问题！

There is nothing wrong with the service technician trying to make money, as we live in a capitalist society and that is one thing that makes this country great. But, there is equally nothing wrong with making your hard-earned dollar stretch and make you money.

维修技师想赚钱无可厚非，毕竟我们生活在资本主义社会，而这正是这个国家伟大的原因之一。但是，让自己辛苦赚来的每一分钱都物尽其用，这同样无可厚非。

People sometimes may get embarrassed by asking for more. Some people may consider it cheap or even rude. I am a very generous person, but there is nothing cheap about me when I ask for more. Having the benefit of being around ultra-wealthy people, one thing I noticed was that the rich do not worry about being cheap, and sometimes others think they are being rude. But, in all reality they are doing what got them to where they are, asking for more. Ask yourself: Would you rather have your money, or give it to someone else? As I mentioned earlier, people in countries all around the world negotiate and bargain all day long in a very open and outgoing manner. Some in the United States may find it comical or even rude; well, erase that thought from your mind if you believe it. Asking for more means more for you, more for your favorite charity, more for your family, and more out of life.

人们有时会因为开口索要更多而感到尴尬。有些人甚至会觉得这样做小气，或者很没礼貌。我本人非常慷慨，但我开口索要更多时，绝不会显得小气。有幸与超级富豪们相处，我注意到，富人从不担心自己显得吝啬，有时别人会觉得他们很无礼。但实际上，他们正是靠着索要更多才走到今天这一步。不妨问问自己：你是更愿意自己拥有金钱，还是更愿意把它送给别人？正如我之前提到的，世界各地的人们每天都在以非常开放和外向的方式进行谈判和讨价还价。在美国，有些人可能会觉得这种行为滑稽甚至无礼；如果你这么想，那就把这种想法抛到脑后吧。索要更多意味着你能获得更多，你能为你喜爱的慈善机构获得更多，你能为你的家人获得更多，你的生活也会更加精彩。

The follow-up question may save you more money at that very moment, but it may also save you money down the line. The service technician who knows that you are funding his paycheck wants you to come back. So, he may give you a coupon for the next trip or offer to have your car detailed. Either way, it is a win-win scenario, as discussed earlier in the book. You got your car serviced for less—and maybe get a free detail or coupon—and the service technician “sold you” on the service and retained a customer.

后续的提问或许能让你当下省下更多钱，但从长远来看，也可能帮你省钱。维修技师知道你是他的经济支柱，所以他希望你能再次光顾。因此，他可能会给你下次保养的优惠券，或者主动提出免费为你做一次汽车精细清洁。无论哪种方式，这都是双赢的局面，正如本书前面所讨论的。你以更低的价格完成了汽车保养——或许还能获得免费的精细清洁或优惠券——而维修技师则成功地“推销”了服务，并留住了一位顾客。

THAT LITTLE QUESTION WILL TAKE YOU A LONG WAY

这个问题看似简单，却意义非凡。

I was speaking with a friend of mine who is the ultimate pessimist. My friend kept going on about how this technique wouldn’t work because of this or that, and I said, “Try it next time you purchase or pay ”—there is difference—“for anything.” He had some old gold jewelry that he wanted to sell for scrap. He brought the jewelry in, and they told him they would give him $150 for it. My friend proudly told me he then asked, “Is there anything else you can do for me?” and said nothing else. The man behind the counter looked at the gold and his calculator and said, “Yeah, I can give you $175.” Doesn’t seem like much, but $25 will put gas in your tank, fill your belly, or add up to thousands of dollars in your retirement account.

我和一个朋友聊天，他是个十足的悲观主义者。他一直喋喋不休地说这个方法行不通，因为这样那样的原因，我就说：“下次你买东西或者付款的时候试试——这两者是有区别的——“买任何东西的时候都行。”他有一些旧金饰想卖废品。他把金饰拿去店里，店员说只给他150美元。我朋友得意地告诉我，他接着问：“还有什么需要帮忙的吗？”然后就没再说什么了。柜台后面的店员看了看金饰，又拿了计算器，说：“嗯，我可以给你175美元。”听起来不多，但25美元可以帮你加满油，填饱肚子，或者攒到几千美元的退休金里。

Thousands of dollars? Yeah, thousands! Let’s say the above real story happened in 1980. Now let’s assume you put that meager $25 into a retirement account and your average rate of return was 12 percent annually; you would have $7,225 in fifty years. You need to change the way you see things. That meager $25 today is really $7,225 over a fifty-year time span. It’s not just twenty-five bucks—it’s your future!

几千美元？没错，几千美元！假设上面这个真实故事发生在1980年。现在假设你把那区区25美元存入退休账户，年均收益率为12%；五十年后，你将拥有7225美元。你需要改变一下看待这件事的方式。今天那区区25美元，五十年后就变成了7225美元。这不仅仅是25美元——这是你的未来！

You may be wondering why I bother telling you a story about $25. I tell it because it is a real story, and you can start using this phrase immediately. Most important, it’s also scalable. What do I mean by scalable? Well, you can increase or even decrease the amounts to figure out how much richer or how much closer you are to becoming truly financially free if you begin using this phrase over time. If you can apply this single phrase to your daily routine and habits, you will make thousands of dollars a year. For some, it may be tens of thousands, and at higher levels it can become millions . I have used the phrase and made millions of dollars during the worst economic slump in the history of the United States, if not the world. The dealership scenario was a true story that happened to me personally, and I saved $200. I can easily invest this $200 and turn it into $57,000 through programs that are available to anyone.

你可能想知道我为什么要费心跟你讲一个关于25美元的故事。我讲这个故事是因为它是真实的，而且你可以立即开始使用这个短语。最重要的是，它具有可扩展性。可扩展性是什么意思呢？你可以增加或减少金额，从而计算出如果你长期使用这个短语，你的财富会增加多少，或者离真正的财务自由又近了多远。如果你能将这个短语融入你的日常生活和习惯中，你每年就能赚到几千美元。对某些人来说，这可能是几万美元，而更高层次的运用甚至可以达到数百万美元。我曾在美国乃至世界历史上最严重的经济衰退时期使用过这个短语，并赚到了数百万美元。这个关于汽车经销店的例子是我亲身经历的真实故事，我当时省下了200美元。我可以轻松地将这200美元投资，并通过任何人都可以参与的项目，将其变成57,000美元。

If you are reading this book and you are a multimillionaire, you may feel like you don’t need to “save” $25. You need to reset that type of thinking. If you are reading this book and it was difficult for you to come up with the money to pay for it, you may be thinking the same thing. My response is the same: There is an address at the back of this book. Feel free to send me $25, and if you do, I will make the check out to the United Way. Saving $25 now is really making thousands of dollars .

如果你正在读这本书，而你又是一位千万富翁，你或许会觉得没必要“省”25美元。你需要改变这种想法。如果你正在读这本书，但当初为了买它而费尽周折，你或许也会有同样的顾虑。我的回答也一样：书的背面有一个地址。欢迎你给我寄25美元，我会把支票开给联合劝募协会（United Way）。现在省下25美元，实际上相当于积累了数千美元。

ARE YOU A BELIEVER YET? YOU NEED TO BE!

你现在是信徒了吗？你必须成为信徒！

There is another thing I want to point out about the above story—my friend is a pessimist about everything. He most likely only half-believed the phrase would work. When your belief level is higher and you truly believe that the techniques in this book will work, your success rate will be much higher. You must believe in what you are doing. We, as human beings, can sense and tell when another is not confident in his or her actions. Ever hear the phrase, “they can smell your fear”? Most animals can actually smell when you are afraid and can be more aggressive with you. Humans can also sense when you are not confident in your actions. When your confidence level is low, you are less likely to achieve your goals. You must, in your core, believe that the techniques in this book will work. Imagine if my friend’s confidence level was higher when he used the phrase; maybe he would have gotten more.

关于上面的故事，我还有一点想指出——我的朋友是个悲观主义者，对什么事都抱有怀疑。他很可能只是半信半疑地认为这句话会奏效。当你更有信心，真正相信这本书里的技巧会奏效时，你的成功率就会高得多。你必须相信自己正在做的事情。作为人类，我们能够感知到他人是否对自己的行为缺乏信心。你听过“他们能闻到你的恐惧”这句话吗？大多数动物确实能闻到你害怕的气味，并会对你表现出更强的攻击性。人类也能感知到你对自己的行为缺乏信心。当你缺乏自信时，你实现目标的可能性就会降低。你必须从内心深处相信这本书里的技巧会奏效。想象一下，如果我的朋友在使用这句话时更有信心，也许他会取得更大的成功。

THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN PAYING AND PURCHASING

支付和购买的区别

Earlier I said there is a difference between paying for and purchasing something. We pay for things we need, like food, clothes, gas, and electricity … you know, the basic things that we need to live in a normal society. I believe you purchase things that are not necessary to live in a modern society, like a car, a computer, your cable, or your Internet service.

我之前说过，付款和购买是有区别的。我们付款是为了购买必需品，比如食物、衣服、汽油和电……你知道，就是那些我们在正常社会中生活所必需的基本东西。我认为，你购买的那些东西并非现代社会生活所必需，比如汽车、电脑、有线电视或网络服务。

Why do I differentiate between the two? Well, when most people pay for things, they accept the price without thinking. They get a bill and they pay it, month after month, without thinking. What if next time you get a bill that you have to pay , you use the phrase? What if it saved you 20 percent off your home energy bill? That would be worth the cost of the book, right? Of course it would. Did you know the average yearly cost for home energy pay out is $240 billion in the Unites States? Could you use an extra $48 billion? That’s 20 percent of $240 billion. The number seems too large to grasp, but on an individual level that equates to roughly $420 a year. If you ask my question for things that you pay for, you will save and make thousands of dollars a year. But, like the lottery, you can’t win if you don’t play. If you don’t ask the question, you will never know the answer. Most of us are willing to “save” money off of things we purchase , and as a society, we purchase a lot of things, but it’s important to remember to use my phrase when you pay for things, also.

我为什么要区分这两者呢？嗯，大多数人在付款时，都会不假思索地接受价格。他们收到账单，然后每月都照常付款，从未想过后果。下次当你收到账单时，如果换一种说法呢？如果它能帮你节省20%的家庭能源账单呢？那这本书就值回票价了，对吧？当然值。你知道美国每年家庭能源支出平均高达2400亿美元吗？你难道不想多省下480亿美元吗？这可是2400亿美元的20%啊！这个数字听起来似乎难以想象，但对个人而言，这相当于每年大约420美元。如果你用我提出的问题来思考你正在支付的费用，你每年就能省下甚至赚到数千美元。但是，就像买彩票一样，你不尝试就永远不会中奖。如果你不问这个问题，你就永远不会知道答案。我们大多数人都愿意在购物时“省钱”，作为一个社会，我们购买了很多东西，但重要的是，在付款时也要记住使用我的这句话。

WHY IT ALWAYS WORKS!

为什么它总是有效！

Did you notice something about the gold scenario? It wasn’t a purchase or a buy , it was a sale . Yeah, the phrase works in that scenario, too. You see, it is my belief that as human beings we are inherently creatures who want to help each other. If I were wrong, then the world wouldn’t exist. Everyone needs help, and everyone likes to give help and feel good about it. That is why I use the phrase, “Is there anything else you can do for me?” You see, I am essentially asking for help, and humans instinctively help each other. So the phrase, even with the most highly skilled and hardened people, triggers something in their brains. In many instances without even realizing it, many people subconsciously “help” you. This phrase breaks down all the barriers that are up in a pay, sell , or purchase situation, and the person on the other end of the question subconsciously and briefly forgets about personal pecuniary interests.

你注意到黄金的例子了吗？那不是买入，而是卖出。没错，这句话在那种情况下也适用。你看，我相信作为人类，我们天生就乐于助人。如果我错了，世界就不会存在。每个人都需要帮助，每个人都喜欢帮助别人，并且乐于助人。这就是为什么我会说“还有什么需要帮忙的吗？”。你看，我本质上是在寻求帮助，而人类的本能就是互相帮助。所以，即使是对那些经验最丰富、最铁石心肠的人来说，这句话也能触动他们的内心。很多时候，人们甚至在不知不觉中就“帮助”了你。这句话打破了买卖交易中所有存在的障碍，让对方在潜意识里短暂地忘记了个人的经济利益。

I was on the phone—a cell phone (one device that seems to have morphed from a purchase to a pay item)—a few weeks back with a friend of mine about this book and the phrase. He was telling me how he was waiting for a call back from his telecom company, because he thought the current rate they were charging him was too high. He was going to tell them that he was going to switch to another carrier. As I alluded to earlier, before you ask the phrase, you have to ask yourself, “What is your goal? What do you want?” I asked my friend what he wanted. I asked him several questions: “Do you like your phone? Do you get good reception? Is the price similar to that of other carriers?” He said he just wants to lower his bill, as he was only upset about the cost. I told him to relax, and when he speaks with the carrier—most likely a person with limited authority—explain that he likes the service and the phone and has been a customer for several years, but feels the monthly fee was high, and that he wondered if “there was anything they could do for him?”

几周前，我和一位朋友通电话——我们用的是手机（一种似乎已经从购买变成付费的设备）——聊到这本书和那句话。他告诉我，他正在等电信公司的回电，因为他觉得现在的资费太高了。他打算告诉他们他要换一家运营商。正如我之前提到的，在你问出那句话之前，你必须先问问自己：“你的目标是什么？你想要什么？”我问朋友他想要什么。我问了他几个问题：“你喜欢你的手机吗？信号好吗？价格和其他运营商差不多吗？”他说他只是想降低话费，因为他唯一不满的就是费用。我告诉他放松，当他与运营商（很可能是一个权限有限的人）交谈时，解释说他喜欢这项服务和手机，并且已经是多年的老客户了，但他觉得月费太高，并想知道“他们是否能为他做些什么？”

You see, this is a modification (like “ What else can you do for me?”) of the phrase (there was no “else”), but it accomplishes the same thing. It magically broke down the tense situation into one in which the other person was now trying to help my friend. The other person had a job to do, and that job ultimately was to use the limited power that the representative had in order to keep a satisfied customer. My friend got his phone bill reduced by several hundred dollars over the life of his agreement. As we mentioned earlier, before you use this powerful phrase, ask yourself what the other person wants to accomplish, and know what you want to accomplish. In this scenario, we were dealing with a customer service agent who had limited power. Because this person was now “helping” my friend, she found a way to save and make him hundreds of dollars .

你看，这其实是对原句的一种修改（类似于“你还能为我做些什么？”），原句里并没有“还能做什么”，但效果是一样的。它神奇地化解了原本紧张的局面，让对方主动帮助了我的朋友。对方有了工作要做，而这项工作的最终目的就是利用客服代表有限的权力来留住客户。我的朋友在合约期内成功节省了几百美元的电话费。正如我们之前提到的，在使用这句强有力的短语之前，先问问自己对方想要达成什么目标，以及你自己想要达成什么目标。在这个例子中，我们面对的是一位权力有限的客服人员。正因为这位客服人员现在在“帮助”我的朋友，所以她找到了一个方法，既帮他省了钱，又让他赚了几百美元。

Just today my friend who sold the gold came to me and said he used the technique. He caught me off guard, and I didn’t understand what he meant. So, he said it again: “I used the technique !” He told me how he saved $40 a month off his cable bill, got more channels, and received $300 in gift cards by saying one simple thing: “Is there anything else you can do for me?” He is now a believer!

就在今天，我那个卖黄金的朋友来找我，说他用了这个方法。我当时完全懵了，一时没明白他的意思。于是，他又重复了一遍：“我用了这个方法！”他告诉我，他只说了一句话：“还有什么需要帮忙的吗？”就省下了每月40美元的有线电视费，还多看了一些频道，最后还收到了价值300美元的礼品卡。他现在彻底信服了！

This one phrase will change your life! Also know that saving $480 ($40 per month times twelve months) is like making more than $100,000 over fifty years. Think about it: Saving $480 is like making $100,000! Could you use an extra $100,000 when you retire?

这句话将改变你的人生！要知道，每月存下480美元（每月40美元，一年下来就是10万美元），相当于50年后赚到10万美元以上。想想看：存下480美元就相当于赚了10万美元！退休时，你难道不想多攒下10万美元吗？

Another friend named John recently came to me to tell me an amazing story about totaling his car. He was on the highway, hit a slick part of the road, did a 360, hit the guardrail, and ultimately totaled his car. Since he wasn’t hurt in the accident, I asked if anyone else was injured, and he said no. I said, “Thank God,” and I thought that was the end of his story.

最近，我另一个朋友约翰跟我讲了一个惊险的故事，他的车撞毁了。当时他在高速公路上，撞到路面湿滑的地方，车子原地转了360度，撞上了护栏，最终报废了。因为他自己没受伤，我就问他有没有其他人受伤，他说没有。我说了声“谢天谢地”，以为他的故事到此就结束了。

John then told me that he bought his car for $8,900 a year ago, and the insurance company told him they were willing to give him $7,300 for his car. John told me that when he asked one question, “Is there anything else you can do for me?” the insurance agent responded by asking, “What were you thinking?”

约翰接着告诉我，他一年前花了8900美元买的这辆车，保险公司却说他们只愿意赔他7300美元。约翰还说，他问了保险代理人一个问题：“还有什么可以帮到我的吗？”代理人却反问：“你在想什么？”

Now, this part is important. John knew in his head what he wanted before asking the all-important phrase that pays. He wanted $8,000, so he told her he was thinking in the $8,300 range. John was assuming they would meet at $8,000; to his surprise—because, as he admitted to me, he had not fully bought into my techniques—she agreed to $8,000. By asking this one simple question, John made $700, and it is tax free ! But, John proudly told me, he wasn’t done. After she agreed, he said, “Well, is there any more you can do for me?” John asked this because at the time of the accident, he happened to have a flat-screen TV in his car. As you can expect, the TV was ruined. She asked him how much the TV was worth, and he told her $250. She said, “Sure, that is a part of your insurance and we will cut you a check for an additional $250.” John had now made close to $1,000 tax-free just by asking. But he still wasn’t done: he then told the agent how he had to pay out-of-pocket tow fees because AAA didn’t cover towing on the highway. Guess what? He got compensated for that, too.

现在，这部分很重要。约翰在问出那句至关重要的“金句”之前，心里就已经想好了要多少钱。他想要8000美元，所以告诉她他考虑的是8300美元左右。约翰以为他们最终会以8000美元成交；但令他惊讶的是——正如他向我承认的那样，他并没有完全相信我的技巧——她竟然同意了8000美元。仅仅问了这一个简单的问题，约翰就赚了700美元，而且这笔钱是免税的！但是，约翰得意地告诉我，他还没完。在她同意之后，他问道：“还有什么需要我帮忙的吗？”约翰这么问是因为事故发生时，他的车里正好有一台平板电视。可想而知，电视机被撞坏了。她问他电视机值多少钱，他告诉她250美元。她说：“当然，这在你的保险范围内，我们会再给你开一张250美元的支票。”约翰光是开口问就赚了将近1000美元的免税款。但这还没完：他接着告诉代理人，因为AAA不承保高速公路上的拖车服务，他不得不自掏腰包支付拖车费。你猜怎么着？他也得到了相应的补偿。

This is a great story. It shows that the technique works, but what it also proves is that this works in every situation. Most people would just accept the amount the insurance company was offering. But not John: he knew about my technique, and it made him $1,000! Don’t accept the first offer, and don’t assume the technique won’t work with big companies.

这是一个很棒的故事。它不仅证明了这种方法的有效性，更重要的是，它证明了这种方法在任何情况下都有效。大多数人都会接受保险公司给出的赔偿金额。但约翰不一样：他知道我的方法，并因此获得了1000美元！不要接受保险公司的第一次报价，也不要认为这种方法对大公司无效。

They work!

它们真的有效！

They work!

它们真的有效！

They work!

它们真的有效！

A DOLLAR SAVED IS A DOLLAR ASKED FOR: BRIEF TESTIMONIALS

省下一美元，就等于要求多花一美元：简短证词

So here are just a few of the victories people I know have had using my technique—just some random samples of people I asked in passing while writing the book. And now that the secret is out, there are bound to be thousands more across America!

以下是我认识的人运用我的方法取得的一些成功案例——这些只是我在写这本书时随意询问的一些例子。现在秘密已经公开，美国各地肯定会有成千上万的人受益！

  • Saved $15 on a shipping charge for some hard drives—Mike S.


    Mike S. 节省了 15 美元的硬盘运费。
  • Saved $30 on shipping for lost credit card and got card sent overnight—Tim C.


    丢失信用卡后，节省了 30 美元的运费，而且信用卡隔夜就寄到了——蒂姆·C。
  • Got two premium channels for cable television for free, a $40 value—Mike S.


    免费获得了两个付费有线电视频道，价值 40 美元——Mike S.
  • Saved $10 on a lunch, by asking if they could reduce the bill—Ryan


    瑞恩通过询问是否可以减免午餐费用，省下了10美元。
  • Saved $13 on printing costs for a project—Shauna F.


    Shauna F. 为一个项目节省了 13 美元的打印费用。
  • Saved $100 on a membership charge for the Chamber of Commerce—John M.


    约翰·M. 节省了 100 美元的商会会员费。
  • Saved 10 percent on chiropractic work for an entire year—Chris M.


    克里斯·M：一整年节省了 10% 的脊椎按摩费用。
  • Saved $4,000 on a home HVAC system—Andrew M.


    安德鲁·M. 为家庭暖通空调系统节省了 4,000 美元
  • Saved $4,000 on dental work and got two more teeth done—Mike P.


    节省了 4000 美元的牙科费用，还补了两颗牙——Mike P.
  • Saved $100 on a christening banquet charge—Andrew M.


    安德鲁·M. 节省了 100 美元的洗礼宴会费用
  • Reduced debt by $360 by asking credit card company to reduce the bill—Andrew M.


    通过要求信用卡公司减少账单，减少了 360 美元的债务——安德鲁·M。
  • Saved $25 on service bill at Land Rover—Kristin S.


    在路虎维修中心节省了 25 美元——克里斯汀·S
  • Saved my company $500,000 by asking a finance company to reduce their rate—Jason B.


    通过要求金融公司降低利率，为我的公司节省了 50 万美元——Jason B.
  • Got my company an extra $100,000 by asking American Express to increase our line of credit—Jeff J.


    我通过向美国运通公司申请提高信用额度，为我的公司争取到了额外的 10 万美元——杰夫·J。
  • Saved $23,000 on a Porsche engine by asking Porche headquarters if there was anything they could do for me, even though my Porche was out of warranty—Matt R.


    马特·R：我向保时捷总部询问他们是否能帮我解决保时捷发动机的问题，即使我的保时捷已经过了保修期，结果节省了 23,000 美元。

A FEW MORE MAGIC QUESTIONS TO NEGOTIATE FOR MORE

还有一些神奇的问题可以用来谈判，争取更多

Many people don’t ask any questions. When you get a bill, do you ask yourself, “Is this right?” Or do you ask the representative if there is any way they could reduce the amount? To some people, asking for a discount after you get the bill is unethical. But, there is nothing wrong with making sure the bill is accurate or asking for a discount off the current bill. Most companies will do it, and it is a very effective negotiation tool.

很多人收到账单后都不会问任何问题。你会问自己“这个价格对吗？”还是会询问客服人员是否有办法降低金额？有些人认为收到账单后再要求折扣是不道德的。但是，确认账单的准确性或要求折扣并没有错。大多数公司都会这样做，而且这是一种非常有效的谈判技巧。

But here are some other great questions that work magically in reducing what you have to take out of your pocket:

但以下这些问题也能神奇地帮你减少开支：

“CAN WE ACCOMPLISH THE SAME THING FOR LESS MONEY?”

“我们能否用更少的钱完成同样的事情？”

This question will prompt the seller to think if they can reduce the price or maybe give you something else of value. I used this question when I had my bathroom redone, and saved $1,000. How did this happen? The contractor just spent an extra day in the bathroom himself, rather than having a crew in there. My bathroom was done a day later, but I saved $1,000! Just by asking ! Just recently, when purchasing some media for one of our products, I used this exact phrase as a follow-up to, “Is there anything else you can do for me?” I wound up saving a total of $5,000, and I got twice the number of impressions I was looking for.

这个问题会促使卖家思考是否可以降价，或者提供其他有价值的东西。我装修浴室的时候就用了这个问题，省了1000美元。这是怎么回事呢？承包商只是自己多花了一天时间在浴室里干活，而不是派人一起。我的浴室晚了一天完工，但我却省了1000美元！仅仅是问了一下而已！就在不久前，我为我们的一个产品购买媒体宣传材料时，我用了同样的句式，在问完“还有什么可以帮到我的吗？”之后又问了一句。结果我一共省了5000美元，而且获得的曝光量是预期的两倍。

“IS THAT THE BEST YOU CAN DO?”

“这就是你所能做到的最好结果吗？”

This is a very commonly used question and the answer is almost always “Yes, that is the best I can do.” In response to their answer, ask it again. “Is that the best you can do? Really?” This is a very effective technique and will save you money almost every time. This phrase is effective, because most people have heard it or encountered it at one time or another in their lives. As a result, this familiar phrase almost always gets a follow-up, which is usually even more effective if the person asking doesn’t get what they want. I was in sales training and the trainer said it takes five no ’s before you get a yes ; sometimes the follow-up is where you get what you want.

这是一个非常常见的问题，答案几乎总是“是的，这是我能做到的极限了”。针对他们的回答，再问一遍：“你真的只能做到这个程度了吗？”这是一个非常有效的技巧，几乎每次都能帮你省钱。这句话之所以有效，是因为大多数人一生中都曾听到或遇到过。因此，这句熟悉的短语几乎总能引出后续的询问，而如果提问者没有得到他们想要的，后续询问通常会更加有效。我曾经参加过销售培训，培训师说过，在得到一个“是”之前，你需要经历五个“不”；有时候，后续询问才是你最终获得想要的东西的关键。

“DO YOU HAVE ANY DISCOUNTS AVAILABLE?”

请问你们有任何折扣吗？

I have my work clothes dry-cleaned at a local dry cleaner, and I have been going there for a few years. One day, I asked, “Do you have any discounts available?” The answer was yes, and for three years I’ve received a 15 percent discount on my dry cleaning. This discount has saved me hundreds of dollars a year. This question is a great one to use in big box retailers. I use it at places like Macy’s, Bloomingdale’s, Best Buy, Walmart, and Target, and I save money every time! I could fill pages with examples from people who tell me this works. It does!

我的工作服一直在一家本地干洗店干洗，已经光顾好几年了。有一天，我问：“你们有什么折扣吗？” 答案是肯定的，之后三年我一直享受着15%的干洗折扣。这项折扣每年能帮我省下几百美元。这个问题在大型零售商那里也同样适用。我在梅西百货、布鲁明戴尔百货、百思买、沃尔玛和塔吉特等地方都用过，每次都能省钱！我可以写满好几页纸，列举出无数个成功案例。这招真的管用！

“I MADE A MISTAKE; WHAT CAN YOU DO FOR ME?”

“我犯了个错误；你能帮我做些什么？”

We all make mistakes, and I make them every day. Recognizing that you made the mistake is extremely important. Many people, even after recognizing that they made a mistake, do not realize that you can fix it by using not only the phrase, “What else can you do for me?” but also the other strategies and techniques in this book.

我们都会犯错，我每天都会犯错。认识到自己犯错至关重要。很多人即使意识到自己犯了错，也没有意识到除了问“你还能为我做些什么？”之外，还可以运用本书中的其他策略和技巧来弥补错误。

Recently, a friend of mine made a mistake when leasing a new car. He went from his 2010 car to a new 2011 in late December of 2011. The mistake he made was that he paid his lease payment in December for his old car and then got his new car without realizing his December payment was for the use of his old car in January 2012. He caught his mistake a few months later and called the dealership to explain. Calling a car dealership and asking them to write you a check is a very formidable task. My friend calmly explained how the mistake was made and asked if there was anything they could do for him. Sure enough, they obliged by giving him a $500 credit in the service department. So you see, the techniques in this book for negotiating for more can be used even after a negotiation has happened. Don’t let pride get in the way of your financial future.

最近，我的一位朋友在租车时犯了个错误。他在2011年12月底把2010款的旧车换成了2011款的新车。他的错误在于，他在12月份支付了旧车的租金，然后拿到新车时却没意识到，那笔12月份的租金实际上是2012年1月份旧车的使用费。几个月后他才发现自己犯了错，于是打电话给经销商解释。打电话给汽车经销商，让他们给你开支票，这可不是件容易的事。我的朋友冷静地解释了错误经过，并询问他们是否能帮他做些什么。果然，他们同意了，给了他500美元的维修保养抵用券。所以你看，这本书里教的谈判技巧，即使在谈判结束后，仍然可以运用。别让自尊心阻碍了你的财务未来。

BELIEVE MORE!

多相信！

As I type, one of my employees entered my office to tell me he used the “technique” on his credit card company. My employee explained that he had accumulated 90,000 points on his credit card that he was anticipating using for free travel, but the points expired. He called his credit card company and explained the situation. Then he asked, “Is there anything you can do for me?” They said, “Yes, we will credit you back half of the points today.” He followed up with a sincere thank-you and then asked, “What about tomorrow? Can you give me back all of the points tomorrow?” The person on the telephone chuckled and said, “I have never had anyone ask that question, but yes, I will.” My employee made an honest mistake and just wanted it to be rectified, and by asking questions he got what he wanted. Ask more , and you will get more .

我正在打字的时候，一位员工走进我的办公室，告诉我他用这个“技巧”联系了他的信用卡公司。他解释说，他的信用卡累积了9万积分，原本打算用这些积分兑换免费旅行，结果积分过期了。他打电话给信用卡公司说明了情况，然后问道：“你们能帮我解决一下吗？”对方说：“可以，今天先退还一半积分。”他真诚地道谢后又问：“那明天呢？明天能把所有积分都退给我吗？”电话那头的人笑着说：“我还没遇到过这样的问题，不过没关系，我会的。”我的员工犯了一个无心之失，只是想寻求纠正，而通过提问，他如愿以偿了。多问，你就会得到更多。

WHAT DO SALESPEOPLE KNOW, AND HOW DO I KNOW WHEN I AM BEING SOLD?

销售人员究竟了解多少？我如何知道自己是否被推销了？

I learned so much of the material above from being an insider in the sales world, since I am a salesperson. And at the end of the day, knowing what the salesperson knows goes a long way to help you negotiate for more. Now, the market is flooded with thousands of sales training books, and there are hundreds of training courses that legions of salespeople—and wannabe salespeople—flock to every year to hone sales skills they can use against you to sell you stuff. Now there is nothing wrong with learning your craft and perfecting it. A plumber or a machinist learns a certain set of skills and over time perfects and hones those skills to make them better. Salespeople are not bad people, and like any other professional, they hone their skills too. Now clearly there are some bad apples in the sales game. And unfortunately for salespeople, the bad apples seem to get all the attention and hurt the image of the sales profession as a whole.

以上很多内容都是我从销售行业内部学到的，因为我本身就是一名销售人员。说到底，了解销售人员的知识对于谈判技巧大有裨益。如今，市面上充斥着成千上万本销售培训书籍，每年都有成百上千的培训课程吸引着无数的销售人员——以及那些渴望成为销售人员的人——前来磨练销售技巧，以便日后能用这些技巧向你推销产品。学习和精进自己的技艺无可厚非。水管工或机械师学习一套技能，然后随着时间的推移不断完善和磨练这些技能，使之更加精湛。销售人员并非坏人，和其他专业人士一样，他们也在不断提升自己的技能。当然，销售行业中也存在一些害群之马。不幸的是，这些害群之马似乎总是能吸引所有人的注意力，损害整个销售行业的形象。

But more commonly, consumers are often unable to identify the techniques a salesperson is using and thus are ill-equipped to combat them. This lack of preparedness leads to frustration on the part of the consumer and often gives salespeople a bad name. I know I’m painting with a broad brush, but generally, when people are taken advantage of it is usually because they didn’t follow the 3 P’s + 1 P technique. They then tell their friends about their bad experience, and the salesperson is demonized.

但更常见的情况是，消费者往往无法识别销售人员使用的销售技巧，因此也缺乏应对之策。这种准备不足会导致消费者感到沮丧，并常常败坏销售人员的名声。我知道我的说法有些以偏概全，但通常来说，人们被占便宜往往是因为他们没有遵循“3P+1P”销售技巧。之后，他们会把自己的糟糕经历告诉朋友，销售人员也就因此名声扫地。

When I was first introduced to selling cars, I had the same perception that most people have—car salespeople are the bottom of the barrel; they are dishonest and intent on screwing people. Well, if that was my perception, why would I take a chance and be employed as a car salesperson? To be honest … I saw an advertisement in the newspaper that guaranteed $425 a week, and I needed money. I was fresh out of college and didn’t have my life plan mapped out. I was nervous, because I had never sold anything before—at least I didn’t think I had.

我最初接触汽车销售行业时，和大多数人一样，觉得汽车销售员都是社会底层，他们不诚实，一心只想坑骗顾客。既然如此，我为什么还要冒险去做汽车销售员呢？说实话……我在报纸上看到一则广告，保证每周425美元的收入，而我当时正需要钱。我刚从大学毕业，对未来还没有规划。我很紧张，因为我以前从未卖过东西——至少我自认为没有。

Both the formal and on-the-job training I received from Ford-Lincoln-Mercury was top-notch. During my first two weeks, all I did was train. The first thing a good salesperson is taught is product knowledge. So, I was determined to know everything about every make and model, and to be successful, I had to. I sat at a desk in the back of the showroom and no one talked to me. Now, this was in 1997 at the height of an economic boom, and people were buying cars just because they could. I felt uneasy and didn’t understand why no one talked to me. Finally, when people began to talk to me, it was to tell me that I wasn’t cut out for this line of work. I was a “college boy” and this was for men. It shocked me how mean some of the salespeople were to me, but I later learned that I was perceived as someone who was taking money out of their pockets and food off their tables. Eventually, I proved that I was worthy and that I was sticking around. I became friendly with all of the other sales professionals and have maintained relationships with many of them over the years.

我在福特-林肯-水星公司接受的正规培训和在职培训都堪称一流。头两周，我除了培训什么都没做。一个优秀的销售员首先要学习的就是产品知识。因此，我决心要了解每一款车型的一切，要想成功，我必须做到。我坐在展厅后面的办公桌旁，没人跟我说话。当时是1997年，正值经济繁荣时期，人们买车只是因为他们买得起。我感到很不自在，不明白为什么没人跟我说话。最后，当人们开始跟我说话时，他们却告诉我，我不适合这份工作。我当时还是个“大学生”，而这份工作是成年人的天下。一些销售员对我的刻薄让我震惊，但我后来才知道，在他们眼里，我是一个会从他们口袋里掏钱、抢走他们饭碗的人。最终，我证明了自己的价值，并留了下来。我与其他所有销售人员都成了朋友，多年来一直与其中许多人保持着联系。

Now, I went through this extensive sales training and have supplemented that with all kinds of sales education through the years, because, as I stated earlier, I am a salesperson. But you are a salesperson too, although you may not know it yet. And here is some quick insider information that can transform you from a victim to a player in the sales game.

我接受过全面的销售培训，并且多年来不断补充各种销售知识，因为正如我之前所说，我是一名销售人员。但你也是一名销售人员，尽管你可能还没有意识到这一点。以下是一些内部信息，可以帮助你从销售游戏中的受害者转变为玩家。

INSIDER SALES TECHNIQUE: LOWERING CUSTOMER EXPECTATIONS

内部销售技巧：降低客户期望值

Often we hear how a particular business is cutthroat, and car selling is one of those businesses. It is not for the faint of heart or for people who are easily offended. One of the on-the-job skills that I learned—and all salespeople learn sooner or later—is to develop tough, thick skin. I had to let things that seemed offensive or rude roll off my back. Salespeople are taught not to be shaken or intimidated. When I first started actually selling cars, we used a technique called “dollar drops.” The typical question a customer asked when negotiating was, “Can you reduce the price?” We, as salespeople, were taught to look and act shocked. Then we were supposed to give in and reduce the price—by one dollar. Now imagine—a customer comes in to buy a Grand Marquis for $19,999 and wants a discount. We were taught to say, “Well, if I could get you $19,998, would you buy it right now?” This technique, called “dollar drops,” blew up if not done properly, and for a young salesperson it was tough to do. The purpose of this was to lower the expectation of the buyer, while at the same time not offending him or her. After we used this technique, the customer realized that we weren’t going to drop the price by thousands. We had effectively lowered their expectations and put the entire sale process into perspective.

我们经常听到有人说某个行业竞争残酷，汽车销售就是其中之一。这行不适合胆小的人，也不适合容易被冒犯的人。我在工作中学到的一项技能——所有销售人员迟早都会学到——就是练就一副厚脸皮。我必须对那些看似冒犯或粗鲁的话一笑置之。销售人员被教导不要被吓倒或动摇。我刚开始卖车的时候，我们用一种叫做“降价”的技巧。客户在谈判时最常问的问题是：“能降价吗？”我们作为销售人员，被教导要装出一副惊讶的样子。然后我们应该让步，降价——哪怕只降一美元。现在想象一下——一位客户进来想买一辆19999美元的Grand Marquis，想要打折。我们被教导要说：“如果我能以19998美元的价格卖给您，您现在就买吗？”这种被称为“降价”的技巧，如果运用不当会适得其反，而且对于年轻的销售人员来说，掌握起来难度很大。其目的是降低买家的期望值，同时又不冒犯他们。运用这种技巧后，客户意识到我们不会大幅降价。我们有效地降低了他们的期望值，让他们对整个销售过程有了更清晰的认识。

INSIDER SALES TECHNIQUE: BUILD RAPPORT AND TAKE CONTROL

内部销售技巧：建立融洽关系并掌控局面

When you are not in control of a negotiation, you are more likely to leave money on the table and not get the deal you could have. A good salesperson will first build a rapport with you, usually by asking you questions about your life and what you do. They do this to take your mind off the real reason why you are there. Top-notch salespeople can relate to pretty much any person and are thus perceived as good guys or gals. By building a rapport with you, they now seem more like your friend, and friends always look out for each other, right? When you are asked questions like, “How about them Red Sox?” or “How’s the weather?” they are just softening you up and ultimately gaining your trust. Before you know it, they have taken control of the situation and you have no idea what hit you. It is okay to build rapport. It’s also okay as a buyer to interact, but don’t let your guard down.

当你无法掌控谈判节奏时，你很可能错失良机，无法达成理想的交易。优秀的销售人员会先与你建立融洽的关系，通常会询问你的生活和工作情况。他们这样做是为了让你暂时忘记你此行的真正目的。顶尖的销售人员几乎能与任何人建立联系，因此会给人留下良好的印象。通过建立融洽的关系，他们看起来更像是你的朋友，而朋友之间总是会互相照顾，对吧？当他们问你“红袜队怎么样？”或者“天气如何？”之类的问题时，他们只是在逐步放松你的警惕，最终赢得你的信任。不知不觉中，他们就掌控了局面，而你却毫无防备。建立融洽的关系是可以的，作为买家，与销售人员互动也是可以的，但千万不要放松警惕。

Recently, I got a call from a young man named Rick from my dealership (I drive a Lexus and I mostly lease my vehicles). Rick said something like, “Mike, you are a preferred customer and your current Lexus is in pristine shape. Our inventory is low on your model; if I could get you in a new one for the same price or less, that would be a good deal, right?” Now, the “right?” part is what we call a “tie down,” as he asked me a question that pretty much the only rational answer to is “ yes .” The other leap he took right in the very beginning was addressing me by my first name and not my surname; this makes the sale more personal and less formal, even though we are dealing with a very expensive proposition. This doesn’t work in every situation, but it worked with me. So I told him, “Great job on the tie down; I will be there later.” It was obvious to me he was well trained. Rick then tried to get me to commit by taking control. He tried to set a time; I responded by saying I would be there when I’d be there. He was nice and friendly, using great tonalities. He had the ability to use his voice to emphasize certain words and was genuinely excited. Rick’s excitable and effervescent sales pitch was the key to him closing me. He used his tonalities and the persuasive techniques like rapport building to get me in the door.

最近，我接到一个自称里克（Rick）的年轻人的电话，他是我们经销店的（我开的是雷克萨斯，而且我的车大多是租赁的）。里克说：“迈克，您是我们的VIP客户，您现在的雷克萨斯车况非常好。我们店里您这款车的库存不多了；如果我能帮您以相同或更低的价格买到一辆新车，那肯定很划算，对吧？” 他问的“对吧？”其实就是个“套路”，因为他问的这个问题，几乎唯一的合理答案就是“是”。他一开始就直呼我的名字而不是姓氏，这让销售过程显得更亲切、更随意，即使这是一笔很贵的交易。这种做法并非在所有情况下都有效，但对我来说确实奏效了。所以我告诉他：“套路做得好；我待会儿就过去。” 我感觉他受过专业的培训。之后，里克试图通过掌控局面来促使我下定决心。他想定个时间；我回应说，到时候我自然会到。他态度友善，说话语气也很好。他能巧妙地运用声音强调某些词语，而且看起来非常热情。里克那充满活力、激情四溢的销售话术是他成功拿下我的关键。他运用了语气和建立良好关系等说服技巧，最终让我走进了店门。

During the call I began to use rapport building on him. I asked him where he was from, how long he had been in the business, and told him he was doing a great job. I was doing this so he would both “like me” and really like me. A salesperson will always act as if they like a prospective customer, because it means dollars and cents in his or her pocket. But, if the salesperson genuinely likes you, you are more apt to get a better deal. So, when you are in a situation that involves buying or selling certain items, take an interest in the other person.
