Whether you are the buyer or the seller, tell them they are doing a great job and ask them questions like “How long have you been doing this?” “Where are you from?” and—one of my favorites when it comes down to making a decision—“Would you do it if you were me?” That question reaches into the moral core of everyone asked, and unless you’re dealing with a sociopathic narcissist (e.g., Bernie Madoff), you will get an honest answer.

通话过程中，我开始尝试与他建立融洽的关系。我问他来自哪里，从事这行多久了，还夸他做得非常出色。我这样做是为了让他既“喜欢”我，又真正喜欢我。销售人员总是会表现得对潜在客户很友好，因为这意味着能赚到钱。但是，如果销售人员真心喜欢你，你就更有可能获得更好的交易。所以，当你遇到买卖商品的情况时，要对对方表现出兴趣。无论你是买家还是卖家，都要夸奖他们做得好，并问一些问题，比如“你从事这行多久了？”“你来自哪里？”以及——在做决定时我最喜欢的一个问题——“如果你是我，你会这么做吗？”这个问题触及了每个人的道德底线，除非你遇到的是反社会型自恋者（比如伯纳德·麦道夫），否则你都会得到一个诚实的答案。

When I arrived at the dealership, the general manager greeted me, then quickly handed me off to a seasoned car guy named Gene. I told them about the call and picked out a vehicle that I would consider. You see, for me it was initially an offer I couldn’t refuse—get a new vehicle at the same price and color I wanted. Gene began to ask all about me, what I did, where I was from, and so forth. I could tell immediately that he was a very nice guy. He was well dressed, well spoken, and likeable. He was very easy to talk to, and made buying or leasing painless. I sat there while they ran the numbers. And I did pick out a car that was slightly more expensive than my original, so I knew they would hit me with a higher payment. I then applied a combination of all of the skills mentioned in this book. One of the easiest to use and most important skills was rapport building with Gene by finding a commonality with him; I sold cars right out of college, so we chatted about the business, and he respected my knowledge. Secondly I used the phrase that pays: “What else can you do for me?” Funny, when I used the phrase, both Gene and Willy (the general manager) were perplexed with the question; their initial response was to claim they couldn’t go any lower.

我到达经销店后，总经理接待了我，然后迅速把我介绍给一位名叫吉恩的资深汽车销售员。我告诉他们我之前接到的电话，并挑选了一辆我考虑的车型。你知道，对我来说，这最初是一个无法拒绝的提议——以我想要的价格和颜色买到一辆新车。吉恩开始询问我的各种信息，比如我的职业、我来自哪里等等。我立刻就感觉到他是个非常友善的人。他衣着得体，谈吐优雅，让人感觉很亲切。和他交谈非常轻松愉快，让购车或租赁的过程变得轻松无压力。我坐在那里，看着他们计算价格。我选的这辆车比我最初想买的那辆略贵一些，所以我知道他们的月供会更高。然后，我运用了这本书里提到的所有技巧。其中最简单也最重要的技巧之一就是和吉恩建立融洽的关系，找到我们之间的共同点；我大学毕业后就卖过车，所以我们聊起了这行，他很尊重我的专业知识。其次，我用了那句很管用的话：“你们还能为我做些什么？” 有趣的是，当我用这句话时，吉恩和威利（总经理）都对这个问题感到困惑；他们最初的反应是声称他们已经不能再降价了。

In the end, I got a car with more options than my previous vehicle for roughly $7,000 off the retail price, complete with all-weather mats and leather protection (I have a little girl, so the protection is definitely necessary). In addition, I also got two full tanks of gas—all for virtually the same price as my other car.

最后，我以比零售价低约7000美元的价格买到了一辆配置比之前那辆车更高的车，而且还配备了全天候脚垫和真皮座椅保护套（我有个女儿，所以保护套绝对必不可少）。此外，我还加满了两箱油——所有这些加起来的价格几乎和我之前的车一样。

How do I know I got a good deal? Well, I followed the 3 P’s + 1 P strategy: I had a plan, I knew what they wanted, and I knew what I wanted. Plus, I was prepared to walk away. Could I have negotiated a “better deal”? Maybe it was possible, but highly unlikely. When you are trying to get the best deal possible, all you have to do is implement the strategies and the techniques in this book, and you will never have to ask yourself, “Did I get a good deal?” As I stated earlier, even if you find that you made a mistake, you can still apply the techniques in this book after the fact to minimize the severity of the mistake. You just have to ask!

我怎么知道自己谈成了好价钱？嗯，我遵循了“3P+1P”策略：我制定了计划，了解对方的需求，也清楚自己想要什么。此外，我还做好了随时放弃的准备。我还能谈成“更好的价格”吗？也许有可能，但可能性极小。当你努力争取最佳交易时，你只需运用本书中的策略和技巧，就无需再问自己“我谈成了好价钱吗？”。正如我之前所说，即使你发现自己犯了错误，你仍然可以事后运用本书中的技巧来尽量减少错误的影响。你只需要问自己！

#↩

CHAPTER 7

第七章

HOW TO SAVE MORE!

如何省更多钱！

FIRST OF ALL—DON’T BUY WHAT YOU CAN’T AFFORD

首先——不要买你买不起的东西。

A few years ago, Saturday Night Live with Steve Martin aired a really funny spoof about the infomercial business. They were mocking a well-known pitchman who has pitched everything from how to get “Free Money” to a tape that cures pain to books that give you a photographic memory. The skit was about a book on how to get out of debt titled Don’t Buy Stuff You Cannot Afford . It sounds simplistically humorous, but it’s also very true. In this MTV Cribs society, we want to appear wealthy and seem to be addicted to appearing to have stuff. Remember MC Hammer, a famous rapper who appeared to have everything but lost it all? Or celebrities like Nicolas Cage and others who end up bankrupt or sell off assets simply because they bought things they couldn’t afford?

几年前，史蒂夫·马丁主持的《周六夜现场》播出了一段非常搞笑的电视购物广告恶搞短片。他们嘲讽了一位知名推销员，他推销过各种各样的东西，从如何“免费获得金钱”到能治愈疼痛的磁带，再到能让人拥有过目不忘能力的书籍。这段短片讲述的是一本名为《别买你负担不起的东西》的摆脱债务的书。听起来似乎有点简单粗暴，但却很有道理。在这个充斥着MTV Cribs（MTV名人豪宅）的社会里，我们都想看起来很富有，似乎对拥有物质财富上瘾。还记得MC Hammer吗？这位著名的说唱歌手曾经看起来拥有一切，但最终却一无所有。还有像尼古拉斯·凯奇这样的名人，他们最终破产或变卖资产，仅仅是因为他们买了自己负担不起的东西。

One of the main reasons why the real estate market is a total mess is because too many people bought unaffordable houses. They signed up for exotic mortgages without having to document their income, hoping somehow they could pay for it. The American Dream is to own a home with a white picket fence, but in reality the dream is not realized overnight. As with most things that happen overnight, you eventually wake up in a real nightmare.

房地产市场一团糟的主要原因之一是太多人购买了他们负担不起的房子。他们签下了复杂的抵押贷款，却无需提供收入证明，只是抱着侥幸心理，希望自己能偿还得起。拥有一栋带白色栅栏的房子是美国人的梦想，但现实是，梦想并非一蹴而就。就像大多数一夜之间发生的事一样，最终你会从噩梦中醒来。

I knew a guy who lacked formal education and had no marketable skills, but he got lucky with a get-rich-quick scheme. He went from zero income to making a projected $200,000 a year. However, he was only pacing $200,000 a year, and hadn’t yet actually earned that amount over a full year. Despite this, he decided he was going to buy a big home, and I remember thinking, “He is going to lose this house, and his wife and daughter are going to be devastated.” Sure enough, less than a year later the get-rich money dried up, and he had no marketable skills to fall back on. Not surprisingly, he couldn’t come close to paying his $5,000-a-month mortgage. The bank fore-closed, he lost his home, and he is now living in his in-laws’ basement. This is happening all over America, and everyone wants to blame the big banks or financial institutions for creating this chaotic, unstable financial world. In reality, if people only bought things they could afford, we would not be in this crisis.

我认识一个人，他没受过正规教育，也没有什么谋生技能，却靠着一个快速致富的计划走了狗屎运。他从零收入一下子跃升到预计年收入20万美元。然而，他只是按计划年入20万美元，实际上还没赚够一年。尽管如此，他还是决定买一套大房子。我记得当时我就想：“他肯定会失去这房子，他的妻子和女儿肯定会伤心欲绝。” 果不其然，不到一年，他的致富之道就破灭了，而他也没有任何可以依靠的技能。不出所料，他连每月5000美元的房贷都付不起。银行收回了他的房子，他失去了房子，现在只能住在岳父母家的地下室里。这种情况在美国各地都在发生，而每个人都想把责任归咎于大型银行或金融机构，说是他们造成了如今混乱不堪、动荡不安的金融世界。事实上，如果人们只购买自己买得起的东西，我们就不会陷入这场危机。

When you want to buy anything—from a pen to a piece of clothing to a house—ask yourself:

当你想买任何东西——从钢笔、衣服到房子——时，问问自己：

Can I afford to pay for it right now?

我现在能付得起吗？

Can I afford to part with the cash that I have to get the thing I want?

我有能力花掉我现有的钱去买我想要的东西吗？

Do I have a plan to be able to make the monthly mortgage payments, plus all of the other expenses?

我是否有计划能够支付每月房贷以及所有其他开支？

If you are not one hundred percent positive, then you can’t afford it. It’s that simple. If you can’t afford it, then you can’t buy it. Period! Later, I will teach you how to be more disciplined as you run YOU Enterprises, Inc. In the future, with proper planning, you will absolutely get everything you want and desire, but if you are dishonest with yourself, your debt will continue to climb and make financial freedom more difficult.

如果你没有百分之百的信心，那就买不起。就这么简单。买不起，就别买。就这么简单！以后我会教你如何更自律地经营你的“YOU Enterprises, Inc.”公司。未来，只要规划得当，你绝对能得到你想要的一切；但如果你对自己不诚实，你的债务就会不断攀升，让你更难实现财务自由。

CASH IS KING

现金为王

Over the past four decades, the proliferation of credit cards has been extraordinary. In fact, many people only use “plastic.” If you are in debt and you want to reduce that debt, simply follow this very simple-to-understand and easy-to-implement technique: buy and pay for things only with cash. Don’t even use a debit card. Debit cards are convenient, but many cost you money with fees. Did you know the average person wastes $200 per year on ATM fees? Crazy! Check your statement! For some reason, cash is the new four-letter word. People seem afraid to use it. Cash is clumsy and inconvenient. But, until cash becomes obsolete—and I cringe at the day that may happen— cash is what runs this country and the world. When you buy and pay with cash , you will understand the true value of those dollar bills and the coins in your hand. A debit card cuts out the physiological and psychological response that our body and brain register when we actually touch, feel, count, and smell the money. Later we will discuss how to run your life like a business, and one of the principles in that section is to become fiscally responsible for your financial health. Debt is a big part of it.

过去四十年，信用卡的普及速度惊人。事实上，许多人只用“塑料卡”。如果你负债累累，想要减少债务，只需遵循这个简单易懂、易于执行的方法：只用现金购物和支付。甚至不要使用借记卡。借记卡虽然方便，但很多借记卡都会收取手续费。你知道吗？普通人每年在ATM取款手续费上浪费200美元！简直不可思议！看看你的账单就知道了！不知为何，现金现在成了人们避之不及的词汇。人们似乎害怕使用它。现金笨重又不方便。但是，在现金彻底消失之前——我真不敢想象那一天会到来——现金仍然是这个国家乃至世界运转的基石。当你用现金购物和支付时，你才会真正体会到手中那些纸币和硬币的价值。借记卡会阻断我们身体和大脑在触摸、感受、清点和嗅闻金钱时所产生的生理和心理反应。稍后我们将探讨如何像经营企业一样管理你的生活，其中一个原则就是对自己的财务健康负责。债务是其中非常重要的一部分。

In order to reduce and eliminate your debt with this strategy, you must only use cash and hard currency. Use hundred-dollar bills, because when you break a $100 bill, you think harder about what it takes to make that hundred versus a $10 or a $20 bill. Use your biggest bills when you buy things. Try this for a month and watch your debt dwindle. You can reduce your debt now .

为了运用这种策略减少并最终消除债务，你必须只使用现金和硬通货。尽量使用百元大钞，因为当你找零一张百元钞时，你会比找零一张十元或二十元钞时更仔细地思考凑够一百元需要多少钱。购物时尽量使用面额最大的钞票。尝试一个月，你会发现债务逐渐减少。现在就可以开始减少债务了。

Paying with cash is not only better for your pocketbook; it also helps the merchant selling you things. When you use a credit or a debit card, the merchant pays a fee to Visa, MasterCard, or American Express, ranging from 1 to 8 percent of the purchase. Before you divulge how you pay for something, ask these questions: What if I pay in cash? Can you work on the price for me? You see, cash not only increases the merchant’s bottom line, but also your own bottom line. More times than not, this effective and easy technique will save you money. The other very important benefit for the merchant is the reduced risk of bad debt. It’s possible the credit card will be declined, and if it is, the merchant gets charged for that transaction. If a check is written, there is a possibility of insufficient funds or a stop payment on the check. This is also an example of win-win negotiation. You get the product for less, and the merchant reduces his cost of selling you the goods.

用现金支付不仅更省钱，还能帮助商家。如果您使用信用卡或借记卡，商家需要向Visa、MasterCard或American Express支付手续费，费用通常在交易额的1%到8%之间。在您透露付款方式之前，不妨问问自己：如果我用现金支付呢？价格可以再优惠一些吗？您看，现金支付不仅能提高商家的利润，也能让您省钱。很多时候，这种简单有效的支付方式都能帮您省钱。对商家来说，另一个非常重要的好处是降低了坏账风险。信用卡可能会被拒付，如果被拒付，商家就得承担这笔交易的费用。如果用支票支付，则可能出现资金不足或支票被止付的情况。这也是一种双赢的谈判方式。您能以更低的价格买到商品，而商家也能降低销售成本。

Consider the following scenarios to prove my point.

以下情景可以证明我的观点。

Heather, a medical professional, was working holidays and pulling overtime as a result of over $55,000 in credit card debt due to medical bills. She tossed and turned countless sleepless nights, juggling the bills in her mind. It took her some time, but she applied the techniques in my book, cut up her credit cards, and climbed out of debt.

希瑟是一名医护人员，由于医疗账单欠下超过5.5万美元的信用卡债务，她不得不节假日加班加点地工作。无数个不眠之夜，她辗转反侧，辗转反侧，脑子里全是账单。她花了一些时间，但最终运用了我书中的方法，剪掉了信用卡，摆脱了债务。

By the time she was twenty-eight years old, Shaniqua had amassed close to $30,000 in debt, with about half of it in student loans. Like many young adults, her debt load started when she was eighteen and gleefully got her first clothing store card. She now had sixteen credit cards! She applied the techniques: paying with cash and running her life like a business. She also climbed out of her debt quagmire.

莎妮卡28岁时，已经背负了近3万美元的债务，其中大约一半是学生贷款。和许多年轻人一样，她的债务始于18岁，当时她兴高采烈地办了第一张服装店信用卡。她竟然有16张信用卡！她学会了各种理财技巧：用现金支付，像经营企业一样管理自己的生活。最终，她也摆脱了债务泥潭。

Kristin was buried in credit card debt for years, and her credit score was negatively impacted. She was able to pay only her minimum monthly payment and sometimes used one credit card to pay the other! She applied my principles and in a short period of time reduced almost $100,000 in credit card debt to only $30,000. She increased her credit score and gained a grasp on her financial future. And she did this without credit agencies.

克里斯汀多年来深陷信用卡债务泥潭，信用评分也因此受到严重影响。她每月只能勉强支付最低还款额，有时甚至用一张信用卡来偿还另一张！她运用了我的理财方法，在短时间内就将近10万美元的信用卡债务减少到仅剩3万美元。她的信用评分显著提升，也重新掌控了自己的财务未来。而且，这一切都是在没有信用机构的情况下完成的。

NEGOTIATE YOUR DEBT

协商您的债务

While this book is not a “debt book” per se, the totality of the techniques, when combined in a debt situation, will most certainly apply. You can negotiate your debt, regardless of the type of debt. Let’s say you owe one hundred dollars and you want to eliminate it, but you only have sixty dollars. Call the person or company to whom the debt is owed and tell them you can’t pay the one hundred dollars, but you can pay sixty right now. Asking to reduce the debt can and does work in many situations, without any negative impact on your credit. You just need to ask. If the offer of paying sixty dollars on a one hundred dollar debt is accepted, you have eliminated forty percent of the debt instantly, and the entire one hundred–dollar debt is now also gone.

虽然这本书本身并非一本“债务指南”，但其中所有技巧，如果结合运用到实际的债务情境中，绝对适用。无论债务类型如何，你都可以进行协商。假设你欠了100美元，想还清，但你只有60美元。你可以打电话给债权人或公司，告诉他们你无法一次性支付100美元，但可以立即支付60美元。在很多情况下，请求减免债务都是行之有效的，而且不会对你的信用记录造成任何负面影响。你只需要开口询问。如果对方接受了你用60美元偿还100美元债务的提议，那么你立即就免除了40%的债务，剩下的100美元债务也就彻底消失了。

THE TOP TWO BIGGEST POTENTIAL SAVERS!

最有潜力的两大储蓄者！

I am a licensed real estate broker in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts: not a mortgage broker, but a real estate broker. I am not an expert by any means, but I know enough about the real estate world to be dangerous. As I mention in television advertisements for Ask More, Get More , the two most expensive things people buy in the United States, if not the world, are a car and a house. Next, I discuss the fear of buying these two very important things. And I will also demystify the purchase and sale of these two items by showing you how to be prepared, and I will show you a simple and easy system to apply that will save you thousands if not tens of thousands of dollars. As you will discover later on, this system may actually make you hundreds of thousands, if not millions. Some of the techniques and principles will be discussed in more detail later on in the book.

我是马萨诸塞州的一名持牌房地产经纪人：不是抵押贷款经纪人，而是房地产经纪人。我绝非专家，但我对房地产行业略知一二，足以构成威胁。正如我在“多问，多得”的电视广告中提到的，在美国乃至全世界，人们购买的最昂贵的两样东西就是汽车和房子。接下来，我将探讨人们对购买这两件重要物品的恐惧。我还会揭开这两样东西买卖的神秘面纱，向您展示如何做好准备，并向您介绍一套简单易行的系统，它可以为您节省数千甚至数万美元。您稍后将会发现，这套系统实际上可以为您带来数十万甚至数百万美元的收益。本书后面将更详细地讨论一些技巧和原则。

YOUR HOUSE

你的房子

I made millions of dollars at a very young age, but I also live a pretty humble life. I live in a small cape house in a modest neighborhood. It is a really nice house to raise my daughter in, and it is located in a neighborhood where she can be a kid and not worry about anything else other than being a kid. Even though my house is modest, I saved thousands of dollars on the purchase price, the renovations, and also the mortgage just by asking the right questions—but more importantly, asking for more , to get more !

我年纪轻轻就赚了数百万美元，但我的生活却相当简朴。我住在一个普通社区的一栋小房子里。这房子很适合抚养女儿，而且社区环境也很好，她可以无忧无虑地享受童年。虽然我的房子并不起眼，但我通过问对问题——更重要的是，多问问题，争取更多——在购房、装修和贷款方面都省下了数千美元！

When you are buying a house in a typical transaction, you have the buyer and the seller , and then you also have the seller’s agent and sometimes the buyer’s agent. One very simple thing to realize (and this will save you thousands of dollars) is that you do not need either one. If you are a seller or a buyer you can handle the transaction yourself. As I mentioned in my television advertisement, “Real Estate,” the concept of real estate is so archaic and complicated that I would not advise jumping into the real estate world as a profession without a solid education. However, if you are buying a house to live in, you can easily do all the research yourself, set appointments to see the property yourself, and negotiate the price yourself. Prior to doing any of this, here are the following steps that will make you and save you thousands of dollars.

在典型的房屋交易中，买卖双方通常会有买家和卖家，此外还有卖家的经纪人，有时也会有买家的经纪人。但有一点非常简单，却能帮你省下数千美元：你其实并不需要他们。无论你是卖家还是买家，都可以自己处理交易。正如我在电视广告“房地产”中提到的，房地产的概念非常古老且复杂，因此我建议不要在没有接受过扎实教育的情况下贸然进入房地产行业。但是，如果你买房是为了自住，你完全可以自己完成所有调查研究，自行预约看房，并自行协商价格。在此之前，以下步骤将帮助你节省数千美元。

Retain a Lawyer in Your Area . People have the misconception that this is expensive, but most real estate lawyers cost no more than a couple thousand dollars, and only get paid at the closing. Among many other things, they will help you draw up a purchase and sales agreement. Too many people make the costly mistake of retaining a lawyer after they sign a purchase and sales agreement. This is not advisable. If you get a lawyer after you signed the purchase and sales, or even worse, if you need a lawyer after the purchase and sales, you are in big trouble. Retain a lawyer prior to even looking. An experienced real estate lawyer can walk you through the process prior to actually looking for a home. A brief talk with the lawyer will both save and make you thousands.

聘请您所在地区的律师。人们常常误以为聘请律师费用昂贵，但大多数房地产律师的收费不超过几千美元，而且只在房屋交割时收取费用。律师会协助您起草买卖协议等诸多事项。很多人犯了一个代价高昂的错误，那就是在签署买卖协议后才聘请律师。这种做法并不可取。如果您在签署买卖协议后才聘请律师，或者更糟糕的是，在买卖完成后才需要律师，那您就麻烦大了。最好在开始看房之前就聘请律师。经验丰富的房地产律师可以在您实际看房之前指导您完成整个流程。与律师进行一次简短的沟通，就能为您节省或带来数千美元的收益。

Also, since the lawyer is not compensated from the sale price, she is truly in your corner. Real estate agents are ethically obligated to represent their clients, whether the buyer or seller, and disregard their own pecuniary interest. However, I believe this ethical obligation is not uniformly followed, and they are often blinded by their own financial interest. The major difference between the two professions is that a lawyer must graduate law school, pass an ethics exam, and pass the bar exam, whereas real estate agents can take an online course, pass a quick test, and voila ! they are now licensed professionals. When in doubt, go with a lawyer.

此外，由于律师的佣金不从房屋售价中扣除，她会真正站在你这边。房地产经纪人有义务在职业道德上代表客户（无论是买方还是卖方）的利益，而不应考虑自身的经济利益。然而，我认为这种职业道德并非普遍得到遵守，他们常常被自身的经济利益蒙蔽双眼。这两种职业的主要区别在于，律师必须从法学院毕业，通过职业道德考试和律师资格考试，而房地产经纪人只需参加一个在线课程，通过一个快速测试，就成了持证专业人士。如有疑问，最好咨询律师。

Cut Out Third Parties . If you are the buyer , cutting out the buyer’s agent can save you anywhere from 2 to 4 percent of the purchase price. For a house costing $100,000, that is $2,000-$4,000, which if you paid interest on over thirty years would conservatively cost you $10,000-$20,000. If you are the seller, you can list and show your house on your own. Real estate agents try to make this process confusing or complicated, when it couldn’t be easier. I have done it, and know many others who have done it. So, you can list and sell your own home with ease. Homes that are for sale by owner are also generally cheaper, and you will not have to deal with brokers.

省去第三方。如果您是买家，省去买方经纪人可以帮您节省购房款的2%到4%。对于一套价值10万美元的房子来说，这相当于2000到4000美元，如果按30年期支付利息，保守估计也要花费1万到2万美元。如果您是卖家，您可以自行挂牌出售房屋。房地产经纪人总是试图把这个过程搞得复杂，其实非常简单。我自己就这么做过，也认识很多这样做的人。所以，您可以轻松地自行挂牌出售房屋。业主自售的房屋通常也更便宜，而且您无需与经纪人打交道。

Research the Area. Of course you would, right? But I have heard horror stories from homebuyers who had no idea that the town they lived in had a horrible school system or that there were plans to have a casino developed the next town over. Buying a home is a very emotional process and should be one that is filled with joy. Buying a home is also a very big deal and usually the biggest purchase of your life. Spend the time to learn everything. Research the school system. Investigate the water supply. Check out the crime rate in surrounding areas. All of this can be done on the Internet.

当然，买房前一定要做好功课，对吧？但我听说过一些购房者的惨痛经历，他们完全不知道自己居住的小镇学校系统糟糕透顶，也不知道隔壁镇计划建赌场。买房是一个充满情感的过程，应该充满喜悦。买房也是人生大事，通常是你一生中最大的一笔支出。所以，一定要花时间了解所有情况。研究一下学校系统，调查一下供水情况，看看周边地区的犯罪率。所有这些都可以在网上找到。

Research the Homes You Are Considering. If you are looking at a particular home, there are many things you can do to gain an advantage when making the decision to submit an offer. Find the local registry of deeds, which you can use to find almost every document pertaining to that home. Multiple Listing Services, or MLS, is a tool only real estate professionals claim to have access to, but it can also be used by non–real estate professionals. This tool will provide you with a plethora of data on homes. You can see what the current owners paid for their homes; you can find out if they took out a second mortgage, if there are liens, encumbrances, etc. Knowing what the current owners paid is invaluable and can put the whole transaction into perspective. If they bought the home for $300,000 and they are looking for one million, they may be asking for way too much money and would probably be willing to take $500,000. 3 P’s + 1 P = Money, peace of mind, and confidence.

对您考虑的房产进行调研。如果您正在关注某处房产，您可以做很多事情来增加在提交报价时的优势。首先，找到当地的房产登记处，您可以通过它找到几乎所有与该房产相关的文档。多重上市服务（MLS）是房地产专业人士声称拥有访问权限的工具，但非房地产专业人士也可以使用。该工具将为您提供大量房产数据。您可以查看当前房主购买房屋的价格；您可以了解他们是否申请了二次抵押贷款，是否存在留置权、产权负担等。了解当前房主的购房价格至关重要，可以帮助您全面了解整个交易。如果他们以 30 万美元的价格购入该房产，而现在要价 100 万美元，那么他们的要价可能过高，或许 50 万美元就足够了。3P + 1P = 金钱、安心和信心。

State, Federal, or Local Incentives. Most states offer first-time buyer’s programs, even on the city level. These incentives can even work for acquiring commercial property. The deals you can get are remarkable. I have a friend who bought an entire commercial building worth over a million dollars from a town—for one dollar! How did he get such a deal? Well, it was in a not-so-glamorous town, but the building was in good condition, and he was bringing jobs to the town. Find out about first-time homebuyer’s programs on state, local, and federal levels. Ask what is available in the area. Ask yourself what you are trying to accomplish. Are you looking to raise a family, or just own some property that you can later sell at a profit, allowing you to purchase your dream house?

州、联邦或地方政府的优惠政策。大多数州都提供首次购房者计划，甚至在市一级也有。这些优惠政策也适用于购买商业地产。你能获得的优惠力度令人难以置信。我有个朋友只花了一美元就从一个镇上买下了一栋价值超过一百万美元的商业楼！他是怎么做到的？嗯，虽然那栋楼位于一个并不繁华的小镇，但楼况良好，而且他还为当地带来了就业机会。了解一下州、地方和联邦层面的首次购房者计划。询问一下你所在地区有哪些优惠政策。问问自己你的目标是什么。你是想组建家庭，还是只想拥有一处房产，以便日后出售获利，从而购买你梦想中的房子？

If it is the latter, consider towns that are not perfect, but where you can purchase property cheap, live comfortably, and build equity. On my website I have a listing of federal agencies that can help you purchase a home.

如果是后者，可以考虑一些并非完美无缺，但房价低廉、生活舒适且能积累资产的城镇。我的网站上列出了可以帮助您购房的联邦机构。

Explore Different Mortgage Options. The real estate market is a mess due to unethical practices by the big banks and mortgage brokers, who preyed upon vulnerable people who could not afford a home. These people had no idea what it meant to own a home and should not have purchased. This is one of the biggest national scams in the history of the United States, and most of the parties perpetuating this fraud walked away with millions.

探索不同的抵押贷款方案。由于大型银行和抵押贷款经纪人的不道德行为，房地产市场一片混乱。他们利用那些无力购房的弱势群体牟利。这些人根本不了解拥有住房意味着什么，他们本不应该买房。这是美国历史上最大的全国性骗局之一，而大多数参与诈骗的人都卷走了数百万美元。

There are several types of mortgages that are now available to the American public. When considering these options, think worst-case scenario. What happens when the time comes for mortgage rate increases? What is really going on when I am only paying the interest? What is a balloon payment, and what will happen if I get there? A lot of the mortgages that are available may be a very good tool for a responsible person to get into a house, but you need to ask yourself, “Can I afford the mortgage payment if the adjustable rate goes up? Can I refinance? What happens if I can’t make the payments?” The following is an explanation of one of the most common exotic and dangerous mortgages.

目前美国公众可以选择多种类型的抵押贷款。在考虑这些选项时，务必考虑最坏的情况。如果抵押贷款利率上涨会怎样？如果我只支付利息，实际情况又是如何？什么是气球式还款？如果我最终不得不一次性付清所有款项，又会发生什么？许多抵押贷款对于负责任的购房者来说或许是很好的购房工具，但您需要扪心自问：“如果浮动利率上涨，我还能负担得起抵押贷款吗？我可以进行再融资吗？如果我无力偿还贷款会怎样？”以下是对一种最常见且风险最高的抵押贷款的解释。

Adjustable Rate Mortgage (ARM). ARMs were designed for the very purpose of reducing the monthly mortgage bill for a period of time in order to make home purchases more affordable. There are several different types of ARMs, but the most common is a three-year ARM, where the rate is low for three years, then adjusts to the predetermined rate. ARMs are great, but you need to ask yourself: “In three years, five years, ten years, will I be able to afford the monthly payment?” With an ARM, usually the principal balance carries over, so even though you are making monthly payments, 99 percent of the payment is going to only interest. As a result you are not really gaining equity unless the real estate market climbs.

可调利率抵押贷款（ARM）。可调利率抵押贷款的设计初衷就是为了在一段时间内降低每月还款额，从而降低购房成本。可调利率抵押贷款有多种类型，但最常见的是三年期可调利率抵押贷款，即前三年利率较低，之后调整至预先设定的利率。可调利率抵押贷款固然不错，但您需要扪心自问：“三年、五年、十年后，我还能负担得起每月还款吗？” 使用可调利率抵押贷款时，通常本金余额会结转到下一年，因此即使您每月都在还款，其中99%的还款都用于支付利息。因此，除非房地产市场上涨，否则您实际上无法积累房屋净值。

On the other hand, what I really like about an ARM is this: You can use an ARM—even if you can make the higher payment in a conventional fixed mortgage—take the difference between the ARM payment and the conventional payment over the three, five, or ten years, and invest it in other vehicles. Right now, I would invest in precious metals and the stock market. People are making a killing presently in both. One basic, simple, and easy way to get in the stock market is to max your 401k contribution (if you have one), start a Roth IRA, or buy some mutual funds. Essentially, the ARM gives you the option of putting money into other vehicles for the first three years of the mortgage. In the long run, this will actually make you more money.

另一方面，我真正喜欢可调利率抵押贷款（ARM）的一点是：即使您有能力支付传统固定利率抵押贷款更高的月供，您也可以选择使用ARM——将三年、五年或十年内ARM月供与传统月供之间的差额投资于其他资产。目前，我会选择投资贵金属和股票市场。现在，人们在这两个领域都赚得盆满钵满。进入股票市场的一个简单易行的方法是：如果您有401k账户，就将其缴款额度用满；开设一个罗斯个人退休账户（Roth IRA）；或者购买一些共同基金。本质上，ARM让您有机会在抵押贷款的前三年将资金投入其他资产。从长远来看，这实际上会让您获得更多收益。

QUICK TIPS

快速提示

  • If you are dealing with a buyer’s or seller’s agent, ask the agent to reduce the commission rate.


    如果你正在与买方或卖方经纪人打交道，请经纪人降低佣金率。
  • Negotiate the price, no matter what. My rule of thumb is offer 30 percent less than what they are asking. It is not offensive and will most likely elicit a response.


    无论如何都要讨价还价。我的经验是，出价比他们要价低30%。这样既不会冒犯对方，而且很可能会有回应。
  • Look for foreclosures, bank-owned properties, and short sales. You can get amazing deals. On my website, I have a list of great websites that can help you find these in your area.


    寻找法拍房、银行所有房产和短售房。您可以找到非常划算的交易。我的网站上列出了一些很棒的网站，可以帮助您找到您所在地区的这类房产。
  • If you go with a conventional mortgage, see what a fifteen-year fixed mortgage monthly payment looks like, as it will save you tens of thousands in interest.


    如果你选择传统的抵押贷款，不妨了解一下十五年期固定抵押贷款的月供是多少，因为它可以为你节省数万英镑的利息。
  • Pay something—anything—each month toward the principal, and make sure you designate the additional payment as a “principal payment,” or it may just be applied to interest.


    每个月都要支付一些钱——哪怕只是一点点——用于偿还本金，并且要确保将额外的付款指定为“本金支付”，否则它可能就被用来支付利息了。
  • Look for local incentives to buy; ask about first-time homebuyer incentives and veterans’ benefits.


    寻找当地的购房优惠政策；询问首次购房者优惠政策和退伍军人福利政策。
  • Be prepared to walk away if the deal isn’t right.


    如果交易不合适，就要做好放弃的准备。

YOUR AUTOMOBILE

您的汽车

Later on in the book I further discuss my illustrious career as a car salesman, where I learned many things. My advice comes from a few years of day-to-day experience. I know that buying a car is also a very emotional purchase. We spend a significant part of our lives in a car, and we as human beings have an affinity for the automobile. One of the first things—and I believe the most important thing—to do when purchasing a car is to take the emotion out of the purchase. You can take the emotion out of the purchasing decision by asking questions before you walk into a dealership.

在本书的后半部分，我会进一步探讨我辉煌的汽车销售生涯，以及我从中汲取的诸多经验。我的建议源于数年的日常实践。我知道买车也是一件非常感性的事情。我们一生中相当一部分时间都待在车里，作为人类，我们对汽车有着特殊的情感。买车时，首先要做的事情——而且我认为是最重要的事情——就是要排除情感因素。你可以在走进经销商展厅之前就提出问题，从而避免情感干扰你的购车决定。

Over the past ten years the car purchasing experience has changed significantly. Since the beginnings of the Internet, consumers have become educated and savvy. Over the Internet, you can compare cars, do virtual tours, get the invoice, hire companies to buy the car for you, and even buy the car without ever walking into the dealership. Even though consumers are now armed with the Internet tools, purchasing a car can still be complicated. The more questions you ask, the more you will save.

过去十年，购车体验发生了翻天覆地的变化。自互联网诞生以来，消费者变得更加见多识广、精明能干。通过互联网，您可以比较不同车型、进行虚拟看车、获取发票、委托公司代为购车，甚至无需亲临经销商即可完成购车。尽管消费者如今拥有了各种互联网工具，但购车过程仍然可能十分复杂。您提出的问题越多，就能节省越多。

Buying a new car versus buying a used car are two completely different types of transactions, and when you have a trade, the transaction becomes more complicated. And leasing involves a different type of transaction. I discuss each scenario in greater length on my website, but the following list is designed to get you to ask more questions before you walk into the dealership in order to get more . Later on there are techniques that you will learn that should be applied as well.

购买新车和购买二手车是两种截然不同的交易，如果需要置换旧车，交易会更加复杂。而租赁则涉及另一种交易方式。我在我的网站上对每种情况都有更详细的讨论，但以下清单旨在引导您在走进经销商之前提出更多问题，以便获得更多信息。稍后您还会学到一些技巧，这些技巧也应该加以运用。

QUICK TIPS

快速提示

  • Cut out all emotion.


    摒弃一切情感。
  • Know exactly why you want the car.


    要清楚自己为什么想要这辆车。
  • Get the invoice and find out about all incentives, including incentives the manufacturer is giving to the dealerships.


    拿到发票，了解所有优惠政策，包括制造商向经销商提供的优惠。
  • Check consumer reports for safety and reliability.


    查看消费者报告，了解安全性和可靠性。
  • Ask yourself how much can you afford, and never go over it.


    问问自己你能负担得起多少，并且永远不要超过这个限额。
  • Ask yourself how you will feel in the vehicle three years later. A lot of people get out of their car three years later and they are upside down, meaning the amount owed is greater than what the car is actually worth.


    想想三年后你坐在这辆车里会是什么感觉。很多人三年后卖掉车时发现自己资不抵债，也就是说，欠款金额超过了车的实际价值。
  • Get quotes from online dealerships in writing. Still very difficult to do, but understand that these quotes are usually not the bottom-line price.


    务必向在线经销商索取书面报价。虽然这仍然很难做到，但要知道这些报价通常并非最终价格。
  • Shop price; go to several dealerships with the firm decision that you are not buying, no matter what the deal. Take out the emotion!


    货比三家；去几家经销商，但要坚定地决定无论价格如何你都不会买。排除情感因素！
  • When you finally settle on a car, test drive the car, and if the car is used, take the car to your mechanic. If you do nothing else, take the car to your mechanic. This will save you thousands. Ask the mechanic this question: “If you were me, would you buy this car?”


    当你最终选定一辆车时，一定要试驾。如果是二手车，就把车送到你的修车师傅那里。即使什么都不做，也要把车送到修车师傅那里。这能帮你省下好几千块钱。问问修车师傅这个问题：“如果你是我，你会买这辆车吗？”
  • Research the dealership; go to the Better Business Bureau and see if they have a good rating. If not, don’t bother walking through the doors.


    先调查一下这家经销商；去商业改进局（Better Business Bureau）看看他们的评级如何。如果评级不好，就别去了。
  • When you are ready to make the purchasing decision, do it on the last day of the month. Yes, you really will get a better deal then. In fact, go in later in the day on the last day of the month.


    当你准备做出购买决定时，最好在月底最后一天去。没错，那样你真的能买到更划算的商品。事实上，最好在月底最后一天晚些时候去。
  • When you enter the dealership, ask to speak with the manager. They will then give you a salesperson who is usually no-nonsense.


    进入经销店后，要求与经理交谈。他们会安排一位通常比较务实的销售人员接待您。
  • Negotiate price, not payment (leasing is different). Since you have done your homework, you will know what the payment will be, based upon the price.


    谈判的是价格，而不是月供（租赁情况不同）。既然你已经做足了功课，你应该能根据价格估算出月供是多少。
  • Even though you know the invoice and all of the incentives, offer 20 percent less than the invoice.


    即使你知道发票金额和所有优惠，也要比发票金额低 20%。
  • Never tell the salesperson that you have done your homework. Claiming ignorance can work to your advantage.


    永远不要告诉销售人员你已经做足了功课。装作不知情反而可能对你有利。
  • Negotiate the trade after you negotiate the price of your car. Dealerships will inflate what you think you are getting on your trade due to the markup on the car you are buying.


    先谈好新车价格，再谈旧车置换价格。由于新车价格较高，经销商往往会虚报旧车置换价格，让你觉得最终到手的钱比他们预想的要多。

These tips may all seem like common sense, but in my experience, when people walk into the dealership, emotion takes over and rational thought goes out the window. As a result, the skills that you are learning in Ask More, Get More are forgotten. Don’t let emotion take over, and when you finish the book, the strategies and techniques that you will have learned, coupled with the tips in this section, will get you the best deal you have ever gotten on a car, and you will feel good about it.

这些建议看似都是常识，但根据我的经验，当人们走进汽车经销店时，情绪往往会占据上风，理性思考则会被抛诸脑后。结果，你在《多问，多得》这本书中学到的技巧就被遗忘了。不要让情绪左右你的判断，当你读完这本书，你所学到的策略和技巧，再加上本节的建议，将帮助你以有史以来最优惠的价格买到心仪的汽车，而且你会为此感到无比自豪。

SAVINGS UNLIMITED!

省钱无极限！

My other book, Reduce Debt Now (available on my website), contains the exact way to reduce your debt, and this chapter expounds on some of those principles while highlighting a few new ones. However, it is the totality of the concepts, techniques, and principles in Reduce Debt Now that will reduce and even eliminate your debt. From going on vacation for free, to understanding how and when to ask the right questions, you will reduce your debt and possibly eliminate it. If your goal is to lower debt, do not just rely on this chapter—incorporate the entire book into your debt reduction or elimination plan.

我的另一本书《立即减少债务》（可在我的网站上购买）详细介绍了减少债务的具体方法，本章将阐述其中的一些原则，并重点介绍一些新的原则。然而，真正能减少甚至消除债务的是《立即减少债务》一书中所有概念、技巧和原则的综合运用。从免费度假到了解如何以及何时提出正确的问题，您将能够减少债务，甚至有可能彻底摆脱债务。如果您的目标是降低债务，请不要仅仅依赖本章——将整本书的内容融入到您的债务减少或消除计划中。

TAXES

税收

I am by no means a tax expert, and I suggest you consult with an accountant before you make any decisions, but you need to prepare for taxes as if they were due now. Tax preparation should not be something that you prepare when it’s time to file. The tax code changes every year, but a few simple things can be done to save you and make you a lot of money. I also believe that even though the tax code is complicated and often changing, programs like Turbo Tax are a great tool and can save you the fee that a tax service agency would charge you.

我绝非税务专家，建议您在做任何决定前咨询会计师，但您需要像现在就要报税一样做好报税准备。报税不应该等到报税截止日期临近才开始准备。税法每年都在变化，但一些简单的措施就能帮您省钱，甚至让您赚到一大笔钱。我还认为，尽管税法复杂且经常变化，但像TurboTax这样的报税软件非常实用，可以帮您省下税务服务机构收取的费用。

PAY TO SAVE!

付费才能省钱！

This advice may seem crazy, but you can make energy-efficient improvements to your home and qualify for a credit of up to 30 percent of the cost, with a maximum credit of $1,500. Insulation, energy-efficient windows, and heating and air-conditioning systems all qualify. These credits seem to change from year to year, so check with your tax adviser, but you can buy things for your home that save you money, and essentially get things like windows for free !

这个建议听起来可能有点不可思议，但你可以通过对房屋进行节能改造，获得高达改造费用30%的税收抵免，最高可达1500美元。隔热材料、节能窗户以及供暖和空调系统都符合条件。这些税收抵免政策似乎每年都会有所变化，所以最好咨询你的税务顾问。但你可以购买一些能帮你省钱的家居用品，比如节能窗户，相当于免费获得！

CHARITABLE DONATIONS

慈善捐款

If you contribute to your church, your local colleges, the local dog pound, the United Way, and/or various organizations that help with disaster relief, be sure to make these donations throughout the year, and don’t wait. Later on we discuss giving back. Regardless of your financial situation, it is always great to give back. Not only are there tax benefits, but what goes around does come around, and it also is just the right thing to do. Don’t be careless with your charitable gifts; get receipts so that you will have them when it’s time to file. Charitable organizations understand that your contributions are tax deductible, so always ask for a receipt and keep a record of it.

如果您向教会、当地大学、当地动物收容所、联合劝募协会和/或各种救灾组织捐款，请务必全年持续捐赠，不要拖延。我们稍后会讨论回馈社会的问题。无论您的经济状况如何，回馈社会总是有益的。这不仅可以享受税收优惠，而且善有善报，也是理所应当的。请认真对待您的慈善捐赠；务必索取收据，以便在报税时使用。慈善机构明白您的捐款可以抵税，所以请务必索取收据并妥善保管。

TIP: If you don’t have the cash …

提示：如果您没有足够的现金……

Find out whether the organization can process a donation via credit card. As long as the donation is made by December 31, it’s a valid deduction that year, even if you don’t pay your credit card bill until next year. However, I would only recommend this if your credit card bills are under control.

了解该机构是否接受信用卡捐款。只要捐款在12月31日前完成，即使您明年才还清信用卡账单，当年的捐款也可以作为有效抵扣项。但是，我建议只有在您的信用卡账单控制良好的情况下才这样做。

MORTGAGE INTEREST

抵押贷款利息

If you are fortunate enough to own a home and have money available to do so, make your January 1 mortgage payment by December 31 of the previous year. The downside is that you won’t be able to deduct the payment from your following year’s return, but you can keep rolling it each year during the life of your mortgage.

如果你有幸拥有房产并且资金充裕，那么请在前一年的12月31日之前支付1月1日的房贷。缺点是你将无法在下一年的纳税申报中扣除这笔款项，但你可以在房贷期限内每年都这样做。

REAL ESTATE TAXES

房地产税

If you pay your own real estate taxes, make any payments due in the beginning of the new year by December 31 of the current year. My taxes are taken out monthly with each mortgage payment. I am, unfortunately, not able to take advantage of this technique.

如果您自行缴纳房产税，请在当年12月31日前缴纳新年伊始应缴的税款。我的房产税是每月随抵押贷款一起扣除的。很遗憾，我无法使用这种方法。

CAPITAL GAINS AND LOSSES

资本收益和损失

As I write this book, 2011 has been a wild ride for investments and will most certainly end leaving us with more questions than answers. Over time, the market will show a return, so investing $25 is still like making $7,225. This can seem a little complicated, but remember this: if you have capital gains, remember that any net capital losses over the $3,000 allowed on this year’s tax return should be carried forward to offset those following years’ gains. If you still have net losses, up to $3,000 may be used to offset ordinary income for the current year.

在我撰写本书之时，2011年对于投资而言可谓跌宕起伏，而且很可能会给我们留下更多疑问而非答案。随着时间的推移，市场终将带来回报，因此投资25美元仍然相当于赚取7225美元。这听起来可能有点复杂，但请记住：如果您有资本收益，请记住，任何超过当年纳税申报表允许的3000美元净资本损失都应结转至以后年度，以抵消后续年度的收益。如果您仍有净损失，则最多可以使用3000美元来抵消当年的普通收入。

Also, remember that when you have a capital gain from an investment, you pay substantially less taxes. Just ask Warren Buffet, who has been pretty vocal about his tax bracket. Warren Buffet, one of the richest men in the world, pays a lower tax rate than his secretary, because his income is derived from investments. This is a big secret of the rich. Warren Buffet, who is now a billionaire, pays roughly 17 percent in taxes, while his secretary pays close to 36 percent. Buffet has been making noise about this for a few years, but you didn’t hear him making this noise when he was on his way up. This was and, quite frankly, still is a well-guarded secret of the rich. Despite what the media coverage is or may be in the future, people don’t understand how to invest and make money. But, you now know it is possible and can be done. Want to pay less in taxes?

此外，请记住，投资收益带来的资本利得税会大幅降低。不妨问问沃伦·巴菲特，他一直以来都对自己的税率问题直言不讳。作为世界上最富有的人之一，沃伦·巴菲特的税率甚至比他的秘书还低，因为他的收入来源于投资。这可是富人的秘密。如今已是亿万富翁的沃伦·巴菲特，税率约为17%，而他的秘书却要缴纳接近36%的税。巴菲特几年前就开始公开谈论此事，但在他事业起步阶段，你可没听他提起过。坦白说，这曾经是，而且现在仍然是富人严守的秘密。无论媒体报道如何，人们仍然不了解如何投资赚钱。但现在你知道，这是完全可能的。想少缴税吗？

INVEST!

投资！

The pieces of advice mentioned above are just a few basic things to consider when filing or preparing taxes. In the spirit of Ask More, Get More , I urge you to spend a little time now preparing for the future and educating yourself, so that you can ask the right questions to maximize your tax benefit. The rich use the tax code to their advantage, and that’s only because they ask more . You should too! There are many other things that can be done, and the tax code is constantly changing, so pay attention. You can also find more tips at www.AskMore-GetMore.com .

以上建议只是报税时需要考虑的一些基本事项。秉持着“多问，多得”的精神，我建议您现在就花些时间为未来做好准备，并学习相关知识，以便提出正确的问题，最大限度地享受税收优惠。富人之所以能利用税法为自己谋利，正是因为他们敢于提出更多问题。您也应该这样做！税法也在不断变化，所以务必密切关注。您还可以访问 www.AskMore-GetMore.com 获取更多建议。

IF YOU OWE TAXES OR HAVE A TAX LIEN ON YOUR PROPERTY

如果您欠税或您的房产有税务留置权

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is a scary government agency. They are probably the most powerful agency within the executive branch of the United States government. You hear all sorts of horror stories about people losing their homes and their businesses. Then there are those frightening commercials: “Do you owe the IRS money? Are they showing up at your home or business? If so, then don’t go at it alone; we will ‘settle’ your tax liability.” If you listen closely, they just say that they are going to “settle” your tax problem. The truth is that you can settle your own tax problem.

美国国税局（IRS）是一个令人畏惧的政府机构。它可能是美国政府行政部门中最有权势的机构。你经常会听到各种各样关于人们失去家园和生意的恐怖故事。还有那些吓人的广告：“你欠国税局的钱吗？他们是不是要上门查房了？如果是的话，别独自面对；我们会帮你‘解决’税务问题。”仔细听，你会发现他们只是说要帮你“解决”税务问题。但事实是，你自己完全可以解决税务问题。

The IRS doesn’t advertise the fact that you can reduce your tax obligation and even avoid penalties, although there is information on their website. One thing that the IRS does offer is called an Offer in Compromise (OIC) in which you pay a nominal fee and submit an offer to settle for less money than is owed. The IRS can legally reduce your tax obligation for one of the following reasons:

美国国税局 (IRS) 并未大肆宣传您可以减少税款甚至避免罚款，尽管其网站上有相关信息。国税局确实提供一项名为“和解提议”(Offer in Compromise，简称 OIC) 的服务，您只需支付少量费用，即可提交一份和解提议，以低于欠款的金额达成和解。国税局可以基于以下原因合法地减少您的税款：

  • Doubt as to liability: if you can raise doubt as to the exact amount owed.


    对责任的质疑：如果您能对所欠款项的确切金额提出质疑。
  • Doubt as to collectability: There is doubt that you could ever pay the full amount.


    能否收回款项存疑：有人怀疑你是否能够支付全部款项。
  • Promoting effective tax administration: I like this one; it basically acknowledges that you do in fact owe money but you have a hardship or other special circumstances, which would prevent you from paying the full amount.

    There are three types of OICs:


    促进有效税务管理：我喜欢这个；它基本上承认你确实欠税，但你面临困难或其他特殊情况，导致你无法全额支付。OIC 有三种类型：
  • Lump Sum Cash: You agree on an amount and you pay the lump sum within five or fewer installments from the notice of acceptance.


    一次性现金支付：您与对方约定金额，并在收到接受通知后五期或更少的分期付款中一次性支付该金额。
  • Short Term Periodic Payment: This is basically a payment plan at an agreed upon amount for two years.


    短期定期付款：这基本上是指在两年内按约定金额支付款项的计划。
  • Deferred Periodic Payment: Can be paid out longer than twenty-four months, but must be paid within ten years.


    延期定期付款：付款期限可超过二十四个月，但必须在十年内付清。

The OIC is not always accepted, but can be appealed. You can learn more about the OIC on my website www.AskMore-GetMore.com or at www.irs.gov .

和解协议并非总是被接受，但可以提出上诉。您可以在我的网站 www.AskMore-GetMore.com 或 www.irs.gov 上了解更多关于和解协议的信息。

DON’T LET IT BECOME A MENTAL MONSTER

别让它变成精神上的怪物

I have a relative who has his own small business. And although he is a great carpenter, he is admittedly not a good bookkeeper. For ten years, he neglected to file tax returns. He did this because he was living hand-to-mouth, barely scraping by, and thought he would end up owing money to the IRS should he actually file his taxes. So he just never filed and just kept running the business. This carried on until the day when the big, bad IRS showed up in a big way. They put a lien on his house, and guess what? IRS agents started showing up at that house and threatening to take it. He was petrified. We talked about this dilemma, and there were many mistakes that he made along the way.

我有个亲戚自己经营一家小公司。虽然他是个很棒的木匠，但他承认自己记账很差。整整十年，他都没报税。他这么做是因为他当时生活拮据，勉强糊口，觉得如果报税的话，最终会欠国税局的钱。所以他就一直瞒着，继续经营着公司。这种情况一直持续到有一天，国税局找上门来。他们查封了他的房子，你猜怎么着？国税局的探员开始上门，威胁要没收房子。他吓坏了。我们聊起这件事，他一路走来犯了很多错误。

Number one, he was acting as a sole proprietor. Thus, he was putting all of his personal assets at risk because he did not want to “waste time” by forming a corporation or a limited liability company.

第一，他当时是以个体户的身份经营。因此，他将所有个人资产都置于风险之中，因为他不想“浪费时间”去成立公司或有限责任公司。

Number two, he didn’t have a bookkeeper who logged his income and expenses.

第二，他没有记账员来记录他的收入和支出。

Number three—and this was the reason for a lot of his fear—he never filed taxes.

第三点——这也是他很多恐惧的原因——他从未报税。

So, he finally got over the fear, went to a tax accountant, and filed his taxes. To his pleasant surprise, not only did he not owe money, but he was due money! He was shocked! For almost ten years, he was living in constant fear of losing his home—needlessly.

于是，他终于克服了恐惧，去找了税务会计师，报了税。令他惊喜的是，他不仅不用缴税，反而还有退税！他简直不敢相信！将近十年来，他一直生活在失去房子的恐惧之中——而这一切原本都是多余的。

I have another relative who barely makes enough money to feed his family. This relative has not only decided not to file taxes for years, he also claimed too many dependents and did, in fact, owe money. He was trying to stretch the dollar he was earning by not filing. Well, those penalties and the interest do not go away; in fact, they get worse. This family member has his already meager wages attached by the IRS, plus he has to pay child support. Each week he barely has enough money to put gas in his car to get to work!

我还有一位亲戚，收入微薄，勉强糊口。这位亲戚不仅多年来一直不报税，还申报了过多的受抚养人，实际上欠了税。他想通过不报税来省钱。然而，罚款和利息并不会消失，反而会越来越严重。这位亲戚原本就微薄的工资现在被国税局扣押，他还要支付子女抚养费。他每周连开车上班的油钱都捉襟见肘！

File your taxes and deal with the situation now, rather than waiting. Most of the horror stories you hear involving people losing their homes or assets are a result of being ill-prepared and just waiting until it is too late. Quickly pull the Band-Aid off! It may hurt or sting, but in the long term your wounds will heal.

与其拖延，不如现在就报税并处理好这件事。你听到的那些失去房屋或财产的惨痛故事，大多都是因为准备不足，等到为时已晚才采取行动造成的。赶紧把创可贴撕掉！虽然可能会有点疼，但从长远来看，你的伤口终会愈合。

The IRS will work with you no matter what the situation. Several years ago, I got hit with an unexpected tax bill, and I did not have nearly enough money to pay it. Rather than just tossing the notice in the garbage and acting like it didn’t exist, I called the IRS. I worked out a plan with them and turned what was a fairly large tax bill into a zero-dollar tax burden rather quickly.

无论情况如何，美国国税局都会与您合作。几年前，我收到了一张意料之外的税单，当时我根本没有足够的钱来支付。我没有把通知扔进垃圾桶，假装它不存在，而是打电话给了国税局。我和他们一起制定了一个方案，很快就把原本数额不小的税单变成了零税负。

If you get a notice or if the IRS shows up at your place of work or home, you need to remain calm and treat the other person with respect. They are just doing their job and are not “out to get you.” When you discuss your tax challenge with them, be honest when describing your situation, and they will work with you. Ask to have the penalties and interests waived, and inquire about working out a payment plan. Even if you enter into a payment plan and you can’t make that payment, communicate with them. Nobody likes to pay taxes, but taxes are a part of your life, so you have to deal with them. Be nice, be honest, treat the other person with respect, and you will find that your tax challenge will soon be a thing of the past.

如果您收到通知，或者国税局人员上门拜访，请务必保持冷静，并尊重对方。他们只是在履行职责，并非有意针对您。在与他们讨论税务问题时，请如实描述您的情况，他们会尽力帮助您。您可以请求免除罚款和利息，并询问是否可以制定分期付款计划。即使您最终选择了分期付款计划，但未能按时支付，也请与他们保持沟通。没有人喜欢缴税，但税收是生活的一部分，您必须面对它。保持友善、诚实和尊重，您会发现税务问题很快就会迎刃而解。

ASK YOURSELF: ARE YOU USING AND PAYING TOO MUCH FOR YOUR WATER?

问问自己：你的用水量和用水费用是否过高？

Water bills vary by state, county, and town but range from $15–60 a month per household. When I was conducting research for this book, I told one of my research interns a technique I’ve used since I was a kid and he looked at me like I was crazy. After the research was over, he got the picture. In the United States, we flush close to five billion gallons of water every day! The toilet uses the most water in the household, accounting for a little more than 26 percent of the daily water usage.

水费因州、县和镇而异，但每户每月通常在 15 到 60 美元之间。我为这本书做研究时，曾跟一位研究实习生讲过我从小就用的一个方法，他当时觉得我疯了。研究结束后，他才明白过来。在美国，我们每天冲水量接近 50 亿加仑！厕所是家庭用水量最大的来源，占每日用水量的 26% 以上。

The average toilet uses 1.6 gallons of water per flush. During the course of a day, that adds up to a fair amount of water. One way to reduce your toilet’s consumption is to reduce the amount of water it uses per flush. When placed in the tank, an ordinary brick will displace roughly a quart of the water it takes to fill up the tank. Over the course of a day, those quarts can add up to several gallons of water per day, per week, per month, and eventually per year. You could also double up and use two bricks. Most towns now require homeowners to install new modern, more efficient toilets. You can often get a rebate for installing a toilet that uses less water. If you don’t want to spend $300–500 for a new toilet, use the brick trick to save water and money.

普通马桶每次冲水平均耗水1.6加仑（约7.7升）。一天下来，这相当于相当多的水。减少马桶用水量的一个方法是减少每次冲水的水量。在水箱里放一块普通的砖，大约可以占到水箱注满水所需的1夸脱（约950毫升）水。日积月累，这些水加起来就能节省好几加仑（约19升）的水，日积月累，一年下来，节省的水量可观。你也可以用两块砖。现在大多数城镇都要求房主安装新型的、更高效的马桶。安装节水马桶通常可以获得补贴。如果你不想花300到500美元换个新马桶，不妨试试用砖头代替水，既省水又省钱。

Showers account for about 17 percent of water usage, with the washer accounting for about 22 percent. For many of us, the shower is the only time we relax. We sit under the scalding hot water until the heat runs out. Ask yourself: How much could I save and ultimately make if I spent a little less time in the shower? Would you be able to relax more if your water bill was cut in half? One thing I do at my house that reduces my water bills is to always shower at the gym. I figure I pay a monthly bill anyway, why use my water when I can use theirs?

淋浴用水量约占总用水量的17%，洗衣机用水量约占22%。对我们许多人来说，淋浴是我们唯一放松的时刻。我们坐在滚烫的热水下，直到热水用完。不妨问问自己：如果我少花一点时间淋浴，最终能省下多少钱？如果水费减半，是不是就能更放松了？我在家省水费的一个方法是去健身房淋浴。反正我每个月都要交水费，既然能用健身房的水，为什么还要用自己的呢？

SAVE MORE BY ASKING YOURSELF AND YOUR UTILITY A FEW QUESTIONS

问自己和你的公用事业公司几个问题，就能省更多钱。

As I mentioned in a television advertisement for Ask More, Get More , in the late 1970s several states began to deregulate both electricity and natural gas. Honestly, I had no idea this existed until a few years ago, when I was researching a company that was marketing its services for reduced electricity rates. Electricity and gas are things that you pay for, and you can use the phrases, techniques, and strategies in this book to reduce your rates significantly. The utility companies have done a great job for close to forty years of keeping this deregulation a secret, and they are not going to be happy when they read this book. The following list identifies which states have deregulated their electricity and gas industries, and which states still regulate both.

正如我在《多问，多得》的电视广告中提到的，上世纪70年代末，一些州开始放松对电力和天然气的管制。说实话，直到几年前，我才知道这件事，当时我正在调查一家以降低电价为卖点的公司。电力和天然气都是需要付费的，你可以运用本书中的技巧、方法和策略来大幅降低费用。近四十年来，公用事业公司一直成功地掩盖了这一放松管制的秘密，他们读到这本书后肯定会很不高兴。以下列表列出了哪些州已经放松了对电力和天然气行业的管制，以及哪些州仍然对两者进行管制。

You can go to www.AskMore-GetMore.com for a list of companies in your state that provide you with options.

您可以访问 www.AskMore-GetMore.com 获取您所在州提供相关服务的公司列表。

The reason the utility companies were deregulated was because they were a monopoly, and a monopoly is never good for the consumer. Don’t be afraid of changing your electricity supplier, as the electricity you receive is the same from supplier to supplier. Your electricity and natural gas will continue to be delivered safely and reliably by the local utility company—a company still regulated by the Public Utility Commission. With deregulation, you have the option to pay less—sometimes up to 50 percent less! The average household spends $105 per month on electricity. If you could save $50 a month—$600 a year—by making a quick and easy change, this book would pay for itself twenty times over! Saving money is making money! And this is just electricity!

公用事业公司之所以被解除管制，是因为它们存在垄断，而垄断对消费者来说从来都不是好事。不要害怕更换电力供应商，因为无论哪个供应商，你获得的电力质量都是一样的。你的电力和天然气将继续由当地的公用事业公司安全可靠地输送——该公司仍然受公共事业委员会的监管。解除管制后，你可以选择支付更少的费用——有时甚至能节省高达50%！普通家庭每月平均电费支出为105美元。如果你能通过简单快捷的更换，每月节省50美元——每年节省600美元——那么这本书的价值就相当于它售价的20倍！省钱就是赚钱！而这仅仅是电费而已！

What if you are a renter and your electric or gas is included? Ask your landlord to look at the energy providers, and provide them with options to reduce cost. Then ask the landlord to reduce your monthly rent proportional to the energy savings.

如果你是租房客，而且电费或燃气费包含在房租里怎么办？你可以请房东调查一下能源供应商，并向他们提供一些降低成本的方案。然后，你可以要求房东根据节省的能源费用按比例降低你的月租金。

Now, we are just talking about switching to a different provider. If you call your supplier and use the skills, phrases, and techniques in the book, you may not need to switch. In addition to using the easily applied skills and techniques in the book with your supplier, the following are some tips that can reduce your total electric bill, regardless of the supplier. On my website, AskMore-GetMore.com , I include additional tips and discuss some cool devices to help reduce costs and make you money!

现在，我们只是讨论更换供应商的问题。如果您致电现有供应商并运用本书中介绍的技巧、措辞和方法，您可能无需更换供应商。除了运用本书中简单易行的技巧和方法与供应商沟通外，以下是一些无论使用哪家供应商都能降低您总电费的实用建议。我的网站 AskMore-GetMore.com 上提供了更多技巧，并介绍了一些有助于降低成本、帮您省钱的实用设备！

MORE ENERGY SAVING—MONEY SAVING—TIPS!

更节能省钱——小贴士！

The term “electricity vampire” references household items that constantly drain energy and ultimately cost you money even if they are off. Things like your TV, your phone charger, a blow-dryer, a computer, a lamp, toaster, microwave, or a stereo can all suck electricity and cost you money. The first thing you need to do is get into the habit of unplugging them every day or night. Another great thing to do is purchase a power-bar or a mat with timer settings on them—also known as a power mat. With a power mat you can charge multiple things at once. With a power bar, you can plug multiple items in, but the timer shuts them off and essentially disconnects them from the wall. Ever notice that your DVD player or TV may have an LED light on showing that it is “off”? That light doesn’t magically appear; it takes electricity and costs you money. The devices that are shut off but still plugged in are responsible for anywhere from 5–10 percent of the average household electric bill!

“耗电大户”指的是那些即使关机也会持续消耗电能，最终导致电费上涨的家用电器。例如电视、手机充电器、吹风机、电脑、台灯、烤面包机、微波炉或音响等，都会消耗电力，增加你的电费支出。你需要做的第一件事就是养成每天早晚拔掉这些电器插头的习惯。另一个好办法是购买带定时功能的电源插座或电源垫——也称为电源垫。电源垫可以同时为多个电器充电。电源插座可以同时连接多个电器，但定时器会自动关闭它们，相当于将它们从墙上的电源插座断开。你有没有注意到，DVD播放机或电视机上的LED指示灯明明显示“已关闭”？这个指示灯可不是凭空出现的；它们会消耗电力，让你损失电费。这些关机但仍插着电源的电器，平均会消耗家庭电费的5%到10%！

TIP: Thinking of buying a computer? Pack up those old desktops in favor of the more lightweight and energy-efficient laptops. They consume less than one-third of the energy with almost all of the benefits of a desktop, and with the advent of wireless technology, you can use them all over your house.

小贴士：想买电脑吗？不妨把那些老旧的台式机收起来，换成更轻便、更节能的笔记本电脑。它们的能耗不到台式机的三分之一，却几乎具备台式机的所有优点。而且随着无线技术的普及，你可以在家里的任何地方使用它们。

You have probably seen those lightbulbs that look like a small, curled-up snake. Well, these squirrelly little fluorescent lightbulbs use 78 percent less electricity than the round ones you have been buying since the beginning of time. They give you the same amount of light output, cost you less, and are safer. They don’t produce as much heat, and when broken, they do not shatter all over the place like the ones you bought from Thomas Edison.

你可能见过那种看起来像蜷缩着的小蛇的灯泡。这些造型奇特的荧光灯泡比你从古至今一直在买的圆形灯泡节能78%。它们亮度相同，价格更低，也更安全。它们发热量更少，而且即使破碎，也不会像你从托马斯·爱迪生那里买来的灯泡那样碎裂成片。

If you still have an old tube-TV? Well, this is a great reason to get the flat screen you have been yearning for. LCD TVs use significantly less energy, and many of them are already Energy Star–rated. Plus, the flat-screen TVs are rapidly dropping in price. Opt for an LCD over a plasma TV, as plasma TVs use more energy and are not as reliable.

如果你家还有老式显像管电视？那现在正是入手梦寐以求的平板电视的绝佳时机。液晶电视的能耗显著降低，而且很多都获得了能源之星认证。此外，平板电视的价格也在迅速下降。相比等离子电视，液晶电视更节能，可靠性也稍逊一筹。

When I started to write Ask More, Get More , I looked at my own personal electricity situation. For some reason, my family used more electricity than anyone in my neighborhood. I thought I was doing all the right things, and I couldn’t figure out why our bill was barely moving south. One huge draw on our electric bill was an old refrigerator in our garage that we use as a spare and for storing excess food. We actually got the fridge for free! Well, that fridge has probably cost me three times what it was worth! I switched to an Energy Star freezer and watched my bill drop noticeably! If you are considering a refrigerator purchase, make sure it is Energy Star–rated. The same goes for your washer and dryer. When I bought my house, we negotiated the washer and dryer as part of the purchase. Several years ago, that was a good deal, but long-term if I had kept that dryer, my “free” dryer would have actually cost me.

当我开始写《多问，多得》这本书时，我审视了自己的用电情况。不知何故，我家用电量比邻居们都高。我自认为已经尽力做到了所有该做的，却始终不明白为什么电费几乎没有下降。电费的一大来源是我们车库里一台旧冰箱，我们把它当备用冰箱，也用来存放多余的食物。这台冰箱我们竟然是免费得到的！然而，这台冰箱现在给我造成的损失可能是它价值的三倍！我换了一台节能之星认证的冰箱，电费立刻就明显下降了！如果你正打算买冰箱，一定要确保它是节能之星认证的。洗衣机和烘干机也一样。我买房子的时候，洗衣机和烘干机是包含在房款里的。几年前，这笔交易很划算，但从长远来看，如果我当初留下那台“免费”的烘干机，实际上反而会让我付出更多。

ONE MAN’S TRASH IS ANOTHER MAN’S WAY OF ASKING FOR MORE

一个人的垃圾，是另一个人索要更多东西的方式。

After I properly disassembled the refrigerator, I assumed the garbage men would take it. I didn’t have time to find out. The morning of trash day, a short, middle-aged Hispanic man knocked on my door and asked for my help. When I looked past my driveway, he had an old, small-cab Chevy pickup full of scrap metal parked next to my garbage. The reason why he knocked was that my old refrigerator was worth something to him.

我把冰箱拆解好之后，以为垃圾车会把它收走。但我没时间去验证。垃圾车收走那天早上，一个身材矮小的中年西班牙裔男子敲响了我的门，请求我帮忙。我往车道外看去，发现他开着一辆老旧的雪佛兰小型皮卡，车里装满了废金属，就停在我的垃圾桶旁边。他敲门的原因是，我的旧冰箱对他来说值点钱。

As I approached the man’s pickup, which was overflowing with junk and the refrigerator at the end of the bed of his truck, I realized the refrigerator would not fit, but he was determined to get it on his truck. We rearranged the items in his vehicle and then put the refrigerator on top of his truck. As we were moving the refrigerator around all the sharp pieces of metal and old lawn mowers, I noticed that this man was missing two fingers on his left hand, and I was impressed with his strength for a man who barely stood five feet.

当我走近那辆堆满杂物的皮卡车时，我意识到冰箱肯定放不下，但他执意要把它搬上去。我们重新整理了一下车里的东西，然后把冰箱抬到了车顶上。在挪动冰箱的时候，周围都是锋利的金属碎片和旧割草机，我注意到他左手少了两个手指，他个子不高，却力气惊人，这让我很佩服。

After the refrigerator was successfully loaded onto the truck, I told him that it wasn’t safe, and he couldn’t drive away without it being secure. I told him to hold on, and I got a rope to help secure the refrigerator on top of his small, overflowing Chevy pickup. Once we finally got the refrigerator secure, I asked him his name, and he said José. I shook his hand and was proud to know him for that brief moment. He went on to tell me that he would get about $30 for the refrigerator, and that he gets about $150 a day in scrap metal, driving from town to town on different trash days.

冰箱顺利装上卡车后，我告诉他这样不安全，没固定好不能开车走。我让他抓紧，然后拿来一根绳子，帮他把冰箱固定在他那辆塞得满满当当的小雪佛兰皮卡车顶上。冰箱终于固定好后，我问他叫什么名字，他说他叫何塞。我跟他握了握手，很荣幸能认识他这么久。他接着告诉我，这冰箱他大概能卖30美元，而他每天跑遍各个城镇，在不同的垃圾回收日收废金属，能挣到大约150美元。

José didn’t care what I thought or what other people thought of him. José has a family to feed and basic living expenses to pay. He is disabled and speaks little English, but he used inner strength and creative thinking to find a way to put food on his table and money in his pocket. José is a fine example of human ingenuity, drive, and desire. I didn’t spend a lot of time with José, but anyone can apply the skills that we all have from within to not only survive, but to prosper.

何塞不在乎我的想法，也不在乎别人怎么看他。他要养家糊口，还要支付基本的生活开销。他身有残疾，英语也不太好，但他凭借着内在的力量和创造性的思维，找到了养家糊口、挣钱的办法。何塞是人类智慧、进取心和渴望的绝佳典范。我和何塞相处的时间并不长，但每个人都可以运用自身蕴藏的潜能，不仅能够生存下去，还能获得成功。

And you can do the same if you apply the strategies and techniques in this book and absorb its principles. You can save money on the basic things in your life like water, electricity, food, gas, and anything else you pay for or purchase. You can also apply the strategies to every aspect of your life so that you can have a better life, just as José was determined to have. On my website, I have many saving techniques that are invaluable, but not appropriate for the book. There are literally hundreds of things you can do to reduce your water and electric bills, but ultimately it goes back to the basics you will learn in the book. When you understand that saving fifty dollars a month is like making almost $15,000, you will begin to realize that, regardless of your current financial situation, you can and should make and save money. These techniques work both in the short-term and long-term. Nike said it best: Just do it ! Think just a little differently, and you will change your financial future.

如果你运用本书中的策略和技巧，并理解其中的原则，你也能做到。你可以节省生活中基本开销，例如水、电、食物、汽油以及其他任何你付费或购买的东西。你还可以将这些策略应用到生活的方方面面，从而拥有更美好的生活，就像何塞决心要拥有的那样。我的网站上有很多非常宝贵的省钱技巧，但这些技巧并不适合本书。实际上，你可以做数百种事情来降低水费和电费，但最终还是要回到你将在书中学到的基本原则。当你明白每月节省五十美元相当于赚了近一万五千美元时，你就会开始意识到，无论你目前的财务状况如何，你都可以而且应该赚钱和存钱。这些技巧在短期和长期都有效。耐克说得最好：Just do it！稍微改变一下你的思维方式，你就能改变你的财务未来。

#↩

PART III

第三部分

ASK MORE FROM LIFE

对生活有更高的要求

#↩

CHAPTER 8

第八章

BE A CEO INSTEAD OF A SUBORDINATE

要做CEO，而不是下属

IS THAT HOW YOU WANT TO BE REMEMBERED?

这就是你想被人记住的方式吗？

As I have stated throughout the book, when I was a kid I struggled with doing the right thing. I used to get into fights a lot. I generally would not start the altercations, but I used to fight almost daily. Most of the time it was another teenager trying to prove how tough he was; I was and am a big guy, so others were constantly challenging me. One day I was in the next town over from where I grew up with some of my friends, and we met a group of other teenagers. We did not know them, but after introductions they knew me. They knew me because of my reputation as a tough street kid. When I got home I proudly told my mother that I was known to these kids from another town. She asked me how they knew me. I told her it was because they heard of how tough I was. My mom then looked at me and said, “Is that how you want to be remembered?” I was fourteen or fifteen at the time, and that question hit me hard. Is that how I want to be remembered—as just a tough guy?

正如我在书中多次提到的，我小时候总是难以分辨是非对错。我经常打架。虽然通常不是我先挑起的，但我几乎每天都会打架。大多数时候，都是其他青少年想证明自己有多厉害；我身材高大，所以别人总是挑战我。有一天，我和几个朋友去了隔壁镇，遇到了一群青少年。我们之前并不认识他们，但自我介绍之后，他们认出了我。他们认识我是因为我出了名的街头混混。回家后，我得意地告诉妈妈，我被其他镇上的孩子们认识了。她问我他们是怎么认识我的。我说是因为他们听说我很强悍。妈妈看着我说：“你想让别人记住你这个样子吗？” 我当时十四五岁，这个问题深深地刺痛了我。我想让别人记住我吗——仅仅是一个“硬汉”？

I then started asking myself questions almost immediately. How far will this take me in life? Where will this take me in life? Where will I end up? As I tried to answer the questions I was asking myself, I knew that being a tough guy was not going to lead to good things. I did get into some scuffles after that fateful day, but they were literally self-defense. As I began to get more involved with sports and academics, the fighting dissipated, and to this day I ask myself a modified version of my mother’s question: How do I want to be remembered?

我几乎立刻开始问自己一些问题。这会把我的人生带向何方？这会把我的人生引向何方？我最终会落得什么下场？当我试图回答这些问题时，我知道做一个硬汉不会带来好结果。在那一天之后，我的确和人发生过一些冲突，但那纯粹是出于自卫。随着我更多地参与体育运动和学习，打架斗殴的现象逐渐消失。直到今天，我仍然会问自己一个类似于母亲曾经问过我的问题：我希望人们如何记住我？

I CAN BUY AN ICE CREAM

我可以买冰淇淋

This past summer I was at a local beach with my daughter, and we were buying some ice cream. We were looking over the different flavors and we each picked what we wanted. We each got cookies and cream with sprinkles, both smalls; she got hers on a sugar cone and I got mine in a cup. After we paid, we were sitting down at a bench right next to the service window. As we were blissfully enjoying our ice cream, an old woman slowly walked up to the window. She appeared to be reviewing the flavors, and then I heard her ask how much the small was. After hearing the price she looked down into her hand and then sadly walked away. This woman was probably in her eighties, and I could tell from her body language that she was upset because she couldn’t afford the ice cream.

去年夏天，我和女儿在附近的海滩玩，我们去买冰淇淋。我们仔细看了看各种口味，各自选了自己喜欢的。我们都点了曲奇奶油口味，加了糖屑，都是小份的；她要的是甜筒装的，我要的是杯子装的。付完钱后，我们坐在服务窗口旁边的长椅上。正当我们津津有味地享用冰淇淋时，一位老太太缓缓走到窗口。她似乎也在看冰淇淋的口味，然后我听到她问小份多少钱。听到价格后，她低头看着自己的手，然后难过地走开了。这位老太太大概有八十多岁了，从她的肢体语言来看，她很沮丧，因为她买不起冰淇淋。

It hit me so hard that this woman either could not afford an ice cream or made the decision not to buy the ice cream because it didn’t fit into her budget. I was saddened by witnessing this, but I was also so appreciative that I can buy an ice cream for my daughter and me whenever we want. I can pretty much buy anything we want or need without looking at the price (but I always do) or doing the math in my head to see if we can afford it.

这件事深深触动了我，这位女士要么是买不起冰淇淋，要么是因为超出预算而决定不买。目睹这一切让我很难过，但同时我也无比庆幸自己可以随时给女儿和我买冰淇淋。我几乎可以买到任何我们想要或需要的东西，而不用看价格（虽然我总是会看），也不用在心里算账看我们是否负担得起。

The simple things in life, the things that I, too, couldn’t afford when I was a kid, I can now enjoy. Funny thing is, when I was a kid and could not afford an ice cream, my friends and I would collect cans, cash them in, and go to the local Dairy Queen. They had a cool program called the “Mistake.” Mistakes were ice creams, ice cream floats, frappes, or other ice cream concoctions that for some reason or another were mistakenly made and then put in the freezer. For ten cents you could go to the ice cream window and ask for a Mistake without knowing what you would get. Sometimes you would get a banana split or a small vanilla with rainbow sprinkles. But we didn’t care! Ten cents for ice cream bliss.

生活中那些简单的小事，那些我小时候也买不起的东西，现在我都能享受到了。说来也怪，小时候我连冰淇淋都买不起，就和朋友们一起收集易拉罐，换成现金，然后去附近的冰雪皇后（Dairy Queen）。他们有个很棒的项目叫“意外惊喜”（Mistake）。所谓“意外惊喜”，指的是那些因为各种原因做错的冰淇淋、冰淇淋汽水、冰沙或其他冰淇淋饮品，然后被放进了冰箱。花10美分，你就可以去冰淇淋窗口点一份“意外惊喜”，完全不知道会拿到什么。有时候是香蕉船，有时候是撒了彩虹糖的小份香草冰淇淋。但我们根本不在乎！10美分就能享受冰淇淋的美味。

But I digress … the important point is that it wasn’t too long ago where I would get anxiety when going through a cashier stand and not knowing whether or not my credit card would be declined. In fact, many times I would make a joke before they ran it and say things like, “I hope I didn’t forget to pay the bill,” to alleviate any potential embarrassment. Today when my credit card is declined, I still get the uneasy feeling of what it felt like to not be able to buy a real ice cream. But now I know it is usually my credit card company protecting the card, or it’s some mistake.

但言归正传……重点是，不久前，我每次去收银台结账都会焦虑不安，不知道信用卡会不会被拒。事实上，很多时候，为了避免尴尬，我会在他们刷卡前开玩笑说：“希望我没忘记付账。” 如今，即使信用卡被拒，我仍然会感到那种买不到冰淇淋的忐忑不安。但现在我知道，这通常是信用卡公司为了保护我的卡而采取的措施，或者只是个错误。

But the fear of not being able to pay is still with me and also drives me to continue to make sure that I will always be able to buy my little girl an ice cream. Ask yourself: Wouldn’t it feel great to not worry about what things cost? Or worry about how you will pay for things? You can do it by following the many techniques in my book and simply by asking more out of life.

但我仍然害怕付不起钱，这种恐惧也驱使我不断努力，确保总能给我的小女儿买冰淇淋。不妨问问自己：如果不用再为东西的价格而担忧，或者为如何支付而烦恼，那该有多好？你可以通过我书中介绍的多种方法，以及对生活提出更高的要求来实现这一点。

HOW TO RUN YOUR LIFE LIKE A BUSINESS: BE THE CEO OF YOU ENTERPRISES, INC.

如何像经营企业一样管理你的生活：成为你自己的企业有限公司的首席执行官

Robert Kiyosaki, in Rich Dad, Poor Dad , says that people need to “mind their own business.” Too many people work for a company or for a person, and they don’t think of their life as a business. In Rich Dad, Poor Dad he tells a story about Ray Kroc and what his “business” was. Ray Kroc’s business was building real estate, while his profession was salesman of McDonald’s franchises. You need to understand that your profession is what you are doing right now (or want to do), but your business is you .

罗伯特·清崎在《富爸爸，穷爸爸》中说，人们需要“管好自己的事”。太多人为公司或个人工作，却不把自己的生活当成一项事业。在《富爸爸，穷爸爸》中，他讲述了雷·克罗克的故事，以及他的“事业”究竟是什么。雷·克罗克的事业是房地产开发，而他的职业是麦当劳特许经营权的销售员。你需要明白，你的职业是你现在正在做的（或想要做的），而你的事业就是你自己。

Do you ever wonder what “rich people” do to get there? Joan Rivers had a show that was on TV for a little bit that was a bit like Robin Leach’s show, Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous . Her show was called How’d You Get So Rich? I thought it was a brilliant concept; she would appear at the front door of large estates and ask the person who answered, “How’d you get so rich?” I didn’t watch every episode, but in all the ones I watched, the people became rich by owning their own businesses and running their personal lives like a business.

你有没有想过“有钱人”是怎么发家致富的？琼·里弗斯曾经主持过一个电视节目，有点像罗宾·利奇的《富豪生活方式》。她的节目叫《你是怎么变得这么富有的？》。我觉得这个创意很棒：她会出现在一些豪宅的门口，问应门的人：“你是怎么变得这么富有的？”我没看完每一集，但就我看过的几集来看，这些人都是通过拥有自己的企业，并且像经营企业一样管理自己的个人生活而致富的。

Before I started Blue Vase Marketing, LLC ( www.bluevasellc.com ) a few years ago, I studied the habits of other rich and successful people and how they maintained their wealth and success. I also studied people who made it and then lost it. The difference between the two is that the people who kept their wealth set up their personal life like a business.

几年前，在我创办 Blue Vase Marketing, LLC (www.bluevasellc.com) 之前，我研究过其他富裕成功人士的习惯，以及他们如何保持财富和成功。我还研究过那些曾经成功却最终失去财富的人。两者的区别在于，那些保住财富的人把个人生活经营得像经营企业一样。

When I was in law school I cringed at taking classes like Wills and Trusts, and Trusts and Estates. In fact, I didn’t even know what a trust was. You always hear of trust fund babies; have you ever met a poor trust fund baby? No, you haven’t. That is because these trust fund babies were the beneficiary of family members, usually parents or grandparents, who set up their personal life like a business, enabling them to take care of the beneficiary. I have been studying the personal lives of many rich and successful people, and when I was able to peek behind the curtains, I was amazed at the level of sophistication and surprised how easy it was to set up and organize your personal life in a way that seemed complex, but in reality was very easy.

我在法学院的时候，最讨厌的就是遗嘱信托和遗产信托这类课程。事实上，我当时甚至都不知道信托是什么。你总是听到“信托基金宝宝”这个词；你见过穷困潦倒的信托基金宝宝吗？肯定没有。这是因为这些信托基金宝宝都是家族成员的受益人，通常是父母或祖父母，他们把自己的生活经营得像经营生意一样，从而能够照顾受益人。我一直在研究许多富人和成功人士的个人生活，当我得以窥见他们生活的幕后时，我惊叹于他们高超的理财技巧，也惊讶于建立和安排个人生活的方式竟然如此简单——看似复杂，实则不然。

Another very interesting thing I have noticed is that middle-class or poor people don’t think they need things like trusts, wills, life insurance, or some other things that “rich people” have. I, too, once thought a trust or a will was just too difficult to understand or manage. Setting up a trust, having a will, or having life insurance are simple tools, and in most instances very inexpensive. They will protect you and your family, save your family’s money, and prepare your family for the future. There are too many legal cases that create heartache, litigation, and many times tear families apart because the deceased did not set up his or her life like a business.

我还注意到一个非常有趣的现象：中产阶级或贫困人群往往认为自己不需要信托、遗嘱、人寿保险或其他一些“富人”才会拥有的东西。我也曾一度认为信托或遗嘱太过复杂难懂，难以管理。但事实上，设立信托、立遗嘱或购买人寿保险都是简单易行的工具，而且在大多数情况下成本很低。它们可以保护您和您的家人，为家庭节省开支，并为家庭的未来做好准备。太多法律纠纷造成了痛苦、诉讼，甚至导致家庭破裂，而这一切仅仅是因为逝者没有像经营企业一样规划好自己的生活。

A good friend of mine recently lost his dad, who passed away without a will. His father wasn’t a wealthy man, but he had some land in Louisiana. This land was swampland; but lo and behold, after some geological surveys were conducted, it just so happens this land sits on a very large natural gas reserve and potential oil. The land is potentially worth millions, and a major energy company wants to lease the land. The problem is, due to the fact that my friend’s dad “didn’t think he needed a will,” this land could be tied up in land and probate court for years, causing not only heartache, but also costing him a lot of money in legal fees. It may seem coldhearted, but the fact is, if my friend’s dad had run his life like a business, he would have had things like a will, a trust, and life insurance.

我的一位好友最近失去了父亲，他父亲去世时没有留下遗嘱。他父亲虽然并不富裕，但在路易斯安那州拥有一块土地。这块地原本是沼泽地；然而，经过地质勘测后，人们发现这块地竟然蕴藏着丰富的天然气和石油资源。这块地价值数百万美元，一家大型能源公司想要租赁它。问题是，由于我朋友的父亲“认为自己不需要遗嘱”，这块地可能会在土地和遗嘱认证法庭上被搁置多年，不仅会给他带来痛苦，还会让他支付高昂的诉讼费用。这听起来或许有些冷酷无情，但事实是，如果我朋友的父亲像经营企业一样规划自己的人生，他就会立下遗嘱、设立信托并购买人寿保险。

If you think that you don’t need things like wills, trusts, and life insurance, then you need to change the way you think. You are your own natural gas and oil reserve, and you need to protect you . If you don’t have assets and money right now, you will soon. Your life is your personal business, and just like eating healthy and exercising in order to live longer, you need to properly set up your personal life to ensure the financial health of YOU Enterprises, Inc. and to prepare yourself for future success.

如果你认为自己不需要遗嘱、信托和人寿保险之类的东西，那你需要改变一下想法。你就像自己的天然气和石油储备，你需要保护自己。如果你现在没有资产和金钱，很快就会有了。你的生活是你自己的事，就像健康饮食和锻炼可以延年益寿一样，你需要妥善安排你的个人生活，以确保你的“企业”（YOU Enterprises, Inc.）的财务健康，并为未来的成功做好准备。

YOU ARE THE CEO OF YOU ENTERPRISES, INC.

您是 YOU ENTERPRISES, INC. 的首席执行官。

A chief executive officer (CEO) has to make tough decisions; if not, the company could collapse. Your own life could face similar problems if, as the CEO of YOU Enterprises, Inc., you don’t make the tough decisions. As you have already read, you must take responsibility for your own life. You can think of this as a kind of sole proprietorship. That means you have to be honest with yourself first. If you can’t be honest with yourself and look at things objectively, then your success in almost any venture will be hampered and difficult to obtain.

首席执行官（CEO）必须做出艰难的决定；否则，公司可能会倒闭。作为“你”企业有限公司的CEO，如果你不做出艰难的决定，你的人生也可能面临类似的困境。正如你已经读到的，你必须为自己的人生负责。你可以把这看作是一种独资经营。这意味着你首先必须对自己诚实。如果你不能对自己诚实，不能客观地看待事物，那么你在几乎任何事业上的成功都会受到阻碍，并且难以实现。

I once heard a psychologist explain why the American economy and the world economy essentially collapsed. He said, in more eloquent and clinical terms, that the national debt of the United States is so huge and out of control that as human beings, politicians’ natural defense mechanisms kick in and don’t allow for them to actually deal with the situation (some people would disagree that politicians are human). He went on to say that if the human brain were to attempt to handle this situation, the flight-defense part of our brain would be so strained that we as human beings would essentially have a mental breakdown. So rather than dealing with the situation, we just keep pushing it away. We procrastinate. Procrastination is another disease that leads to failure, and if not put in check can turn into a mental monster !

我曾听一位心理学家解释美国经济乃至世界经济崩溃的原因。他用更雄辩、更专业的语言指出，美国的国债如此庞大且失控，以至于作为人类，政客们的本能防御机制被激活，使他们无法真正面对这种情况（当然，有些人可能不认同政客是人）。他接着说，如果人类大脑试图处理这种情况，大脑的防御机制就会不堪重负，最终导致精神崩溃。因此，我们不去解决问题，而是选择拖延。拖延是另一种导致失败的“疾病”，如果不加以控制，它会变成一个精神上的怪物！

PREPARE LIKE NEXT WEEK IS CHRISTMAS

做好准备，就像下周就是圣诞节一样！

I discovered something that is fairly obvious, but that we rarely think about. When I was analyzing my company’s year-end sales, I noticed that the week before Christmas our sales were down significantly. I decided to look back at previous years and noticed the same thing. I asked all of my executive team why this was, and even talked to individual sales professionals. They all had the same answer: people were Christmas shopping and saving in order to make sure they could buy gifts for friends and family members.

我发现了一个显而易见却又常常被我们忽略的事实。在分析公司年终销售数据时，我注意到圣诞节前一周的销售额大幅下降。我回顾了往年的数据，发现情况也一样。我询问了所有高管团队，甚至与每位销售人员都进行了交流，他们的答案都一样：人们都在忙着圣诞购物和攒钱，以便为亲朋好友购买礼物。

Then, while I was reviewing bonuses for my employees, I observed that my employees were not only waiting for their bonuses, but depending on them so they could pay for Christmas gifts. It then hit me like a Mack truck: What if we as a society prepared every week as if the following week were Christmas? The reason why my sales were down—and probably always will be—a week or so before Christmas is because people are “saving” or “preparing” for the holiday. Many times, people are not prepared, and as a result they use that fabulous plastic thing in our wallets that allows us to forget what is really happening to our financial future—the credit card. A friend of mine who owns a company gave out bonuses even though he couldn’t financially justify it. I asked him why. He answered that we as a society believe it is important to try to give gifts, even to our own personal financial detriment. And that is what happens when you don’t prepare and end up using your credit card for gifts. You are actually paying more for the gift by using a credit card. Any creditable financial adviser will tell you to never pay for a vacation or gifts on a credit card, with two small caveats: if you get points and if you can pay it off.

后来，我在审核员工奖金的时候发现，我的员工不仅在翘首期盼奖金，还指望着用奖金来支付圣诞礼物。那一刻我恍然大悟：如果我们整个社会都像准备过圣诞节一样，每周都做好准备，那会怎样？我的销售额在圣诞节前一周左右下降——而且可能一直都会下降——的原因就是人们都在为节日“存钱”或“准备”。很多时候，人们并没有做好准备，结果就是他们用上了钱包里那张神奇的塑料卡片，让我们忘记了真正影响我们财务未来的信用卡。我有个朋友开了一家公司，他发奖金的时候，即使从财务角度来看并不划算，也照发不误。我问他为什么。他回答说，我们整个社会都认为送礼物很重要，即使这会损害我们自身的财务状况。而当你没有做好准备，最终用信用卡买礼物时，就会出现这种情况。实际上，用信用卡买礼物反而会让你付出更多。任何一位合格的财务顾问都会告诉你，永远不要用信用卡支付度假或礼物费用，但有两个小小的例外：一是你能获得积分，二是你能还清欠款。

Moving forward, prepare each week like the following week is Christmas, and you will find that you will cut out unnecessary items from your personal budget. Zig Ziglar said in See You at the Top that you should work every day like you are going on vacation the next day, and you will get a lot more accomplished. Work each week like the following week is Christmas, and you will find that you save more, have more flexibility, and are more prepared.

从现在开始，把每周都当作过圣诞节一样认真准备，你会发现自己能从个人预算中剔除不必要的开支。齐格·齐格勒在《巅峰相见》一书中说过，你应该每天都像明天就要去度假一样工作，这样你就能完成更多的事情。把每周都当作过圣诞节一样认真准备，你会发现自己能存下更多钱，拥有更大的灵活性，也准备得更充分。

TIP: Christmas Clubs.

提示：圣诞俱乐部。

If your company offers one, take advantage of it. It forces you to prepare for a time that is already stressful.

如果公司提供这项服务，一定要利用好。这能让你提前做好准备，应对本就压力巨大的时期。

BE HONEST WITH YOUR PERSONAL BUSINESS

对你的私事要诚实

One of my first “real” businesses was created from an idea I had in college. Like many college students, I did my fair share of drinking, and in my senior year we were doing shots and chasing the shots with freeze pops. It came to me one night—the great idea of combining alcohol with the freeze pops. After I graduated college, one of the first things I did when I got home was buy a chemistry kit, sort of the kind you got when you were a kid. I began to experiment with different formulations. I was trying to find the perfect ratio so that the freeze pop would freeze.

我最早的“真正”创业项目之一源于大学时的一个想法。和很多大学生一样，我没少喝酒，大四那年我们经常喝烈酒，然后就着冰棍吃。一天晚上，我突然灵光一闪——把酒精和冰棍结合起来！大学毕业后，我回家做的第一件事就是买了一套化学实验套装，就是那种小时候玩的。我开始尝试不同的配方，努力找到完美的比例，让冰棍能够冻得结实。

Now, I knew nothing about chemistry or the liquor business, but I had a great, million-dollar idea, and I was not going to let it slip by. I was not going to be that guy who said, “If I had only tried that idea, I wonder what would have happened?” I was going to take a risk. After a few weeks I found the proper ratio of juice to alcohol. They froze solid, were 8.2 percent alcohol, and tasted great! I invented a freeze pop called Zeus Juice that was infused with alcohol and froze solid. Genius!

当时我对化学和酒类行业一窍不通，但我却有一个价值百万美元的绝妙点子，我绝不会让它白白溜走。我可不想成为那种事后后悔的人，说：“要是我当初试过那个点子，结果会怎样呢？” 我决定冒险一试。几周后，我找到了果汁和酒精的最佳比例。它们冻得结实，酒精度达到8.2%，而且味道棒极了！我发明了一种叫做“宙斯果汁”的冰棒，它加入了酒精，冻得结实。真是天才之作！

As I began to explore what it took to run a business and began to study things like capital, sales projections, and marketing, I met someone who gave me some pretty sound advice. Unfortunately, I didn’t listen. This person told me that whatever you think you need for capital, multiply it by three; and boy, were they right.

当我开始探索经营企业所需的一切，并开始研究资金、销售预测和市场营销等问题时，我遇到了一位给了我一些非常中肯建议的人。可惜的是，我当时并没有听取他的意见。这个人告诉我，无论你认为需要多少资金，都要乘以三；事实证明，他说的完全正确。

More importantly, this individual said that when you are evaluating a business venture, ask yourself two very important questions: 1) Has anyone else thought of the idea? 2) If they had thought of the idea, are they still doing it? To my surprise, I learned I wasn’t the first one who thought of this. In fact, I found several companies that had tried making frozen alcoholic popsicles. One company was even having success overseas with the idea, but not in the United States. I decided to not ask any more questions. I didn’t apply the 3 P’s + 1 P technique, and I pushed forward.
