That was a big mistake, and I paid dearly. Many other companies had tried my idea, and all failed for one reason or another. Some truly failed. Some tried and gave up. And the one company overseas was having major legal challenges trying to get their product into the United States. I saw this as my opportunity to beat them to the market, and I did! I spent close to $100,000 getting a freeze pop infused with alcohol approved by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives and licensed in many of the states. Ultimately, I ran out of capital because I didn’t listen to my friend—who was and is a very successful businessman. And I did not ask enough questions. I wish the story ended there.

更重要的是，这个人说，在评估一项商业计划时，要问自己两个非常重要的问题：1）其他人是否也想到过这个想法？2）如果他们想到过，他们现在还在做吗？令我惊讶的是，我发现自己并非第一个想到这个点子的人。事实上，我发现有好几家公司都尝试过生产冷冻酒精冰棒。其中一家公司甚至在海外凭借这个想法取得了成功，但在美国却失败了。我决定不再追问。我没有运用3P+1P营销策略，而是一意孤行。这是一个巨大的错误，我为此付出了惨痛的代价。许多其他公司也尝试过我的想法，但都因为这样那样的原因失败了。有些是彻底失败了，有些是尝试过但最终放弃了。而那家海外公司在试图将产品打入美国市场时，遇到了严重的法律挑战。我把这看作是我抢占市场先机的机会，而我也确实做到了！我花了将近十万美元，才让一款添加了酒精的冰棒通过了美国烟酒枪炮及爆炸物管理局的审批，并在多个州获得了销售许可证。最终，我资金耗尽，因为我没有听从朋友的建议——他是一位非常成功的商人，而且现在依然如此。我也问的问题不够多。我真希望故事到此结束。

I was forced to file for bankruptcy and to shut the business down. It was a horrible feeling, and I felt defeated. Filing for bankruptcy has a stigma and hurts your credit for ten years, but I was forced to make the tough decision with my personal life—also known as ME Enterprises, Inc. Filing bankruptcy is one technique with which you can eliminate your debt. By filing bankruptcy I eliminated over $200,000 in debt. Bankruptcy is a great option for people who took a chance like I did; it gives you a second chance. Consider bankruptcy when necessary to give yourself a fresh start. But do not abuse bankruptcy; many people file for bankruptcy simply because they are living a lifestyle that they should not have.

我被迫申请破产并关闭了公司。那种感觉糟透了，我感觉自己彻底失败了。申请破产会带来污名，而且会影响你的信用记录长达十年，但我不得不做出这个艰难的决定，这关系到我个人的生活——也就是我的公司ME Enterprises, Inc.。申请破产是消除债务的一种方法。通过申请破产，我摆脱了超过20万美元的债务。对于像我一样冒险的人来说，破产是一个很好的选择；它给了你第二次机会。必要时，可以考虑申请破产，给自己一个重新开始的机会。但不要滥用破产；许多人申请破产仅仅是因为他们过着不该有的生活方式。

But the important thing is that even though that one endeavor didn’t work, the business that is “me” did! A few years later, I found some investors, asked myself all the right questions, applied 3 P’s + 1 P, analyzed why other others were not successful, and formed a new company. As I type today, we are approved in thirteen states, and we have the infrastructure set up to really take Zeus Juice to market.

但重要的是，即便那一次尝试失败了，我这个“创业者”却成功了！几年后，我找到了一些投资人，问了自己所有关键问题，运用了3P+1P营销理论，分析了其他人失败的原因，并成立了一家新公司。就在我敲下这些文字的时候，我们的产品已经获得了13个州的批准，并且我们已经搭建好了基础设施，可以真正将宙斯果汁推向市场了。

GET REAL PERSONAL

获得真正的个人体验

Earlier in the book, I discussed insanity as defined by Albert Einstein, and I think so many of us actually suffer with insanity as it relates to our personal finances. You have to ask yourself tough questions that you may not want to hear the answer to. When you are able to do that, you will be in a much better position to evaluate your business and make the right decisions.

在本书前面部分，我探讨了爱因斯坦对“疯狂”的定义，我认为我们很多人在个人财务方面实际上都存在着类似的“疯狂”。你必须问自己一些棘手的问题，而这些问题的答案你可能并不想听到。当你能够做到这一点时，你就能更好地评估你的财务状况并做出正确的决策。

Ask yourself questions like:

问问自己以下问题：

  • Am I spending more than I make? For most, the answer is yes.


    我的支出是否超过了收入？对大多数人来说，答案是肯定的。
  • Am I living beyond my means?


    我的生活是否超出了我的经济能力？
  • Does my partner (spouse) know our real financial situation?


    我的伴侣（配偶）了解我们真实的财务状况吗？
  • Am I doing everything I can to reduce my costs?


    我是否已尽一切努力降低成本？

Once you find the answers to the questions, you have to do something different to make the necessary changes. Waiting will make it worse. The more you put it off, the more it becomes a mental monster . Do not let your personal business become a mental monster; it doesn’t have to be. The following are some additional tough questions, listed in no particular order. Most people don’t like to ask themselves these questions, but if you do and answer them honestly, you can begin to become financially free.

一旦你找到了问题的答案，就必须采取不同的行动来做出必要的改变。等待只会让情况变得更糟。你拖延得越久，它就越会变成一个精神上的怪兽。不要让你的个人问题变成你的精神怪兽；它本不该如此。以下是一些其他棘手的问题，排名不分先后。大多数人都不喜欢问自己这些问题，但如果你能问，并且诚实地回答，你就能开始实现财务自由。

  • Do I have a five-year plan? A ten-year plan? Fifteen, twenty, etc.?


    我有没有五年计划？十年计划？十五年、二十年等等？
  • If I were to stop bringing in income today, how long could I sustain my current lifestyle?


    如果我今天停止收入，我还能维持目前的生活方式多久？
  • Do I have enough money set aside for emergencies?


    我是否预留了足够的应急资金？
  • Am I saving enough money?


    我存的钱够吗？
  • Do I spend money on things I shouldn’t, like cigarettes, alcohol, or drugs?


    我是否会把钱花在不该花的东西上，比如香烟、酒精或毒品？
  • Am I saving for my child’s education?


    我在为孩子的教育存钱吗？
  • Do I have a daily, weekly, and monthly budget?


    我是否有每日、每周和每月的预算？
  • What is my financial net worth? If I paid all my debts, what would be left over?


    我的净资产是多少？如果我还清所有债务，还剩下多少钱？

I’m sure you can come up with more questions, and you should. Once you can face and answer the tough questions, the ones you don’t want to hear the answers to, you can then address the questions and change course, allowing you to cure your personal financial insanity. Ask more questions and get more out of your personal business. Don’t let your personal financial situation turn into a mental monster that could become impossible to defeat; ask questions now !

我相信你还能提出更多问题，而且你应该这样做。一旦你能够面对并回答那些棘手的问题，那些你不想听到答案的问题，你就能着手解决这些问题，改变方向，从而摆脱个人财务困境。多问问题，从你的个人事务中获得更多。不要让你的个人财务状况变成一个难以战胜的精神怪兽；现在就开始提问吧！

Some say that it is depressing to know their true financial picture. They don’t want to face the fact that they are working day after day, not getting anywhere, going deeper into debt, and that their future does not look bright. But if you don’t learn about your financial troubles now, when you finally decide to make the decision to ask yourself the tough questions it will be that much more difficult to reverse the damage that was being caused because of your lack of personal accountability and refusal to ask tough questions. Remember, you are the CEO of YOU Enterprises, Inc. and you need to be able to make the tough decisions and ask the tough questions in order for your business—your life—to thrive.

有些人说，了解自己的真实财务状况令人沮丧。他们不愿面对日复一日辛勤工作却毫无进展、债务越滚越大、未来一片黯淡的现实。但如果你现在不去了解自己的财务困境，那么当你最终决定扪心自问那些棘手的问题时，由于缺乏个人责任感和拒绝提出尖锐的问题而造成的损害将更难挽回。记住，你是“你企业有限公司”的首席执行官，你必须能够做出艰难的决定，提出尖锐的问题，你的事业——你的人生——才能蓬勃发展。

YOUR CASH FLOW

您的现金流

As I mentioned earlier, my father is a machinist, the classic, hardworking, lower-middle-class guy, always trying to stretch his paycheck a little bit further, but just barely getting by. One thing I learned from him when I was a kid was that every weekend he used to handwrite—with a pencil so he could adjust—his bills and his cash flow. My parents are divorced, and I would see my dad on the weekends. He would essentially create a cash flow projection for his personal life. Almost always it was in the red.

正如我之前提到的，我父亲是一名机械师，典型的勤劳的中下层阶级，总是想方设法让工资更省着用，但收入也只能勉强维持生计。我小时候从他身上学到的一件事是，他每个周末都会用铅笔手写账单和现金流，这样方便调整。我的父母离异，我只能在周末见到父亲。他会给自己做一份个人财务预测。几乎每次都是赤字。

But his income is not the point. He did not hide behind the fact that his bills were growing faster than his income; he wrote down in a pretty organized manner what was owed and what he had. This is the first step to running your personal life like a business.

但他的收入并非重点。他没有掩饰自己账单增长速度超过收入的事实；他有条不紊地记录了欠款和收入。这是像经营企业一样管理个人生活的第一步。

BUT DON’T BE OVERCAUTIOUS—GO FOR IT!

但不要过于谨慎——放手一搏吧！

“The biggest risk is not taking one.” I saw that quote in a magazine for an insurance company, and I thought it was a very clever ad. An insurance company advertising the idea that risks are necessary for achieving your goals seemed like the antithesis of a typical insurance company’s philosophy. Robert Kiyosaki said almost the same thing in Rich Dad, Poor Dad : “In today’s rapidly changing world, the people who are not taking risk are the risk takers.”

“最大的风险就是不承担风险。”我在一本保险公司的杂志上看到了这句话，觉得这则广告非常巧妙。一家保险公司宣传风险对于实现目标至关重要，这似乎与典型的保险公司理念截然相反。罗伯特·清崎在《富爸爸，穷爸爸》中也表达了类似的观点：“在当今瞬息万变的世界里，那些不承担风险的人才是真正的风险承担者。”

A universal trait of successful people is that they take risks. I take risks every day. Most people wouldn’t even consider the risks that I take in order to grow my business. I have maxed out all of my credit cards, closed out my 401k several times, borrowed millions of dollars that I personally guarantee, and put everything I own on the line several times. Taking risks in your personal life and business, if well thought out, will always lead to success at some point. It is important to remember that the risks you take must be morally, legally, and ethically correct.

成功人士的一个共同特点是敢于冒险。我每天都在冒险。大多数人甚至不会想到我为了发展事业所承担的风险。我刷爆了所有信用卡，多次清空了我的401k退休账户，借了数百万美元并由我个人担保，还多次将我的所有财产都押上。在个人生活和事业中，只要经过深思熟虑，冒险总能在某个时刻带来成功。重要的是要记住，你所承担的风险必须在道德、法律和伦理上都是正确的。

Taking the frozen shot risk was a big one, but I knew if I were to suffer a few setbacks I could recover and try again. If Zeus Juice had not suffered the temporary defeat as a result of my risk-taking, I would not have found my first job in the business I am in now. I would not have made millions in this business, and I certainly would not be writing this book.

尝试冷冻果汁的风险很大，但我知道即使遭遇一些挫折，我也能重新振作，再次尝试。如果宙斯果汁没有因为我的冒险而遭受暂时的失败，我就不会找到现在这份工作，也不会在这个行业赚到数百万美元，更不会写这本书。

Taking a risk is absolutely necessary to be successful in business and your personal life. When analyzing the risk, apply the 3 P’s + 1 P technique, and you will minimize the potential for your risk-taking to cause financial or emotional distress. 3 P’s + 1 P will also alleviate any fear that you may have. Fear is a biomarker of excusetosis, and can impede your ability to take calculated risks. Successful people take risks!

承担风险对于事业和个人生活的成功都至关重要。在分析风险时，运用“3P+1P”法则，可以最大限度地降低风险行为可能造成的经济或精神损失。“3P+1P”法则还能消除你的恐惧。恐惧是借口的生物标志，会阻碍你进行理性评估并承担风险。成功人士敢于冒险！

Bill Gates was quoted as saying, “To win big, you sometimes have to take big risks.” Donald Trump, Michael Dell, Steve Jobs, and everyone before them all took risks. All of them also use and apply several of the strategies and techniques in my book. Just ask any successful person you know, and they will tell you they take risks.

比尔·盖茨曾说过：“要想获得巨大成功，有时就必须承担巨大的风险。”唐纳德·特朗普、迈克尔·戴尔、史蒂夫·乔布斯以及他们之前的所有人，都曾承担过风险。他们也都运用了我书中提到的几种策略和技巧。随便问问你认识的任何一位成功人士，他们都会告诉你，他们都敢于冒险。

Here are the stories of a few famous and successful risk-takers:

以下是一些著名且成功的冒险家的故事：

STEVE JOBS, FOUNDER OF APPLE AND PIXAR

史蒂夫·乔布斯，苹果和皮克斯创始人

Steve Jobs dropped out of Reed College after a semester, spent a year in India, and returned to found Apple with his friend, Stephen Wozniak. Mr. Jobs was forced out of Apple in 1985, went off and founded two other companies, NeXT and Pixar, before returning to Apple in 1996 and becoming chief executive officer in 1997. NeXT did not work, but Mr. Jobs put practically every dollar he had into Pixar, and that risk paid off, big-time.

史蒂夫·乔布斯在里德学院读了一个学期后辍学，在印度待了一年，之后回到美国与好友史蒂芬·沃兹尼亚克共同创立了苹果公司。1985年，乔布斯被迫离开苹果，随后又创办了NeXT和皮克斯两家公司。1996年，他重返苹果，并于1997年成为首席执行官。NeXT最终以失败告终，但乔布斯几乎将自己所有的积蓄都投入到了皮克斯，而这一冒险最终获得了巨大的成功。

TIM WESTERGREN, FOUNDER OF PANDORA RADIO

蒂姆·韦斯特格伦 (Tim Westergren)，潘多拉广播电台创始人

In the winter of 2001, Pandora was completely out of money. Tim Westergren had a clear choice: cut his losses or find a way to make it work. He decided to keep the company alive by deferring salaries—risks that employees took. Ultimately, more than fifty people deferred roughly $1.5 million over the course of two years. In 2004, with eleven of his credit cards maxed out, they got an infusion of cash, and the rest is history.

2001年冬天，潘多拉公司资金彻底耗尽。蒂姆·韦斯特格伦面临着一个明确的选择：要么止损，要么想办法让公司继续运转下去。他决定通过延迟发放工资来维持公司的生存——这需要员工承担风险。最终，在两年的时间里，超过50名员工延迟发放了约150万美元的工资。2004年，由于他的11张信用卡都已刷爆，公司获得了一笔资金注入，剩下的故事大家都知道了。

JERRY JONES, OWNER OF THE DALLAS COWBOYS

杰里·琼斯，达拉斯牛仔队老板

In 1989, when the Dallas Cowboys franchise was losing $1 million a month and was nowhere near “America’s Team,” Jerry Jones bought 13 percent of the franchise for close to $155 million. He spent nearly everything he had. In 2008, he broke ground on one of the most ambitious stadium builds in the history of the NFL, and now the Dallas Cowboys are valued at close to $2 billion dollars!

1989年，达拉斯牛仔队每月亏损100万美元，距离“美国之队”的称号还相去甚远。当时，杰里·琼斯斥资近1.55亿美元收购了球队13%的股份。他几乎花光了所有积蓄。2008年，他启动了NFL历史上最雄心勃勃的体育场建设项目之一，如今达拉斯牛仔队的估值已接近20亿美元！

DAVID CHOE, FAMOUS ARTIST

大卫·乔，著名艺术家

Although not at risk of living in the street if it didn’t pay off, David Choe, a famous contemporary muralist, was asked by Sean Parker, then president of a little-known company called Facebook, to paint their offices for free in exchange for stock options. Choe would normally have charged $60,000 to paint his famous murals on the office walls, but agreed to do it for stock. Now Choe’s risk has paid off to the tune of about $200 million in stock value.

尽管即便失败也不会流落街头，但著名当代壁画家大卫·崔（David Choe）还是应当时名不见经传的Facebook公司总裁肖恩·帕克（Sean Parker）的邀请，免费为公司办公室绘制壁画，以换取股票期权。崔通常会收取6万美元的报酬，但他同意以股票作为交换。如今，崔的冒险之举已为公司带来了约2亿美元的股票价值。

CURTIS JAMES JACKSON, AKA 50 CENT, FAMOUS RAPPER/ENTERTAINER

柯蒂斯·詹姆斯·杰克逊，又名50 Cent，著名说唱歌手/艺人

Now, 50 Cent did not live the most righteous life in his earlier years, but he took a risk that some rumored to be worth over $400 million when he was asked by Vitamin Water to be their spokesperson and appear in their advertisements. He agreed, but took the risk—betting his time and potential royalty deal—of opting for stock instead of a royalty. According to my research, after all was said and done, 50 Cent walked away with close to $100 million.

50 Cent早年的生活并不算光明磊落，但他接受Vitamin Water的代言邀请，出演广告，据传此举价值超过4亿美元。他欣然应允，但却冒着时间和潜在版税的风险，选择了股票而非版税。据我调查，最终50 Cent从中获利近1亿美元。

The key to taking risks is to minimize that risk by being prepared and thinking through every possible scenario. Taking risks also involves vision, an intangible part of taking a risk that cannot be put on paper or into a formula. Sometimes you have to trust your vision and instinct.

承担风险的关键在于通过充分准备和深思熟虑来降低风险。承担风险也需要远见，这是风险中一种无形的因素，无法用文字或公式来描述。有时，你必须相信自己的远见和直觉。

STAND UP—AND BE YOURSELF

站起来——做你自己

Asking for more isn’t only about material things or money; it’s also about how you feel at the end of the day. Ask yourself: Are you able to have a hobby? Do you do things that just make you happy? I am not a very religious person, but I believe in my own inner spirit and the inner spirit of all human beings. If your inner spirit is not happy, then happiness will be very difficult to find. Many times the self-fulfilling prophecy that comes your way is a direct result of your inner thoughts, emotions, and spirit. Be happy and you will find happiness; be miserable and you will find misery. It’s tough to be happy when you are surrounded by despair, but there is always a silver lining to everything, and once you find it, you will find happiness.

追求更多并非仅仅指物质或金钱，也关乎你一天结束时的感受。问问自己：你是否有爱好？你是否做那些能让你真正快乐的事情？我并非虔诚的信徒，但我相信自己的内心世界，也相信所有人的内心世界。如果你的内心世界并不快乐，那么快乐就很难寻觅。很多时候，你所经历的自我实现的预言，正是你内心想法、情感和精神状态的直接结果。保持快乐，你就会找到快乐；保持痛苦，你就会找到痛苦。身处绝望之中，很难感到快乐，但凡事总有转机，一旦你找到它，你就会找到快乐。

I always thought I was a funny guy. I enjoy stand-up comedy, and one day I was discussing my hysterical comedic talent with a friend and he challenged me to get on stage and see if a bunch of strangers agreed with my assessment of my humor. Well, I took that challenge, and I wouldn’t say that I “killed it” (comedians’ expression for doing very well) but I had a good set. That was several months ago, and I have continued to go up on stage. I have performed in Boston, Los Angeles, Orlando, and San Diego at some pretty major comedy clubs. They were all open mics, but some were very difficult to actually get stage time in, such as the iconic Improv in Hollywood. As I continued to do stand-up, the very friend who challenged me asked to take me out to lunch, which doesn’t happen that often. He sat me down and said, “Mike, you have a very successful company, you are on TV every day with some of the top-rated infomercials, you are a successful lawyer, you have a book deal … what’s up with the comedy? Are you having a midlife crisis? What is your endgame?”

我一直觉得自己挺幽默的。我喜欢单口喜剧，有一天我和一个朋友聊起我那令人捧腹的喜剧天赋，他怂恿我上台表演，看看一群陌生人是否认同我对自己幽默感的评价。好吧，我接受了挑战，虽然不能说我“表现得非常出色”（喜剧演员常用的表达），但我的表演还算不错。那是几个月前的事了，之后我一直坚持上台表演。我在波士顿、洛杉矶、奥兰多和圣地亚哥的一些知名喜剧俱乐部都演出过。虽然都是开放麦，但有些地方很难争取到上台表演的机会，比如好莱坞著名的即兴喜剧俱乐部（Improv）。随着我继续表演单口喜剧，当初挑战我的那个朋友竟然主动提出要请我吃午饭，这可不是经常发生的事。他让我坐下，然后说：“迈克，你拥有一家非常成功的公司，你每天都出现在电视上，出演一些收视率最高的电视购物广告，你是一位成功的律师，你还签了出版合同……你为什么突然不去搞喜剧了？你是不是遇到了中年危机？你的最终目标是什么？”

I told him I didn’t have an endgame, and I’m not having a midlife crisis. I told him, “I just want to be happy. I had a goal of performing at a club in Boston to see if the crowd responded, which they did, but I have no endgame.” Sometimes you do things just for fun; stand-up comedy for me is just a hobby. I actually enjoy the art of comedy and how one word, one facial expression, or your tone of voice can make or break a joke. Not everything you do has to have an endgame.

我告诉他我没有最终目标，也不是中年危机。我告诉他：“我只想快乐。我原本的目标是在波士顿的一家俱乐部表演，看看观众的反应，结果他们确实很热情，但我没有最终目标。” 有时候，你做某些事只是为了好玩；对我来说，单口喜剧只是个爱好。我真的很享受喜剧的艺术，享受一个词、一个表情，甚至一个语气，就能成就或毁掉一个笑话。并不是你做的每件事都必须有个最终目标。

KYLA CAN DO NO WRONG

凯拉永远不会犯错

I had a dog named Kyla for almost ten years. We adopted her at the local shelter, and she was the best dog anyone could wish for. She was a big, intimidating-looking dog when we saw her, and she was probably about five years old. She sat in the pound for several months with an eye infection, a skin infection, and generally looking pretty scary. We think she was part pit bull and part pointer. That combination of being tall with a big chest, a big head, and all muscle made her difficult to want to adopt. Kyla was loyal, yet mischievous, a beggar but also a listener, strong but gentle: all in all, an amazing dog. We adopted her for $100 but spent roughly $8,000 on having both knees fixed, and we loved this dog like a blood relative.

我养了一条名叫凯拉的狗将近十年。我们是从当地的动物收容所领养的她，她是我们梦寐以求的狗狗。我们第一次见到她时，她体型庞大，看起来很吓人，大概五岁左右。她当时在收容所待了好几个月，眼睛和皮肤都感染了，看起来十分凶猛。我们觉得她可能是比特犬和指示犬的混血。她身材高大，胸膛宽阔，头也很大，浑身肌肉发达，这些特点让我们一开始很难决定是否领养她。凯拉忠诚又调皮，会乞食但也很听话，强壮却温柔：总而言之，她是一条非常棒的狗狗。我们当初只花了100美元就领养了她，但后来花了大约8000美元给她做了双膝关节手术，我们像对待亲人一样爱着她。

Kyla grew old and began to lose her senses and faculties. It was so sad to see, because she also seemed happy. Eventually her breathing became so labored that we were concerned she would have a heart attack. After consulting with the veterinarian, we made one of the most gut-wrenching decisions: it was time to put her down. We actually scheduled a date, one that no dog lover is ever prepared for. But before that date, for about a week, we had a Kyla Could Do No Wrong policy and treated her like the queen she was. We gave her steak for dinner and marrow bones all day long. She slept where she wanted and did what she wanted. We spent as much time petting her and loving her as possible. We bought her special dog treats and she got tons of them. Her last day, she happily sat on our front lawn and chewed on a marrow bone. On the way to the veterinarian’s I stopped and got her a bagel with peanut butter. When we arrived at the veterinarian’s office I brought with me a cushion from the couch she loved. And then she peacefully went to dog heaven. I loved that dog!

凯拉渐渐老去，开始失去知觉和能力。看着她这样，我们非常难过，因为她看起来也很快乐。最终，她的呼吸变得异常困难，我们担心她会心脏病发作。咨询兽医后，我们做出了一个无比痛苦的决定：是时候让她安乐死了。我们甚至安排了日期，这是任何爱狗人士都无法预料的。但在那之前的一周左右，我们奉行“凯拉永远都是最好的”原则，像对待女王一样宠爱她。我们给她准备了牛排晚餐，整天都给她啃骨髓。她想睡哪儿就睡哪儿，想干什么就干什么。我们尽可能多地抚摸她、爱她。我们给她买了特制的狗零食，而且给她吃了很多。在她生命的最后一天，她快乐地坐在我们家门前的草坪上，啃着一根骨髓。去兽医诊所的路上，我停下来给她买了一个涂了花生酱的百吉饼。我们到达兽医诊所时，我带了一个她生前最爱的沙发垫。然后，她安详地去了狗狗天堂。我爱那只狗狗！

But, the point of telling you this story is that sometimes you too have to have a You Can Do No Wrong Day and live life. Enjoy the things that make you happy, spend time with your family. Do whatever makes you happy. I’m still figuring life out, but after having a Kyla Can Do No Wrong Week, it dawned on me that we need the same thing, not when it is our time to go, but whenever we can. It is good for the soul. You always hear people who have beat cancer have more of an appreciation for life, for the smaller things like actually smelling the roses and the coffee. So in your pursuit of success, whatever that may be, on your way there and when you get there, make sure you have a You Can Do No Wrong Day here and there. I am very fortunate to be able to have several Do No Wrong Days in a row.

但是，我讲这个故事的重点是，有时候你也需要拥有“无所不能”的一天，好好享受生活。享受那些让你快乐的事情，多花时间陪伴家人。做任何让你快乐的事情。我还在摸索人生，但在经历了“凯拉无所不能”的一周后，我突然意识到，我们都需要同样的东西，不是在我们生命终结之时，而是在我们还能享受生活的时候。这对心灵有益。你总是会听到那些战胜癌症的人更加珍惜生命，更加懂得欣赏生活中的点滴美好，比如闻闻玫瑰的芬芳，品尝一杯香浓的咖啡。所以，在你追求成功的过程中，无论你的目标是什么，在通往成功的路上，以及当你最终到达终点时，一定要确保自己时不时地拥有一个“无所不能”的日子。我很幸运，能够连续拥有好几个这样的“无所不能”的日子。

It’s also a good idea to give someone you know a You Can Do No Wrong Day, whether it be a spouse, sibling, or coworker; everyone needs one. If you feel like a day is not possible, you can do an hour, a half-day, or whatever it is. Ask yourself: When was the last time I had a Do No Wrong Day?

不妨也给身边的人安排一个“无所不能日”，无论是配偶、兄弟姐妹还是同事；每个人都需要这样的日子。如果你觉得一天不太现实，也可以安排一个小时、半天，或者任何你喜欢的时长。问问自己：我上一次拥有“无所不能日”是什么时候？

DON’T FIGHT AUTHORITY: RESPECT IT AND DEMAND THAT IT RESPECT YOU!

不要对抗权威：尊重权威，并要求权威尊重你！

As a kid I obviously had drive and wanted more, but I also participated in activities that no one would be proud of. Shoplifting was an option for me as a kid. I never got caught, and to be honest it wasn’t something I did a lot, but I did. One time I was at the mall with two of my friends and we were in Sears. As we walked out we were approached by an undercover security guard. Both of my friends had stolen video games; I for some reason, thankfully did not! Even though I hadn’t stolen anything, we were all brought to the security area, and we had to call our parents and were told we were never allowed in the store again. I was “scared straight,” as they would say.

小时候，我显然很有上进心，渴望拥有更多，但也做过一些让人不齿的事情。偷东西对我来说是件很常见的事。我从没被抓到过，老实说，我偷东西的次数也不多，但确实发生过。有一次，我和两个朋友在商场里，我们去了西尔斯百货。出来的时候，一个便衣保安拦住了我们。我的两个朋友偷了电子游戏；不知怎么的，我竟然没偷！虽然我什么都没偷，但我们都被带到了保安室，不得不打电话给父母，还被告知以后永远不准再进这家店。我算是被“吓唬”了，就像人们常说的那样。

When people ask me what made me different than a lot of the kids I grew up with, I joke around and say, “Well, I never got caught.” But, what really set me apart was that I respected authority and my elders. I was deathly afraid of getting in trouble; I was already the poor kid, and people expected me to be involved in petty crime, but I just didn’t want to make it any worse. Many of the kids that I grew up with just didn’t care. They were already fatally infected with excusetosis and ultimately had no self-respect. I wanted more than to be accepted by my peers and their parents; I wanted to be respected. In order to be respected you have to respect others. I think my mom told me that.

当人们问我，我和一起长大的很多孩子有什么不同时，我常常开玩笑说：“嗯，我从来没被抓到过。” 但真正让我与众不同的是，我尊重权威和长辈。我非常害怕惹麻烦；我本来就是个穷孩子，大家都觉得我迟早会犯些小错，但我不想让情况变得更糟。我一起长大的很多孩子根本不在乎。他们早已患上了“找借口”的顽疾，最终失去了自尊。我想要的不仅仅是被同龄人和他们的父母接纳；我想要的是被尊重。想要获得尊重，首先要尊重他人。我想我妈妈曾经这样告诉过我。

HOW I LEARNED TO STOP BEING AFRAID TO OFFEND: THE POWER OF “FUCK”

我如何学会不再害怕冒犯他人：“FUCK”的力量

I never imagined that my book would use expletives, and I had a hard time recognizing the benefit of using what some may find an offensive word in my book. But, well, I grew up just outside of Boston, and the word “fuck” is just a part of our everyday vernacular. It is not a word you want to use around children, and it is obviously offensive to some. However, the offensiveness of the word is what also makes it powerful. It is not appropriate in every situation, but when used properly it can be very effective.

我从未想过我的书里会用到脏话，也很难理解在书中使用这些可能被某些人视为冒犯的词语的意义。但是，嗯，我是在波士顿郊外长大的，“fuck”这个词在我们日常用语中早已司空见惯。当然，你肯定不想在孩子面前用这个词，而且它显然会冒犯到一些人。然而，正是这种冒犯性赋予了它强大的力量。它并非适用于所有场合，但如果运用得当，它能产生非常显著的效果。

Case in point: about a year ago, I had an employee who works for me mess up a major part of her job. She has a very important position, and the information she gives to me affects my business decisions as well as the entire company and its employees. This person also is a very good friend of mine and she has known me since I was twelve. All this meant that she ended up becoming the unfortunate (or I could say fortunate) person to learn about the power of “fuck.”

举个例子：大约一年前，我的一位员工在工作中犯了一个大错。她身居要职，她提供的信息不仅影响我的商业决策，也影响整个公司及其员工。这个人还是我的好朋友，我们从我十二岁就认识了。这一切最终导致她不幸（或者说幸运）地领教了“fuck”的力量。

The conversation went something like this:

对话大致如下：

Me: Sue, you realize that you fucked up royally? You realize that because you were not prepared and essentially didn’t do your job, that you fucked me and the company, right?

我：苏，你意识到你搞砸了吗？你意识到因为你没有做好准备，而且基本上没有尽到你的职责，你害了我，也害了公司，对吧？

Sue: Michael, why are you talking like this to me? Why are you degrading me?

苏：迈克尔，你为什么这样跟我说话？你为什么要贬低我？

Me: Sue, you have known me since I was twelve, right?

我：苏，你从我十二岁起就认识我了，对吧？

Sue: Yeah.

苏：是啊。

Me: Have I not used the word “fuck” since then?

我：从那以后我就没用过“fuck”这个词了吗？

Sue: Yeah.

苏：是啊。

Me: Okay, then, well you fucked up, almost cost me and the company millions , and you almost got fired. Don’t ever do it again, and remember this conversation in the future. I still love you.

我：好吧，那你搞砸了，差点让我和公司损失几百万，你也差点被炒鱿鱼。以后别再犯这种错误了，记住我们这次谈话的内容。我依然爱你。

Now, there are many businesspeople who would totally disagree with the use of this word. They would say that I am immature, that there are more effective ways to communicate, and it is just downright crass. Well, they may be right. But, I know this: Sue has never made the mistake again, and as a result she double- and triple-checks her data before giving it to me. I also challenge her, and for the most part, her information since the above conversation has been correct.

现在，很多商界人士会完全不同意我使用这个词。他们会说我不成熟，有更有效的沟通方式，而且这种说法简直粗鲁无礼。好吧，他们或许是对的。但我知道一点：苏之后再也没有犯过同样的错误，所以她现在每次给我数据之前都会反复核对。我也会质疑她，而且从上次谈话之后，她提供的信息大部分都是正确的。

Did I offend her? Yeah, probably. Did she get it? Did she understand the magnitude of her mistake? Yes, she did. Will she make the same mistake again? Well, I don’t have a crystal ball in front of me. But, by my “offending” her by using the word fuck , she got it.

我冒犯到她了吗？嗯，可能吧。她明白了吗？她意识到自己犯的错误有多严重了吗？是的，她明白了。她还会犯同样的错误吗？嗯，我可没有水晶球。但是，我用了“fuck”这个词“冒犯”了她，她已经明白了。

I actually held a meeting about being more assertive and, yes, using the word fuck with my executives. Most of my day consists of speaking with my executives about the business and our vendors, clients, and customers. Many times I give a directive, and because it is not in the executives’ demeanor, they are not as aggressive as they should be and thus not as effective. I had a call center that takes a lot of our calls essentially steal from our company, treat my customers poorly, and ultimately just do a horrible job. I asked one of my executives to express my concerns and to fix it. Well, as I bet you can guess, the executive was not as passionate with his concerns and was a little more “professional.” But, I have to point out that we have a very large staff, and they have families and children. They depend on us. Furthermore, we have customers who expect a certain level of service, and our reputation is everything. When a vendor does not do what we expect on our behalf, they are essentially telling me, my employees, and my customers to fuck off , and I am extremely offended by such a lack of care and service. I picked up the phone and expressed my concerns to the VP of sales and marketing at this particular call center, using the word fuck as a verb, an adjective, and a noun, and guess what? They fixed the problem and gave us a credit.

我确实召开了一次会议，讨论如何更加强硬地与高管沟通，甚至包括使用“fuck”这个词。我每天的大部分时间都花在与高管讨论业务、供应商、客户和顾客的事情上。很多时候，我下达指令，但由于高管们缺乏这种魄力，他们无法像应该的那样积极主动，因此效率也较低。我有一个呼叫中心，他们接听我们很多电话，实际上就是在窃取公司财物，对待客户态度恶劣，最终工作表现糟糕透顶。我要求一位高管表达我的担忧并解决这个问题。不出所料，这位高管并没有像我一样充满热情地表达他的担忧，而是表现得更加“专业”。但是，我必须指出，我们公司员工众多，他们都有家庭和孩子。他们依赖我们。此外，我们的客户期望获得一定水平的服务，而我们的声誉至关重要。当供应商没有按照我们的预期行事时，他们实际上是在对我和我的员工、我的客户说“滚蛋”，这种缺乏关心和服务的态度让我非常愤怒。我拿起电话，向这家呼叫中心的销售和市场营销副总裁表达了我的不满，我用了“滚蛋”这个词作为动词、形容词和名词，你猜怎么着？他们解决了问题，还给了我们补偿。

One time I picked up the phone and said to a vendor, “I know you are fucking me.” That’s all I said. The vendor responded and asked me what I wanted. As you already know, when I said that I knew what I wanted. They had about $250,000 of my money (they are essentially a bank), and I wanted it, now. Guess what? I got it, and they reduced the rate that they were charging me in the future.

有一次，我拿起电话对一个供应商说：“我知道你在坑我。” 我就说了这么一句。供应商接了电话，问我想要什么。你也知道，我说这话的时候，心里就清楚自己想要什么。他们手里有我大约25万美元（他们本质上就是个银行），而我想要这笔钱，现在就要。你猜怎么着？我拿到了，而且他们还降低了我以后要付的利率。

Now, if you do not use this word in your life and you are offended by it, then let me apologize. It is not the use of the word fuck that is important. It is the use of the English language in a way that will effectively convey to the other party that they have screwed you, hurt you, or disappointed you. And, you cannot be afraid to offend someone who fucks you, in your personal or business life, because at the end of the day you are the only one who is responsible for making YOU Enterprises, Inc. successful.

如果你生活中不使用这个词，却因此感到冒犯，那我先道个歉。重要的不是“fuck”这个词本身，而是用英语有效地向对方传达他们辜负了你、伤害了你或让你失望了。无论是在个人生活还是商业生活中，你都不应该害怕得罪那些辜负你的人，因为归根结底，只有你自己才能让“你企业有限公司”（YOU Enterprises, Inc.）取得成功。

RELATIONSHIPS

人际关系

One thing I have learned in my thirty-eight years on this planet is the importance of developing and maintaining strong personal and business relationships. When the time comes to ask for more from people, they are much more receptive if you have a relationship with them. In business I have developed strong relationships that have grown and become stronger over time. Many of these relationships truly were built on a handshake and my word. I’m sure you always hear things like “my word is my bond,” or “you have my word.” But, if you don’t really mean it, if you don’t stick to what you agreed to, then your word is worthless.

我在这世上活了三十八年，学到的最重要的一点就是建立和维护牢固的个人和商业关系的重要性。当你需要向他人提出更多要求时，如果你与他们建立了良好的关系，他们会更容易接受。在商业领域，我建立了许多牢固的关系，这些关系随着时间的推移不断发展壮大。其中许多关系的确是建立在握手和承诺之上的。我相信你经常听到“一诺千金”或“我保证”之类的话。但是，如果你言而无信，如果你没有履行承诺，那么你的承诺就毫无价值。

As business relationships develop and even evolve into friendships, your professional life will thrive and grow. When I first got into the direct response industry I was at a free cocktail party with a colleague. I was what some people would call “green.” I didn’t know anyone, and we were there to network. A man walked up to my colleague and me and introduced himself. We didn’t know him or anything about the company he worked for. That relationship began on a handshake, and my good friend Mark Biglow, a partner at Mercury Media, has gone to bat for me several times. His company financed many of my projects based on my word, and as I type, I still owe them money, but we continue to do business and pay down our balances. This relationship, which was built on a handshake and a word, has literally generated tens of millions of dollars. I have asked them for things most people would not even consider asking, but because of our relationship, not only did they grant my requests, but they continue to.

随着商业关系的建立，甚至发展成友谊，你的职业生涯也会蓬勃发展。我刚入行直效营销行业时，和一位同事参加了一个免费的鸡尾酒会。当时的我可谓是“菜鸟”，人生地不熟，我们去那里就是为了拓展人脉。这时，一位男士走到我和同事面前，做了自我介绍。我们之前并不认识他，也不知道他所在的公司是怎样的。这段关系始于一次握手，我的好朋友马克·比格洛（Mark Biglow）是Mercury Media的合伙人，他曾多次为我出谋划策。他的公司基于我的口头承诺为我的许多项目提供了资金，即便现在我还欠他们一些钱，但我们仍然保持着合作关系，并努力偿还欠款。这段建立在握手和承诺之上的关系，已经为我们创造了数千万美元的收益。我曾向他们提出过一些大多数人想都不敢想的要求，但正因为我们之间的关系，他们不仅满足了我的请求，而且还一直给予我支持。

When I first started Blue Vase I had limited funds, credit cards, and my word. My credit cards and limited funds alone would not have gotten me to where I am today. Since I am in the advertising business, our biggest expense is media. When you buy media you have to pay two weeks in advance. I did not have two weeks’ worth of media to grow my company. But I had developed a relationship with a man by the name of Peter Bieler. Peter is one of the most successful people in the direct response industry; he has a beautiful house in the hills of Malibu and was responsible for the Thigh Master infomercial. As a result of our strong relationship, Peter has literally loaned me tens of millions of dollars. A kid from the projects with no ties to wealthy people was able to take the only thing I had—the only thing you have—my word , to grow my business.

我刚创办Blue Vase的时候，资金有限，只有信用卡和我的信誉。单凭信用卡和有限的资金，我不可能走到今天。因为我从事广告行业，最大的开销就是媒体投放。购买媒体投放需要提前两周付款。我当时根本没有足够的资金来支付两周的媒体费用，也就无法发展壮大我的公司。但我与一位名叫Peter Bieler的人建立了良好的关系。Peter是直复营销行业最成功的人士之一；他在马里布山拥有一栋漂亮的房子，而且还是“健腿大师”（Thigh Master）电视购物广告的制作人。正因为我们关系密切，Peter借给了我数千万美元。一个来自贫民窟、与富人没有任何关系的孩子，竟然能够凭借我——也是你——唯一拥有的东西——我的信誉——来发展我的事业。

About three years ago, my business was growing at a rapid pace. We had close to two hundred people and we were doing millions of dollars in sales every week. My accountant, who was new to the industry, had made some miscalculations, and we were actually hemorrhaging money. Yes, I realize that last sentence sounds a whole lot like an excuse, and I am really the one responsible, but for purposes of the story that’s what happened. But by the time I realized what had really happened, we owed Peter over $1 million, and I had nothing in our bank account. I needed another $250,000 just to cover payroll. I will never forget that day. I was actually sitting on a park bench talking with some of my executives and trying to solve this enormous challenge. The only person I knew who could lend that kind of money on a handshake was Peter, the guy I already owed all the money to that I couldn’t pay back!

大约三年前，我的公司发展迅猛。我们当时有近两百名员工，每周销售额高达数百万美元。我的会计是个新手，他算错了账，导致我们实际上一直在亏损。是的，我知道最后这句话听起来很像借口，而且确实是我的责任，但为了方便叙述，事情就是这样发生的。等我意识到真相的时候，我们已经欠彼得一百多万美元，而我的银行账户里已经空空如也。我还需要25万美元才能支付员工工资。我永远不会忘记那天。当时我正坐在公园的长椅上，和几位高管商量如何解决这个巨大的难题。我认识的唯一一个能凭握手就借给我这么多钱的人，就是彼得——那个我欠了他一大笔钱却还不上的人！

I called him up, explained the situation and asked him to wire me $250,000! Well, he didn’t just immediately say yes; he actually had to look at a lot of things, speak with his team, and make a major decision. His numbers showed that we were not looking good financially, and he was concerned about the original million that I owed him. We spoke for about an hour, and he asked me to come up with a plan for how I was going to pay him back. In about an hour we developed a plan, which involved having to lay people off, reduce our media, and take a long, hard look at our expenses. We sent him the report, and after a little more discussion he agreed.

我给他打了电话，说明了情况，让他给我汇25万美元！他并没有立刻答应；他其实需要仔细考虑很多事情，和他的团队商量，并做出一个重要的决定。他的数据显示，我们的财务状况并不乐观，而且他很担心我之前欠他的那100万美元。我们谈了一个小时左右，他让我制定一个还款计划。我们又花了一个小时制定了一个方案，其中包括裁员、减少媒体投入，以及仔细审查我们的各项开支。我们把报告发给了他，经过一番讨论，他同意了。

Ultimately, what allowed Peter to do this was our strong relationship and my word. To this day, Peter is a financing partner on several of my television campaigns, and I consider him a good friend.

最终，彼得之所以能做到这一点，是因为我们之间牢固的关系以及我的信誉。时至今日，彼得仍然是我多个电视广告活动的融资伙伴，我视他为挚友。

Ask yourself: Is your word really your word ? How strong are your relationships? What makes your relationships stronger? Your word .

扪心自问：你的承诺真的有效吗？你的人际关系有多牢固？是什么让你的关系更牢固？你的承诺。

IS THAT HOW YOU WANT TO BE REMEMBERED?—REVISITED

这就是你想被人记住的方式吗？——重温

I was recently talking with a former eighth grade teacher about life. I told him that if it weren’t for some teachers giving me the opportunity to change my ways by giving me more responsibility , then I probably would have ended up dead, in jail, or addicted to drugs. He told me about an exercise that he had all of his eighth grade students do at the end of the school year: he had them write their own obituary. He said he started doing this in 1968 in inner-city Los Angeles. In 1968, we had the LA riots, the country was in complete turmoil over the Vietnam War, racial tensions were extremely high, and LA was just a scary place to live. So he figured this might help make the kids look forward to a better time in their lives. He didn’t give me any compelling, tear-jerking story, but he did tell me about one student who wrote in his obituary that he “was” the head football coach. Well, that kid actually became the head football coach and went on to become the principal of a neighboring high school.

最近我和一位以前教八年级的老师聊起了人生。我告诉他，如果不是有些老师给了我机会，让我承担更多责任，从而改变我的行为，我可能早就死了，进了监狱，或者染上了毒瘾。他跟我讲了一个他在学年结束时让所有八年级学生做的练习：写自己的讣告。他说他从1968年开始在洛杉矶的内城区做这件事。1968年，洛杉矶发生了骚乱，整个国家都因为越南战争而陷入动荡，种族关系极其紧张，洛杉矶当时是个令人恐惧的地方。所以他觉得这样做或许能让孩子们对未来充满希望。他没有给我讲什么感人肺腑、催人泪下的故事，但他确实跟我讲了一个学生在讣告里写道，他“曾经”是橄榄球队的主教练。后来，那个孩子竟然当上了橄榄球队主教练，之后又当上了邻近一所高中的校长。

What would your obituary look like right now ? What would people write about you? Have you ever read the obituary section and seen an entry that just states the person’s name and date of death? Why do you think that is? Who were these people? What did they do in life? What was their legacy? Wasn’t there more to say? Maybe there was not because they didn’t ask for more in their life.

如果你的讣告现在发布，会是什么样子？人们会怎么写你？你是否曾经在讣告栏目里看到过只有姓名和逝世日期的条目？你觉得这是为什么？这些人是谁？他们生前做过什么？他们留下了什么遗产？难道就没有更多值得讲述的内容吗？也许是因为他们生前没有奢求更多。

What will your obituary read when you ultimately pass? I didn’t realize this, but I have been asking myself that question a lot during my life, just not in those exact words. I constantly ask myself, “What will my legacy be?” But, I also ask myself, “What do I want it to be?” The good news is, right now you can control what your legacy will be and how your obituary will read.

当你最终离世时，你的讣告会怎么写？我以前从未意识到这一点，但其实我一生中一直在问自己这个问题，只是措辞不同而已。我经常问自己：“我的遗产会是什么？” 但我也常常问自己：“我希望它是什么？” 好消息是，现在你就可以掌控你的遗产是什么，以及你的讣告会如何写。

I don’t ask in this book that you do many activities. But do this: write your own obituary. It is very difficult to do and seems a bit morbid. But do it and see how you feel. Write it as of today. If you are not happy with what is on that piece of paper, then you can change it. You have time.

这本书里我没要求你做很多事。但请你做一件事：写一篇你自己的讣告。这很难，而且听起来有点病态。但请你写，看看你的感受。就从今天开始写。如果你对纸上的内容不满意，你可以修改。你还有时间。

#↩

CHAPTER 9

第九章

WHAT GOES AROUND STARTS WITH YOU: GIVE BACK!

善有善报，从你做起：回馈社会！

Most of the rich, famous, and super successful people I have known give back, whether through donations, setting up charitable foundations, or donating their actual time. But you don’t have to be rich and famous to give back; that’s just what good human beings do.

我认识的大多数富有、有名和超级成功人士都会回馈社会，无论是捐款、设立慈善基金会还是贡献自己的时间。但你不必富有或有名才能回馈社会；这只是善良的人应该做的。

When I was in high school we had a program that recognized students for things such as picking up trash at the high school to donating their time at the local food pantry. The program was called Beverly High Pride. When students did something, other students would nominate their peers for a Pride Pin. It was a real honor to get a Pride Pin. One cold winter day we were on a field trip in Boston, and we were having lunch at a pizza place. When we were all done eating we realized that we had enough pizza to feed at least a dozen more people. I came up with the idea to find some homeless people and give them this warm, fresh, and awesome pizza. We walked around and found a group of homeless men battling the cold, surrounding a barrel with a controlled fire in it, trying to stay warm. A group of us walked up to them and handed them a few large pizzas. I don’t remember what was said, but I will never forget the look in one of the men’s eyes, a look of absolute appreciation and thanks. It warmed my heart, and the feeling that I got is indescribable.

我上高中的时候，学校有个项目，表彰学生们的贡献，比如在校园里捡垃圾，或者在当地的食物救济站做义工。这个项目叫“贝弗利高中骄傲计划”。学生们做了好事，其他同学就会提名他们获得骄傲徽章。能拿到骄傲徽章真是莫大的荣幸。一个寒冷的冬日，我们去波士顿郊游，在一家披萨店吃午饭。吃完后，我们发现剩下的披萨足够至少十几个人吃。我灵机一动，想找些无家可归的人，把这些热乎乎、新鲜又美味的披萨送给他们。我们四处走走，发现一群无家可归的男人围着一个烧着火的桶取暖，抵御着严寒。我们几个走上前去，递给他们几个大披萨。我不记得当时说了什么，但我永远不会忘记其中一个男人眼中的神情，那是由衷的感激和谢意。它温暖了我的心，那种感觉难以言喻。

Zig Ziglar says you have not helped people until you help someone who cannot repay the favor. In high school I didn’t know who Zig Ziglar was, but he is right. Helping those in need without any sort of expectation of a return favor will change you and give you an appreciation for what you have. To end this story, I was nominated for a Pride Pin along with a few of my peers, and I was extremely proud, but that was secondary to the amazing feeling I had sharing with someone who couldn’t pay me back.

齐格·齐格勒说过，只有帮助了那些无法回报你的人，你才算真正帮助了别人。高中时我并不知道齐格·齐格勒是谁，但他说的没错。不求回报地帮助有需要的人，会改变你，让你更加珍惜自己所拥有的一切。故事的结尾，我和几个同学一起获得了骄傲徽章的提名，我为此感到无比自豪，但比起帮助那些无法回报我的人，那种感觉更加美妙。

That feeling may have been enhanced by the fact that more than a few times during my youth I was on the other side of the equation and knew what it felt like to have someone else care. You see, when my mother was diagnosed with HIV, it was devastating to me, and back then it was a death sentence. My mom never made a lot of money in her life but was always a hard worker, and she is just a gracious, generous person. When she realized that she had this disease, there were a few organizations that she reached out to, and they helped us with things such as rent, Christmas gifts, car payments, and other daily expenses. The name of the organization was called Aids Action North Shore. It is an amazing group of people who help sufferers cope with this disease.

或许是因为在我年轻的时候，我曾多次感同身受，体会过被人关爱的滋味，所以这种感受才更加强烈。你知道，当我母亲被确诊感染艾滋病毒时，我感到无比悲痛，因为在当时，这几乎等同于死刑判决。我母亲一生收入并不高，但她一直勤劳肯干，而且她心地善良、慷慨大方。当她意识到自己患病后，她联系了一些慈善机构，这些机构帮助我们支付房租、圣诞礼物、车贷以及其他日常开支。这些机构的名字叫“北岸艾滋病行动”（Aids Action North Shore）。这是一个了不起的团体，他们帮助艾滋病患者应对疾病带来的种种挑战。

But even as my mother was battling her own pain and suffering, she gave back in a way that cannot be valued or quantified, and it impacted me greatly. When I was in high school, no one knew about my mother’s diagnosis, but she asked how she could help Aids Action. Aids Action asked her to speak at high schools and tell her story. I never went to one of her speeches and she never spoke at my high school, due to the stigma it may have caused for me. One day my mother came home and told me how she spoke at Hamilton Wenham High School in a neighboring town. After her speech a young man came up to her, thanked her, and hugged her. Well, that young man also knew me and my friends very well. My mother was fearful that he would tell others about her status and somehow hurt me. He never did, but I decided that since my mother was okay with telling her story, educating people and giving back, that I was also okay with it.

即使我母亲在与病痛抗争的同时，她也以一种无法估量的方式回馈社会，这对我影响深远。我上高中时，没有人知道母亲的病情，但她主动询问如何才能帮助艾滋病行动组织。艾滋病行动组织邀请她到各个高中演讲，讲述她的故事。我从未去过她的演讲，她也从未到过我的学校演讲，因为担心这会给我带来歧视。有一天，母亲回家告诉我，她在邻镇的汉密尔顿·温汉姆高中演讲。演讲结束后，一位年轻男子走过来，向她道谢并拥抱了她。这位年轻男子也认识我和我的朋友们。母亲担心他会把她的病情告诉别人，从而伤害到我。他最终没有这样做，但我意识到，既然母亲愿意讲述她的故事，教育人们，回馈社会，我也应该如此。

Her story likely saved people’s lives. I know that a major part of her story was safe sex. My mom was not a drug addict but was infected by my stepfather. Absolutely devastating! But, through her speeches I am sure high school kids who were having sex protected themselves and potentially saved their own lives.

她的故事很可能拯救了许多人的生命。我知道她故事中很重要的一部分是安全性行为。我的母亲并非吸毒者，却被继父传染了。这真是令人痛心！但我相信，通过她的演讲，那些有性行为的高中生学会了保护自己，并有可能挽救了自己的生命。

Now giving back does not always have to pull at the heartstrings. Random acts of kindness are also a great way to give back. Last year I was lost just outside of Orlando, and I kept looping around and going through the same tollbooth. Well, I finally ran out of quarters at the tollbooth. In Orlando many of these tollbooths are unmanned. I didn’t know what to do when I looked back and realized there was a car behind me. I decided to get out of my car and ask a random man behind me for a dollar. Orlando, like many major cities, has some major crime, and Florida has many citizens who carry firearms. But I only had two options: blow through the booth or ask for help. The man in a beat-up old Honda Accord handed me four quarters without thinking. Now this is only one dollar , but I was so grateful. I’m not sure if he had the same feeling, but it made me feel great that I was able to ask a fellow human being for help.

回馈社会并不总是需要煽情。随机的善举也是一种很好的回馈方式。去年我在奥兰多郊外迷路了，一直在同一个收费站兜圈子。最后，我的硬币用完了。奥兰多的很多收费站都是无人值守的。我回头一看，发现后面有一辆车，不知所措。于是我决定下车，向后面一位素不相识的男士要一块钱。奥兰多和许多大城市一样，犯罪率很高，而且佛罗里达州有很多居民携带枪支。但我只有两个选择：要么直接通过收费站，要么寻求帮助。那位开着破旧本田雅阁的男士想都没想就给了我四个25美分硬币。虽然只有一块钱，但我非常感激。我不知道他是否也有同样的感觉，但能够向一位好心人求助，让我感到非常欣慰。

GOING TO THE AMUSEMENT PARK

去游乐园

When I was a kid, my dad’s employer used to have a family day at a local amusement park. They would pay for the day, food, and rides. I remember being so excited. A young, poor kid doesn’t get to go to amusement parks all that often. It was such a treat. A few years later there was a local youth center in my town who used to have counselors go to the local neighborhoods and talk to kids like me; they used to sponsor events that took kids to the same amusement park my dad’s work brought me to. I was fortunate enough to be able to go to the park with the youth center and some of my neighborhood friends, and again, it was such a fun time. We were able to get out of the neighborhood for a day and just enjoy the innocence of being a kid.

小时候，我爸爸的公司经常组织员工去当地游乐园玩，他们包吃包住，还包游乐设施。我记得当时特别兴奋。像我这样家境贫寒的孩子，平时很少有机会去游乐园，所以那次简直是莫大的享受。几年后，我们镇上开了一家青少年中心，他们会派辅导员到社区里给像我一样的孩子们做心理辅导；他们还会组织一些活动，带孩子们去我爸爸公司带我去的那个游乐园。我很幸运，能和青少年中心以及一些邻居小伙伴一起去游乐园，那又是一段非常快乐的时光。我们终于可以暂时离开家，好好享受一下童年的纯真。

Recently, as a part of my community outreach program for Blue Vase, we organized a trip to the exact same park for more than thirty underprivileged kids plus a parent. We are paying for transportation on a nice bus, food for the day, all-access passes to the rides, plus ten dollars a kid. Why am I doing this? The times that I was fortunate enough to be able to get out of my neighborhood and just be a kid helped change my life. If I can do the same for those kids, then my legacy will go beyond what I could possibly imagine. I may never know if this fun day helps change these kids’ lives, but it makes me feel that I am contributing to the greater good of humanity. I do this because someone did it for me. People always talk about the concept of karma and how your actions, good or bad, come back to you some way. It is a fact and relates to what I previously touched upon: your inner spirit. When you do good things, your inner spirit will be happy and your outer world will also be good to you. Karma is a real thing, and most people don’t think about its power, but what you do today will affect you tomorrow.

最近，作为我为“蓝花瓶”（Blue Vase）开展的社区服务项目的一部分，我们组织了一次去同一个公园的旅行，邀请了三十多名贫困儿童和他们的家长。我们支付了舒适的巴士交通费、当天的伙食费、所有游乐设施的通票，外加每个孩子十美元。我为什么要这样做呢？因为我小时候有幸能离开家，像个孩子一样自由自在地玩耍，这些经历改变了我的人生。如果我也能为这些孩子做同样的事情，那么我所留下的遗产将远远超出我的想象。我或许永远无法确定这充满乐趣的一天是否真的能改变这些孩子的人生，但它让我感到自己正在为人类的福祉贡献一份力量。我这样做，是因为曾经有人这样帮助过我。人们总是谈论因果报应，说你的行为，无论是善行还是恶行，都会以某种方式回到你身上。这是事实，也与我之前提到的——你的内心世界——息息相关。当你行善时，你的内心会感到快乐，你的外在世界也会善待你。因果报应是真实存在的，大多数人并没有意识到它的力量，但你今天所做的事情会影响你的明天。

ARCADE OR CASINO?

街机厅还是赌场？

Giving back doesn’t necessarily involve a charitable event. Give back to your friends or family. Giving back doesn’t necessarily involve money, either. If you can help someone with a challenging situation, then you should. I’m a lawyer, so most friends and family think I know everything about the law. That is not the case for any lawyer. However, when a legal challenge arrives and I am asked to help, I help as best as I can.

回馈社会并不一定意味着参与慈善活动。你可以善待你的朋友或家人。回馈社会也不一定需要金钱。如果你能帮助身处困境的人，就应该伸出援手。我是一名律师，所以大多数朋友和家人都认为我精通法律。但事实上，任何律师都不可能无所不知。然而，当遇到法律难题需要我帮忙时，我会尽我所能提供帮助。

About seven years ago a very good friend of mine opened up an arcade. But the arcade was very unique: his arcade had machines that looked like slot machines and video poker. But, they were not machines that paid out cash. Their system was exactly what Chuck E. Cheese’s does: you play a game, win tickets, and redeem them for a prize. About a year after he opened with all of the proper approvals and licenses, he was shut down by the town. There were accusations that he was running an illegal casino, but we all knew he wasn’t. He came to me and asked me to help. I knew nothing about gaming law, but I knew I could find someone who did. After several hours of research and reaching out to my network of lawyer friends, I found a few experts in the field who were able to successfully argue to the town and the commonwealth that what my friend was doing was legal and was not a casino. As a result he was able to open back up. That was seven years ago. As I type today, the laws have changed and my friend opened a second arcade, but about a week ago both places were raided and shut down by the attorney general, and it is now a criminal matter. I am not a criminal lawyer, but I have begun to help mount his defense. Giving back to friends, family, and even strangers is what makes the world go round. If you can help, then you should. It’s that simple.

大约七年前，我的一位挚友开了一家游戏厅。这家游戏厅非常特别：里面的机器看起来像老虎机和视频扑克，但实际上并不吐现金。他们的系统和Chuck E. Cheese's（一家连锁快餐店）的模式一模一样：玩家玩游戏赢取奖券，然后用奖券兑换奖品。开业大约一年后，尽管所有审批和执照都齐全，游戏厅还是被镇政府勒令停业。有人指控他经营非法赌场，但我们都知道他并非如此。他来找我帮忙。我对博彩法一窍不通，但我知道我可以找到懂行的人。经过几个小时的研究，并联系了我认识的律师朋友，我找到了几位这方面的专家，他们成功地向镇政府和州政府证明，我朋友的经营是合法的，并非赌场。最终，他得以重新开业。那是七年前的事了。就在我敲下这些文字的时候，法律已经修改，我的朋友开了第二家游戏厅。但大约一周前，两家店都被司法部长查封，现在这已经上升到了刑事诉讼的层面。我不是刑事律师，但我已经开始帮他准备辩护。帮助朋友、家人，甚至陌生人，这才是世界运转的动力。如果你能帮上忙，那就应该伸出援手。就这么简单。

A LITTLE GIRL GOES TO CAMP

一个小女孩去露营

When I was a kid, my mother found a way to get me to go to camp during the summer. Sometimes it was a week, other times it was a whole month. The camp was sponsored by the YMCA and was one of the best things for me. Every morning I was picked up by a bus and went to the YMCA campus to spend all day doing things like playing sports, swimming, arts and crafts, going on adventure walks, and playing with other kids. When I think about this time, I am very grateful for what my mother was able to accomplish, and it was truly a wonderful experience. I was able to get out of the neighborhood, see new things, meet new people, and be a kid.

小时候，妈妈总能想方设法让我暑假去参加夏令营。有时是一周，有时是一整个月。夏令营是由基督教青年会（YMCA）主办的，对我来说是一段美好的回忆。每天早上，我都会坐巴士去YMCA的营地，在那里度过一整天，参加各种活动，比如运动、游泳、做手工、探险远足，以及和其他小朋友一起玩耍。每当我想起那段时光，我都无比感激妈妈的安排，那真是一段难忘的经历。我得以走出家门，看看新鲜事物，结识新朋友，真正地做回一个孩子。

When I graduated from high school, I went to Springfield College in Springfield, Massachusetts, the birthplace of American basketball and also a school that was founded on the principles of Spirit, Mind, and Body. One of the college’s main missions was to help promote churches and the YMCA. I didn’t pick Springfield for this reason, but it seems that the YMCA and I have been connected since my childhood.

高中毕业后，我去了位于马萨诸塞州斯普林菲尔德的斯普林菲尔德学院。斯普林菲尔德是美国篮球的发源地，也是一所秉持“精神、思想和身体”理念的学校。学院的主要使命之一是帮助推广教会和基督教青年会（YMCA）。我选择斯普林菲尔德并非出于这个原因，但似乎从我童年起，我就与基督教青年会结下了不解之缘。

Since I was so fond of my time at the YMCA summer camp, I wanted to give less-fortunate kids the ability to go to have similar experiences. It seemed like a nice thing to do, but it became a difficult task due to the red tape of the YMCA. I had my human resources manager reach out to the YMCA to tell them that we wanted to send a few kids to camp for the summer. But again, due to the red tape, it couldn’t be done. We were told to just make a donation, but I wanted to do more. I wanted to make sure an underprivileged child was going to be able to go to camp with our donation. Not just a general cash donation, but one with a purpose and that was dear to my heart. Well, you should know by now that I don’t accept “it can’t be done” for an answer.

因为我非常怀念在基督教青年会夏令营的时光，所以我希望那些家境不好的孩子也能有机会体验类似的经历。这看似是一件好事，但由于基督教青年会繁琐的手续，却成了一件难事。我让我的人力资源经理联系基督教青年会，告诉他们我们想送几个孩子去参加夏令营。但同样，由于繁文缛节，这件事还是没能实现。他们让我们捐款，但我想要做得更多。我希望确保我们的捐款能够真正帮助到有需要的孩子去参加夏令营。不仅仅是普通的现金捐赠，而是真正有意义的捐款，这对我来说意义非凡。你应该知道，我从不接受“做不到”这样的答案。

Early in the summer of 2011, I went for a walk outside my office, which also happens to be located behind my old neighborhood. I went for this walk so that I could walk through my old neighborhood to find some kids in need and offer to send them to camp. Now, I must say this seems a little odd—a big guy in shorts and a T-shirt, perspiring a bit, walking through my old neighborhood, looking to send kids to camp.

2011年初夏，我出门散步，我的办公室就在我以前住的街区后面。我散步的目的是想穿过我以前住的街区，看看能不能找到一些需要帮助的孩子，并邀请他们去参加夏令营。现在想想，这场景确实有点奇怪——一个身材魁梧的男人，穿着短裤和T恤，微微出汗，在我以前住的街区里走来走去，想找人送孩子去夏令营。

The actual house that I grew up in had a little girl the same age as my daughter playing out front by herself. She was a cute little girl, and I thought she would be a perfect candidate. So I stood on the corner waiting for her mom to come out so I could approach her and tell her what I wanted to do. It seemed like an eternity standing there, and I felt a little uneasy. Finally, her mother, Maria, did come out, and I approached her and told her what I wanted to do. Of course she was a little guarded and skeptical, but we talked at length and I asked her to meet me in my office the upcoming Monday. Maria arrived at my office on that Monday, and she was a little taken aback. I remember she said, “You are real,” and I didn’t really understand what she meant. She went on to say that the situation in which I approached her on a Saturday afternoon—randomly, in shorts, unshaven, and perspiring a bit—just didn’t seem real. I have to admit she had every right to be skeptical.

我小时候住的那栋房子前，有个和我女儿同龄的小女孩独自在外面玩耍。她很可爱，我觉得她很适合做我的模特。于是我站在街角，等着她妈妈出来，好跟她妈妈说说我的想法。站在那里感觉时间过得特别慢，我有点忐忑不安。最后，她妈妈玛丽亚出来了，我走上前去，告诉她我的想法。她当然有点戒备和怀疑，但我们聊了很久，我约她下周一到我办公室见面。玛丽亚周一如约来到我的办公室，她有点吃惊。我记得她说：“你是真的。”我当时不太明白她的意思。她接着说，我周六下午穿着短裤，胡子拉碴，还有些出汗，突然出现在她面前，这场景实在太不真实了。我得承认，她有理由怀疑。

After cutting through the red tape at the YMCA, we were able to send her daughter to camp for the summer. When I think about this, it warms my heart. Maria and her daughter were very grateful and appreciative of my generosity. But, I was more appreciative to be able to give back to a young child what was given to me as a kid. Those summers when my mother was able to get a grant or come up with the money to send me to camp had a lasting impression on my life. I wanted to and will continue to give back as so many others gave to me.

在克服了基督教青年会的重重阻碍后，我们终于能够送她的女儿去参加夏令营了。每当想起这件事，我都感到无比温暖。玛丽亚和她的女儿对我的慷慨解囊感激不尽。但对我来说，更让我感到欣慰的是，我能够将我小时候得到的帮助回馈给一个年幼的孩子。那些年夏天，我的母亲设法申请到助学金或筹集资金送我去参加夏令营，这段经历深深地影响了我的一生。我一直想，也将会继续回馈社会，就像许多人曾经帮助过我一样。

By the way, Maria was unemployed when I spoke with her. She was intelligent, had worked for the airlines for several years, and had fallen on hard times. I asked her to send me her résumé, and told her I might have a position for her. Even though I am a generous person and believe in the power of giving back, I will not give people jobs solely for the purpose of employing them. However, Maria had skills that were an asset to my company. She now works for Blue Vase Marketing in our quality control department and has added tremendous value to that department.

顺便一提，我跟玛丽亚谈话时，她正处于失业状态。她很聪明，曾在航空公司工作多年，只是最近遇到了些困难。我请她把简历发给我，并告诉她我可能有个职位适合她。虽然我为人慷慨，也相信回馈社会的力量，但我不会仅仅为了雇佣别人而给他们工作。不过，玛丽亚的技能对我们公司来说确实很有价值。她现在在我们蓝花瓶营销公司的质检部门工作，为该部门做出了巨大的贡献。

Think about what really happened in the above story. I wanted to give something back with no intention of getting something in return, other than the warm feeling and pride of being able to help others in need. What really happened? My generosity instantly gave me back something of value. I now have a very professional, very caring, and hardworking employee who continues to add value to my company.

想想上面这个故事的真正含义。我当时只是想回馈社会，并不求任何回报，除了帮助他人带来的温暖和自豪感。结果如何呢？我的慷慨立刻给了我宝贵的回报。我现在拥有了一位非常专业、非常关心他人、非常勤奋的员工，他持续为我的公司创造价值。

Benevolent intentions are not benevolent if you are hoping for something in return, but if your heart is in the right place, it always comes back one way or another.

如果你希望得到回报，那么你的善意就不是善意了；但如果你心地善良，总会以某种方式得到回报。

STAND UP FOR A FRIEND

为朋友挺身而出

One night after one of my comedy routines I was talking with a couple of local comedians who were actually from the same town I am from. We got to discussing sports and then football. One of the comedians, Jeff Koen (star of the movie Heavy Times ), and I both played linebacker together. The other comedian, Dave Rattigan, is a writer for a few Boston newspapers, host of a sports talk radio show, and has been on Sirius XM a lot. One of us mentioned a friend who also played linebacker, Eric Shairs. Eric was paralyzed in a tragic pool accident about ten years ago. He dove into the pool, hit his head, and then climbed out of the pool, but that movement severed his spinal column, and he is now a quadriplegic. He has two girls and tragically, this accident actually happened in front of them. Eric is a great guy, and he was a physical specimen and an unbelievable athlete as well. So Dave, Jeff, and myself came up with the idea of doing a comedy night to help raise some funds for Eric. His expenses are extraordinary and insurance doesn’t cover a lot of them. So, I spear-headed the organization of this event and we had an amazing night. Dave, Jeff, myself, and two other comedians, Chris Dimitrakopoulos (Chris D) and Juston McKinney ( The Tonight Show , Comedy Central), all killed it and essentially donated our services. We raised a lot of money, but most important, everyone laughed. Eric had an amazing time. Now, Eric and I were not super close when we played together. But we did this event because Eric is a great guy, because Jeff, Dave, and I all live in the same town as Eric, and because it was just the right and fun thing to do.

一天晚上，我表演完一段喜剧后，和几个本地的喜剧演员聊天，他们和我来自同一个小镇。我们聊起了体育，然后又聊到了橄榄球。其中一位喜剧演员杰夫·科恩（电影《重磅时刻》的主演）和我以前都打过橄榄球线卫。另一位喜剧演员戴夫·拉蒂根是波士顿几家报纸的撰稿人，主持一档体育脱口秀广播节目，而且经常上Sirius XM电台。我们其中一人提到了一位也打过线卫的朋友，埃里克·谢尔斯。大约十年前，埃里克在一场不幸的泳池事故中瘫痪了。他跳进泳池，头部撞到了池底，然后爬出了泳池，但这个动作导致他的脊柱断裂，现在他四肢瘫痪。他有两个女儿，不幸的是，这场事故就发生在她们面前。埃里克是个很棒的人，他曾经体格健壮，也是一位令人难以置信的运动员。所以，我和戴夫、杰夫一起想出了举办一场喜剧之夜的主意，希望能帮埃里克筹集一些资金。他的开销非常巨大，而且保险还不包括很多。于是，我牵头组织了这场活动，我们度过了一个非常棒的夜晚。戴夫、杰夫、我，还有另外两位喜剧演员——克里斯·迪米特拉科波洛斯（Chris D）和贾斯顿·麦金尼（曾出演《今夜秀》和喜剧中心频道）——都表现出色，而且基本上是义务演出。我们筹集了很多钱，但最重要的是，每个人都开怀大笑。埃里克玩得非常开心。其实，我和埃里克以前一起演出的时候关系并不算特别亲密。但我们举办这场活动，是因为埃里克是个很棒的人，因为杰夫、戴夫和我都和埃里克住在同一个城市，而且因为这确实是一件既合适又有趣的事情。

By the way, Eric is also truly an inspiration. He went from being an amazing athlete to being confined to a chair, and likely could be that way for the rest of his life (though I hope modern science will prove us wrong). He has limited mobility of his arms and hands, and as a result he was able to have his car retrofitted so he can actually drive with his hands! Yet Eric went on to get his master’s and works at a local college, helping students pick their classes and keeping them on the right track. He is a very positive person who wakes up every day, takes his daughters to their softball games, goes to the beach, goes to physical therapy, and tries to live a normal life. He also believes that someday he will walk again. I believe that with modern science and a little help from friends, family, and even strangers, that goal will be accomplished.

顺便说一句，埃里克也真是个鼓舞人心的人。他曾经是一位杰出的运动员，如今却只能坐在轮椅上，而且很可能终生如此（但我希望现代科学能证明我们错了）。他的手臂和手部活动受限，因此他改装了自己的汽车，这样他就可以用手开车了！然而，埃里克仍然坚持攻读硕士学位，并在当地一所大学工作，帮助学生选课，确保他们走上正确的学习道路。他是一个非常乐观的人，每天起床后，都会带女儿们去看垒球比赛，去海滩，去做理疗，努力过上正常的生活。他也相信自己有一天能再次行走。我相信，凭借现代科学，再加上朋友、家人甚至陌生人的帮助，这个目标一定能够实现。

If you would like to help Eric achieve his goal, you could send a check to The Eric Shairs Recovery Fund, 100 Cummings Center, Suite 354B, Beverly, MA 01915.

如果您想帮助埃里克实现他的目标，您可以向埃里克·谢尔斯康复基金寄送支票，地址为：100 Cummings Center, Suite 354B, Beverly, MA 01915。

BOOTSTRAPPING

自助创业

As I mention in the advertisement for my book, and earlier in the book itself, I grew up poor. I was the beneficiary of many government and nongovernment programs on the local, state, and federal levels. One in particular is a small charitable organization called Beverly Bootstraps. This is a very unique charitable organization that offers a wide variety of services for people in need. But when I was a kid, my mother used to go to them to get things like food and even help with the rent, utilities, and other necessities. Since my company is based in Beverly, Massachusetts, where I grew up, I felt compelled to give back to the local community, the one that had the most impact on my life. I didn’t do this out of feelings of guilt, but as a part of my duty as a human being and a citizen of this country.

正如我在书的广告和书的前文中提到的，我出身贫寒。我曾受益于地方、州和联邦政府的许多项目，包括一些非政府项目。其中一个特别值得一提的是名为“贝弗利自力更生”（Beverly Bootstraps）的小型慈善组织。这是一个非常独特的慈善组织，为有需要的人提供各种各样的服务。在我小时候，我的母亲经常去那里领取食物，甚至还能得到房租、水电费和其他生活必需品的帮助。由于我的公司总部设在我长大的马萨诸塞州贝弗利市，我感到有义务回馈当地社区，因为那里对我的生活影响最大。我这样做并非出于愧疚，而是出于作为一个人、一个公民应尽的责任。

Since I have opened my doors, we have done some pretty remarkable things that I am proud of. We held a diaper drive that provided families with things like diapers, sanitary napkins, soap, and other things most people take for granted. We held an Easter basket drive for local families so that their children could enjoy the fun part of the Easter holiday. Imagine what that little kid felt like when he or she came downstairs and the Easter Bunny came. That has to warm your heart. We also have done the traditional Toys for Tots programs and food drives. One year, we actually sponsored individual families and took care of their entire Christmas celebrations!

自从我开门营业以来，我们做了很多令我引以为豪的了。我们举办了尿布捐赠活动，为有需要的家庭提供了尿布、卫生巾、肥皂以及其他一些人们习以为常的必需品。我们还为当地家庭举办了复活节彩蛋篮捐赠活动，让他们的孩子们也能享受复活节的乐趣。想象一下，当孩子们下楼看到复活节兔子出现时，他们该是多么开心！这一定让人感到无比温暖。我们也参与了传统的“玩具总动员”活动和食品捐赠活动。有一年，我们甚至资助了一些家庭，为他们安排了整个圣诞节庆祝活动！

You won’t meet a truly successful person who doesn’t give back in one way or another. Giving back is, in my opinion, your inherent social responsibility. Some may claim that there are many people milking the system, and that may be true, but there are many individuals who are not; they are simply hardworking people trying to get by. Pick a charitable organization that is dear to your heart, and get active: check out a local animal shelter or the United Way. It doesn’t matter, as you will get so much in return. But you will also appreciate what you have. I am not a socialist and don’t believe in coddling people, but I do believe that we, as a human race, since the beginning of time have helped each other get to where we are today. Everyone needs a little help sometimes—even me !

你不会遇到一个真正成功的人不以某种方式回馈社会。在我看来，回馈社会是你与生俱来的社会责任。有些人可能会说，很多人都在钻制度的空子，这或许没错，但也有很多人并非如此；他们只是努力工作，勉强维持生计。选择一个你真心喜欢的慈善机构，积极参与其中：去当地的动物收容所或联合劝募协会看看。无论你选择哪个机构，你都会从中受益匪浅。同时，你也会更加珍惜你所拥有的一切。我不是社会主义者，也不赞成娇惯他人，但我相信，自古以来，我们人类就一直在互相帮助，才有了今天的成就。每个人都需要帮助——即使是我！

Giving back doesn’t need to have a charitable aspect to it. Give back to your friends, your family, and your community. What I mean is, help people out when you can. If someone needs help in moving, if someone is having trouble with a car, or whatever it is, help out. I am a very busy person, but I am always available to help my friends, neighbors, relatives, or business associates. Someday, sometime, you will need help, and people remember what you did for them. By helping someone now, you are essentially asking them to help you later, without actually asking.

回馈社会并不一定非得是慈善性质的。你可以回馈你的朋友、家人和社区。我的意思是，尽你所能帮助别人。如果有人需要搬家帮忙，如果有人遇到汽车故障，或者其他任何需要帮助的事情，都伸出援手。我本人非常忙碌，但我随时乐意帮助我的朋友、邻居、亲戚或商业伙伴。总有一天，你也会需要帮助，而人们会记住你曾经为他们做过的事。你现在帮助别人，实际上就是在默默地请求他们将来帮助你。

This is not the end of Ask More, Get More . The next section has additional powerful techniques, secrets, and strategies that will get you more out of life. So, get ready—because people asked me for more.

这并非《多问，多得》的结尾。下一节将介绍更多强大的技巧、秘诀和策略，助你拥有更精彩的人生。所以，准备好吧——因为大家都希望我分享更多。

#↩

BONUS

奖金

SOME MORE WAYS TO ASK FOR MORE: SAVINGS SECRETS!

更多省钱妙招：省钱秘诀！

VACATION FOR FREE?

免费度假？

Yes, it is possible and can be accomplished many ways. I have a little girl who has been fortunate enough to visit Disney World a couple of times. The last time we went for two weeks, the first week was free ! That’s right— free ! How is this possible? Well, I have a credit card where I earn points, known as Disney Points, that I can use toward any hotel on the Disney World properties. I also have traveled all over the United States, from Miami to Santa Monica, for free !

是的，这完全可行，而且有很多方法可以实现。我有个小女儿，她很幸运地去过几次迪士尼世界。上次我们去了两周，第一周竟然是免费的！没错——免费！这是怎么做到的呢？其实，我有一张可以赚取积分的信用卡，这些积分叫做迪士尼积分，可以用来兑换迪士尼世界旗下任何一家酒店。我还用这些积分免费游遍了美国各地，从迈阿密到圣莫尼卡！

Earlier we discussed credit cards and how to use them properly. One of the things that I recommend is using credit cards that give cash back and allow you to earn points. American Express allows you to earn points which you can basically use for anything you want. They offer a $200 credit each year that can be used on JetBlue, though you have to make sure that you actually use it. A friend of mine traveled to China and back first class by using his AMEX points. That is equivalent to a $17,000 plane ticket. Find a credit card that offers cash back, points, or other incentives that allow you to use them for whatever you want. Debit cards also have incentives, depending on the bank. You can go to my website at www.AskMore-GetMore.com for a list of credit cards that offer all types of incentives.

我们之前讨论过信用卡以及如何正确使用。我推荐的一点是使用能返现和赚取积分的信用卡。美国运通卡可以让你赚取积分，这些积分几乎可以用于任何你想做的事情。他们每年提供200美元的捷蓝航空（JetBlue）机票抵扣额度，但你必须确保自己真的用掉了。我的一个朋友用他的美国运通积分兑换了往返中国的头等舱机票，这相当于一张价值17000美元的机票。找一张能提供返现、积分或其他奖励的信用卡，这样你就可以随心所欲地使用它们了。借记卡也有奖励，具体取决于银行。你可以访问我的网站www.AskMore-GetMore.com，查看提供各种奖励的信用卡列表。

Many of us have heard the term “frequent flyer miles.” I have friends who have enough frequent flyer miles to travel almost every day for ten years and not run out. Many times if you travel for work, you can personally accumulate the frequent flyer miles and use them for your family vacation. The best way to do this is to pick a particular airline, and if possible, only use that airline when you travel. There are alliances among airlines. For instance, the Star Alliance is Continental, United, US Airways, Air Canada, Lufthansa, and several other airlines; traveling on any of these airlines will allow you to aggregate frequent flyer miles.

我们很多人都听说过“飞行常客里程”这个词。我有些朋友的飞行常客里程多到可以连续十年几乎每天都飞，都不会用完。很多时候，如果你出差旅行，可以积累飞行常客里程，然后用于家庭度假。最好的方法是选择一家特定的航空公司，并且尽可能只乘坐这家航空公司的航班。航空公司之间有很多联盟。例如，星空联盟的成员包括美国大陆航空、美国联合航空、全美航空、加拿大航空、汉莎航空以及其他几家航空公司；乘坐这些航空公司的航班都可以累积飞行常客里程。

TIP: Points.com is a cool website that allows you to trade different types of points with others to get what you are looking for: bartering at its best.

提示：Points.com 是一个很棒的网站，它允许你与其他用户交换不同类型的积分，以获得你想要的东西：物物交换的最佳方式。

SPEND A DAY GETTING PITCHED AND TRAVEL FOR FREE!

花一天时间接受推介，还能免费旅行！

I first learned of this technique when I was a young child, and I was able to go to Disney World with my mom. I wondered how we were able to travel with hardly any money. Now my mom did essentially spend her tax refund money on the trip, but a large portion of the trip was taken care of by a company that lured us down to Florida to pitch us time-shares. That was pretty funny, since we could barely buy milk, but we were showed several properties that were available for a time-share or purchase. I remember being bored, but it paid for a good portion of my Disney adventure. We had our hotel and even passes to Disney World paid for just by spending a couple of hours looking at things we couldn’t afford. These types of programs are offered every day, all over the country. Some are better than others, but they are a great way to travel for free ! On my website I list many companies that offer free vacations just to convince people to hear what they have to say.

我小时候第一次听说这种方法，当时我和妈妈去了迪士尼乐园。我很好奇我们是怎么做到几乎没钱就去旅行的。虽然我妈妈基本上是用退税款支付了这次旅行，但很大一部分费用是由一家公司承担的，这家公司把我们引诱到佛罗里达，向我们推销分时度假。这挺搞笑的，因为我们当时连牛奶都买不起，但他们却带我们看了好几处可以购买或分时度假的房产。我记得当时很无聊，但这笔费用却支付了我迪士尼之旅的大部分费用。我们只花了几个小时看了看那些我们根本买不起的东西，就得到了酒店住宿甚至迪士尼乐园的门票。这类项目每天都在全国各地提供。有些项目比其他的好，但它们确实是免费旅行的好方法！我的网站上列出了许多提供免费度假的公司，就是为了让大家听听他们的说法。

START A BUSINESS AND TRAVEL AROUND THE WORLD FOR FREE !

创业，免费环游世界！

I know people who have started and own travel agencies for the sole purpose of traveling for free. When you own a travel agency, you will find that hotels and resorts want you to come to their property so that you can recommend them to your prospective clients. Some of the people I know travel to five-star hotels where they are catered to hand and foot for weeks on end, and the entire trip, including airfare, is paid for! Some of these resorts will also pay for the family to come along with the agent. This is a great technique and easy to use.

我认识一些人，他们创办旅行社的唯一目的就是免费旅行。当你拥有一家旅行社后，你会发现酒店和度假村都希望你去他们的酒店或度假村，以便你向潜在客户推荐他们。我认识的一些人甚至会去五星级酒店，享受长达数周的无微不至的照顾，而且包括机票在内的所有费用都由酒店承担！有些度假村还会支付旅行社代理的家人同行的费用。这真是一个绝妙的技巧，而且操作简单。

There are also several home-based businesses that tap into the multitrillion-dollar travel industry, thus creating travel agents that make money based on a multilevel marketing plan. Many of them have created and continue to create millionaires. Multilevel marketing companies get a bad reputation for many reasons, but companies like Amway, Herbalife, Shaklee, Melaleuca, and YTB Travel are multimillion-dollar, multinational companies that do give people financial freedom. On my website I list several home-based businesses that tap into the travel industry, and you can decide for yourself.

还有一些居家创业项目利用价值数万亿美元的旅游业，通过多层次营销模式，让旅行社从中获利。其中许多项目已经并将继续造就百万富翁。多层次营销公司由于种种原因名声不佳，但像安利、康宝莱、嘉康利、美乐家和YTB Travel这样的公司，都是价值数百万美元的跨国企业，确实能帮助人们实现财务自由。我的网站上列出了一些利用旅游业的居家创业项目，您可以自行选择。

Also, if you have a business and you need to travel for your business, you can write off essentially every expense that is related to your business. If you need to go to France, China, or South Africa for your business you are entitled to write these expenses off. Let’s face it; you don’t spend every waking hour working when you travel. I call these working vacations and they are great. You can accomplish your business goals and objectives, but you can also vacation.

此外，如果您经营企业并且需要出差，几乎所有与业务相关的费用都可以抵税。如果您需要去法国、中国或南非出差，这些费用都可以抵税。说实话，出差的时候您不可能每时每刻都在工作。我把这种旅行称为“工作假期”，它非常棒。您既可以完成业务目标，又可以享受假期。

BECOME A MYSTERY SHOPPER

成为神秘顾客

I have a friend whose dad has not paid to go out to eat in over three years. He is retired, so to keep busy he works as a mystery shopper. He is even a mystery shopper for local restaurants that serve items like pizza and Chinese food. He does simple things like take a picture of the food when it arrives at his house and details whether the driver was on time and courteous. He must also note if he was offered specials and checks to make sure they delivered the order correctly, among other things. These are all things that you do anyway—so why not get paid to do it, and eat for free ?

我有个朋友，他爸爸三年多没花钱出去吃过饭了。他退休了，为了打发时间，就去做神秘顾客。他甚至还给一些本地餐馆做神秘顾客，比如披萨店和中餐馆。他做的都是些简单的事，比如外卖送到家时拍张照片，记录送餐员是否准时、服务是否周到。他还得记下有没有特价菜，以及账单是否正确送达等等。这些都是你平时就会做的事——为什么不一边做一边赚钱，还能免费吃饭呢？

There are organizations that serve the travel and hospitality industry by providing mystery shoppers to give evaluations of the industry. So, you could travel for free and enjoy the nicest hotels, spas, and cruises in the world just by becoming a mystery shopper.

有些机构为旅游和酒店行业提供神秘顾客服务，由神秘顾客对行业进行评估。因此，你只需成为一名神秘顾客，就有机会免费旅行，享受世界上最棒的酒店、水疗中心和邮轮体验。

There are companies that will hire you as a consultant to go to a really nice hotel—let’s say the Ritz Carlton in Miami. You go for free , stay for free , go to the spa, eat at their restaurants, order room service, and everything in between, and you get paid for it! This is real! On my website I have links to companies such as the Coyle Hospitality Group, which has been providing mystery shoppers for the hospitality industry since 1966, and you could be one of their next shoppers!

有些公司会聘请你做顾问，去体验一些非常高级的酒店——比如迈阿密的丽思卡尔顿酒店。你可以免费入住，享受水疗、餐厅用餐、客房送餐服务等等，所有服务都包含在内，而且你还能拿到报酬！这是真的！我的网站上有Coyle Hospitality Group等公司的链接，这家公司自1966年以来就一直为酒店业提供神秘顾客服务，你可能就是他们的下一位神秘顾客！

HOUSE SWAP

房屋交换

This is one of my favorites. You can go stay at homes all over the world for free ! All you have to do is give up your home for the same amount of time. This is a great way to see different parts of the world without having to pay for your stay. A friend of mine does this all the time by following this process: He accumulates frequent flyer mile points so that he can fly anywhere in the continental United States for free and makes sure he has enough miles for his wife and two kids. He then swaps his home with families from all over the country. When this happens, he usually gets to use that family’s car, their Internet, and their phone—he is literally trading spaces with another family for a certain period of time. There are a bunch of online agencies that allow you to swap houses with other families in exchange for a small fee, or you can go on Craigslist and do it for free on your own. I have a list of many of these agencies on AskMore-GetMore.com .

这是我最喜欢的方法之一。你可以免费入住世界各地的家庭！你只需要把自己的房子让给对方同样长的时间。这是个不用花钱就能游览世界各地的绝佳方式。我有个朋友经常这么做，他的方法是这样的：他积累飞行常客里程，这样他就可以在美国本土免费飞行，并且确保自己有足够的里程供妻子和两个孩子使用。然后，他把自己的房子和来自全国各地的家庭交换。这样一来，他通常可以使用对方家庭的汽车、网络和电话——他实际上是在一段时间内和另一个家庭交换空间。有很多在线机构可以让你以支付少量费用的方式与其他家庭交换房屋，或者你也可以自己去Craigslist网站免费寻找房源。我在AskMore-GetMore.com网站上列出了很多这样的机构。

GET GROCERIES FOR FREE !

免费领取食品杂货！

Getting groceries for free is simple, and anyone can do this—you don’t need a computer, a credit card, or anything else. All you need is a little bit of time and persistence. The term “couponing,” or “extreme couponing,” has become popular due to certain reality shows, which feature soccer moms who seem to get high by saving money and getting their groceries for free . I can’t blame them. The average household spends between $140 and $280 a week on groceries. On the high end, that is a savings of $15,000 a year! Now, take that $15k and put it in the stock market, and guess what that turns into in fifty years? $4,335,032.85—that is the power of compound interest. Four million, three hundred thousand dollars! I have a compound interest calculator on my website, AskMore-GetMore.com , so you can play with the numbers.

免费获取食品杂货很简单，任何人都能做到——你不需要电脑、信用卡或其他任何东西。你只需要一点时间和毅力。“优惠券”或“极限优惠券”这个词因为某些真人秀节目而流行起来，这些节目里的“足球妈妈”们似乎乐此不疲地省钱，免费获得食品杂货。我完全理解她们。普通家庭每周在食品杂货上的花费在 140 美元到 280 美元之间。按最高额计算，一年就能节省 15,000 美元！现在，把这 15,000 美元投入股市，猜猜 50 年后会变成什么？4,335,032.85 美元——这就是复利的力量。四百三十万美元！我的网站 AskMore-GetMore.com 上有一个复利计算器，你可以自己算算。

But in a nutshell, extreme couponing involves dedicating time toward acquiring as many coupons as possible. At first glance, this may seem like an all-consuming task. In fact, it is easy to unearth a number of cost-effective and time-efficient couponing tips that can put hundreds of dollars back into your wallet. Not only do these techniques save money, they are also user-friendly, as these methods are easy enough for even the most casual shopper to reap noticeable results. Here is a list of some of these tips.

简而言之，极限优惠券使用法就是投入大量时间去收集尽可能多的优惠券。乍一看，这似乎是一项极其耗时耗力的任务。但实际上，你很容易就能找到许多既省钱又省时的优惠券使用技巧，帮你省下几百美元。这些技巧不仅能省钱，而且非常容易上手，即使是普通消费者也能轻松掌握，并从中获益。以下是一些实用技巧。

Subscribe to the Sunday Paper. Let’s start with something easy: a subscription to a reputable Sunday paper instantly brings you access to a plethora of coupons for a variety of products. If you can’t afford a subscription, go to local stores that carry the Sunday paper, and at the end of the day ask for the coupons. You can go to multiple stores and get hundreds of coupons this way.

订阅周日报纸。我们先从简单的开始：订阅一份信誉良好的周日报纸，就能立即获得大量各种商品的优惠券。如果您负担不起订阅费用，可以去当地销售周日报纸的商店，在一天结束时向店员索取优惠券。您可以去多家商店，这样就能获得数百张优惠券。

Don’t Rush. Spending just fifteen minutes of coupon clipping won’t get you groceries for free, but will certainly save you a lot of money. However, like anything else in life, the amount of success you experience with couponing depends on the amount of effort you put into it. Try and get as much information as possible about the sales and coupons offered by your favorite grocery stores, and then plan accordingly. Thanks to the Internet, this has become easy.

别着急。花十五分钟剪优惠券虽然不能让你免费买到所有东西，但肯定能省下不少钱。不过，就像生活中的其他事情一样，使用优惠券的成功率取决于你投入的精力。尽量多了解你常去的超市的促销活动和优惠券信息，然后据此制定购物计划。多亏了互联网，这一切都变得很容易了。

Learn the Coupon Policies of Your Local Stores . Some grocers offer triple- or double-coupon days. This means that they will either double or triple the savings that the coupon offers. For example, suppose you bring in a coupon for $1 off on crackers. On double coupon day, you will actually receive $2 off your purchase. This policy is not without restrictions; stores usually only offer to double coupons up to a certain amount, typically around the one-dollar mark, and sometimes they limit the number of coupons you are allowed to double. Local grocers may also allow you to use coupons from other stores, or to “stack” coupons. “Stacking” occurs when a shopper stocks up on coupons for a particular item, with the intent of using them all at once when the product goes on sale.

了解您当地商店的优惠券政策。一些杂货店会推出优惠券翻倍或三倍优惠日。这意味着他们会将优惠券的优惠金额翻倍或三倍。例如，假设您有一张价值 1 美元的饼干优惠券。在优惠券翻倍日，您实际上可以享受 2 美元的折扣。这项政策并非没有限制；商店通常只提供一定金额的优惠券翻倍优惠，一般在 1 美元左右，有时还会限制您可以同时使用翻倍优惠的优惠券数量。当地杂货店也可能允许您使用其他商店的优惠券，或者“叠加”优惠券。“叠加”是指顾客囤积特定商品的优惠券，以便在该商品打折时一次性使用。

Acquire Coupons from the Internet. When many of us think of coupons, we think of the paper coupons that come attached to our favorite newspapers. While this is a tried-and-true method of saving money, there exists an additional avenue that a shopper can use to acquire coupons—the Internet. Simply select your coupons, print them out, and take them down to the local grocery store. If you are not sure where to start looking for online coupons, here is a list of some popular coupon websites, and you will find more listed on my website:

从网上获取优惠券。说到优惠券，我们很多人首先想到的是报纸上附赠的纸质优惠券。虽然这是一种行之有效的省钱方法，但消费者还可以通过另一种途径获取优惠券——互联网。只需选择您需要的优惠券，打印出来，然后带到附近的超市即可。如果您不知道从哪里开始寻找在线优惠券，这里列出了一些热门的优惠券网站，您还可以在我的网站上找到更多：

  • Coupons.com
    Coupons.com

  • CouponCabin.com
    CouponCabin.com

  • CouponMom.com
    CouponMom.com

  • RetailMeNot.com
    RetailMeNot.com

  • SmartSource.com
    SmartSource.com

It also bears mentioning that many retailers announce new sales on their Facebook accounts. If you Facebook regularly, you might consider adding some well-known grocers to your friend list.

值得一提的是，许多零售商会在他们的Facebook账号上发布新的促销信息。如果您经常使用Facebook，不妨考虑将一些知名的杂货店添加到您的好友列表中。

Let Coupons Determine Dinner (and Other Meals) . This is a really easy one. If you come across an excellent deal for pasta, whip up a pasta dish for dinner. Should you see a coupon offering a “Buy 1 Get 1 Free” special for tuna, plan on having a tuna sandwich for lunch. Essentially, try to plan your future meals based on the coupons you collect from various sources.

让优惠券决定晚餐（以及其他餐点）。这很简单。如果你发现意面有超值的优惠，那就做一份意面当晚餐。如果你看到金枪鱼“买一送一”的优惠券，那就计划午餐吃个金枪鱼三明治。总之，尽量根据你从各种渠道收集到的优惠券来计划你未来的餐食。

Be Organized. While virtually no one disputes the effectiveness and usefulness of coupons, many shoppers are wary about storing them. Indeed, many of us have trouble organizing our belongings and can easily envision ourselves losing a particular coupon among stacks of other coupons. This is where a coupon folder could prove very helpful. First, purchase an expandable folder (these folders are often used for keeping track of various tax documents). Second, divide this folder into specific sections, much the way you probably once divided your folders for school. For example, try creating separate sections for snacks, meats, fruits, veggies, or coupons set to expire in the immediate future. You could also try attaching related coupons using paper clips.

保持条理。虽然几乎没有人质疑优惠券的有效性和实用性，但许多购物者却对如何妥善保管它们感到担忧。事实上，我们很多人都不擅长整理物品，很容易想象自己把某张优惠券淹没在一堆优惠券中。这时，一个优惠券文件夹就能派上用场了。首先，购买一个可扩展的文件夹（这种文件夹通常用于存放各种税务文件）。其次，像你以前整理学校文件夹那样，把这个文件夹分成几个区域。例如，可以分别存放零食、肉类、水果、蔬菜，或者即将过期的优惠券。你也可以尝试用回形针把相关的优惠券夹在一起。

Join the Club. A number of retailers offer membership in “shopping clubs,” complete with their very own card. This is a great way to save time, especially for those who loathe spending time clipping or printing out coupons. Once you join the club, place the club’s card on your key ring or in your wallet. While ringing up your groceries, the cashier simply swipes the card, and the various grocery savings are added automatically to your purchases. Not only does this method require little effort on the part of the consumer, it can also yield big dividends, to the tune of 30 to 50 percent off in total savings.
